HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Rates Down, Offerings Up in One Note Category

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
The arcane market for asset-backed securities is popping with new issues, according to Clifton Lewis, an analyst at the Capital Markets Assurance Corporation, a bond insurer based in New York.
Asset-backed securities are notes secured by pools of consumer loans, most commonly those made to shoppers who carry an unpaid credit-card balance. Issuance may be up because interest rates on asset-backed issues are down, ranging between 90 and 125 basis points above comparable Treasury notes, Mr. Lewis said. 
 In May, a record of more than $6.6 billion in new asset-backed issues came to market, more than twice the amount sold in the like month last year. That eclipsed the previous one-month record of $6.3 billion, set last June. New entries in the first five months of this year total $19.1 billion, also a record level and 40 percent higher than the amount sold in the corresponding period of 1990. With the books on June still open, $4 billion in new notes have been sold, twice what was expected, Mr. Lewis said.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Looking Beyond Innovation, an Award for Results

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
It is one thing to look at new technologies, and quite another to look at how the technologies are put to use to improve business productivity. A hammer and chisel are far less interesting than the marble statues created with them; computers and software are simply fancier tools used to create elegant business systems.
Elegant in the sense, for example, of delivering the chips (potato variety) on time. Or making a better plug faster. Or delivering the news in four languages. Last week, these were among the star performances being honored in the annual ceremonies held by Computerworld, a magazine published by the International Data Group Inc., of Framingham, Mass., and the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. 
 Frito-Lay Inc., the $4.9 billion snack-food division of Pepsico Inc. that is based in Plano, Tex., took the prize in the category of business and related services for its work with handheld computers. The company's 10,000 sales representatives use them to sell more than 100 different brand-name products to more than 400,000 retail stores.
Using the bricklike Fujitsu computer, which replaced conventional paper forms, each route representative can send detailed sales and inventory information back to Frito-Lay headquarters each day. The computers keep track of prices, special promotions for each store, information on stale or returned products and other details. A printer in each delivery truck allows the sales representative to give the store manager a comprehensive receipt and invoice.
At the end of each day, instead of spreading paper receipts on the kitchen table and reaching for the calculator, pencil and aspirin, the sales representative simply hooks the Fujitsu to a telephone and sends the data to Frito-Lay's headquarters. The data are collected, compiled and distilled. "We pick up every sale of every bag made to every customer every day," said Charles S. Feld, vice president of management information services for Frito-Lay. This information is then relayed to Frito-Lay's manufacturing and distribution centers as a "real-time" inventory system.
"The result is that we can keep fresh products moving through the system continuously," Mr. Feld said. "Having the right product in the right place at the right time is really critical to us." The daily sales data are also used to develop market strategies.
The Fujitsu computers were chosen for their ruggedness, Mr. Feld said, having proved out with minimal failure rates since the program began to be implemented in 1988. On average, they operate for three years without a failure, even though dropped, jostled and used in temperatures ranging from the 40 degrees below zero of a Wyoming winter to the 120 degrees of an Arizona summer.
 The company spends about $2,500 to equip each of the 10,000 route salespeople with the Fujitsu computer and a printer for the delivery truck. And Mr. Feld and his team spent more than 18 months developing the software for the central system and for the system that returns the information to manufacturing and distribution centers.
 Even so, Mr. Feld said, the system "paid for itself well within a year, and it has paid for itself more than once." A Frito-Lay spokesman said the company saved more than $40 million in its first year from reduced paperwork, reduced losses from stale products and route consolidation.
Mr. Feld said the company was now investigating systems that would hook directly into a customer's computer, handling accounts payable and receivables, and allowing store managers to assess which Frito-Lay products are most profitable.
 The Computerworld-Smithsonian manufacturing award went to Raychem-Advanter, a division of the Raychem Corporation that is based in Richmond, British Columbia. Raychem-Advanter manufactures highly specialized electronic adapters and connectors that are used principally by the aerospace and military electronics industries. "At the simplest level they're basically electric plugs, but with more than a million variable components," a company spokesman said by way of explanation.
 "We wanted to create a state-of-the-art facility for creating these exotic plugs, which are made primarily of metal," said Raychem's Bill Mitchell, senior vice president for electronics. In the past, he said, Raychem often turned to outside machine shops for the parts. The company sometimes had to wait weeks or months for the parts and was not always satisfied with the quality.
So Raychem created Raychem-Advanter, designed around a computer-integrated manufacturing, or C.I.M., system, that uses Sparcstation computers made by Sun Microsystems Inc. of Mountain View, Calif. The system distributes information to everyone in the 35-person manufacturing setup, from managers to machine operators. This allows decisions to be made faster and easier, the company says.
 "Everything is now controlled by the computers, including incoming orders and manufacturing orders, product design, factory scheduling, quality control, the documentation, and so on," Mr. Mitchell said. And the company believes that the results have been striking.
 "Quality is extraordinarily superb," Mr. Mitchell said. "At a typical outside shop we might have been quoted a 26-week lead time. Now we typically turn things around in two days or less. In the older shop, it took 4 to 8 hours to set up machines to run a few parts, with actual manufacturing time of about 20 minutes. It's been an absolutely fundamental breakthrough for our business."
Unlike the Frito-Lay system, the Raychem-Advanter system has not yet been a financial success, largely because the military and the aerospace industries have sharply curtailed spending. Even so, Mr. Mitchell said, Raychem believes it has taken a major step toward developing a model for all its manufacturing.
Then there's making-do. The Tenderloin Times, a nonprofit newspaper in the Tenderloin district of San Francisco, uses donated Apple Macintosh computers, a laser printer and basic desktop publishing software to create what it says is the country's only four-language newspaper. The Times, which serves the neighborhood's large population of Southeast Asian immigrants, beat out such corporate giants as Capital Cities/ABC and Thames Television of England to claim the media, arts and entertainment award.
 Times stories are written in English, translated, and then re-entered and printed using Vietnamese, Lao and Cambodian word processing programs. Until The Times got its computers, the Asian languages section was laboriously written by hand. Elizabeth Price, the paper's business manager, said the editors were now hoping for the donation of a laser printer able to print on standard tabloid sized 11-inch by 17-inch paper.

HEADLINE: All About/Weddings;
It's One Party Even the Recession Can't Spoil

BYLINE: By RACHEL POWELL

 BODY:
When Shannon and Gregg Scott of San Diego got married in May, it was not the best time to spend $25,000 on a wedding. She is an interior decorator, he a construction executive, and business was not exactly booming. Though both sets of parents helped out, the couple still spent most of their savings on an elegant wedding ceremony and reception for 240 guests.
"If times were to get worse for us, we wouldn't have our cushion," said Ms. Scott, who is 25. "But even from a money perspective I don't regret what we spent at all. We did things exactly the way we always dreamed they would be." 
 The Scotts' approach was typical of the American way of marriage. Weddings are marketed as the event of a lifetime. Although couples are more careful with their money these days, they are still spending nearly as much as they did before the recession began.
In 1990, more than 2.4 million couples tied the knot. Bride's magazine, the most widely read publication in the field, estimates that for its readers -- generally middle class and upper middle class -- the average wedding cost, including honeymoon, is more than $19,000. Bride's, published by Conde Nast, also estimates that the total wedding market reached $32 billion last year, once the honeymoon and gifts were figured in.
"This market is so steady, so solid, so consistent. It's like death and taxes, only much more fun," said William Bondlow, the publisher of Globe Communications's Bridal Guide.
The most encouraging trend in the eyes of the industry is that large, expensive formal weddings remain fashionable, even as the homespun 1990's replace the glitzy 1980's. A recent survey of 2,000 readers of Modern Bride, published by Reed Publishing USA, another magazine aimed at those on the wedding track, found that 59 percent were planning formal black-tie affairs.

 
 
Magazines for Advice
Prime Ad Season Is December to June

The most efficient way for retailers and service providers to reach marriage-bound people is through the bridal magazines. The three mentioned above dominate the market, although some regional publications are popular as well.
The circulation and advertising of these publications vary over the course of the year. Overall, Bride's circulation averages 370,000 a year; Modern Bride is at about 300,000, and Bridal Guide is at 240,000. But December through May is the prime season, since 50 percent of all weddings take place in the spring and summer. June is still the biggest month, followed by August.
The recession-related drop-off in advertising spending that has affected the magazine business in general has hurt the bridal magazines, but only minimally.
Between January and April, the Publishers Information Bureau reported that Bride's saw advertising revenues rise a scant 1 percent over 1990, to $23.1 million, while Modern Bride's revenues dropped 2.4 percent, to $16.6 million. The organization does not follow Bridal Guide, a relative newcomer to the field, but Mr. Bondlow said advertising revenues are ahead of last year.
"The recession has certainly slowed things. It has proved that the bridal industry is not totally recession-proof," said Mr. Bondlow. But he and others characterized the economic damage as temporary and light.
"Businesses indigenous to the bridal market such as home furnishings, apparel and travel rely on us as a way to do business," said Howard Friedberg, publisher of Modern Bride. "While those industries may be affected by the recession, the bridal magazines are the last place that they want to cut advertising."

 
 
The Dress
It's Still White, Satin and Expensive
 Not surprisingly, clothes for the bridal party are one of the single biggest wedding expenditures. Although no exact figures are available, of the $16.4 billion spent on wedding ceremonies last year, a sizable portion was for apparel for the wedding party.
Though wedding mini-dresses are becoming more common in advertising layouts, most brides are still wearing the quintessential floor-length white satin gown. According to a Bride's readers' survey, the average cost of a wedding dress and veil was $960 last year, with prices varying widely depending on the style, designer and amount of alteration necessary for a custom fit.
"They absolutely do not want to skimp on their gowns," said Deborah Harding, editor of Bridal Guide. "The dress is one of the highest priorities."
But some skimping does take place, most of it probably at the reception. Guest lists remain long, but menus can be scaled down.
"People aren't necessarily cutting their budgets, but they're looking at their finances more carefully," said Marcy Blum, a wedding consultant in New York. "A reception for 250 guests might become a four-hour cocktail party rather than a sit-down dinner with five courses." Catering costs for a sit-down dinner average $150 a person in major cities, while cocktails and hors d'oeuvres cost just $50 a person.
"The most important thing that the recession has brought is that people are looking for value. They are more likely to shop carefully," said Barbara Tober, editor of Bride's.

 
 
Honeymooners
One Bright Spot For Travel
 The recession-resistance of the wedding business may, in fact, have helped to shore up at least one sagging industry. Although travel in general has suffered in the last nine months, honeymooners have apparently kept their plans intact.
"The recession has had no effect on our honeymoon business. It's as good or better than last year," said Steven Heydt, a senior vice president in charge of marketing at Liberty Travel, a privately owned chain of 168 travel agencies.
Modern Bride estimates the honeymoon market at $3 billion a year, with Hawaii and the Caribbean the destinations of choice. "The honeymoon is not a cheap sale," said Mr. Heydt. They will demand the cheapest air fare, he added, but "they want deluxe hotels and the best rooms."
Cheap air fare or not, Bride's readers said they still spent an average of $3,200 on the vacation of a lifetime.
"It is a pie that is lucrative and important. The honeymoon business is far more reliable than business or meeting travel." said Mr. Friedberg of Modern Bride.
Modern Bride has recently entered into a deal with American Express Vacations, agreeing to produce vacation guides offering special travel packages in the magazine every six months for the next three years. The magazine expects to reap more than $1 million a year from the arrangement.

 
 
MANY MORE PLACES TO REGISTER

Although department stores still have the best-known bridal registries, many other kinds of stores have entered the market. New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, for example, has found its bridal registry, in existence since 1980, to be a tidy source of income. Other businesses from sporting goods stores to art galleries have tried the tactic as a way to guarantee sales.
"In the last year or so, the business has grown," said Judith Block, manager of the museum's registry. "It's not our main source of income, but it's still a nice piece of change.
Ms. Block said original china and glassware are still the best sellers, but that couples are also registering for art books and other items at the museum's shop.
The average wedding guest spends $67 on a wedding present, according to a survey of Modern Bride readers. And an increasing number of couples said they planned to register for non-traditional items like VCR's.
And Janice Hartoch, a development officer for the University of California at Santa Barbara, plans to register at a wine store. "My fiance made a special request," she explained.
The concept does not seem to work everywhere. Liberty Travel started a registry two years ago at its 168 agencies.
"The idea was to set up a program like Bloomingdale's or Macy's, because we believe the honeymoon is the new couple's single biggest purchase other than furniture or fixtures for their home," said Steven Heydt, a senior vice president in charge of marketing for Liberty Travel.
The response, however, was less than enthusiastic. "They wanted a little more privacy in the transaction than we anticipated," said Mr. Heydt.

HEADLINE: What Really Hurt Natural Gas

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Bottom-Fishing in the Gas Patch" (May 19), Thomas C. Hayes overlooked the primary cause of the surplus of natural gas deliverability in the United States. 
 The severe natural gas shortage of the mid-1970's occurred because Federal price controls on natural gas depressed producers' economic returns to the point where the risk/reward ratio was inadequate to justify the new investment required. That shortage was a watershed.
 Congress passed the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978, designed to provide incentives for producers to invest in new drilling by replacing the old price controls with a system of escalating ceiling prices. By the date of the program's enactment, more than 80 percent of Midwestern and Northeastern industrial gas consumers had installed dual-fuel capability, thus setting the stage for serious gas-oil competition at the plant gate.
Pipeline companies, eager to lock up new supplies, rushed to producers' doors to offer long-term purchase agreements providing maximum ceiling prices allowable. Since ceiling prices placed a cap on price-based bidding, pipelines competed for new supply contracts by bidding up the percentage of the contract quantities that they would pay for even if they could not take the gas.
Thus encouraged by Congress and their pipeline customers, natural gas producers quickly met the demands of the marketplace. The higher prices, however, drove the fuel-switchable industrial consumer away from natural gas.
The net effect was that an oversupply of natural gas deliverability occurred by the early 1980's and market prices fell below the ceiling prices. Pipeline companies unilaterally abrogated their contracts rather than absorb the losses. Most natural gas producers were left holding the bag. Mild winters during recent years have not helped to work off the oversupply.
Hopefully, when the natural gas market ultimately achieves equilibrium, Congress will remember these lessons and avoid the temptation to re-regulate pricing.
 
RANDAL K. WALKER
McLean, Va., May 30
 
The author is president of the Power Gas Corporation, a natural gas producer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: U.N. Index on Freedom Enrages Third World

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 21

 BODY:
The publication by a United Nations agency of a new index showing that the world's poorest nations are generally also the least free has provoked a storm of outrage among third-world countries.
The storm erupted here this month at a meeting of the governing council of the United Nations Development Program, an independent agency through which the world's richer countries last year channeled some $1.4 billion in technical assistance to the third world. 
 The controversy centers on the agency's second-annual Human Development Report, which was issued last month and for the first time contained a "human freedom index" ranking 88 countries according to the degree of freedom their citizens enjoy.
The index, which is based on a study made in the mid-1980's by Charles Humana, a British academic, of adherence to various human-rights treaties and conventions, classes Sweden as the world's freest country, with 38 of a possible 40 points, and Iraq as the least free, with a score of zero.
But it also indicates that most of the world's poorest countries, including China, Zaire, Bangladesh, Tanzania, Liberia and Kenya, have little freedom, scoring 10 points or fewer. Thirty-two countries, including India, Egypt, Nigeria and Mexico, enjoy only a medium level of freedom, with scores between 11 and 30.
Those with high freedom scores, between 31 and 40, are all industrialized countries except for Costa Rica. The United States occupies 13th place with a score of 33.
The report, prepared by a distinguished Pakistani economist, Mahbub ul-Haq, who has also served as his country's Finance Minister, concludes that "over all there seems to be a high correlation between human development and human freedom."
 The report argues that in some cases "political freedom seems to have unleashed the creative energies of the people -- and lead to ever higher levels of income and social progress."
Spokesmen for third-world countries have strenuously criticized the human-freedom index, calling it inaccurate, a waste of money, interference in their internal affairs and irrelevant to their development needs.
Many also expressed fears that it would encourage industrialized countries to tie development aid to recipients' human-rights records.
Speaking for the African countries, Kenya's deputy representative, Robert Kamau Gathungu, said they "strongly question" the United Nations' right to publish the index and do not understand "how it can be used in implementing projects in developing countries."
Some third-world countries are now drafting a resolution, to be voted on next week, banning further publication of the human-freedom index.
But so far the United Nations Development Program's top management, with backing from the United States, is saying that while the index should be improved and brought up to date, it will continue to appear.
"If society represses its people, it also represses their creativity and motivation and thus its growth rate and human progress," William H. Draper, the program's Administrator, told the governing body on Wednesday.
"We should not let our concern with finding a better way to measure freedom question the need for integrating freedom into our concept of human development," he said. "It needs no defense and it certainly needs no apology."
To chart how well the world's 160 Governments met their peoples' basic human needs last year, the new report also ranks them on a human-needs index that measures education, life expectancy and economic wealth.
While Japan is first and the United States is in seventh place, oil-producing Arab countries do relatively poorly because they neglect education of girls, and the poorest African nations occupy the bottom places.
The report also documents many third-world spending priorities that Dr. ul-Haq thinks democracy would help to change. While Pakistan spends three times as much on the military as on education and health care, for example, Japan has four times as many teachers as soldiers.

HEADLINE: Dollar's Rise a Crucial Issue for Group of Seven

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 22

 BODY:
When finance ministers and central bankers of the seven leading industrial democracies meet here on Sunday, they are likely to agree that the dollar's rise against other currencies is causing problems for the European and Japanese economies, private economists say.
Proposals for promising aid to the Soviet Union, if it tries to develop a free-market economy, are also expected to be discussed by officials from the so-called Group of Seven: Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States. But the British officials hosting the gathering play down the possibility that a decision on aid will be made. That issue will be left to the mid-July summit meeting here, at the end of which Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet with leaders of the seven countries.
 
Invitation to Soviets Is Possible
 However, the Soviets could be immediately offered associate membership in the International Monetary Fund, British officials said. That would enable the I.M.F. to give the Soviet Union technical assistance in reforming its economy but would not allow the Soviets to receive I.M.F. money. 
 Another likely topic is the effort to revive the stalled trade talks known as the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Economists predict that the finance ministers and central bankers will call for the current value of the dollar to be maintained or to be lowered slightly. But many doubt that such an effort will hold the dollar down for more than a couple of months.
"The economic fundamentals around the world are for a stronger dollar," said David Morrison, a London economist for Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The dollar has soared in value since February. It is trading about 14 percent higher against a trade-weighted "basket" of currencies, nearly 25 percent higher against the German mark and nearly 9 percent higher against the Japanese yen.
A further rise would probably force Germany, other European countries and Japan to maintain or raise their interest rates, forcing the dollar down. Such increases will undoubtedly hurt their already weakening economies. And if those countries then bought less from the United States, that could sap the weak American economic recovery that many economists say has begun.
 
New Rate Policy Unlikely
 With the United States, Germany and Japan grappling with different economic problems, the ministers and central bankers seem unlikely to agree on a coordinated interest-rate policy, economists say. That belief was reinforced on Thursday, when Helmut Schlesinger, president-elect of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, said he did not expect the meeting to produce a concrete statement on the dollar.
Without such a coordinated rate policy, economists doubt that the dollar's rise can be contained. With inflation in Germany rising, economists expect the Germans to raise their interest rates sometime soon. That would prevent the weak mark from declining further.
With their economy weakening, the Japanese are believed to want to cut interest rates soon. But economists think they do not want the yen's value to drop, which would cause Japan's trade surplus to grow and risk further aggravating relations with the United States and the European Community.

HEADLINE: A Sense of Fiscal Doom

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
With just over a week till New York City's new fiscal year begins, City Hall is besieged by protesters and gripped by a sense of impending disaster. After striving for months to avoid deep cuts in city services, Mayor David N. Dinkins is now facing the prospect of adopting a budget balanced with cuts far more severe than those in the May plan that was called his "doomsday" budget.
Those cuts were meant to be so harsh as to force the state to give more aid and unions to make concessions. But that help has not come. And now both the Mayor and the City Council seem intent on passing a $29 billion budget so full of pain that they would immediately begin jockeying to find the money to undo it. 
 It is a political battle of great proportions, with Mr. Dinkins's very future at stake. Both sides remain nearly $500 million apart in how they would solve a budget gap of at least $3.5 billion, with the Council calling for much deeper cuts and the Mayor urging more property taxes. But far more than politics is at issue: at stake is perhaps $2 billion in cuts in city services and the inevitability of tax increases that also would affect all New Yorkers and change the city for years to come.
In this spring's cloudy fiscal climate, with the state budget passed two months late and still unresolved, the Mayor's most senior advisers complain they have no time even to think about what to do, and that there is not enough time for the inevitable political dances -- delicate in every budget and tortured this year -- to play themselves out.
 
Mayor Reduced to Exhortation
 Mr. Dinkins, obsessed with avoiding a takeover of the city's finances by a state panel, the Financial Control Board, but with less and less control over the factors that could provoke one, has been reduced to exhortation, calling on Albany, the Council, the unions and the citizenry to pitch in and help him balance the budget as required by law, simply because, he says, they have no choice.
The Mayor, who granted raises to the city's workers just months ago, says he hopes their unions might still make concessions on wages or benefits that would help avoid some of the 10,000 layoffs he has begun. He and the Council both still hope that after they pass a budget, the Municipal Assistance Corporation -- set up to borrow money on the city's behalf in its last fiscal crisis -- might still provide hundreds of millions of dollars in aid by refinancing some of the corporation's bonds.
"We're working very closely with all the pieces of this," the Mayor said on Friday. "There are many components, as you know."
But around City Hall, there is a growing sense that even if the combatants make peace at Armageddon, it would only be to return to the apocalypse within a few months or by next spring at the latest. The city's spending will remain fundamentally out of whack with the revenues it is able to take in, even if it manages to balance the budget for the fiscal year that starts on July 1.
"There is no plan, no leadership, no foresight," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses.
Last week, the Financial Control Board -- which could assert binding powers over the city's finances if the city ran a deficit of $100 million or more, lost access to the bond market or failed to make a debt service payment on its outstanding bonds -- issued a report noting that the Mayor's plan for getting beyond the coming year assumes $500 million a year in higher real-estate taxes, steadily increasing state aid and no further spending cuts.
The plan also assumes no further wage increases through mid-1995, and that would mean a wage freeze of unprecedented duration, the board said.
Mr. Horton of the Budget Commission took the uncharacteristic step of recently suggesting that the city need not pass the budget on time for the first time since the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's. There would be little gain from such punctuality, he said, if it would not result in structural changes like permanently reducing the cost of city programs or shifting burdens, like welfare costs, to the state through a complex net of new state laws and cooperation between City Hall and Albany.
 
Costs of a Late Budget
 But others point out that the budget will be precariously balanced at best, and that only deadlines can impel action. If the city adopts a budget after the July 1 deadline, its current budget would continue in place, but since costs for debt service on bonds already issued will rise in any event, that, too could raise the hackles of the Control Board. Moreover, if the budget was late, it would have only 11 months of new tax revenues and 11 months worth of savings from spending cuts, and that would mean even deeper cuts.
The Budget Commission and Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, have argued that using one-time funds from the M.A.C., or from the sale of city land or other sources, should only be used as a bridge toward a fundamental reshaping of the size and scope of city spending.
Mr. Dinkins, too, argues that the state and Federal governments should bear greater costs, but there is little immediate prospect of that happening. The Mayor contends the city is primarily the victim of a cyclical recession that will pass.
For now, if Mr. Dinkins cannot stave off the worst of his own proposed cuts, he will be forced to sacrifice much of the expansive -- and expensive -- agenda he campaigned for two years ago, with consequences for his political future that would presumably not be promising. On the other hand, if he fails to balance the budget, he will invite a takeover by the state and risk being remembered as a Mayor too weak and waffling to have protected his own.
For the Council, newly empowered by recent changes in the City Charter, much is also at stake. It has positioned itself as the defender of the middle class by struggling to hold down property taxes. If the Control Board assumed binding powers, the Council would be the biggest loser of all, since Mr. Dinkins is at least a member of the board, while the Council is not, and it would have even less say over the city's spending priorities.
The Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said that about the best the Council can hope for at the moment is to reshape some of Mr. Dinkins's spending priorities, but that without help from the unions or the M.A.C., little else can be done.
"There's no way the pie's going to get bigger unless the other parties come back to the table," he said.

HEADLINE: Nashua Journal;
On Docket, Long Wait For Sound Of a Gavel

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H., June 21

 BODY:
It looks like a courthouse.
 The three-story brick-veneer building, which was completed last fall at a cost of $6.9 million, has the usual accompaniment of courtrooms, cell blocks, library space and judges' chambers. Security guards patrol its corridors, and lights illuminate it at night. 
 But the Hillsborough County Superior Court building here has no furniture. Worse, it has no judges.
The penny-conscious Legislature in this conservative state, which prides itself on having no income tax or sales tax, had initially failed to set aside enough money for furniture and judges. So the courthouse, which is urgently needed to relieve a backlog of up to 12 months for civil cases, sits unopened.
The tale of how the courthouse came to be built but left unused has provoked amusement, befuddlement and anger in Nashua, a rapidly growing city of 80,000 people that is now the second largest in New Hampshire.
"It is a joke, and some people say it's an example of government mismanagement at its worst," said Ernest A. Jette, a lawyer and president of the Nashua Bar Association. "People feel it is absolutely ridiculous that the state spends $7 million to build a courthouse that was ready to be put into service in 1990 and is still not being used."
To add injury to insult, Mr. Jette said, utilities, heat and security for the empty building cost about $70,000 each month.
The tale of the empty courthouse is a reflection on both New Hampshire's quirky politics and the recession that is gripping the state and much of the Northeast.
The troubles began in 1985 when the designers of the building projected its cost at $9 million to $10 million. It was widely agreed that the new courthouse was needed, because Nashua had grown from a population of 55,820 in 1970 to 79,662 in 1990, as New Hampshire had the second fastest-growing economy east of the Mississippi River after Florida. But the only courthouse in the county was in Manchester, 15 miles to the north.
Still, state legislators, most of whom were elected after taking what is known here as "the pledge," a vow not to impose a state income tax or sales tax, reduced the appropriation to $7.5 million.
Construction then began. But, said Mary Nelson, a Democratic State Senator from Nashua, "I don't think anybody took a look and noticed there wasn't enough money for furnishings."
Last year, as the building neared completion and the problem became apparent, Ms. Nelson sponsored a bill to set aside $980,000 for furniture. But by then New Hampshire's economy had suddenly gone into reverse, and the resulting drop in revenue caused large deficits in the state budget. Gov. Judd Gregg, a Republican, vetoed the bill as being too expensive.
In May, with embarrassment over the courthouse's plight mounting, Ms. Nelson put in four bills to buy furniture. "I made darn sure it would go through somehow," she said. This time, Governor Gregg signed the legislation.
But another bill she sponsored to employ four judges at the court has failed, so far. "Everyone is very supportive," she said, "but it's crazy in the Legislature. There is no money and everyone is afraid."
A big fear is that the continuing budget shortfall might finally arouse public support for an income tax or sales tax. Although the Legislature and the Governor have already made cuts of about $150 million, the $3.4 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 is still unbalanced.
So John Safford, clerk of the county court, is uncertain what will happen to the courthouse. He will soon be ordering the furniture, and expects it in September. Mr. Safford said he also believed that the state might reassign one or more of the six judges in Manchester to serve in the new building in Nashua.
That would not clear up the backlog of cases, which got so bad in 1989 that the county had to stop hearing all civil cases for three months. But at least it would allow the citizens of Nashua to have their own courthouse and would also relieve the pressure at the Manchester court, where trials are being held in makeshift courtrooms.
"I think a courtroom should have some dignity," Mr. Safford said, "in keeping with the solemnity of the proceedings."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Cuomo, Novelty Long Gone, Faces Up to 3d-Term Slump

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 22

 BODY:
Just six months into his third term, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's popularity has plummeted, by his own estimates. After more than eight years in office, he is facing problems that critics increasingly say are of his own making.
And as New York's budget extravaganza nears its angry denouement, the Governor's dominance of the state government, once unchallenged, no longer seems quite so secure. 
 Nobody ever said that a politician's job becomes easier the longer he sticks around.
 
'Kill the Messenger'?
 Just how much of the Governor's third-term troubles are simply a result of the state's budget problems -- and how much a result of his response to the problems -- is unclear. As Mr. Cuomo often notes, politics is often ruled by a "kill the messenger" mentality that blames the bearer of bad news for the bad news itself. And in a recession, there is plenty of bad news for the Governor to impart.
What does seem clear, though, as the Governor struggles to resolve the state's lingering budget problems, is that he is suffering from many of the familiar problems of political longevity. Much of what Mr. Cuomo did in his first two terms is now haunting him in his third.
"I don't know of a single politician that's been left unscathed by a third term," said Norman Adler, a political consultant whose clients include many state legislators. "The novelty has worn off. They go from initiating ideas to defending initiatives they did in the past. In effect, that's what's happening here."
Take, for example, the Governor's spending policies. During his first several years in office, Mr. Cuomo was presiding in a time of unusual affluence, and state spending during his first two terms, adjusted for inflation, grew by almost 20 percent. The Governor's liberal philosophy seemed, for the most part, to be in sync with his fiscal policies.
During the course of this year's record-breaking budget struggle, though, Mr. Cuomo has often seemed to be trying to remake his image for recessionary times.
Although he has not dropped his familiar liberal message, he has advocated a more conservative approach to budget making. He has pressed for sharp cuts in social-service programs and maligned those who call for maintaining these programs through higher taxes. And as if to underscore this new image, two weeks ago the Governor vetoed nearly $1 billion worth of spending the Legislature had added to his budget, saying it was not supported by sufficient revenues.
The Governor's fiscal conservatism, however, gives him something of the air of a reformed sinner: the state has run a deficit in six of the last eight years, including some when New York experienced record revenue growth.
Many politicians try to explain the shift as evidence of a nascent Presidential campaign by Mr. Cuomo. The Governor, always insisting that he has no plans to run for President and no plans to make plans, naturally denies this.
"You'd have to be kind of dumb in politics," Mr. Cuomo said recently, "or more clever than any politician I've ever met to figure out how plunging yourself 25 points in the polls, having all of your strongest constituents, even in Iowa, announce that you're dead meat politically, how all of this is a clever scheme to slip into the Presidential race and surge to the top."
 
No Regrets for Past Spending
 Instead, Mr. Cuomo says that he is simply responding to a new set of economic realities. While it was good to expand state programs when there was money -- and Mr. Cuomo says he regrets none of the spending he did in the past -- it is impossible to do so, he says, when there is no money.
But despite the Governor's efforts to define his position as the reasonable middle ground, at this point he has, it seems, satisfied neither side. Conservative groups, recalling his first two terms in office, accuse him of being a Johnny-come-lately to the cause of balanced budgets. Liberal groups accuse him of hypocrisy.
This quandary, political analysts say, demonstrates a classic problem of political survivors. Often, when conditions change, a politician finds it is dangerous, perhaps even impossible, to change with them.
"Mario Cuomo cut his political teeth a long time ago," said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, which does frequent polling on state issues. "In politics it's very hard to get a new set of teeth. Some of the erosion in the Governor's support may be attributable to what is perceived as a lack of consistency."
A former aide to the Governor put it more bluntly: "You could say that he's ended up with the worst of both worlds."
Like the Governor's spending policies, his cool relations with the Legislature, once an asset, are threatening to become a liability to him.
For most of the last eight years, the testy relations between the Governor and the Legislature have worked to his advantage. Anonymous, undisciplined, at times even corrupt, the Legislature provided a useful antagonist against which the Governor sharpened his own image of hard work and rectitude.
Four years ago, for example, the Legislature approved a government ethics bill that Mr. Cuomo vetoed as inadequate. The Governor emerged as the clear moral victor, forcing the Legislature to pass a new and tougher bill.
Now, however, it is not so clear that the Governor will emerge victorious from his latest struggle with the Legislature, nor is it even clear what victory would consist of.
Earlier this month, when the Governor vetoed almost $1 billion worth of aid to struggling school districts and local governments, many applauded the move as courageous. The Governor, they said, was taking an unpopular but justifiably tough stand against excessive spending.
Critics, however, saw the move as a gambit intended to force lawmakers to renegotiate a budget that the Governor, who did not participate in the last phase of negotiations, found he did not like.
Whatever the Governor's motives were for the vetoes, they have set off state government's equivalent of a civil war. "The rift," the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, said with uncharacteristic understatement, "is growing."
 
Wants Back What He Vetoed
 Just how the Governor plans to end this war is uncertain. Having vetoed funds considered crucial to New York City and other municipalities, Mr. Cuomo is now in the awkward position of having to ask the Legislature to restore some of them. Last week, Mr. Cuomo publicly called on the legislative leaders to join him at the negotiating table.
But the legislative leaders, always wary of Mr. Cuomo, are now more reluctant than ever to cooperate with him. They say they want to see a full-fledged plan for how to restore the money before they negotiate.
As the standoff continues, it seems that Mr. Cuomo, even if he is still ahead in the public relations battle, is having increasing trouble scoring points against the Legislature. In Albany, there is mounting talk about a possible veto override, which would be a first for Mr. Cuomo. And outside of Albany, there seems to be a feeling that the state government, with Governor Cuomo at the helm, is running adrift.
"You don't get a sense that he's trying to lead this process or reach out to people," one New York City official said. "You don't know where he's going. There's an odd sense of directionlessness to the process."

Cuomo, now serving his third term in office, appears to be haunted by much of what he did in his first two terms. Two weeks ago, Mr. Cuomo announced his veto of $1 billion in the state budget. (Associated Press) (pg. 24)

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
In Taxes on Real Estate Where Is The Limit?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
EVER since Peter Minuit swapped about $24 in fripperies for land over which the Manhattoes -- the first participants in New York's tribal politics -- held a disputed claim, people have been debating the true value of the city's real estate. Now, 365 years later, the debate has been elevated from the abstract to the concrete: are the property taxes that New York City or its precursors began imposing in 1654 approaching their legal and practical limits?
That debate will be joined this week when the City Council is expected to deal with Mayor David N. Dinkins's proposal to raise real estate taxes by $776 million to balance the $29 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning a week from tomorrow. The Council has acknowledged that an increase is necessary, but has refused to budge beyond $300 million. 
 Not surprisingly, property owners complain that even that figure is too much -- particularly during a recession when any additional cost of living or of doing business, coupled with higher water and sewer charges and the certainty of reductions in municipal services, may prompt landlords to abandon their buildings and commercial tenants to close or, along with homeowners, to leave town and take thousands of jobs with them.
A coalition of property owners has already spent nearly $1 million on a radio and print advertising campaign to persuade Mayor Dinkins and Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, to mine other sources of revenue and to cut expenses before turning further to the property tax, which the city can raise without the state's permission. Total revenues from the increased property tax proposed by the Mayor would account for more than $7.3 billion, or nearly half of the local tax revenue generated to pay for his proposed budget.
The debate is complicated by a formula established by the state Legislature a decade ago. In New York City, the relatively modest property tax on private homes represents a multibillion-dollar subsidy for the middle class. As a result, many other New Yorkers pay more -- including residents of cooperatives and condominiums and residential and commercial tenants.
The effective rate for owners of one- , two- and three-family homes and small condominiums this year is about 79 cents for every $100 of their home's market value; for apartment buildings, including co-ops and condominiums, the comparable rate is $4.12. While many variables can make comparisons misleading, the system also perpetuates disparities between urban and suburban homeowners, who typically pay more.
The formula's inflexibility has united a broad coalition of property owners. They favor the lowest possible increase beyond the $130 million earmarked for the Mayor's anti-crime program and the higher bills that result from an increase in the assessed valuation of individual properties rather than from a rise in the tax rate. The coalition recalls that during the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's property taxes were actually frozen for five years to give landlords and developers a modicum of stability. (This time, the city projects another $1 billion in increases for the two fiscal years beginning July 1, 1992.) The property owners point to the rise in property-tax delinquencies -- up about 1 percent over last year when $75 million of the taxes assessed by the city were not collected. And they are invoking what may be an arcane technical device to advance their case: whether the city is nearing its constitutional debt limit.
The State Constitution provides that to pay for operating expenses, the city may tax property up to 2.5 percent of the average full valuation of taxable real estate. The State Board of Equalization and Assessment is supposed to conduct a market survey every three years, but last completed one in 1987 -- before real estate prices tumbled. As a result, the board's estimate represents an approximation, from which trends are extrapolated that diverge dramatically from other official calculations.
"Whether you own a condo or a co-op, a small apartment building or a large one, you know in your heart of hearts it's not worth what it was three years ago," said John J. Gilbert 3d, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a landlords' group, which has provided evidence of the decline to the state board.
"What David Dinkins and the City Council do by July 1 will shape whether New York City begins to move out of the recession and whether the programs the Mayor would like funded will ever be funded," said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.
City officials acknowledge the decline, but figure that they still have plenty of leeway -- $2 billion or more -- before the legal window on property tax increase begins to close in the mid-1990's. Behind that technical debate, though, lies a more fundamental question.
"The reality of politics is, you have to pass a tax rate," said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, which oversees city finances. "The city still has billions of dollars in tax authority today, but the reality is, who's going to raise the tax rate to capture all of that? The real estate people hope that by challenging the nature of the limit, they will bring the statutory number below the political reality.
"The city's property tax has been the primary source of growth for the last several years -- about 10 percent a year -- and it really has been funding all the expansion in social services," Mr. Proctor said. "The tax burden is having an adverse affect. You never quite know when you cross the line of affordability, but you certainly would have crossed it under the Mayor's plan."
Crossing that line would be bad news for landlords. But if property owners have to choose between paying their banks or paying their taxes, the consequences for a city in which property values have soared from $24 to well over $100 billion could be equally grim. The perversity of the business cycle is such, though, that when things get bad enough they can become good again, at least for those tenants who have won favorable terms from landlords hungry for a guaranteed source of revenue. One tenant, with two and a half years left on its lease in midtown Manhattan, renegotiated for 10 years at roughly half the rent. That tenant, as it happens, was the Real Estate Board of New York.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Free Trade: No Longer Just a Case of North Versus South

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.

 BODY:
TRADE politics in the United States does not just fail to follow party lines. It also no longer follows the traditional boundaries of regions.
Rather, the nation has become a quilt of different views on free trade, with patches of strong advocacy sometimes adjacent to strong opposition. 
 In few regions has this become as clear as in the South, and especially in North Carolina, a state whose many stands of silent pine trees cloak pharmaceutical research laboratories and computer factories as well as turn-of-the-century textile mills. The recent opening of negotiations with Mexico for a proposed free trade agreement and the pending votes in the next two weeks on whether to renew China's most-favored-nation trade status are part of a debate that has divided a state long proud of its sense of community.
 "You're getting a real division, much more by districts," on trade votes as the variety of industries in the South increases, said Deborah L. Spar, an assistant professor at the Harvard Business School.
On one side in North Carolina are lawmakers like Representative Howard Coble, a Republican from the textile center of Greensboro. He defied his party and the Administration last month to vote against the renewal of the President's authority to negotiate trade agreements and submit them for so-called "fast track consideration" by Congress. In effect, the vote was against the negotiation of a free-trade agreement with Mexico and another international round of trade liberalization, either of which might allow another surge of textile imports. Now Mr. Coble is leaning toward voting against a renewal of China's preferential access to the American market, an aide said Thursday.
But Representative David E. Price, a Democrat whose district is adjacent to Mr. Coble's and includes Chapel Hill, a university town, and Raleigh, the state capital, also defied his party to vote in favor of "fast track" authority for the President. His district includes factories of multinationals like the International Business Machines Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company,and smaller businesses like hosiery and soybean producers. All feel they are internationally competitive and would prosper if worldwide trade barriers were reduced.
The contradictory votes by Mr. Price and Mr. Coble illustrate a historic change in the South's attitudes toward international trade.
The split divides producers of goods of which the United States is a net importer, like clothing, and industries that are net exporters, ranging from soybeans to telecommunications equipment. All of these divisions have deep historical roots in the South.
An important cause of the Civil War was the South's resentment of rising tariffs on imported manufactured goods imposed to protect infant industries in the North. The South remained resolutely in favor of free trade until the 1930's, largely out of an unwillingness to pay higher prices to allow "shoddy goods from the Northeast to supplant better, or perceived as better, goods from Great Britain," said Edward M. Graham, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
But as textiles, apparel and consumer electronics moved to the South in the middle of this century, attitudes began to change. Low barriers to trade began to mean not inexpensive agricultural machinery from Britain, but low-cost apparel imports from East Asia that could drive Southern factories out of business.
With the free-trade votes of lawmakers like Mr. Price, the issue appears at first glance to have come full circle. Representative Alex McMillan, a Republican from North Carolina's largest city, Charlotte, also voted last month in favor of reducing trade barriers.
But the justifications provided by Southern free trade supporters today are not the same as those offered by, for example, Cordell Hull, a Tennessee Democrat. As Franklin D. Roosevelt's Secretary of State for nearly 12 years, he helped lay the foundations for an international free trade regime after World War II, basing it on the principle that trade barriers discriminate against consumers and in favor of influential industries.
Free trade rhetoric in the South of the 1990's has different themes, in part because the region industrialized. One conspicuous argument has been the need to win greater access to foreign markets for American businesses, thereby preserving American jobs, Mr. Graham said.
Mr. Price, while mentioning consumers' interest in cheaper imports, emphasized the export success of his district's businesses when explaining his vote. "I am confident that our people can be major players in the world economy," he said.
The other strong and fairly new argument for Southern lawmakers to support free trade has been the need to lure foreign investment and technology. In justifying his vote to support free trade negotiations, Mr. McMillan stressed the presence of 340 foreign firms in the Charlotte area, producing everything from chemicals to paper products machinery.
Total foreign direct investment in the United States more than tripled, to $544 billion from $133 billion, between 1982 and 1989, according to a recent inflation-adjusted Commerce Department estimate.
As industries continue to spread across national frontiers and as some Congressional districts attract foreign-owned factories and others do not, foreign investment may become one of the most enduring influences in breaking down regional unity, Ms. Spar said. "As the borders open up, you get less regional politics," she said.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Whining, Excuses, Hysteria

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
If I were a Japanese leader listening to all the anti-Japanese whining and hysteria and double-standarditis in the U.S., I might become an America-basher.
 Americans have turned Japan-bashing into a cottage industry from Congress to the Harvard Business Review to Detroit to the C.I.A. to Main Street and to a recent book hawking a future war with Japan. The Japanese are finally getting frustrated and angry about all this, and may start bashing back. The bashing business (Europeans joining in) could spiral out of control with the most serious consequences, despite the commendable efforts of President Bush and Prime Minister Kaifu.
 
 Beyond argument, Japan's economy is more protectionist than ours, and we should press very hard to change this. That said, the Japanese make two telling points: Americans are not such pure free traders as they pretend; and solutions to many U.S. complaints lie not in Japan but in America.
 Look at the Structural Impediments Initiative, the central dialogue between the two countries on removing barriers to trade and investment. In these exchanges, we are asking Japan to do some sensible things like combatting its anti-competitive business practices. But we are also demanding that the Japanese save less and spend more governmental funds. In other words, we are telling them to go on a consumer binge and increase government deficits, or, in effect, to adopt the self-destructive policies of the Reagan Administration. Fortunately for them, they are not so dumb; they are plowing extra government dollars into infrastructure and strengthening their economy.
 And what is Japan asking us to do in these talks? Among other things, to lower our Federal deficit (to lower interest rates and stimulate investment), to increase our savings rate (to the same end), to improve our public educational system and push our corporations into longer-term business strategies. In sum, Tokyo is urging us to take the very steps any American with half a brain knows we ought to be taking in our own self-interest.
 Remember the Voluntary Restraint Agreement on auto sales? We cornered the Japanese into limiting their auto exports. They did so, and then also started manufacturing more cars in the U.S. (to the delight of the communities where they settled) and thereby increased their total auto sales here.
 Such experiences are part of an established pattern: We cut an agreement with them. They fulfill it to the letter, but are clever enough to find other ways to gain advantage. We accuse them of violating the spirit of the agreement and then issue a new set of demands.
 If U.S. auto manufacturers and auto workers would stop making such demands and whining for a moment, they might stumble on the principal cause of their decline: their Japanese competitors, for the most part, have designed and made better cars.
 The American mania about Japan goes well beyond autos, down to some intriguing new machinations by the C.I.A. A recent C.I.A.-sponsored study by the Rochester Institute of Technology calls Japan "non-democratic," and "racist" and argues that Tokyo is headed for world dominance unless challenged by the West. Is the agency, to justify its post-cold war persona, searching for a new threat to supplant Moscow? Such Japan-bashing certainly finds resonance among Americans, who feel more menaced by Japan than the Soviet Union -- 72 percent to 20 percent, according to a Business Week survey.
 The Japanese do not help themselves much either. Even when they act generously, they do so in begrudging ways that earn them no credit -- as happened with their $13 billion contribution to the Persian Gulf war.
 Sharp conflicts are not new in Japanese-American relations. But leaders on both sides have contained the inevitable economic clashes in the last 20 years by invoking the common Soviet threat. No more.
 Now, as the economic balance of power shifts increasingly toward Tokyo, American self-righteousness and nastiness toward Japan seem to know no bounds. Our protestations surpass our important and legitimate grievances. Our complaints suggest a loss of competitive nerve among American businessmen and workers.
 Their Japan-bashing, supported by a legion of politicians and well-paid consultants, begins to smell like an excuse for not dealing with our own shortcomings.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Council, Blaming Dinkins, Cuts Deeper

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
The leaders of the New York City Council yesterday angrily accused Mayor David N. Dinkins of a failure of leadership, as the Council completed a list of proposals to make $476 million in service cuts on top of the $1.5 billion in cuts already proposed by the Mayor.
"The administration has abdicated its responsibilities," the Council leaders said in a statement issued by Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and his 10-member negotiating committee after a caucus at City Hall. 
 It was the latest twist in an increasingly ominous stalemate between the Mayor and the Council, with only eight days before the deadline for the adoption of a new city budget. Each side is seeking to shift blame for the impasse as the city confronts its worst fiscal crisis since the mid-1970's.
The Council proposed the service cuts -- including the elimination of 2,000 day-care slots and the consolidation of some city agencies -- to replace $476 million in property-tax increases proposed by Mr. Dinkins as part of his $1.1 billion tax package. The Council has agreed to property-tax increases that would produce an estimated $300 million.
 
Large Scale and Painful
 Yesterday, Mr. Vallone said he would not release details of the Council's proposed service cuts until its committee members had a chance to review the list and suggest alternatives. Council staff members would say only that the list included large-scale reorganizations of city agencies, painful cuts in services, and reductions in the budgets of elected officials, including Council members themselves.
On Friday, in a move that incensed many Council members, the Dinkins administration released details of the Council plan. And while the reductions proposed by the Council appeared to differ little from those offered by the administration, aides to Mayor Dinkins said they were unnecessary and would devastate the city.
In a statement issued yesterday by the Mayor's acting press secretary, Leland T. Jones, the administration said the cuts would eliminate the 2,000 day-care slots, reduce economic development programs, the staff of the Human Rights Commission, jobs for young people and adult literacy programs, and slash new education and youth programs proposed by the Mayor as part of a city anti-crime package.
It said that spending for road and highway repairs would be reduced along with money to maintain city-owned buildings.
In the statement, Mr. Jones chided the Council for its "heated rhetoric," and suggested the Council leaders were merely venting their frustration.
Behind the scene, Council members voiced fury at the Mayor and said he was trying to deflect responsiblity for the deep service cuts that he himself had proposed -- from closing libraries to slashing health services -- by urging the public to lobby the Council to restore the cuts.
In their own statement yesterday, Council leaders blamed the administration for the cuts it proposed, and accused it of negotiating in bad faith. If the administration had succeeded in negotiating with the state and city unions, and cut waste from city government, the additional service cuts would never had been proposed, the statement said.
"If the administration had approached this budget crisis intelligently and creatively, it would have gone ahead with a rational plan to cut back the size and cost of government," the statement said. "Instead the administration's only answer is Draconian cuts and crippling taxes."
Mr. Vallone said the Council still hoped to negotiate a settlement with the administration and was not contemplating drafting a budget bill incorporating the cuts.
He suggested that the cuts were a way of showing the administration that the Council was serious about limiting increases in property taxes and was prepared to do what was necessary to see that it was carried out.
Even if the Council passed all the taxes called for in the Mayor's budget, Mr. Vallone said, the cuts proposed by Mr. Dinkins would still be necessary.
"They are trying to show that the Council are the ones that are closing the pharmacies and the prenatal clinics," he said. Mr. Dinkins's budget calls for closing pharmacies in city hospitals and slashing spending on prenatal services.
Staff members for the Council and the Mayor reviewed the Council's proposals over the weekend.
During the last few days, as Mayor Dinkins sought to pressure the Council, l members were deluged with calls from city commissioners, lobbyists and residents.The statement yesterday from the Council's negotiating committee was intended to show that the Council was united behind Mr. Vallone, aides said.
Mr. Vallone said that wage increases granted by the Mayor were responsible for some of the cuts and that the worst cuts could be avoided only if Mr. Dinkins won concessions from city unions that improve productivity.

HEADLINE: A Bounty of Food Festivals

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STOFFEL; JENNIFER STOFFEL contributes to The New York Times from Cleveland.

 BODY:
AFTER a winter of pale, imported substitutes, Midwesterners are inclined to find any number of excuses to enjoy farm-fresh produce and fresh-baked goods. Aside from taking to the fields themselves or merely seeking out a roadside stand or urban market, attending at least one or two of the region's many food festivals is a favored tradition during the summer months.
 Traveling across the region from festival to festival, a visitor is inclined to discover some common themes. With contests ranging from seed spitting to corn shucking and plate lunches made and served by church groups, a typical gathering offers urban visitors a modern-day tour of small-town life. And, in an era when so many agricultural products bear little resemblance to their fresh origins, buying from the farmer has its attractions. 
 One of the biggest and most well-known harvest celebrations in the region, the weeklong Cherry Festival in Traverse City, Mich., in recent years has attracted nearly a half a million people. The city's small downtown, just a block removed from the Lake Michigan beach, is swollen with visitors during the early July festival days. Begun in 1926 to promote the state's crop, the cherries now merely serve as a backdrop for an array of competitions, parades and shows.
 Still, there are plenty of cherries and freshly made cherry baked goods and products on hand. One of the best spots to sample the ruby red Schmidt and Nelson as well as lighter Napoleon varieties of native sweet cherries is at the open-air food market set up along the Lake Michigan bayfront. (The tart Montmorency variety typically ripens later in the season.) During festival week a number of the orchards set up stands filled with cartons of fresh cherries along with cherry cookies, pies, jams and syrups.
 While the more traditional among the festivals are timed to celebrate a particular harvest, nearly anything edible can be the spark of an idea for a single-food celebration. Featuring the products of the local Velvet Ice Cream Company, for 17 years running over Memorial Day weekend, community members of Utica, Ohio, have organized an Old Fashioned Ice Cream Festival.
 This year, a battalion of volunteers dished out ice cream cones, sundaes, banana splits and root beer floats from a makeshift, tent-covered ice cream stand set up in the middle of a grassy field to lines of impatient visitors from not-too-distant Columbus and Cleveland. A Girl Scout troop's offering of ice cream pies and cakes attracted only a few. A nearby vendor hawking pork tenderloin sandwiches and hotdogs was largely ignored. Visitors here come for the ice cream and its better-than-most creamy texture.
 Served up in four-ounce-plus dips, a two-dip cone was priced at a reasonable $1.25; an even larger waffle cone went for $2. "We don't want anyone to go away without eating ice cream," said Ray Lewis, one of the festival's directors.
 Just as popular as the eating of ice cream is watching others compete to eat a lot. The annual Ice Cream Eating Contest is by far the biggest festival attraction, according to Mr. Lewis. So popular, in fact, that it is divided into three sections -- one contest for each day of the three-day event, which is open to all ages. Velvet provides youngsters with all the free vanilla ice cream they can eat for two minutes straight; adults can indulge for eight minutes. The record of six pints was broken this year by Bill Lacurto of nearby Newark, Ohio, who downed eight pints of Velvet vanilla in eight minutes to the roars of encouragement from a crowd of onlookers packed in bleacher seats.
 Spanning the nine-acre grounds of the 75-year-old ice cream company -- the small town's largest single industry -- and flowing over the highway onto a field next to the electric company, crafts, pony rides and a small circus are among the attractions.
 On the top of any list of the most unusual festivals is the annual Moonshine Festival in New Straitsville, Ohio, which says it is the sole food fest in the state celebrating something illegal. The aim of the organizers is to recall the area's Prohibition-Era heritage.
 TAKING over the three-block downtown business district, the fair includes carnival rides, food stands and an entertainment calendar of harmonica playing and fiddle music for an open-air center-of-town stage. At noon, a batch of chicken is cooked on the grill by members of the volunteer fire department. While moonshine itself is (obviously) not served, a locally concocted moonshine pie has an ardent following. The recipe is a closely guarded secret, but the pie has a gooey sweet taste of brown sugar or perhaps molasses.
 It seems that, for residents in the Hocking Hills of central Ohio, where the irregular economy of logging and coal mining has brought with it irregular employment, moonshining has stood its ground as a sort of fallback occupation.
 At Ward's Restaurant, where burgers, fries, homemade vegetable soup and milkshakes are the centerpiece of the lunch menu, most residents queried at the counter during this year's celebration admitted to knowing someone else who continued to operate a still. "I don't know where to get some personally," said Martha Close, who was covering the customers counterside. "But most people around here would."
 Apart from the nostalgia, for Ward's and the town's handful of retail businesses, the three-day Memorial Day weekend festival brings with it the busiest and most profitable days of the year.
 Many of the region's farmers also realize they are on to a good thing. In Milan, Ohio, population 1,500, the Musk Melon Festival was started in 1959 as a side event to the high school's homecoming. These days the town plays host to 150,000 visitors over Labor Day weekend. The tiny town's square -- sliced in half by Ohio Route 113 -- is taken over by melon farmers who pull up their trucks to sell fresh melons. Church members can be counted on to provide musk melon pie and watermelon sherbet. And a nearby dairy has devised a musk melon ice cream for the event.
 While the sandy soil and temperate Lake Erie breezes in Milan were always habitable for musk melon, the crop has grown from a novelty to one of the area's thriving industries, according to Lou Weiss, a festival director for 32 years.
 Some of the smallest, less publicized festivals can also turn out to be the best for an afternoon outing. The creativity of the sideline activities associated with a farm market is limited only by the farmer's imagination and energy. At the Spring Hill Farm Market, a 200-acre farm orchard in Geneva, Ohio, near the Lake Erie shore, enthusiasm for the ripening of nearly every fruit crop brings with it a weekendlong celebration of picking and baking. In August it's peaches; in the fall there are grapes, and before closing for the winter there is an annual harvest festival.
 For strawberry season, irregularly scheduled in June for the past five years -- depending on the ripening of the fruit -- the event typically combines crafts and antique sales and horse and buggy tours of the 200-acre farm orchard with the baking and selling of everything and anything strawberry -- strawberry bread, strawberry-rhubarb pie and strawberry tarts topped with real whipped cream -- all made in the orchard's bakery.
 
WHERE TO DIG INTO CORN, RICE AND FRUIT
 Food festivals in the Midwest are not likely to be listed on anyone's five-star guide to eating, yet there are some tips to discovering the best at any of them. Unless you like greasy bratwurst or fried pork loin sandwiches and french fries literally dripping wet from the deep fryer, stay away from the traveling vendors and search out church groups' food tents, which typically feature the cooking talents of its members. And keep your orders simple: go with the special, which is likely to be the freshest, hottest and best made.
 In addition to festivals mentioned in the accompanying article, these are worth a visit:
 
Illinois
Sweet Corn and Watermelon Festival, Aug. 11 to 17, Mount Vernon. In its 20th year, the weeklong celebration features a parade, a corn-shucking contest and, on the final day, all the sweet corn (cooked in a steam engine) and watermelon you can eat, free. Information: (800) 252-5464.
 
Michigan
Cherry Festival, July 6 to 13, Traverse City. Festival highlights this year include three parades, a marching band competition, a sand-sculpturing competition and a country band show. The final day is the biggest, with both an early morning parade and the grand finale fireworks at night. (616) 947-4230.
 
Minnesota
Wild Rice Days, Aug. 31 to Sept. 1, McGregor. A 15-year tradition, both native wild rice (harvested off the lakes) and the cultured variety (grown in commercial paddies) are featured. A Saturday morning wild rice pancake breakfast, a threshing show, street dancing and carnival rides are part of the list of events. (218) 768-3692.
 
Ohio
Melon Festival, Aug. 31 to Sept. 2, Milan. The big event here is an antique car show on Saturday. There's also musk melon pie and musk melon ice cream, made especially for the occasion. (419) 499-2766.
 
Wisconsin
Cranberry Festival, Sept. 21 and 22, Warrens. Each year Wisconsin and Massachusetts vie for the national title of largest cranberry producer and Warrens is in the middle of cranberry country. Annual cooking contests and an ever-growing flea market attract the crowds. (608) 378-4388. -- J. S.
