HEADLINE: Alternative to Prison Mends Fences and Lives

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
DENNIS BROWN patted down the last handful of peat moss around a circle of marigolds, stood back and admired the design. He wore his baseball cap turned backwards, bubble-gum pink sunglasses and an oversized, sleeveless T-shirt. The name Essie was etched beneath the rose tattoo on his arm. "That's my girlfriend," he said, breaking into a grin. Mr. Brown said he had worked all morning cleaning and landscaping this triangular green across the street from the Connecticut Prison Association's Alternative Incarceration Center in Hartford. Before he was arrested and sentenced to serve three years in prison for a larceny conviction, Mr. Brown had planned to start his own landscaping company, he said.
After spending nine months of his sentence in the state's maximum security prison in Somers, he was accepted into the center's six-month program in May and now lives in one of several apartments managed by the prison association until he can find permanent housing. Five days a week he participates in supervised community service projects, which range from cleaning parks to painting municipal buildings, and he attends daily psychological and job counseling sessions. 
 Since his arrival he has put in more than 100 hours of such community service work, he said.
"In Somers I sat around counting the minutes and trying to figure ways to avoid a fight," said Mr. Brown, who added that he was beaten while in prison and stabbed with a knife and fork. "But in this program I feel like I'm going somewhere."
The Alternative Incarceration Program, developed five years ago by the Prison Association and the State Corrections Department, works with accused and convicted felons who are not considered threats to public safety. They are allowed to leave prison, freeing cells for offenders regarded as more dangerous. In the past two years, 16 centers serving 1,300 offenders have opened across the state, said James Greene, director of programming for the Prison Association. Two-thirds of its clients are people who have been accused of crimes but have not yet gone to trial, he said.
The Alternative Incarceration Program is the major focus in a move to reform the state's penal system by creating punishments that are less restrictive than imprisonment yet more confining than traditional probation. Corrections officials say they want to ease prison overcrowding by giving judges, prosecutors and defense lawyers a better range of sentencing options. Several states, including New York and Alabama, are considering adopting Connecticut's model.
Given the expense of housing the growing the prison population over the next decade, incarceration can no longer be viewed as the main form of criminal punishment, judges said. Because of overcrowding in Connecticut's prisons, they said, 70 percent of offenders spend less than one third of their sentences behind bars. The innovative sanctions will enable the state to imprison more serious offenders for longer portions of their sentence, they said.
"If we can find alternatives that would give the public the safety it requires and the court the accountability it demands, then we can solve the overcrowding problem," said William Carbone, the coordinator of the state's Office of Alternative Sanctions, which was created earlier this year. The office oversees the alternative incarceration centers and will monitor services for offenders like drug treatment and community service programs, halfway houses and vocational training.
The Alternative Incarceration Program is being developed as the state nears completion of a 10-year, $900 million construction and renovation plan that will add 11,000 new prison beds by 1992. Mr. Carbone said that it costs $25,000 a year to house an inmate in one of the state's 22 prisons, while keeping someone in an alternative incarceration center costs around $3,600.
A recent report by the Prison Overcrowding Commission said Connecticut's prison population increased 131 percent from 1980 to 1990, rising to 9,422 inmates from 4,885. The report attributed the steep rise primarily to higher arrest and conviction rates that began in the mid-1980s with the emergence of widespread drug trade. From June 1984 to September 1990, the number of people confined in the state's prisons for sale or possession of drugs increased more than sixfold, to 2,715 from 450.
Critics of traditional punishment have argued that imprisonment is potentially destructive, because it fails to address the underlying psychological and economic reasons that lead people to commit crimes.
"All incarceration does is incapacitate," Mr. Greene said, "whereas alternative sanctions attempt to change a criminal's behavior and give him the tools to go out and not make the same mistakes."
Community service work is a major part of the alternative program, he said. Last month, dozens of work crews from the program cleaned and made repairs at several state and municipal parks in preparation for Memorial Day weekend. While out on the job they wore gray-and-orange T-shirts that read, "We're giving something back."
 
Bathhouses and Picnic Tables
 At Hammonasset Beach State Park in Madison, workers washed and painted bathhouses and picnic tables and will continue to clean litter from the beach and do minor maintenance work once a week through the summer.
The other day, Doug Jackson, 22 years old, was part of a team assigned to mend the park's snow fences. Mr. Jackson said he was sentenced to serve three years for second-degree assault after a fight with his girlfriend that left her partially blind. He said that it was the first time he had hit her, and that he was drunk when the incident occurred.
After spending a year and a half in prison, Mr. Jackson said he was accepted into the Alternative Incarceration Center's program in Hartford nearly six months ago. In that time he has received alcohol and drug counseling that has helped to bolster his self-esteem, he said. He now lives with his sister and visits the center several times a week for job counseling and attends Alcoholics Anonymous meetings. He said he hoped to be hired back at Bradley International Airport, where he worked as a baggage checker before he went to prison.
"One thing I have learned is that I have to do things to better myself," said Mr. Jackson. He added that within the last year he has made peace with his ex-girlfriend, who is now dating someone else. "I told her, 'If you ever need anything, I'll be here for you,' " he said.
Mr. Greene of the Prison Association said that the majority of people in the Alternative Incarceration Program are substance abusers who come from troubled families and need intensive counseling to restore their self-image. During the six-month program, they are closely monitored and must attend daily family and group therapy sessions and be tested regularly for drug abuse, he said.
Their successes and failures are reported to correctional authorities. Of those accepted into the program, some 40 percent fail and are returned to prison, Mr. Greene said.
 
Judges See Shortcomings
 "Clients are told straight out that if they aren't going to cooperate, then we automatically become part of the incarceration process," he said.
Judges in Connecticut have significantly increased their use of alternative sanctions over the past year, but they frequently find that outside programs are not uniform, have limited capacity or are unavailable for judges in some jurisdictions, said Judge Aaron Ment, the state's chief court administrator.
Because most people who are convicted and sentenced to prison typically serve a much shorter time than a community-based program would require, and because the programs require the offenders to expend effort in both work and therapy, many of them are unwilling to submit to alternative sanctions, he said.
"Program time is hard time, and jail time is easy time," Judge Ment said. "We may sentence people to programs, but they may refuse to participate, so we end up sending them to jail. And that's the place where they wanted to be to begin with."
Sherry Haller, the executive director of the Justice Education Center, a state-financed education and research group, said that sentencing reforms are needed to extend punishment and give people convicted of crimes more incentives to remain in alternative programs. She said her center had nearly completed a study of the state's prison population and the options for intermediate sanctions. The research will make it easier for court authorities to determine appropriate sentencing, she said.
 
Transition to Community
 Because statewide alternative sanctions are a relatively new concept, judges said they saw risks in developing such a plan. Any highly publicized incident involving misconduct by an offender from an alternative program could imperil public support, they said.
Yet studies of the state's halfway house programs, introduced in 1980 to serve as a transition from prison to the community, have shown that participants had a lower recidivism rate than those who were released directly from prison into the community, and that the halfway houses do not add to problems of public safety .
Marlene Bermubez, 24, said that the seven months she has spent at the Mary Magdalene Halfway House on Park Avenue in Bridgeport has been far more valuable than the two years she spent in prison. Raised in Father Panik Village, a public-housing complex in Bridgeport noted for its high crime rate, Ms. Bermubez was convicted of first-degree assault for shooting a man in the leg. She said the man was harassing her.
Ms. Bermubez said the drug and alcohol counseling and family therapy sessions offered by the halfway house have taught her to control her anger and think positively about her future. She said her father and three sisters are now serving prison sentences, adding that she hoped to get an apartment and become a home health care aid after her release.
"When I first came here, I thought everyone owed me something," she said. "But now I realize that we're all just hurt children inside, with the same problems to overcome."

HEADLINE: Focus: New Buffalo, Mich.;
Chicagoans Rediscover a Shore Resort

BYLINE: By CHERYL KENT

 BODY:
A RISING second-home market in Michigan communities clustered on the southern edge of Lake Michigan is renewing the regional importance of the area, known as the South Shore, which has long been familiar to Chicagoans as a vacation spot.
Early in the century, Chicago's South Siders went to Michigan and North Siders went to Wisconsin for the summer. The Irish and Lithuanians transplanted the ethnic character of their South Side neighborhoods in the South Shore townships: Union Pier was Lithuanian and Grand Beach was Irish. Though those communities have changed, they still retain their ethnic flavor. 
 Then, as now, Chicagoans were attracted by the South Shore's quiet, wooded atmosphere, beaches and the dunes. Its life as a resort area lasted into the 50's. Vacationers stayed in rambling clapboard-sided hotels or built small frame cottages.
Some families have been going to the South Shore for generations, including the family that gave Chicago two Mayors, Richard J. Daley and his son, Richard M., the current Mayor. But the area began to draw fewer people in the 50's. Air-conditioning had made staying in the city tolerable. And in 1969, Interstate 94, which let people bypass the South Shore and vacation farther afield, was completed, eventually leaving rental cottages and hotels vacant.
But in 1979 the harbor at New Buffalo was dredged after the Army Corps of Engineers cleared the channel to it from Lake Michigan. This lead to the rejuvenation of the South Shore. Cottages and hotels were renovated and once again are filled in July and August. Moreover, vacation homes of a scale and splendor new to the area are under construction.
The interstate, instead of carrying vacationers farther from home, now provides quick access to the relatively close-by South Shore for Chicagoans concerned with the cost of gasoline.
One of the most visible developments is South Cove in New Buffalo, 65 miles from Chicago. Once a 52-acre swamp, it is now a harbor condominium project with 217 units and 400 boat slips. All but the 15 most recently built units have been sold, and some of the earlier units are up for resale. Condominiums that sold for $75,000 in 1980, when the development began, now fetch $130,000, said Karen Larkin, vice president of marketing and sales for New Buffalo Harbor, the local company developing South Cove.
THE project has 110 condominium units of 800 to 2,000 square feet in buildings at the harbor's edge, as well as three sizes of houses built on pilings over the water with boat slips alongside each house. There are 13 houses of 2,400 square feet, 50 of 890 square feet each and 44 of 400 square feet. Fifteen of the mid-size houses were recently completed; they are priced from $200,000 to $225,000. A large house that sold in 1984 for $250,000 is now listed for $310,000.
Buyers of residences not actually on the water have an option to buy a boat slip.
Plans for additional units at South Cove, which was designed by the Chicago architects Harry Weese & Associates, call for 13 private houses and a hotel.
Also in New Buffalo, Forest Beach Property, a local developer undertaking its first project, is selling 43 one-acre lots on a 65-acre lakefront camp bought for $2.8 million from the Y.W.C.A. of Chicago in 1989. Lots with beach frontage are selling for $2,000 a linear foot, or a total of $300,000 for the average 150-foot frontage. Others go for $84,000 to $156,000.
Houses must conform to requirements that spell out minimum size, selected architects and landscaping standards. The developer estimates the houses will cost about $250,000.
A major Forest Beach cost is preparing essentially raw land. The first phase included building and improving roads, tearing down overhead power lines and bringing in electricity, gas and water through underground conduits (the camp had had well water). That phase cost $2.5 million.
In the last 18 months, 22 lots have been sold, although no construction has started on them. A 3,000-square-foot speculative house on an unsold lot listed for $495,000 is nearing completion, and a 4,000-square-foot former camp dormitory has been renovated as a home by the developer and sold for $600,000.
Forest Beach was opposed by some South Shore property owners who hoped that the camp could become a public park.
The project will test the community's ability to attract a large number of buyers willing to invest half a million dollars or more in a second home.
A $500,000 five-story private house with a hot tub on the roof is being built in Grand Beach. It was designed for a Chicago doctor and his family by the Chicago architects Pappageorge/Haymes.
Even though construction of new houses continues, sales of existing homes have been slowed in the last year by the recession. Houses in the $500,000 to $700,000 range are not moving, said Gail Lowrie, a real estate broker in New Buffalo. However, smaller renovated cottages near Lake Michigan, priced around $100,000, have begun to sell again, she said.
"People have money but they are hesitating," she said. "If it's priced really well, they'll buy. But generally they are being prudent."
Summer cottages have been the area's standard historically. Pier One, an eight-cottage compound on one acre in Union Pier, is typical of the area's older building stock. Last year, the cottages, averaging 600 square feet and built in the 30's, were bought from their single owner for $140,000 by Spec Development of Chicago. They have been winterized and renovated and were put up for sale six months ago for $65,000 to $75,000. Two have been sold.
Rejuvenation of the South Shore began when the Army Corps of Engineers opened a channel to the New Buffalo harbor from the lake in 1979. Until then, the main activity in the harbor had been dredging by the Oselka family for detritus to make cement mix for its construction company.
Through their organization, New Buffalo Harbor, the Oselkas -- Paul and his twin sons Rolland and Ronald, plus a partner, Roccy DeFrancesco -- began to develop the harbor after the channel was cleared. They first sold 400 boat slips, which were bought largely by Chicago boaters. Ground was broken for the first South Cove condominiums in 1980. Many say that development attracted the attention of Chicagoans to the area once again.
Some buyers came back as early as 1983. That year, two Chicagoans, Ed and Jean Lawrence, bought and renovated an abandoned 1912 bed and breakfast called the Pebble House in Lakeside. All seven rooms are now taken for July and August, and most of the guests are from Chicago.
In 1986, the infant market was stalled by high lake levels that obliterated beaches, eroded the shoreline and threatened some lakefront houses. When the water receded and beaches came back a year later, property sold rapidly. Cottages that cost $25,000 in the late 80's now are selling for $60,000.

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 10; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1407 words

HEADLINE: Grimly, Graduates Are Finding Few Jobs

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
CORPORATE recruiting on most college campuses in Westchester declined this spring, and for the latest graduates the job search is harder than it has been in years.
"I filled out 11 job applications, had seven interviews and so far I've been turned down by six companies," said a 21-year-old communications major who graduated this month. He would not allow his name to be published because he feared he might sound like a "loser." 
 "The only comfort I have," he said, "is that none of my friends are having luck finding a job either. But I remember that five years ago, when my brother was graduating, he was recruited on campus and had three good job offers in his pocket when he graduated. That was boom time. This is bust time."
Most young job seekers would agree. Fewer jobs are being offered to new college graduates this year. In industries like banking, jobs have been cut drastically.
"We're still recruiting but with a difference," said Anne Schmidt, a human resources officer at the National Westminster Bank USA in White Plains. "We were at the job fair at the Iona campus in Yonkers, and we were talking to graduates, but we are staffing only with part-timers.
"We told the college graduates that we tried to think of the part-time jobs as an opportunity to learn banking. And we've also told them that they'll be considered for full-time positions when such positions become available, as our policy is to promote from within."
At Manhattanville College in Purchase, Karen Ganz, the director of the career service office, said: "We had two weekends of on-campus recruiting but with fewer companies attending. Some companies, such as Chemical Bank, that we've had great success with in the past, canceled at the last minute."
The economy was a factor, Ms. Ganz said, but she also explained that the past approach of recruiting on-campus has diminished and been replaced by the jobs fair. Manhattanville, for instance, is part of a five-college consortium that holds a jobs fair for its graduates every year.
 
'We Banded Together'
 "We banded together with SUNY Purchase, Sarah Lawrence and the two Marymount campuses, one in Westchester and one in New York, for our common good, employment for our graduating seniors," Ms. Ganz said. "We held two jobs fairs early in the year, one at Marymount at the Manhattan campus and the other at Manhattanville in Westchester."
Thirty-eight companies paid $50 each to recruit prospective employees. "The big change wasn't in the number of companies attending, but rather in the number of jobs they had to offer," Ms. Ganz said. "Instead of a company that had five positions last year, there were two this year." But she said some seniors had received firm job offers.
"United Parcel recruited three management trainees, two women and a man," she said. "The starting salaries were good, in the mid-$20,000 range. They begin by driving a United Parcel truck for three months."
 
A More Optimistic Note
 A law firm hired a legal assistant, a publishing house hired an editorial assistant and an insurance company "took one of our seniors to be trained as an underwriter," Ms. Ganz added.
Students may have to work harder to start their careers, but Mary P. Raymond, director of career services at Iona's two campuses, in New Rochelle and Yonkers, said the gloom-and-doom portrayal of the job market was overblown.
"There are those students who tap into that negative way of thinking and that becomes their excuse for not aggressively pursuing employment opportunities," Ms. Raymond said. "Liberal arts graduates and non-career business majors, such as those in management and marketing who lack well-defined objectives, are having the most trouble getting jobs."
Ms. Raymond said companies came to Iona's early spring career fairs in record number.
"Despite charging companies a $30 fee to attend the career fair this year, we still had a 15 percent increase in companies who attended over last year," when there was no fee, she said. But there were fewer job offers than in other years.
"Even though they didn't have jobs, we found that companies came to promote their visibility.The Big Six accounting firms were all represented, and some of our students did receive firm job offers from them. Insurance firms had jobs and so did some of the banks."
 
There's Always Grad School
 Some Iona students, discouraged about their job search, have applied to graduate schools. "I don't think that is a good option," Ms. Raymond said, "because it just prolongs getting into the job process."
A better idea for those students without jobs after graduation, she said, is to work as a volunteer. "Peace Corps and other volunteer groups offer experiences that sometimes lead to a career and salaried job," Ms. Raymond said. "We think so highly of that option that next year we're planning a service fair along the lines of the job fair."
She stressed that graduates use a variety of job-search techniques.
"I tell them it's not enough to put together a resume and to answer a few ads," she said. "Networking, telling friends and acquaintances that you need a job, is probably one of the best approaches for getting one."
Students, Ms. Ganz said, are required to attend class to learn how to put together a resume and how to conduct themselves in an interview.
"We show them all the techniques they can use to get a job," she said. "Our career service programs are open to our alumni as well, and the requests for job-interview information from alumni are creeping up, which is a reflection of the economy."
At Iona, the number of alumni using the college career service has also increased, Ms. Raymond said. "There are so many alums in their 40's out of work and in debt because of mergers and downsizing that we've started a support group for them, which meets on campus."
But some alumni are in a position to help. "Some supply jobs when they can and others phone in with job leads and share information," she said.
Robert Bierman, the employer relations consultant for the Hudson Valley region of the New York Department of Labor, said that the job market for professional and managerial white-collar workers is tight because of the slowdown in the financial industry in New York City.
"It has a ripple effect in Westchester," Mr. Bierman said. "What's happening this year is that people with a lot of experience are taking entry-level jobs and competing with the newly graduated. We see a dramatic increase in unemployment, judging from the claims we're paying out in the white-collar managerial level. The recession has hit this particular segment of the market very hard."
At Mercy College, Marguerite A. Busetti, director of career services, said that despite "a job market as tight as I have ever seen," 42 companies had recruited at Mercy's main campus at Dobbs Ferry this spring, only three fewer than in the year before.
"We've built up a rapport with companies who recruit our graduates," she said. "And although they don't have as many jobs available this year, there were jobs."
Mercy seniors were recruited largely by accounting firms, computer companies, retail stores, insurance companies and nonprofit agencies, she said.
 
Internships as a First Step
 Ann Novotnick, the employment manager at Bloomingdale's in White Plains and the store's representative at Mercy College, said campus recruiting had been an excellent way to find good employees.
"I go to all the Westchester college job fairs," Ms. Novotnick said. "We're already in the process of interviewing 10 people whom I spoke with at the Mercy job fair, and we've already hired five College of New Rochelle graduates for various positions in sales and management."
She advised students interested in a career in retailing to try interning before graduation. "Several undergraduates who have worked as interns for us have landed very good jobs with the store after graduation," she said.
D. Bradford Mills, branch manager of the copier division at the Pitney-Bowes district office in White Plains, also recruited on the Manhattanville campus. "I spoke with some very talented men and women at Manhattanville for positions that we have open as sales representatives," he said. "I'm still talking to some of them, and possibly that will result in some actual jobs. Our sales are slower, but our customers are still buying and we do need good people."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2119 words

HEADLINE: Everything's Up-to-Date in 1830

BYLINE: By Eugen Weber; Eugen Weber's books include "The Western Tradition: From the Renaissance to the Present." His most recent is "My France: Politics, Culture, Myth."

 BODY:

THE BIRTH OF THE MODERN
World Society 1815-1830.
By Paul Johnson.
1,095 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $35.  
 "Modern" derives from the Latin modo, meaning "recently" or "just now." "Modernity," as used pejoratively of course, dates from the mid-19th century. But no one knows quite when, in modern times, the modern was born: in the 17th century, when certain assertive intellectuals began to look on recent achievements as superior to past doings; in the 18th century, when change was widely equated with progress; or in the 19th century, when acceleration of change became the order of the day. In "The Birth of the Modern," Paul Johnson -- professional iconoclast, author of many books, including "Modern Times," and once editor of London's New Statesman -- argues for the 15 years after 1815, and his case is as strong (or as weak) as any other, though more entertaining than most.
He opens his thousand-page tale with two victories: that of Andrew Jackson over the British at New Orleans in 1815 and that of Wellington over the French at Waterloo the same year. The one inaugurated the "special relationship" confirmed by the Treaty of Ghent; the other confirmed British supremacy over the century. Their conjunction marks Mr. Johnson's underlying theme of a world society led into modernity by English-speaking nations that dominate the rest. In the age of steam and coal and iron, this makes good sense; the industrial, cultural and political revolutions of the 19th century were forged there and in France, and exported from these centers.
Modernity aborning is not just about things, but about access to things. Art galleries open to the public are a creation of the French Revolution and of Napoleonic conquests. Royal collections in the Louvre had been opened in 1793; the Accademia in Venice, the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam, the Brera in Milan and the Uffizi in Florence are due to initiatives taken by local administrations established by the French during the Napoleonic era. The Prado in Madrid and the National Gallery in London followed suit when Napoleon was gone.
Art and commercialism advanced together. Mass production of pianos, the tonal volume and sonority of new instruments with iron frames, the growing number of young people practicing their scales, the brilliance of Beethoven's sound -- all went with a growing middle-class audience, more music written for the commercial market, more middle-class artists (Schubert, Berlioz, Mendelssohn, Chopin) serving an increasingly middle-class public. New deeds suggested new words. Wider access to cultural activities prompted Mme. de Stael to coin the term "vulgarity," and German intellectuals to denounce "philistines," just as wider access to travel moved Byron to coin the contemptuous "tourism."
In the 18th century, romances and prose fictions had become novels. By the early 19th century, Jane Austen, daughter of a clergyman, could describe her family as all "great Novel-readers & not ashamed of being so." Soon book sales turned to mass sales, part of a wider commodity market that made affordable what had shortly before been costly. And circulating libraries -- an 18th-century Scottish invention that quickly spread -- made reading more common still.
The technology that helped turn out more goods more cheaply helped to sell them too, Mr. Johnson shows. New shopping arcades sheltered shops with plate glass windows for display; mass advertising rose to serve mass production by urging mass consumption. The revolution of expectations that advertising prompted would, in due course, be matched by a visual revolution that belongs in the second part of the century, when poster art and other forms made not only art but avant-garde art available to ordinary people. Meanwhile, late 18th-century technology transformed the visual expectations of more and more men and women. Limelight (Argand lamps) announced new technologies of vision (dioramas and so on), while gas illuminated London streets, and theaters even more. Possibilities seemed unlimited. Shelley (who planned to explore Africa by balloon) wrote about space travel powered by electricity. His bride, as we all know, gave us the first science fiction novel, "Frankenstein."
Mr. Johnson provides much fascinating information on the scientific and technological progress that inspired such fantasies while it turned luxuries into necessities, at least at the middle levels of society: better roads, cheaper shoes and clothes, steam pumps and engines, steamboats, lithography, omnibuses, but also the rubberized raincoats Charles Macintosh began to mass-produce in 1824. And while steam revolutionized mining, manufacture and travel, steam presses revolutionized printing and launched a newspaper industry, public opinion politics, even, before long, a Fourth Estate. Their contribution to the just-now age was not far off (electric telegraphs began to function in the 1840's). But the French Revolution of 1830, which put an end to the post-Napoleonic Bourbon restoration, does seem, as Mr. Johnson maintains, the first time the news media overthrew a government.
All this was halting and uncertain. If public transport improved, most people still walked: 20 miles was nothing. Lincoln once walked 34 miles just for the pleasure "of hearing a lawyer make a speech," Mr. Johnson writes, quoting from Carl Sandburg. And if goods were becoming less scarce (for some), pain was as rife as ever. Medicine was barely finding its feet, or its prestige. Anesthesia lay in the future. Until the 1840's and 50's, when nitrous oxide gas, ether and chloroform began to be used, surgery placed a premium on speed, and surgical training a premium on snatching bodies for future surgeons to practice on. Pain not subject to surgical intervention depended on drugs -- mostly opiates; and Quakers, later to specialize in chocolate manufacture, made fortunes selling laudanum, paregoric and stronger stuff.
Every "improvement" carried both promise and threat. Urban sprawl bred slums (the word appears in the 1820's). Pollution too: in Edinburgh, said the poet laureate Robert Southey, "you might smoke bacon by hanging it out of the window." Greater traffic brought deafening noise, vast traffic jams and parking problems that, in turn, suggested "carriage parks." Reaction to urban problems inspired a retreat to nature, the cult of gardens, the vogue of "rustic" garden furniture. It also reinforced an escape into history and the myth of simpler, purer, more natural ages.
The early 19th century continued "overawed by distance," as an Australian put it. The first long-distance railway only appeared in 1830. Yet steam, which radically cut the costs of sea travel, accelerated not only migration from Europe but also colonization. Shallow draft steamboats conquered the world's rivers, and many carried guns that fired the devastating antipersonnel shells invented in 1803 by Col. Henry Shrapnel for use against Napoleon. The age of gunboat diplomacy opens in 1825 off the west coast of Africa and, characteristic of the age, the gunboat's task is to discourage the slave trade.
The age of wars of national liberation, of massacres and countermassacres, of anti-European propaganda and anticolonial rhetoric dawned in Latin America around 1810, and much of a chapter called "Masques of Anarchy" is devoted to its sickening story. There, as in Greece -- grave of many illusions -- or later in Italy, nationalists depended on foreign aid, or on the incompetence of the power they challenged. In the end, as Simon Bolivar declared in 1830 when he was sick of it, "he who sows a revolution ploughs the sea."
Mankind, as Mr. Johnson contends, was turning (just beginning to turn) into a global community. One result he does not mention is that mankind's relations, less limited by distance than before, were turning into global conflict. But conflict could be found nearer home. Mr. Johnson's last chapter is titled "The Coming of the Demos." The 1820's experienced new degrees of political tension and terrorism. In France even theater claques were politicized, while operas and plays reflected political conflict and spurred it. Everywhere, economic problems encouraged radicalism and upheaval. Yet everywhere in the West the politics of oligarchy tolerated degrees of violence and vituperation that we would never stomach. In England, when fists and missiles rested, words took their place; witness Byron's epitaph on Castlereagh, the Minister he loathed:
 
 Posterity will ne'er survey
 A nobler grave than this;
 Here lie the bones of Castlereagh:
 Stop, traveller, . . .
In the United States, meanwhile, the first national smear campaign, whose venom was said to have killed Andrew Jackson's wife, did not prevent Jackson from being elected in 1828 -- the country's first modern President. In that context Jackson becomes an iconic figure associated with the rise of the Democratic Party and the spoils system, but also with American democratic rudeness and a meddling moralism out to improve the world while concealing unpleasantness behind euphemisms: "help" for servants, "peculiar institution" for slavery. Nothing much has changed, it seems. In 1828, a letter from the White House took five days to reach Martin Van Buren in New York; it would not take much longer today.
Much of Mr. Johnson's presentation is debatable, not because his anecdotes fail to illuminate or his facts to tell, but because their evidence applies to narrow social and geographical areas. Britain, France, the upper classes and the upper middle classes provide most of the record. And not all of that is flawless. The German Sturm und Drang of the 1770's was not directed against Napoleon's armies. The painter Jacques-Louis David was not sentenced to exile after Waterloo; he chose it. In French, taille -- a poll tax -- does not mean "to pull," but to cut, clip or notch. French women's literacy in 1848 was nowhere near 80 percent (nor to 60 percent in 1830 either). And cleanliness was no characteristic of the 1820's, even in England. Over 100 years later, I found the English middle classes oddly grubby and mistrustful of warm baths.
Nevertheless, Mr. Johnson serves us a savory social history, spiced with lively gossip. He moves fast but is easy to follow. He insists on the intimate connection of literature and politics, on the interplay among literature, philosophy, science and art at the birth of the modern world, and he embodies the phenomena he describes in personalities. The book is a mosaic of brisk cameos (thus Bonaparte at St. Helena, "round and white, like a china pig"). And, though his book is hefty, it is never dull. In many ways a tour de force.
 
WHY HISTORY IS LIKE A RAILROAD
 Paul Johnson, who spends 1,000 pages in his new book arguing that "the modern" was born between 1815 and 1830, acknowledges that critics might disagree. "I don't want to push this assumption too far," the 62-year-old former journalist and author of two dozen books said during a recent telephone interview from his home in the tiny British hamlet of Over Stowey in Somerset. "But it's difficult to think of any aspect of human existence that didn't change radically during these 15 years. I don't think you get this concentration and variety in any other period."
Among changes he mentioned were the beginnings of organized sport and long-distance travel, the development of an international artistic culture and the institution of precursors of the Russian gulags. "Also, those 15 years were absolutely vital in the rest of the world," he said. "In America, the settlement of the West was beginning. In South America, the Spanish Empire was breaking up. And Russia was expanding into Asia." He said this "crowded book" took 10 years of research, "but it's the book I've enjoyed writing most because there were so many interesting people to try to bring to life."
He is deeply committed to popular social history. "I was anxious to show how ordinary people were affected by these changes," he said. "What I try to do is like the 'total history' of the French Annales school. But they tend to write static history, while I believe that one should convey the sense of history rumbling along like a railroad."
Creating big historical works, becoming enthralled with the cast of characters, is exciting, he said, but so is all history; "history is like being on an ocean liner, churning up the past behind while you push ahead, not really knowing what will be there." But he does know what work is ahead for him -- another grand project, he said, "a history of the American people." -- ANDREW L. YARROW

HEADLINE: Supply-Siders Persist in Their Errors

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"We're All Better Off for Reagan's Tax Reforms" by Jude Wanniski (letter, June 6) is another attempt by a supply-sider to perpetuate the myth that the Reagan tax reductions worked miracles for the American economy and that a cut in the capital gains tax would add to the benefits. 
 Mr. Wanniski tells us that the economy is one-third bigger than a decade ago "because of the Reagan reforms." What he does not report is that before the Reagan reforms the United States economy grew even faster: 45 percent in the 1960's and 32 percent in the 1970's, compared with 30 percent in the 80's.
He tells us that the Reagan tax reforms favored labor over capital, and that is why real income per capita has lagged in the "lower income classes" and "why so many jobs were created" in the 80's. Actually, employment grew by more in the two previous decades than in the last one. Moreover, it is difficult to understand why employers should hire more workers simply because those workers' income taxes have been cut.
Mr. Wanniski's main pitch is that the quickest way to increase the real incomes of the lower income classes would be to eliminate the tax on capital gains, "which would encourage capital formation faster than new jobs are supplied." Like the supply-siders' claims of a decade ago, none of which have materialized, the notion that business investment would increase significantly if the capital gains tax were repealed makes little sense. One only has to look at the income statements of major corporations and see how little of their earnings consist of capital gains.
If the argument is that stock prices would rise on elimination of the capital gains tax, and therefore the cost of equity financing would decrease, we need only note that the capital gains tax of 28 percent did not prevent the Dow Jones average from rising above 3,000 recently and the price-earnings ratio from increasing from 14 a year ago to about 20 recently.
Substituting zealotry for sound economics, Mr. Wanniski and his supply-side colleagues still miss no opportunity to peddle their discredited doctrines.
 
ROBERT SOLOMON
Guest Scholar
The Brookings Institution
Washington, June 10, 1991

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Magazines Seeing Signs Of Recovery

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
AN advance look at magazine advertising pages for September, an indicator of the economic health of the marketing and media industries, shows some signs the recession may be at or near an end.
But there are few Pollyannas among the publishing executives, and most said they thought that happy days might not really return until the first or second quarter of next year. 
 Publishers and ad directors at large national monthlies and bimonthlies, where publishing schedules necessitate selling September's ad pages by late June or early July, were informally surveyed about the outlook for the month.
September results are closely watched because at many a magazine, that month's issue carries the most ad pages of any during the year, since it comes at the beginning of the fall-to-Christmas shopping season.
"I wait 11 months for this issue," said Anne Sutherland Fuchs, publisher of Vogue, whose September issue often is as thick as a brick. While it is too early to announce a page count, she added, "We are predicting some softness."
Yet Ms. Fuchs took note of two telephone calls that she received the morning she was interviewed, from two marketers who were not expected to buy any September ad pages: One bought two pages while the other bought four pages.
"I'm never going to close this issue," Ms. Fuchs said jokingly.
Referring to a statement by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that the recession may already be over, or may end soon, James Hayes, publisher of Fortune magazine, said, "You can put my name right next to Greenspan." He added that things looked much better than they did two months ago. "For the past six weeks, we've made our weeks," he said, referring to ad pages that tied or exceeded the levels of the same week a year earlier.
Even so, said Jack Kliger, publisher of Glamour, magazine ad pages are rarely "a first sign of a recession bottoming out," because of the lead time required to commit ad dollars to print media. "This fall does not look like anything people are going to jump up and down about," he said. "We're fighting to maintain share and build that."
September ad pages for the 14 titles of Hearst Magazines will decline by close to 10 percent from last September's levels, said Charlotte Kelly Veal, a spokeswoman. "We know that as an industry we lag coming out of a recession," she continued, "so we are projecting a stronger picture for the second quarter of 1992, but not before then."
And Michael A. Clinton, publisher of GQ magazine, said, "I don't think we are seeing any aggressive movement in terms of advertisers coming back with big schedules yet." While some of his largest retail advertisers "are having a good year, like the Gap and Merry-Go-Round," he added, "things are still spotty."
Yet at Money, September now looks "to be up over last year by about nine pages," said Betsy Martin, advertising sales director. She continued: "It's not a lot, but as we say, up is up. I'm Irish, so I don't like to be too optimistic and press my luck, but we think maybe the worst is over."
Also becoming more cheerful is Michael Golden, publisher of McCall's. Though his September issue does not close until this week, it appears that ad pages will finish even with those of a large special issue last September. "Anytime we're even with last year this year, it's a good sign," he said. "I'm getting to the optimistic side, and I was not there before."
At the Meredith Corporation, Better Homes and Gardens expects September ad pages to increase at least 10 percent, said a spokesman, Rick Phillips, and Midwest Living estimates a similar gain for its September/October issue. And The Ladies' Home Journal is projecting "the largest September in our history," its publisher, Donna Galotti, said. She estimated her ad-page increase at 9 percent 17 percent.

HEADLINE: G. W. Hobbs 3d, 85; Ran Group on Aging

 BODY:
G. Warfield Hobbs 3d, a former chairman of the National Committee on the Aging, died on Saturday in Longwood, Fla. He was 85 years old and moved there last year after living in both Stonington, Conn., and Englewood, Fla., for two decades.
He died of cancer of the liver, his wife, Helen, said. 
 Mr. Hobbs retired in 1965 as a Manhattan-based vice president of the First National City Bank of New York, now Citibank, part of Citicorp.
Under his leadership, the Committee on Aging provided information and counseling in areas like health, employment, retirement and social welfare.
In a speech in 1957, Mr. Hobbs contended that thousands of scientists and engineers were being forced to retire when they could be performing vital national services. And in testimony before a New York State legislative committee in 1953, he warned that rapid expansion of pension systems could harm the American economy.
Mr. Hobbs was born and grew up in Baltimore. He earned a bachelor's degree at Johns Hopkins University in 1928 and then joined the bank, where he headed the pension trust division from 1938 until he retired. He served in the Army Air Forces in World War II.
Besides his wife, the former Helen I. Miller, Mr. Hobbs is survived by a daughter, Susan Connell of North Stonington; two sons, G. Warfield 4th, of New Canaan, Conn., and William, of Milwaukee, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Machine Tools Orders Fell 19.6% in May

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools fell in May for a third straight month, dropping 19.6 percent from the April level, an industry trade group said in a monthly report being released today.
The drop comes in spite of predictions by makers of machine tools and the industry trade group, the Association for Manufacturing Technology, that industry orders would generally improve as American businesses began spending to upgrade their manufacturing plants. 
 Analysts interpreted the May figures as evidence that capital spending continues to show little sign of rebounding and that the nation's economy remains in a recession despite recent signs of recovery.
 
Lowest Since 1987
 In its report, the association said new orders for machine tools fell to $155.8 million in May from $193.7 million in April. It was the lowest monthly new-order total since August 1987, when it was $142 million. New orders in May were also 24.5 percent below the level of May 1990. For the first five months of this year, machine tool orders are down 13.6 percent from a year earlier.
Machine tools are used to cut or shape metal parts used in durable products like appliances, automobiles, aircraft and building components. The level of orders and shipments of machine tools is considered an important indicator of the health of American industry.
"There seems to be a reluctance on the part of manufacturers to upgrade their facilities," said Richard O. Priebe, a spokesman with Cross & Trecker Inc., a large machine tool maker that earlier this month agreed to be acquired by a competitor, Giddings & Lewis Inc. "Manufacturers seemed to be sitting tight right now," Mr. Priebe said. "It reflects a general weakness in the economy, and that caused manufacturers to delay their purchases."
Larry W. Hollis, an analyst with Robert W. Baird & Company, a brokerage in Milwaukee, said the May figures reflected weakness in the economy. "In recessions, orders are generally slow," Mr. Hollis said. He added that the May report indicated that foreign machine tool makers, particularly those in Japan, "continue to make significant inroads in American market share." He added that foreign machine tool producers "now have about half of the domestic market."
 
Link to Factory Use
 Despite the weakness of new orders in recent months, Albert W. Moore, president of the Association for Manufacturing Technology, said he remained encouraged by recent data from the Federal Reserve showing two consecutive months of higher factory utilization. "Conventional wisdom in our industry is that machine tool orders escalate when capacity utilization crosses the 80 percent level," Mr. Moore said.
"Manufacturers also have tigher control over their inventories now than in most downturns," he added. "With lean inventories, production will respond quickly to higher demand, in turn creating demand for the machine tool which will be needed to meet new production levels."
Machine tool orders have been hurt by the economic woes of automobile makers, which typically account for more than a third of the industry's new orders. And some analysts suggest that a pickup of new orders from car makers, who are expected to retool soon for new models, will help stimulate new orders for machine tools.
 
Strong Foreign Demand
 The May report also showed that orders from foreign customers dropped a sharp 54 percent from the previous month. Industry executives said that they could not account for that decline, but analysts suggested that it probably resulted from a large level of foreign orders in April.
Orders from foreign customers, which reached a record last year, were up 10.7 percent for the first five months of the year, while orders from domestic customers fell 18.9 percent in the same period. Orders from domestic customers were down 8.7 percent in May from the April rate.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Picking Issues: Dinkins's Crime, Koch's Housing

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Whoever said talk is cheap never met the Mayor of New York.
A prisoner of his own oratory, Mayor David N. Dinkins sought last fall to end his sentence in political purgatory with a proposition: a four-year $1.8 billion "assault on all fronts" to redeem his campaign pledge to be the city's "toughest mayor on crime" and to compensate for what seemed to be his indifference to a surge in homicides over the summer, which prompted demands that he hire 5,000 more police officers. 
 Instead, after overdue deliberation, Mr. Dinkins proposed that the police force be expanded even more. He coupled the expansion with new resources for the rest of the criminal-justice system and with a more modest investment in preventive programs for youths.
The Mayor's proposal was pared by the City Council. But this week, as he tries to negotiate a budget for the fiscal year beginning on July 1, Mr. Dinkins's stubborn refusal to retreat further from his major tangible achievement has tied his hands. The spending and tax commitments he made to rescue his anti-crime plan earlier this year have wound up, as predicted, subordinating his other priorities in a budget that has been severely constrained by the recession.
Mr. Dinkins is hardly the first elected official to respond to political wind, even when he blew it himself. His promise of toughness was intended to defy a stereotype -- of a liberal who, as a Manhattan borough president, was more concerned with producing social programs for his constituents than more police officers.
Yet New York City's major discretionary spending during the last five years represented calculated political responses to substantive problems that a mayor's oratory compounded.
In 1986, Mayor Edward I. Koch unveiled a 10-year, $4.2 billion proposal to build or renovate tens of thousands of apartments. A "housing crisis," he said, had been precipitated by Federal parsimony. But a political crisis had been created by what many saw as an insensitivity to so cial problems, even as his tough talk on crime seemed to mask his administration's failure to reclaim the streets.
 "Koch had crime, in a certain sense, under control," David Garth, his political strategist, recalled. "What we were criticized for legitimately was the housing problem. Dinkins feels that his vulnerability is in law and order. Koch felt his was compassion."
Mr. Koch often characterized himself as a "liberal with sanity." The epiphany came early in Mr. Koch's first term, though, when he found that once he was a mayor he could not afford to impose programs he had advocated for urban America when he was a Congressman.
Mr. Dinkins's metamorphoses seemed even more pronounced. Less than two days after his inaugural address, when he repeated his pledge to be the toughest mayor on crime, a higher priority took precedence: he postponed planned police hiring to help close a yawning deficit. His decision was applauded at the time, in part because it addressed another of his vulnerabilities: perceived fiscal imprudence. Yet it would haunt him as crime climbed over the summer.
"If the No. 1 issue people were thinking about was crime and drugs and we were not addressing it," Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch said, "then we couldn't make happen some of the things the Mayor was talking about, like reducing infant mortality and promoting racial harmony."
Mr. Koch boldly addressed the housing issue when the economy was flush. He relied heavily on the city's construction budget without impinging on operating funds. But, like Mr. Dinkins's police plan, the housing blueprint may have been well intentioned but somewhat shortsighted.
Advocates for housing, said Andrew Cuomo, whose HELP program builds transitional housing for the homeless, "let government off the hook" by their own political calculation to focus largely on the physical needs of the poor without acknowledging that many homeless people also require a welter of social services, too.
"Nobody was coming back into the housing business," Mr. Koch recalled. "Abandoned buildings with enormous value were deteriorating. There were new programs where you could bring in private-sector dollars. And, finally, you had every editorial beating you up."
Wasn't his response analogous to Mr. Dinkins's? "Mine was sensible; his was not," Mr. Koch said. "As much as any one of us wants more cops, you cannot make cops the World Trade Center and everything else in the budget becomes a brownstone."
Mr. Koch's housing program was insufficient to win him a fourth term. And Mr. Dinkins's police plan may not win him re-election. But it has managed so far to discourage and deflect further criticism that he does not care about crime.
In a democracy, elected officials are supposed to chart a course between political pragmatism and opportunism in responding to the winds of change. But if the ship of state turns out to be a sailboat, then the navigator needs to know when to tack.

HEADLINE: Gap Finds Middle Road to Success

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
The Gap Inc., which became a successful chain in the early 80's with casual clothing like unisex jeans, T-shirts and denim jackets, is doing even better in the 90's by separating the sexes and widening its appeal.
The Gap still sells jeans but has added a broader assortment and greater range of colors in clothing like blouses and dresses. In doing so, the company took a risk that it could keep its regular customers and add new ones. 
 It was right. So right, in fact, that the Gap has become one of retailing's rare superstars, one with consistent double-digit sales gains even in the midst of a recession.
Hoping to keep that momentum going, the company started a new and unusual television advertising campaign last week. With the theme "For every generation there's a Gap," the ads feature relatively little Gap clothing and even show people wearing clothes that are not from the Gap line. The television ads will complement the Gap's celebrity-sprinkled "Individuals of style" ads that have appeared mostly in magazines since 1988. Industry analysts and retailing executives say the Gap owes much of its success to its bold move to establish the Gap name as a brand amid the proliferation of fashion labels.
"The Gap achieved outstanding results with the right merchandise," Stacy Ruchlamer, a retail analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers, New York, wrote in a report after seeing the Gap's overall sales rise 33 percent in May. "The Gap has developed a superior concept of offering fashionable basics for many Americans. The Gap has the potential for substantial growth because it serves a huge market -- young, middle-aged to more mature adults -- with very little competition."
To be sure, the San Bruno, Calif., company is not flawless. Its biggest problem remains its Banana Republic unit, the once-hot, safari-type clothing chain that ran out of steam about 1987. An attempt to start a chain called Hemisphere, with more stylish clothes for affluent shoppers, failed last year.
After shifting to more general newer-fashion sportswear, Banana Republic has shown progress, and company executives seem optimistic that it can climb back to high-profit levels.
Retailing industry analysts credit Donald G. Fisher, the Gap's founder and chief executive, and Millard S. Drexler, its president, with making the 950-store company defy the laws of retailing gravity. Mr. Fisher, is an entrepreneur who built a successful big business but who realized that he needed a proven merchandiser like Mr. Drexler to help put new strategies into place.
 
Strong Same-Store Sales
 Last year, the company had sales of $1.93 billion, up from $1.58 billion. More impressive, in the latest reporting period sales at Gap stores open at least a year, known as "same-store sales," rose 15 percent, about three times the industry average. For the first four months of this year, total sales were $655 million, up 25 percent; same-store sales rose 8 percent.
Adding to the Gap's success are the 170 GapKids stores and the newer, 50 BabyGap departments, both of which have attracted new customers. This year, about 150 new stores are planned, including 25 new Banana Republic units and 50 GapKids stores in the United States, Britain and Canada.
Mr. Fisher boasts that the Gap label is the second-best-selling brand in American clothing, after Levi Strauss and ahead of Benetton and Liz Claiborne.
Mr. Drexler describes the Gap's wares as "not high-risk fashion, but good taste, good style; not too far to the left, not too far to the right."
What seems to differentiate Gap sportswear from most rival offerings is the extensive color palette, ranging from basic black and white to pale beiges to deep maroons to vivid blues. The prices are usually lower than those charged by department stores. The combined effect is that when shoppers find items like polo shirts at $24.50 to $34, they are tempted to buy them in several colors.
Customers who filled the Gap store at 445 Fifth Avenue at 39th Street in Manhattan on Thursday, said the company offered more comfortable, basic styles, a wider selection and at better prices than other stores.
"I like the Gap for its shorts, polos and jeans because the styling appeals to me," said Deidre Egan, a student at New York University. "Their clothes are more comfortable than what I find elsewhere. I do shop in other places, but I always try to include the Gap."
Barbara Debois, of Baldwin, L.I., said she had bought a lot of clothes for her husband in the store.
"I've been shopping at the Gap for at least five years," she said. "Their colors are attractive, and I like very much their mix-and-match sportswear."
Another woman who said she was a "retailing professional" but refused to give her name or that of her company, said she had noticed the Gap's shift. "They've really developed their own niche," she said. "Their colors are a little bit ahead of everyone else's, and their prices are low."
 
Named for Generation Gap
 When Mr. Fisher, an engineer, started the Gap in 1969, he named it for the much-discussed generation gap. A dozen years later, the company had 150 stores with sales of $417 million and earnings of $11.8 million. In the next decade -- Mr. Drexler joined the company in 1983 -- it quadrupled its sales and increased its net income eightfold.
"I was looking for the right person," Mr. Fisher recalled, "and decided that he might be at the best-run specialty chain, the Ann Taylor stores." Mr. Drexler added: "Actually, Don and I were ready to start a new business together in New York because I really didn't want to move to California. But in order to generate such a new startup, the Gap had to do better. So I agreed to go there for three years, and then I decided to stay."
In helping to transform the company, Mr. Drexler has also become one of the highest paid and, because of very generous stock options, one of the wealthiest retail executives in America.
According to the company's proxy statement dated April 26, Mr. Drexler received total compensation of nearly $1.9 million in 1990, practically the same as Mr. Fisher, who is also the chairman. Mr. Drexler's Gap stock holdings as of April 2, amounted to just over two million common shares, or 2.9 percent of the shares outstanding, the proxy says. Valued at $60.375 a share, those holdings are worth more than $123 million.
 
Stress Own Brand
 In becoming its own brand, one of the Gap's most significant changes, Mr. Fisher and Mr. Drexler said, was their decision to drop all rival brands other than Levi, which accounts for about 7 percent of the Gap's merchandise. As evidence of how well that policy has worked, fashion magazines now refer to a Gap cotton shirt when suggesting outfits the same way they do a DKNY blouse or Guess? denim jacket.
"That plan put us in a unique position for a retailer," Mr. Fisher said. "We are the only American retailer of any size with its own brand name on such a dominating share of our business."
When he arrived at the Gap, Mr. Drexler found a major retailer of Levi's that was trying to diversify and broaden itself. The Gap carried as many as 15 different national brands of clothes. Its merchandising approach for getting all those labels out of the stores was to offer "sale" prices every day. But this constant diet of price-cutting proved inconsistent.
Also, as the 80's wore on, the Gap's management gradually noticed some disaffection by women shoppers. Many seemed to feel the unisex look was dominated by men's styling.
 
'Just Plain Ugly'
 "What troubled me especially," recalled Mr. Drexler, "was that the taste level of the merchandise was, well, just plain ugly. The stuff was trendy but not tasteful and the quality was not what I would have liked. The problem was that we were running a margin-driven business based on price. There was no real, bright future in that."
So, in 1987, the Gap set up separate collections for men and women. It doubled its product development staff to create separate units to develop each line. And it more than doubled the number of styles for women.
Mainly though, styling was shifted to "simpler, cleaner lines, all in natural fibers " said John Fumiati, Gap's product development chief.
But true to its something-for-everybody theme, the Gap still carries some unisex clothes for those who like them -- in its men's department.

HEADLINE: Life on the Bottom Line: How Dinkins's Budget Affects Social Services

 BODY:
Sheena Craig, a 32-year-old home-care attendant with no health insurance, walked out of an outpatient pharmacy at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn last Wednesday clutching two plastic bottles of pills -- one for treating a fallopian-tube infection, the other to kill the pain.
Alexis Suter, 28, an unemployed singer who is eight months pregnant, came in for vitamins, and Valerie Dawson, 67, a housecleaner, picked up the $320 worth of prescriptions she needs every month to control high blood pressure and diabetes. 
 The women, like thousands of other New Yorkers, get their medicines and vitamins free through a city program for those unable to pay. But that service may come to an end. With the city facing its worst financial crisis since the 1970's, all 28 pharmacies in the city's public hospitals and clinics are scheduled to close their doors next week. The savings: $30 million.
The closing of the pharmacies, if it happens, will tear a large hole in the city's social safety net. But it is only one of scores of cuts in social services -- from the complete elimination of city dental services and a highly successful infant mortality program to deep cuts in school health programs, drug treatment and shelters for the mentally ill -- included in the fine print of Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed $29 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1.
 
Cuts Across the Board
 The social-service reductions are among a broad array of cuts that the Mayor has proposed in virtually every agency, from parks to sanitation, to help close a budget gap of at least $3.5 billion. Only the Police and Fire Departments would be largely spared.
Some proposed social-service cuts will undoubtedly be carried out -- along with tax increases and cuts in other services that benefit the middle class -- to help the city get through a difficult period. Others were mainly intended to prod the State Legislature, the City Council and municipal unions to come up with alternatives to avert them.
The Legislature is bogged down in its own budget mess, and the municipal unions have not yet agreed to concessions. The Council, though, anxious to test its broad powers under the new City Charter, is close to completing a budget-cutting plan of its own. It would trim services even more.
The details of the Council's plan are not yet available. But in seeking to avoid higher property taxes, the Council wants to cut another $476 million from the Dinkins budget, which already calls for $1.5 billion in cuts.
Mr. Dinkins and Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone are quick to blame one another for the need to cut services.
"I don't want to lose these programs any more than you do -- all these programs are important," Mr. Dinkins told a group of parents and poverty workers gathered on the steps of City Hall last week.
 
Loss of Matching Funds
 Though details are unclear, cuts seem certain and pain is already being felt. With just a week before the start of the fiscal year, it may be increasingly difficult for Mr. Dinkins to reverse the momentum he created.
This would leave Mr. Dinkins -- a Mayor elected on the promise of doing more for the people in the city's most troubled neighborhoods -- presiding over cuts that could fundamentally alter the relationship between New York City government and the poor. The city has a long, if rumpled, tradition of doing more for the poor than many other local governments, and the cuts would choke off many of those efforts.
And city reductions of $278 million in health and human services would be magnified by another $207 lost in state and Federal matching funds. Even Philip R. Michael, the city's budget director, acknowledged that some of proposed cuts are counterproductive and could eventually increase costs because they decimate services, like children's health programs and drug treatment, that are meant to avoid future problems.
Whatever the financial consequences, Mr. Dinkins's 275-page budget proposal lists page after page of "service reductions" in dry bureaucratic language. But behind each line item lies a human story.

HEADLINE: Pomp, Circumstance and Pessimism: Awaiting Hard Knocks After School

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, June 19

 BODY:
Confetti and cheers showered the 335 seniors when they graduated today from Abraham Lincoln High School here. But beneath the euphoria lay haunting worries among the graduates about the future.
Evangelia Notidis, 17 years old and the school's top student, fretted that the economy might undermine her efforts to pay for a medical career. 
 Bryan Mahoney, 19, worried that even with a college education he would be hard-pressed to match his parents' quality of life.
 
Laid Off and Looking for Work
 Nicole Dunnigan, 17, who was laid off earlier this year from a $220-a-week job as a part-time clerk at a real estate agency, has been unable to find other work. She wants to earn money for training to become a court stenographer.
Maureen Powers, 18, who plans to enter college in the fall, best summed up the anxiety felt by her classmates and many other high school graduating seniors around the country: "We're scared."
For good reason. A generation of young people has been pushed into the harshest economic climate any high school class has faced in at least 25 years, according to guidance counselors, economists, demographers and the parents of these students.
For starters, these young people have graduated into a recession that has resulted in widespread layoffs and chilled the creation of new jobs. The job market also continues to shift toward more skilled work in technology, aerospace and health care, which, while not necessarily requiring a college education, does require additional training.
Over all, the Bureau of Labor Statistics expects about 18 million new jobs to be created by the economy from 1988 through the year 2000, only about half the number created in the 12-year period through 1988.
And many of the new jobs will be highly technical, requiring skills beyond the reach of high school graduates who cannot get advanced training. At the same time, most of the unskilled jobs in manufacturing, which paid previous generations enough to support a style of life that included comfortable housing, no longer exist.
 
Housing Is the Hurdle
 Housing prices and rents, moreover, are now among the highest in this century, even when earlier periods are adjusted for inflation. And salaries, both for those with only high school diplomas and those with college degrees, have not kept pace with housing costs.
In 1967, the year many parents of this generation left high school, the average salary for all workers in the United States, including college graduates, was $6,845, according to the Census Bureau, a figure that is $26,786 when adjusted to 1990 dollars. In 1990, the average salary was $29,912, only slightly better and still far behind the rise in the cost of housing, medical care and some other living expenses.
"This generation will have less," said David Capuzzi, the assistant dean at the school of education at Portland State University in Oregon and a former president of the American Association for Counseling and Development. "More will buy their starter home at 40, while their parents bought theirs at 25. They know this, and it has discouraged them."
The shift in the job market seems certain to continue through 2000 as corporations move unskilled jobs to cheaper foreign labor markets. Even demographics have conspired against this generation. The generation of babies born after World War II, the oldest of whom are now in their 40's and some of whom are parents of this generation, have a stranglehold on jobs for at least 20 more years.
 
Good Jobs Move Away
 "There really is a hell of a difference between this class and that of their parents," said Harry C. Wilcox, the principal at Lincoln High School, who for 35 years has watched classes graduate from the ethnically and economically mixed school in Northeast Philadelphia. "The good jobs are moving farther away from the poor jobs, and there aren't any jobs in between. The kid who doesn't go to college won't be able to do as well as their mother or father."
Even those who do go to college are not assured of high-paying, fast-track jobs. For the last two years, college graduates have had to scale back their expectations in the face of a sharply reduced job market, primarily because of the recession.
It is still too early to get statistics on the number of high school graduates who will be going to college in the fall or those who will be seeking specialized training. But in interviews with about 50 graduates around the country, nearly all who are not heading for college said they hope to go to trade school to bolster their skills. Many of their parents were able to slip easily into the job market and begin earning money right away.
One of the few recent graduates to say he would be going straight to the workplace was Michael Arinwine, 17, a graduate of Manual Arts High School in Los Angeles.
"I'll go get a job," Mr. Arinwine said, although he is not yet sure where. "I know the economy ain't that bad. I know I can at least survive."
 
Some Find Reason for Optimism
 One of his classmates, Nia Foxx, is not convinced. "A lot of my friends are going to work in fast-food, but there's no way they can support a family or get anything they want in jobs like that," said Ms. Foxx, who is also 17. "These days, you have to have a college education to get anywhere in life."
To be sure, some students say there is reason for optimism. Miss Foxx plans to attend the University of California at Santa Cruz as a pre-law major, something she said she could not have done in another era because of discrimination. "I have a real chance as a female, a black female, to enter the law profession," she said. "This is not a chance previous generations had, and I can't see how I wouldn't take advantage of that."
Other students have turned to the armed forces, where they said they could learn a variety of skills easily transferable to private business. Wendy Martinez, 17, another graduate of Manual Arts High, decided to join the Army because she said it would assure her of a secure future.
And though the job market is tight, there are high-skilled jobs paying well that go begging for lack of qualified workers, including aerospace machinists and computer programers, said Nancy Hardy, the supervisor of the Salt Lake City Public Schools' department of guidance counselors and a former president of the American School Counselors Association.
 
'I'm Not Going to Worry'
 Maurice Palmer, 17, who graduated last week from Martin Luther King High School in Northwest Philadelphia, insisted in the face of evidence to the contrary that, while the job market is tight, "we have more opportunities than our parents." Mr. Palmer, who plans to pursue a career in banking, added, "I'm not going to worry."
But more often than not, pessimism and uncertainty are the prevailing moods of this generation of graduates, who believe that more education will not necessarily guarantee that they will match their parents' quality of life.
"This generation has a lot of problems," said Lindsey Williams, 18, who graduated last week from Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn and plans to attend St. John's University in Queens this fall. "All I can do is hope and have a little bit of faith in myself."
Tracy Whitsett, who graduated this year from Houston's Memorial High School, plans to major in nuclear engineering at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque. The dour job forecasts for this decade prompted her to decide on nuclear engineering over her first choice, astrophysics, because she thinks it will give her a better chance of finding work.
 
More Going for Degrees
 The increased competitiveness, combined with unpromising job market projections, has prompted many more students who ordinarily would not have pursued higher education to do so.
"I think it was easier before," said Hiram Duarte, a graduate of Miami High School whose father was a laborer until an injury disabled him and whose mother finished only the fifth grade in Cuba. "With a strong attitude and a strong fist you could do anything. Now you can't do anything without a college education."
Mr. Duarte, who already works part-time and is looking for a second summer job to raise money for his college education, plans to attend Florida State University in January. He plans to work toward a teacher's certificate so he can teach woodworking in high school. In time, he wants to own several cabinet-making shops.
"You would never make enough now to buy a house and a raise a family without a college education," he said. "That is making me go to school. I want to come home at the end of the day carrying a briefcase in my hand rather than with a broken back."
 
Extra Efforts by Immigrants
 Other students who found school particularly taxing, especially those who were recent immigrants, made extra efforts to succeed because of the tougher job climate. Maria Garcia, a 20-year-old graduate of Manual Arts High School in Los Angeles, is a case in point.
"It was hard for me to come from Mexico only four years ago -- to learn the language, to learn the customs," said Miss Garcia, who plans to major in business in college. "But if I can graduate from high school only four years after coming to this country, and enter a college, I know I can succeed after college."
Parents and grandparents who celebrated the commencements of their children and grandchildren said they could only hope that this generation would navigate the uncertainties facing them.
"It looks like things are going backward," said Shirley Williams, shaking her head over the tightening, and changing, job market. Her grandson, Carl Williams, graduated last week from Abraham Lincoln High School in Philadelphia, and agreed with his grandmother when she said, "It's going to get worse before it gets better."
