HEADLINE: Fewer Investors Find Haven in Gold

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Some of the world's most influential money managers have been recasting their views about gold's ancient role as a haven for wealth in times of uncertainty or crisis.
In commodities markets, coin shops, Swiss investment houses and in the minds of many disappointed investors, gold is no longer the hedge investment of choice, or lately even a very profitable one. 
 There are many reasons for gold's diminished role. For one thing, the world has changed: there is freer movement of capital, a greater number of alternative investments, a surge in gold production, a relaxation of East-West tensions and less threat of a worldwide financial crisis.
"Nothing persuades me that gold is a good investment," said Ted Arnold, a once-bullish metals specialist for Merrill Lynch & Company in London. "The performance over the years, no matter how long you have tracked it, has been pretty terrible except for some brief periods of time."
 
A New Role in Jewelry
 Long the ancient coin of the realm, gold was once the world's monetary standard, backing the value of currencies in the United States and elsewhere. The metal was an easily obtainable asset that was tradable anywhere. And it was portable.
Today, gold is used more in jewelry, which accounts for 71 percent of production, up from 45 percent 10 years ago. That makes gold behave more like a commodity whose prices fluctuate based on supply and demand.
The Persian Gulf crisis would have seemed the kind of international disruption that would have given gold's price a jolt. But when Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, gold rallied only briefly, from $373.25 an ounce to $413.80 on Aug. 21, the highest price of the gulf crisis.
Prices then fell quickly. Gold edged up to more than $400 an ounce twice more, including just before the allied bombing began on Jan. 17, but wound up at $359.45 -- lower than when the gulf crisis began -- by the time a ceasefire was announced on Feb. 28. Gold closed in New York on Friday at $365.90 an ounce.
"Gold is competing with so many other products we can go to in a crisis," said Ian C. MacDonald, manager of precious metals at Credit Suisse in New York.
This month, the Swiss Bank Corporation, a leading investment adviser to institutions and wealthy individuals, concluded in a report that "gold is no longer the only port in the storm." And in many cases, the bank is not investing client funds in gold.
Also, a recently published review of the world's gold market by Gold Fields Mineral Services Ltd. of London, which publishes a statistical bible on world gold markets, notes a "worrying" downturn in investment demand for gold last year in the Far East, where gold has long been popular even when prices are weak, as they are now.
Now, many investment managers who recommend gold suggest it only as a contrarian investment, which moves in the opposite direction of other assets, to diversify a portfolio.
 
A Laggard Since 1975
 In fact, an investment in gold has been pretty much a loser, racking up a tepid average annual compounded return of 4.7 percent since 1975, when Americans were first allowed to own gold, through the end of last year.
That record lags just about everything from stocks of small companies, which rose by an average of 19.9 percent a year in the period, to Treasury bills, which registered an 8.1 percent average annual gain. In fact, the only investment gold bested was silver, which fell by an average of three-tenths of 1 percent a year.
Last year, gold prices averaged $383.59 an ounce, after adjusting for inflation. It was the lowest average annual price in 13 years and less than half the $835 record price gold touched briefly in January 1980, when double-digit interest rates and inflation reigned.
More significant, last year investment buying of gold fell by more than 50 percent in the Western world, according to the Gold Fields report.
One investor who fell prey to gold's allure is Dr. Jeffrey A. Fisher, a New Jersey physician turned author. In 1989, with the price rising, Dr. Fisher bought $10,000 worth of gold for about $410 an ounce. "When I bought it, everyone was predicting it would go up to $1,000," Dr. Fisher said. "I thought I was making a safe investment."
Dr. Fisher bought gold when the price was rising, a mistake many American investors make. Except for a rally to $423 an ounce in February 1990, gold has settled around $360 to $370 an ounce and Dr. Fisher has lost about 12 percent on his investment. He is still holding on, however, hoping that another rally will give him an opening to sell.
Gold's fading glow is a result of the globalization of world markets, the advent of 24-hour trading and the simple fact that gold prices have been in decline for years thanks partly to a 75 percent rise in production in the 1980's.
 
More Options Today
 Also, with capital moving more freely, investors have far more options today for hedging against inflation and world crises. They can buy futures contracts and options that allow them to hedge against financial risk; they can move their money out of their countries, and with computers, they can respond more quickly to crises.
"In the old days, gold was always a third-rate hedge, but it was the only hedge in town," Mr. Arnold of Merrill Lynch said.
Buying gold as an investment has declined along with the end of the cold war and the reduction in East-West tensions. "Gold is pretty worthless unless a catastrophe happens and then that is the only wealth you have to keep," said Laurence B. Siegel, managing director of Ibbotson Associates in Chicago, an economic consulting firm. Mr. Siegel is an advocate of gold as an addition to a portfolio for this "insurance" protection.
Inflation, long another reason to buy gold, is also less of a threat now.
 
Another Rule Broken
 And during the gulf war, the dollar fell to record lows against the German mark and gold did not rise, breaking another rule of thumb: that gold should strengthen as confidence in the dollar weakens.
One of gold's other major problems is that it is much misunderstood by those who invest in it and, therefore, investors are frequently disappointed. Gold is more likely to be a winner when all other investments are losers.
"In the West, they seem to have this perception that gold is a quick-buck metal and a quick-buck investment, and I do not think that is what gold is all about," said James P. Hildebrandt, vice president for investment of the World Gold Council, an association of 82 gold-producing companies from 14 countries whose goal is to promote world demand.
In the United States, the fall in interest in gold is dramatically reflected in the sales of gold Eagle coins. First minted at the end of 1986, sales of these coins have plummeted by nearly 75 percent, to 457,450 ounces in 1990, from 1.8 million ounces in 1986. Despite a surge in January, when the bombing started in the Persian Gulf, 1991 sales of 171,500 ounces are lagging slightly behind the 1990 pace.
The production of other gold coins, including the Canadian Maple Leaf, has also fallen. Overall coin production and sales were down in 1990 by more than 10 percent. South Africa is planning to market its gold Krugerrands abroad again after the lifting of sanctions in Europe, but slack demand and more competitors will make it difficult for the Krugerrand to become the market leader again.
There are still those gold bulls who see another rally coming. They argue that current data show that the robust production of gold will begin to decline in the mid-1990's, giving prices a reason to advance.
Still, these analysts are not talking of another rush to $800 an ounce. "I don't think so," said Stewart Murray, chief executive of Gold Fields Mineral Services. "We are talking about a moderate increase," he said, and probably a brief one, too. He added that if prices reached $500 or $600 an ounce, production would pick up quickly again, capping the rally.
Gold bulls pin their forecasts on a major crisis that would restore investor faith in gold's durability when all else seemed worthless, something the Persian Gulf crisis apparently did not do. So gold's boosters are counting on something more dramatic, like disruptions in the world financial markets, including bank collapses, or a return to gold as a backer of major currencies. The United States abandoned the gold standard in 1971 as it moved to a free-floating foreign exchange rate.
But even the bulls are a little wary of talking about gold's future, seemingly numbed by the years of the metal's dull performance. Alan Posnick, senior vice president at the MTB Banking Corporation, a major New York-based dealer in gold coins, said: "$800 an ounce? I think you will see it again. But don't ask me when."

HEADLINE: Vacations, Yes, but Closer to Home This Summer

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The third week in June brings not only the summer solstice but also the start of the year's heaviest vacation season. In 10 hectic weeks through Labor Day, millions of Americans spend billions of dollars on air fares, gasoline, hotels and restaurants.
But this year, despite some of the most favorable airline and hotel discounts in years, people in the travel industry say the summer season is not likely to be anything to write home about. Even at this late date, some analysts say they still do not know whether the peak travel season will be disastrous or just disappointing. 
 Representatives of the lodging industry have made public statistics for only the first four months of this year. But Mark Lomanno, the research manager for Smith Travel Research, which follows the $61 billion lodging industry, said, "I'd be real surprised if there's a tremendous turnabout."
Still battered by the effects of a weak economy, many vacationers will be pinching pennies and cutting corners as perhaps never before -- or not since the 1960's and early 70's, at any rate, when traveling on a shoestring was a rite of passage for many.
"People our age for years have sort of done what we wanted to do," said Molly Peterson, a 42-year-old resident of Atlanta, who is staying home this year, along with her husband and three children. "We just figured it would get better and better. But now we are finding that is not the case. When I think about what we used to do -- taking trips every summer, going skiing every March, camp for the children, private schools, a lake house -- we must have been insane, in a dream world. We are no longer in the dream world."
Many Americans will scale back on vacations this year. "Trips will be of shorter duration, people will be traveling mostly by car and they'll be staying closer to home, often with friends and relatives," said Scott Dring, a spokesman for the United States Travel Data Center, a not-for-profit research organiztion in Washington that is financed by the travel industry.
That pattern could well describe Julia Reynolds, a Houston accountant; her husband, Billy, who works as an operator at a chemical plant, and their 2-year-old son. Their summer vacation will consist of driving to Mrs. Reynolds's mother's home in Monroe, La., for four days. As for more ambitious vacation plans, "we decided we can't afford it this year," she said.
 
War and Recession's Effect
 Stephen G. Beuret, a Philadelphia engineer, recently returned from a week of visiting friends in Portland, Ore. "I went because I had somebody there I could stay with," he said. "If I had had to stay in a hotel, I probably would not have gone."
No wonder the most optimistic assessment the American Hotel and Motel Association can manage is that bookings might be up slightly over last year.
"The lodging industry took a double hit early this year, with war and recession," said Michele Kelly, the association's director of communications, "and we need to fill rooms."
Industry officials said many people decided to stay home during the Persian Gulf war because of their interest in following the war on television, the increase in gasoline prices and a general uncertainty over the war's effect.
The promotions and discounts, up to 60 percent in some hotel chains, are likely to help the vacation industry. But Mr. Lamanno said the overall outlook was not promising. The industry already took in $500 million less than expected in the first quarter of this year.
 
Outlook on Air Travel
 No turnabout appears likely soon for some other travel-related industries. Domestic air passenger traffic fell 3.8 percent in the first four months of this year, the latest period for which industry statistics have been made public, compared to the same period in 1990.
And "advance bookings for domestic travel this summer haven't looked too good," said William E. Jackman, a vice president of the Air Transport Association, an industry trade group in Washington. The industry, which had passenger revenues of $58.4 billion last year, had been hoping for a strong summer to help it recover from last year's $4 billion loss, the worst in airline history.
The Travel Data Center predicts that vacation travel by automobile will increase to 84 percent of all 1991 vacation travel in June, July and August, up from 82 percent last summer. It also predicts that air travel will fall to 13 percent this year, from 14 percent in 1990 and 15 percent in 1989 and 1988.
 
Spending Less On Travel
 The data center is projecting 326 million vacation person-trips this summer, about the same as last year. (It defines a person-trip as one person traveling at least 100 miles from home.) But there is less to those figures than meets the eye.
'Most travelers are going to spend about the same or slightly less than last year," said Ida Simmons, director of communications for D. K. Shifflet & Associates, a travel research firm. Taking into account inflation, this means the industry is likely to lose substantial ground, in constant dollars.
While deep discounts and aggressive promotions are pumping life back into the international air travel market, from which the bottom all but dropped out during the gulf war, the Americans who travel to Europe this summer are not likely to be the free spenders of yore.
"It looks like a strong summer, as far as numbers are concerned," said Michel Bouquier, chairman of the European Travel Commission, which represents in this country the national tourist offices of 24 European countries. "But Americans are not staying as long as they used to and not spending as much as they used to."
 
Looking at Special Deals
 They are also setting records for the short interval between the time they inquire about traveling to Europe and their date of departure. "That probably suggests that the special deals and advertising are having an effect, and people feel they have to catch that opportunity," Mr. Bouquier said.
But tightened budgets do not allow some people to cash in on such opportuities. "I wish I could tell you I was going to Hawaii," said Julie Aitken, a public affairs specialist with the Army Corps of Engineers in New Orleans. "Even though I could take a week off, I wouldn't have any money to go anywhere."
 
Patriotic Symbols Suffer
 In the aftermath of the war, many people predicted record numbers of visitors at attractions like the Liberty Bell, Valley Forge in Pennsylvania and similar patriotic symbols. But while official figures from the National Park Service are available only through April, and show mixed results, it is beginning to look as if the turnouts at such sites will fall short of expecations.
John D. Hunt, the head of the recreation and tourism department at the University of Idaho, said the slowdown in travel this summer recalled the early 1980's, when recession also battered the economy.
"The big difference," Professor Hunt said, "is that now the financial difficulties of the airlines and hotel chains are likely to force even more mergers than have occurred because of deregulation of the airlines and overbuilding of hotels in the 1980's, especially in urban areas." If that happens, he added, air fares and room rates will almost certainly rise.
Some of the vacation patterns that are especially noticeable this year have been under way for several years. July, for example, has gradually overtaken August as the most popular month for vacations.
Amtrak has enjoyed strong summer seasons for four or five years, said R. Clifford Black 4th, the manager of public affairs; its trains are heavily booked again this year. And since 1988, the growth rate of travel by automobile has exceeded the growth rate of travel by plane.
 
More 3-Day Trips
 Even the trend toward shorter vacations has been evident for a few years, although that change is said to be less a matter of economics than of the increase in households with two incomes, because it is harder to schedule simultaneous vacations.
But not all areas of the country are expected to lose out this summer. "The southeastern part of the country is seeing a pretty good summer," said Mr. Dring of the Travel Data Center. But he said the Northeast is still feeling the effects of the economic downturn.
Brokers in the Hamptons, Cape Cod, the Catskills and the New Jersey Shore said this spring that demand for summer houses was off, prices were down as much as 20 percent and more second homes were being offered for rent.
"But the big thing now," Mr. Dring said, "is that trips of one to three nights will account for about 51 percent of all vacation trips this year, higher than the 48 percent last year and higher than it ever has been."
That statistic is especially meaningful this summer, when the Fourth of July falls on a Thursday. "I wonder if people will also take off the previous Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, and count it as one of their vacations," said Ms. Simmons of D. K. Shifflet. If so, it will hurt the travel industry, she said, "because as people take shorter trips everybody's going to lose the travel dollar."
But while the travel industry can expect instability over the next few years, Professor Hunt said, the long-term outlook is favorable for the industry and travelers alike.
"A lot of my colleagues talk about the business side of travel," he said. "But people don't travel because travel businesses exist. They travel for pleasure and knowledge and relaxation and all kinds of other reasons, and nothing in the foreseeable future seems likely to change that."

HEADLINE: Health Chief Warns A.M.A. on Cost of Medicine

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 23

 BODY:
The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Louis W. Sullivan, appealed to the nation's largest organization of doctors today to curb soaring medical costs and improve availability of care or risk a virtual popular revolt.
"Unless we act now to meet these goals, we could find ourselves with a critical mass of our citizens demanding a total government takeover of health care," Dr. Sullivan told hundreds of doctors at the opening of the American Medical Association's annual meeting. 
 "I doubt that many in this room today would welcome that development," he said.
The Secretary has been an ally of the doctors' group on issues like trying to keep tobacco out of the hands of minors but, unlike the organization, supports a proposed restructuring of Medicare fees that would reduce payments to doctors for many procedures.
 
Health Care 12% of G.N.P.
 Dr. Sullivan said health care accounted for about 12 percent of the gross national product in 1990 -- or about $2,500 for every citizen.
"As physicians, we must recognize that health care is not the only public good," he said. "As Americans, as well as physicians, we must be concerned that consuming ever larger portions of G.N.P. on health care necessarily diverts resources from other good uses -- for example, increased wages, savings, capital investment, research and development and human services such as drug rehabilitation, foster care and family support."
Dr. Sullivan made only a passing reference to the AIDS epidemic, which is expected to be the dominant topic at the gathering, when he issued a call for increased emphasis on people's accepting responsibility for their own health.
Included, he said, would be improved diet, childhood vaccinations, early prenatal care, elimination of illegal drugs and tobacco and curtailment of sexual practices that can spread AIDS.
 
AIDS and Health-Care Workers
 Among AIDS-related issues expected to be considered by the 300,000-member association's policy-making house of delegates is the question of restricting health-care workers who are infected with the AIDS virus.
The delegates are also expected to discuss whether doctors should undergo regular AIDS testing.
The outgoing president of the association, John C. Tupper, said AIDS "certainly will be the overriding public health issue" considered by the 438 delegates at the five-day gathering.
Tobacco will be another major topic, said a spokeswoman for the association, Pat Clark. One resolution urges the association to encourage major league baseball teams to ban smoking in their stadiums, and commends the Oakland Athletics for doing so.
 
Award for Captain Kangaroo
 Delegates will also review genetic testing, which Dr. Tupper said had the potential for misuse as the technology develops. He said insurance companies could use the testing to screen out prospective policyholders who carry genes for certain diseases.
Also today, the association gave its layman's distinguished service award to Bob Keeshan, who plays Captain Kangaroo on television and who has been an advocate for children.
"In this lovely land, we have made children our principal underclass," said Mr. Keeshan, 63 years old. He urged doctors to take the lead in fighting hunger, malnutrition, measles, whooping cough and polio, which are increasing among some groups of American youngsters.
"Kids can't vote in this country," Mr. Keeshan continued. "Kuwaitis can't vote either. But that did not stop us from coming to the aid of the Kuwaitis in their hour of great peril. If we can help the Kuwaitis, we ought to be able to help our kids."

HEADLINE: 1964 Chain-Gang Escape Follows Man North to L.I.

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRENTWOOD, L.I., June 21

 BODY:
James Harris was 17 years old and a high school truant when he ran into trouble with the law in Alabama in 1962. Beaten, he says, into confessing to a burglary, he was sentenced to 21 years in prison and sent to a chain gang to dig ditches and lay asphalt on Alabama's muddy back roads.
In 1964, with $20 and a pair of shoes from his fellow prisoners, Mr. Harris escaped to Long Island and began to make a life for himself. It has hardly been free of trouble -- there was a robbery in 1974 and a $25 drug bust a year ago -- but along the way, he married twice, had three children, and worked as a welder in his uncle's company. 
 Now, after 27 years, Alabama wants him back -- again.
What makes this case extraordinary, besides the length of time that has elapsed, is that 21 years ago Alabama tried, and failed, to extradite Mr. Harris from New York.
At that time, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, expressing concern about the fairness of the sentence and saying that justice would not be served by sending Mr. Harris back, refused to sign the extradition papers.
Last summer, the Commissioner of Alabama's Department of Corrections, Morris L. Thigpen, signed an order that Mr. Harris be returned to finish his sentence. And, following custom, New York's Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, signed a fugitive warrant, clearing the way for Mr. Harris's return. A judge has temporarily stayed that order, pending a hearing in the case, so Mr. Harris remains here, at least for now.
No one, not even the officials in Alabama seeking his return, argues that Mr. Harris is a hardened criminal. He is described by his lawyer and by his family here, where he lives with his mother, as someone who fell into bad times but never had a bad man's heart. To John Ray, Mr. Harris's lawyer, his client is a modern-day Jean Valjean, the hapless hero who was pursued for years for stealing a loaf of bread in Victor Hugo's "Les Miserables."
 
Too Harsh a Sentence, Lawyer Says
 "There's no way he should have to spend another 20 years of his life in jail for something he did when he was 17," said Mr. Ray. The lawyer argues that Mr. Harris, who is black, was given too harsh a sentence at a time when the South's system of justice was notoriously racist.
His uncle, Cleve Jones, who employed Mr. Harris in his home-improvement business when the economy was better, said: "He's not a mean-spirited guy, you know, trying to hurt people or anything like that. He got into some trouble, just hanging out, I guess. But he's a nice guy."
State Supreme Court Justice Kenneth J. Rohl, who is to hear Mr. Ray's case against Mr. Harris's extradition on July 1, said in an interview that he felt there was a strong case against sending Mr. Harris back to Alabama. By coincidence, Justice Rohl represented Mr. Harris's co-defendant in the 1974 robbery case and so remembered the earlier extradition debate.
He said that Mr. Harris's record in New York had no bearing on whether he should have to finish out a harsh, decades-old sentence in Alabama. "He's paid the price here," Justice Rohl said. "If he's screwed up and been convicted and sentenced, that's an entirely different matter than what he did in Alabama."
Mr. Harris, a soft-spoken man, said he was sure the extradition matter was put to rest years ago. Pulling yellowed-newspaper clippings out of a frayed folder, Mr. Harris said he could not fathom why Alabama would suddenly want him back.
"Since 1964, they have known where I was -- I wasn't hiding from them," he said. "I thought this case was over. Why do they keep bringing it up again?"
Mr. Harris does not pretend he has been a model citizen. "Sure, I made mistakes," he said. "But I paid for them."
Mr. Harris's recent troubles began a year ago, when he was arrested in Suffolk County and charged with helping a drug dealer sell $25 worth of cocaine to undercover police officers. At his bail hearing, by chance in front of Justice Rohl, the assistant district attorney said that a computer check of Mr. Harris's record showed that he was a fugitive in Alabama.
"That was dealt with and completely taken care of," said Justice Rohl, according to a transcript of the hearing. "Those in power who had authority over that matter never pursued it."
Mr. Harris pleaded guilty and went to Attica to begin serving his one-to-three-year sentence.
Meanwhile, New York notified Alabama that Mr. Harris had resurfaced, and Alabama issued a fugitive warrant. "We're required to continue as long as there's any possibility of getting a person back to serve whatever time is owed this state on a sentence," said John Hale, a spokesman for Alabama's Corrections Department.
 
'Governor's Obligation'
 Then, Governor Cuomo signed an order directing New York State officials to turn Mr. Harris over to Alabama after his prison term was over. Thomas Conroy, a spokesman for the Governor, said Mr. Cuomo had little choice. "It is the Governor's obligation to obey the law, and the law is that the Governor must honor the request for extradition," he said.
Legal experts say that is rare for one governor not to honor another's extradition request, but that it can be done. "In cases involving unfair sentences and unfair prosecution from a long time ago, governors can use their discretion in favor of mercy," said Leon Friedman, a professor of criminal procedure at Hofstra University Law School. "If Rockefeller applied it at one time and gave him mercy, why can't Cuomo apply it now?"
Neither state seems to think that what happened in 1970 has much resonance today, and both states said they have destroyed all records of the extradition request and denial.
Justice Rohl has stayed Governor Cuomo's order until the case can be heard. Mr. Ray said he plans to argue that the extradition question was decided long ago. "The state of New York exonerated him; the court at the time exonerated him, so he's not a fugitive," he said. "And once Alabama knew he was in New York and did nothing to arrest him, he was no longer a fugitive."
Until the case is heard, Mr. Harris remains in limbo. Recently released from his drug sentence, he is back in Brentwood, wondering what will become of him.
"After 27 years, I know those people in Alabama don't want to just talk to me," he said. "I went through this 20 years ago, and now I have to go through it again. I don't know too much about the law, but I don't know how they could do this to a person."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alabama now wants James Harris, above, extradited for a crime committed 27 years ago. Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller refused a similar request 21 years ago. (Mike Groll for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: RICH NATIONS BACK JUNIOR SOVIET ROLE IN MONETARY FUND

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 23

 BODY:
The seven leading industrial democracies agreed in principle here today that the Soviet Union should be offered a limited role in the International Monetary Fund, the American Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, said.
He said the offer would probably be made when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev meets with leaders of the seven nations here next month. 
 By acquiring what is being called associate membership in the fund -- and presumably in the fund's sister organization, the World Bank -- the Soviet Union would gain technical assistance toward economic reform but no immediate I.M.F. bailout to revive its moribund economy.
 
Milestone for Soviets
 Still, the move would represent a milestone in Moscow's efforts to join the world financial system. The idea was first proposed by President Bush in December.
Mr. Brady and finance ministers from the other six countries who met here today along with central bankers indicated that they remained divided on the issue of whether Mr. Gorbachev should be offered large-scale financial aid at the end of the July summit meeting.
Of the seven nations, the United States, Japan and Britain are the most opposed to promising the Soviet Union a large amount of financial aid until it is clear that Moscow is firmly on the road to a free-market democracy.
Germany has been much more sympathetic to the idea of promising large amounts of aid. And France today indicated that it was not taking a rigid position. The other countries represented were Italy and Canada.
 
What the I.M.F. Does
 The I.M.F.'s role is to help countries draw up and implement large-scale plans aimed at reforming their economies, often providing them with financial assistance along the way to help them cope with the painful process. For example, the fund could be involved in helping the Soviet Union devise plans to make the ruble convertible into Western currencies as well as strategies to lift price controls, slash subsidies and rein in its rapidly growing money supply.
The World Bank is typically involved in more narrowly focused programs to help countries develop their infrastructure and private sectors. It could be involved in helping Moscow turn the state-owned Soviet oil industry into an investor-owned entity, for example, or in setting up a modern banking and financial system.
Roughly 150 nations belong to the monetary fund and contribute to it under a formula based on their economic power. The United States provides about a fifth of the financing for the monetary fund and the World Bank. Membership in the I.M.F is required for participation in the World Bank.
 
British Appear Guarded
 At a news conference, Mr. Brady said the participants in today's meeting had reached "a general agreement that the idea of associate status" for the Soviet Union in the I.M.F. "was a good one."
Norman Lamont, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, was more guarded when asked about whether the Soviets would be offered associate membership when Mr. Gorbachev meets with leaders of the seven countries on July 17, after their economic summit meeting. He indicated that the Europeans supported the idea, which suggested that perhaps the Japanese had the most reservations.
Analysts said that while associate membership would give Moscow only a limited role, it could serve as an important catalyst for investment and financial aid from other nations. This is because the monetary fund and the World Bank could inspire confidence in the Soviet economy by giving their approval to economic reform programs and individual investment projects.
 
Soviets Declined in 1944
 The I.M.F. and the World Bank were established at a conference at Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, in 1944 as part of the effort to insure stability after World War II. But the Soviet Union declined repeated invitations by Western nations, including the United States, to join the organizations. At the time, Moscow was believed to have a stable currency and did not want to submit to regulations that would require it to disclose the amount of its gold reserves and other economic data.
At his news conference, Mr. Brady said he detected no resistance to the associate membership idea, but he added that no vote had been taken on whether the offer would definitely be made.
Mr. Brady also noted that the countries had still not defined the rights of associate membership. "I assume more work will be done between now and the summit to flesh out exactly what that means," he said.
President Bush suggested the notion of associate membership for the Soviets in December, but the proposal was presumably put on ice following Moscow's crackdown in the independence-minded Baltic republics.
Moscow has been interested in applying for full I.M.F. membership for about two years, analysts said. But gaining full membership is a complicated process and would take six months and possibly much longer, analysts said. The associate membership would be a way for the Soviets to get I.M.F. advice immediately.
David S. Roche, a London-based economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said some Western governments might be hestitant about offering the associate membership at a time when Mr. Gorbachev's commitment to economic reform remains unclear.
Last week, Mr. Gorbachev said he thought he could combine a bold plan drawn up by a group of Harvard economists and Grigory A. Yavlinksy, a Soviet economist, that would transform the Soviet economy over five years with the help of $100 billion in Western aid and a plan by Soviet Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov, which calls for the country's command economy to evolve gradually towards a free market.
"He says he can meld the two approaches and he can't," Mr. Roche said. Noting that associate I.M.F. membership is tantamount to the Soviets agreeing to use an I.M.F.-approved plan to reform their economy, Mr. Roche said the I.M.F. affiliation would not make sense if Mr. Gorbachev backed that kind of compromise plan.
 
U.S. Position Unchanged
 Some analysts noted that the Japanese might be reluctant to offer Moscow greater aid or a greater role in the Western financial system in light of the lack of progress in their efforts to get the Soviets to relinquish islands in the northern part of the Japanese archipelago that the Soviet Union seized at the end of World War II. The Japanese are also among those most skeptical of Moscow's pledges of economic reform.
The United States recently agreed to provide the Soviets with $1.5 billion in credits to buy American farm goods, which some analysts interpreted as a softening of the Bush Administration's opposition to promising large-scale upfront aid to the Soviets at the July meeting. But Mr. Brady stressed today that the Administration's position had not changed and maintained that there was general agreement on this at today's gathering. "Large sums of money are not what we're talking about here," he said.
At their news conferences, however, German and French officials were unwilling to take such a hardline position. Theo Waigel, the German Finance Minister, said he could not anticipate what would happen at the July summit and that a lot depended on what Mr. Gorbachev told the leaders about his plans for political and economic reform.
 
The Trouble With the Dollar
 The other major subject of today's meeting of finance ministers and central bankers was what to do about the surging dollar. The officials indicated that they could live with the dollar at its current level. But they pledged to intervene in the financial markets by buying or selling currencies if the dollar continued to soar too rapidly, upsetting the world economy.
Another thing that the officials could not agree on today was a coordinated interest policy. As a result, economists doubted that central-bank intervention in the markets alone would be able to contain the dollar's rise for more than a couple months.
Since early February, the dollar's value has climbed about 14 percent against a trade-weighted basket of currencies, nearly 25 percent against the German mark and nearly 9 percent against the Japanese yen.
 
No Soviet Response
MOSCOW, June 23 (Special to The New York Times) -- While there was no official comment on the I.M.F. decision here today, President Gorbachev would probably prefer full membership in the organization, and will probably greet associate membership as a step toward full membership.
His greater immediate problem is that the search for Western aid has become a political issue with the right-wing, which has always viewed the I.M.F. as a capitalist tool for world domination. In the pre-Gorbachev days, in fact, the I.M.F. and World Bank were among the leading targets of Soviet propaganda.
The "associate membership" might give the conservatives a weapon both to revive the old foe and to claim that Mr. Gorbachev cannot even get proper aid out of the I.M.F.
The conservatives, who have been feeling themselves on the defensive again, lashed out at Mr. Gorbachev in Parliament last week, ranging behind a short-lived proposal by Mr. Pavlov to acquire greater powers. During the debate, some conservatives seized on the Western aid as a weapon against Mr. Gorbachev, accusing him of letting the West call the shots in Moscow and of preparing to go to London with a begging bowl.
The leaked transcript of a closed-session speech by K.G.B. Chief Vladimir A. Kryuchkov last week revived old charges of a C.I.A. plot to subvert the Soviet economy. Mr. Kryuchkov did not link this to the Yavlinsky-Harvard plan to push the Soviet Union toward a market economy by providing billions of dollars of aid, but in the context he seemed intent on smearing any aid from the West.
The pressure from the right has led Mr. Gorbachev to soft-pedal the Yavlinsky-Harvard plan, saying he will merge it with the Government's "anti-crisis program" and other economic plans.
At the same time, Mr. Gorbachev and liberal advisers like Mr. Yavlinsky are likely to portray the I.M.F. associate membership as evidence that their initiative is bearing fruit, even if they privately feel disappointed.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Industry Coalition Opposes Ad Tax Plan

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
A group of advertising and media trade associations has announced its opposition to a proposal to assess a quarter of 1 percent Federal tax on ad revenues.
The group, the Advertising Tax Coalition, sent a letter Friday to members of Congress, arguing that the tax "could seriously disrupt the economy" and would be a serious blow to newspapers, magazines and broadcasters already suffering in the recession. 
 At a hearing earlier this month of a House of Representatives committee, the tax was suggested as a possible source of public funds for campaign expenses of candidates for Federal offices.
The letter was signed by 10 coalition members, including John E. O'Toole, president and chief executive of the American Association of Advertising Agencies; Cathleen Black, president and chief executive of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, and Edward O. Fritts, president and chief executive of the National Association of Broadcasters.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Margaret Thatcher's Britain

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
In the last week Margaret Thatcher has been feted in the United States. She spoke to weighty audiences in New York and Chicago, and she met President Bush. Americans, it seems, still regard her with a respect bordering on awe.
How different it is in her own country -- and her own Conservative Party. There is still a small group of loyal Thatcherites. But apart from them, the general opinion is that Mrs. Thatcher is an arrogant pest, a political has-been who ought to stop making life difficult for her successor, John Major. 
 Irritation with the former Prime Minister was brought to a boil by her American speeches. Just when Mr. Major was trying to avoid controversy about Britain's place in the European Community, Mrs. Thatcher denounced plans for a European monetary union. She even attacked the decision to bring the pound into the European exchange-rate system, which her own Government made before she was forced out last November.
Polls taken after her speeches found that a majority of the public, and of Conservative back benchers in the House of Commons, thought she should give up her seat in the House at the next general election, which will probably come a year from now.
Those feelings must seem surprising, given Mrs. Thatcher's domination of British politics for so long. She was Prime Minister for 11 years, and the Thatcher Revolution was the talk of conservatives on both sides of the Atlantic.
One reason for the disaffection is that her policies -- the boosting of free-market economics and the downgrading of public service -- had not brought results as happy as advertised.
Her one undoubted achievement was the curbing of the trade unions. That looks permanent. Hardly anyone, least of all the opposition Labor Party, wants to go back to the situation of a few union leaders having the power to bring the economy to its knees.
But the great promise of Thatcherism was that Britain would become a more thrusting, economically enterprising country when freed of government ownership and controls. That has not happened.
The country is in a severe recession now. Manufacturing output has fallen 6.5 percent in the last year. There is nearly 8 percent unemployment, a high figure for Britain.
A particular promise of Thatcher economics was that hard times, if they came, would produce leaner, more efficient industry. But in the most recent three-month period productivity declined by 2.4 percent, and unit labor costs in industry rose by more than 11 percent.
Public resentment of hard times is made more acute by the fact that a handful of the rich are growing richer. A special provocation has been huge pay increases for the chief executives of utilities that the Thatcher Government sold off to private ownership.
The chairman of British Telecom, for example, got a 43 percent increase, to the equivalent of $865,000 a year. The chairman of British Gas went up 66 percent, to $600,000.
There is also deep unhappiness about what happened during the Thatcher years to the National Health Service. It remains a high-quality, universal medical system, but it is under severe strain. There are long waits -- as long as a year for elective surgery such as hip replacements.
The reason is mainly lack of money. Sir Raymond Hoffenberg, immediate past president of the Royal College of Physicians, said: "By international standards, in recent years the Health Service has been grossly underfunded."
But more than economics is involved in the public disaffection with Mrs. Thatcher. Her bossy manner became more and more grating in her later years in office. She took to using the royal we in speech, and she acted as if disagreement with her was lese-majeste. Many Britons felt relief when she quit, and they do not want her back in their lives.
The mood was indicated in a Persian Gulf war military parade last week. The news story in The Times of London, which used to be zealously pro-Thatcher, began:
"When British troops last paraded in victory through the City of London, after the Falklands conflict, Mrs. Thatcher took the salute. Yesterday the real Queen was in her rightful place . . ."

HEADLINE: Essay;
To Protect the Kurds

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In diplomatic secrecy, the Bush Administration is negotiating a deal with its coalition allies to pull the last protective troops out of Iraqi Kurdistan.
Our policy is driven by the politics of extrication: how to get out of Iraq quietly, replacing a force of coalition troops with more than a company of U.N. eunuchs. The plan is to prevent Iraq's underdefeated dictator from merely waiting a decent interval before he breaks his promises of peaceful autonomy and resumes his genocide against the Kurdish people. 
 Here is the preliminary deal being discussed:
First, we await the outcome of talks that took place in Baghdad between Kurdish leaders and Saddam Hussein. The dictator has promised autonomy in Kurdistan, elections throughout the country, the separation of the Baath Party from the Government -- all items he can easily rescind later. He has held back the inclusion of the oil city of Kirkuk in Kurdistan because that might interfere with cash coming in soon.
Next, we await the talks among the Kurds. All Kurds may be victims, but not all Kurds are angels; to a hostile or indifferent world they present a united front, but in the back are as faction-ridden as any nation.
Massoud Barzani, son of Mulla Mustafa, is the authentic leader who has long fought his people's battle in the hills. He must deal with Jalal Talabani, a smooth talker who has spent most of his time outside Kurdistan; and with independent-minded guerrilla leaders on the scene; as well as with longtime Kurdish collaborators with Saddam who swung over to the Kurds' cause when he seemed about to fall, and who precipitated the high-casualty war in the cities.
As the enterprising Patrick Tyler of The New York Times reports from Kurdistan, Mr. Barzani is now selling the imperfect agreement made in Baghdad -- which includes his promise to help Saddam get sanctions eased -- to his colleagues. Arab members of the anti-Saddam coalition tell me he has a shrewd strategy: obtain from Saddam whatever democracy and autonomy he is now ready to falsely offer, and then get the rest of the world to guarantee that those phony promises are kept.
When the Kurds agree with Mr. Barzani to make that gamble, the Americans and other coalition members would take that as a signal to withdraw.
To show that the extrication is not abandonment, a division or two of allied ground troops, including Americans, would remain nearby in Turkey; the U.N. relief observers inside Iraqi Kurdistan would be increased to 500; more significant militarily, coalition air and naval forces would be based in Egypt, the gulf emirates, Saudi Arabia, as well as Turkey. (Syria won't play; Israel won't be asked.)
One purpose of this international force, to be announced later this summer, would be to make certain that no genocidal attacks are launched against Kurds or Shiites.
With this military assurance, on top of a threatened calibration of economic sanctions, the coalition would tiptoe out of the line of fire between a recovering Saddam Hussein and Kurds who always resist subjugation.
Sound good? Sure. Would it work? Only if an unmistakable message accompanied the pullout: that allied air power would enforce the reforms extracted by the Kurds from Baghdad.
Many Kurds suspect their nemesis plans to exploit a withdrawal with a type of warfare he has conducted before: kidnapping or assassinating Kurdish leaders, as he did the brothers of Massoud Barzani. If withdrawal is inexorable, here's how to help prevent that: President Bush should invite Mr. Barzani to visit him in the White House, thereby providing the personal protection and support that Ronald Reagan gave Angola's Jonas Savimbi.
He should assure the Kurdish patriot that the coalition will make Iraqi Kurdistan a gunship-free zone; that relief will be channeled through Turkey to the autonomous Kurdish subgovernment in the regional capital; and that the U.S. will welcome 5,000 Kurdish refugees a year to underscore our concern.
This month, after two decades, Henry Kissinger manfully asserted that the great error America made toward the Kurds in the 70's was in not telling them at the start of their uprising how far we were prepared to back them up. We made that tragic mistake, so costly in lives, again this year. Twice is enough.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Investment in Australia

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, June 24

 BODY:
Australia was the third-largest recipient of Japanese investment, after the United States and Britain, in the last year, with Australia's auto industry attracting most of the cash, according to figures released last week. The Australia-Japan Economic Institute said Japanese investors put $3.67 billion into Australia, a 14 percent drop from $4.26 billion in the previous year, when investment was unusually high because of a boom in real estate and financial services.

HEADLINE: Exporters Fight Costs and Rules of Brazil's Ports

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTOS, Brazil

 BODY:
The number of containers handled here, at Latin America's largest port, tripled in the 1980's as the volume of loose cargo declined. But the port's operations still seem like a parody of modernization. Union work rules and Government regulations require each stevedore gang moving a steel container to include someone schooled in the ancient art of sewing torn coffee sacks.
A forest of archaic regulations, labor cartels and state control has grown so thick around Brazilian ports that the nation's manufacturers think the growth in the 1990's of Latin America's largest economy depends on a more efficient port. 
 "We are afraid that if the port obstacles continue, our exporters will not be able to compete with the Asian 'tigers,' " said Elmar Jose Braun, president of the local association of shipping agents, referring to the fast-growing economies of eastern Asia.
 
Billions May Be Lost
 Over all, Brazil stands to lose $5 billion in potential exports this year because of high port charges, estimated Marcus Vinicius Pratini de Moraes, president of the Association of Brazilian Exporters.
The bag repairer is part of a larger system that renders Brazilian ports among the slowest and most expensive in the world. To load a container on a ship here requires a labor crew of 31 and costs $525. To unload the same container in Rotterdam, one of the world's most automated ports, requires a crew of 10 and costs $130.
The Dutch workers move an average of 28 containers an hour, twice as many as here -- an important consideration when it can cost $25,000 a day to run an oceangoing cargo ship. And unlike American and European ports, most Brazilian ports do not work through the night.
"Many Latin American and Caribbean ports function as if they were still in the first half of this century and seem indifferent to the global economy where they have to compete," the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean said in March in a 150-page study of the region's ports.
The rates for handling one ton of steel in 1988, the report said, were $22 in Santos, compared with $5.60 in Jacksonville, Fla.; $3.80 in Rotterdam, and $3.18 in Kaohiung, Taiwan.
 
'I Feel Robbed'
 "As a steel producer, I feel robbed by the Brazilian port system," Jorge Gerdau Johanpeter, vice president of the Association of Private Steel Mills, recently said in testimony before Brazilian lawmakers. Mr. Gerdau estimated that this year Brazil will forgo $600 million in potential overseas steel sales because of uncompetitive port charges.
In another sign of the labor unrest that plagues Brazil's exporters, workers closed the five ports of Rio de Janeiro state for a two-week strike that ended on Thursday. By the end of the strike, a state steel company was losing $2.5 million a day because of delayed exports or lost orders.
"The Brazilians are just choking off what could be an avenue to free trade," an American broker of shipping space said in an interview.
The business community's congressional testimony favored a Government-sponsored bill that would privatize many port functions and break up union monopolies. But as with efforts by President Fernando Collor de Mello to reform the economy, business people fear that special interests will gut the port bill. Already, it carries 119 amendments.
Luiz Augusto Vieira Braga, the powerful first secretary of the Santos Stevedores Union, said his workers were, in fact, poorly paid.
"Our longshoremen brothers from around the world tell us it is always the same song: 'Rotterdam is more efficient. Rotterdam is more efficient,' " Mr. Braga said at his headquarters. He paused to take calls from an aide to Sao Paulo state's governor and from a powerful state senator.
"Operating costs in Santos are among the lowest in the world," he continued. "Our men earn $300 a month loading containers that American stevedores unload for $5,000 a month."
Business critics say the ports' high costs stem not from wage levels but from a constellation of other problems -- state mismanagement, a lack of investment for improvements, and regulations that penalize private terminal operators and require overstaffing.
In Santos, with 189 cranes and seven miles of docks capable of handling 65 oceangoing ships at a time, the state port authority saw 95 percent of revenues go to cover personnel costs in 1989.
This proportion has since dropped to 70 percent, but the port is still grossly overstaffed. With about 20,000 workers, the port one day in late May was serving only nine ships.
"In Rotterdam, 2,000 people handle 290 million tons a year," said Mr. Braun of the shipping agents' association. "Rotterdam moves 10 times the cargo with 10 times less people."
Although the payroll is being trimmed through attrition, layoff attempts in October and February set off two general strikes, lasting three weeks each. The strikes intensified the exodus of traffic to Brazil's second- and third-largest container ports, Rio de Janeiro and Paranagua.
Private shipping terminals have had more success than state-owned terminals in reducing labor costs. About 80 percent of the 30 million tons of cargo handled annually by Santos moves through private terminals.
But under Brazilian law, a company that owns a private terminal can handle only its own cargo. Other shippers have to use state terminals, and Brazil, virtually bankrupt, has no money for improvements.
"We want to allow more construction of private terminals and to allow private terminals to handle all cargo," said Renato Voltaire Araujo, a member of Integrated Business Action, an association of port users that supports the deregulation bill.
To influence legislators in Brasilia, the association this month published a bound volume of 70 editorials from O Globo, Rio's largest and most influential newspaper. Published over the last two years, all of the editorials bemoan the backward state of the ports.
 
Freedom to Choose Workers
 Shippers also want to win the freedom to choose workers and determine the size of work gangs. Under labor legislation dating to 1934, shipping agents are assigned port workers from a pool. With 12 unions enforcing strict labor categories, work gangs are unecessarily large, shippers say.
"We have absolutely no control over who works for us," said David G. Lorimer, president of the National Center for Transatlantic Navigation, an industry group. "There is no responsibility if a stevedore makes a mistake and swings a container into the side of a ship, or if he drops it," said Mr. Lorimer, who manages a shipping agency here. Sometimes to insure that a crane is operated properly, a shipper will pay a union-supplied worker to stand by idly while a professional from the company performs the job.
In a labor aristocracy, workers carrying union cards routinely sell their assignments to nonunion workers. As a result, the same man often is listed as working on three vessels at the same time.
Mr. Braga says the stevedores in his union are all highly skilled. "If there is damage, it is because of bad equipment," he said. "During all these years, there has never been a ship sunk by Santos stevedores."

HEADLINE: CHINA SAID TO CURB FOREIGN RESEARCH

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
China appears to be moving to cut off access by foreign scholars to social survey data, according to Chinese academics and a secret document distributed recently.
The State Education Commission has already circulated a document that prohibits universities and other institutes from turning over to foreign scholars the results of social surveys, even if they were conducted as a joint effort. Now, the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, one of China's most prominent academic institutions, is planning to draft similar guidelines. 
 Exchange programs between Chinese and foreign scholars were cut back drastically after the military crackdown on the democracy movement in June 1989 and have revived only slowly. This recent effort by Chinese authorities is likely to cast another pall over one of the most important channels of contact between China and the United States.
Foreign academics say the prospect of adopting such guidelines at the academy, which has 20 scholarly exchange agreements abroad, has already doomed some potential projects.
"It's best to stay away from cooperative survey projects, if you want to get approval," a Chinese scholar said.
 
Curbing Western Contacts
 These measures also coincide with a broader national effort to step up efforts to curb contact between Westerners and Chinese and to protect secrets, which in China could include almost anything.
At one institution, for instance, Chinese were instructed late last year not to allow foreigners to use telephone, facsimile and telex machines, as part of stricter secrecy rules. In political study sessions, they were told what not to say in front of foreigners.
The State Education Commission's document, No. 598, issued at the end of last year, applied to social research data and cited as an example opinion polls that shed light on public views toward the party and the Government.
The commission oversees universities and many other educational institutes throughout the nation. That the academy, which is not directly supervised by the commission, is drafting similar guidelines suggests there is a push for such controls from high-level leaders.
The impetus behind the guidelines is the belief that Western countries are eager to obtain information on social trends and developments in China to sharpen their efforts to influence and change China's political system.
So far only two projects are believed to have been directly affected by the document. One was a project to examine marital issues and the other examined political and economic changes at the local levels.

HEADLINE: New Software for Apple Links With I.B.M. Units

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
As part of an increased effort to attract corporate customers, Apple Computer Inc. yesterday introduced its first software package that allows users of large networks of its Macintosh personal computers to communicate easily with I.B.M. mainframes and minicomputers.
Analysts said the Apple software was an improvement over the cumbersome communications software now available from third-party suppliers. 
 "Apple is taking ownership of the problem," said John C. McCarthy, an analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
Last fall, Apple embarked on an ambitious plan to increase its share of the personal computer market from about 11 percent to 20 percent, primarily by increasing volume by cutting prices. But Apple is also trying to make greater inroads into the business market, which accounts for as much as half of all personal computer sales. Apple now has about 8 percent of the corporate market, Mr. McCarthy estimates.
 
Help for Margins
 Corporations tend to buy more powerful systems, which provide higher profit margins to computer makers, an important consideration for Apple, whose margins have suffered from the aggressive price cuts.
Ed Forman, marketing manager of large business for Apple, said the company was working to overcome several myths about its personal computers, including the perception that there is not enough business software available for Apple personal computers. A growing number of business programs, including the popular 1-2-3 spreadsheet from the Lotus Development Corporation, will soon be available for the Macintosh.
Apple must also dispel the notion that the Macintosh "is a system for individuals" instead of for entire corporations, Mr. Forman said.
Corporations have also worried about being able to connect their large mainframes to Apple's personal computers. Yesterday's introduction of the new communications software, called the SNA.ps family of products, is another step in convincing corporate customers that Macintoshes can be easily connected to mainframe computers made by the International Business Machines Corporation, Mr. Forman and analysts said.
But improving networking is only part of the problem. Mr. McCarthy said that to be successful in the corporate market, Apple must establish a strong corporate sales staff and convince third-party retailers to put together packages of Apple equipment and custom-designed software for different businesses.
Mr. Forman said Apple was reorganizing its sales force to be more responsive to corporations.
Apple executives said yesterday's product announcement was unrelated to the recent talks between I.B.M. and Apple.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Down Amid Concern About Rates and Policies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday as concerns about interest rates and reactions to the weekend meeting of Group of Seven monetary officials eroded the gains the dollar chalked up last week.
Investors had bought the dollar on the expectation that the officials would not take a firm stand on limiting its advance. The dollar has risen 20 percent recently as the United States economy has shown signs of reviving. 
 At their meeting in London on Sunday, the finance officials -- who represented the United States, Britain, Canada, Italy, Germany, France and Japan -- issued a statement saying they would intervene jointly in the markets "if necessary." Traders interpreted that as a loose agreement to curb the dollar's gains.
 
Higher German Rates Expected
 Analysts also said the dollar slipped on speculation that Germany would announce higher interest rates later this week. An increase in German rates would make the mark more valuable and decrease demand for the dollar and other currencies.
Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with the Bank of New York, said the dollar was also caught in a crossfire as nervous traders sold the Japanese yen and bought the mark because of scandals involving several big brokerage firms in Tokyo.
The presidents of the Nomura Securities Company, the world's largest securities firm, and of the Nikko Securities Company resigned yesterday, after disclosures that their companies had improperly compensated the firms' biggest clients for their losses.
The dollar fell to 1.7830 marks in New York, from 1.8015 late Friday. In earlier European trading, the dollar dropped to 1.7845 marks, from late Friday's 1.7990.
 
Yen Mixed Against Dollar
 In New York the yen managed a small gain against the dollar, which closed at 138.70 yen, down from 138.90 late Friday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 0.72 yen to a closing 139.77 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 138.85 yen.
The British pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.6470 in New York, from $1.6260. In London, the pound jumped to $1.6425, from $1.6310 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.5345 Swiss francs, down from 1.54785; 6.0545 French francs, down from 6.1225; 1,326.50 Italian lire, down from 1,341.25, and 1.14255 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14325.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.5335 Swiss francs, down from 1.5460; 6.0595 French francs, down from 6.1115; 2.0098 Dutch guilders, down from 2.0265; 1,328.00 Italian lire, down from 1,338.25, and 1.1427 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1428.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Short-Term Notes Down Slightly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in slow trading yesterday, as short-term notes and bills gave ground, while longer-term issues improved somewhat.
Traders said they were surprised by the decline in the price of some short-term maturities, given the big drop in American equity prices, the Japanese stock scandal and a fall in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 leading spot commodity prices for the second straight session. 
 All of those factors tend to encourage investors to seek haven in high-quality, very liquid short-term investments like Treasury bills and notes.
"There has been some ammo for the short end of the market, but it didn't have any impact," said David R. Duerson, manager of government securities trading at the Security Pacific Corporation.
 
'Heavy Supply Coming'
 Mr. Duerson and others said the slight selloff probably was attributable in part to the coming auctions of new two-year and five-year notes. They also pointed to some mild disappointment that the weekend meeting of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations did not produce an agreement to make the Federal Reserve lower short-term interest rates as a way of lowering the value of the dollar on foreign exchange markets. And with the end of the second quarter looming, many accounts are content to close their books now, rather than pick the current moment to take on new risk.
"There is very heavy supply coming, volume is weak and clients are not doing business," another government bond trader said. "Unless we get some good business at the auctions, we are in for a rough week."
Today, the Treasury is expected to sell $12.5 billion worth of new two-year Treasury notes. That auction will be followed on Wednesday with the sale of $9.25 billion worth of new five-year notes.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.99 percent. The five-year notes were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 7.95 percent.
Demand at the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills was good, dealers said.
At the auction, the three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.58 percent, down from the 5.61 percent average rate at last week's sale.
Bids for the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.76 percent, compared with the 5.79 percent average rate a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at 95 7/8, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.50 percent, the same yield as late on Friday.
Among outstanding note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 7/8 in late trading, down 1/32, to yield 8.31 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 3/4, unchanged on the day, to yield 6.88 percent.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues were unchanged in very lethargic trading.
The tempo was much the same in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds.
Market participants said prices of the most widely quoted securities were little changed in thin, boring trading.

HEADLINE: Dexter M. Keezer Is Dead at 95; Economist Gauged U.S. Outlook

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ

 BODY:
Dexter M. Keezer, an economist who developed techniques of projecting the nation's business climate, died yesterday in the Orleans Nursing and Convalescent Center in Orleans, Mass. He was 95 years old and lived in Truro, Mass.
He died of congestive heart failure, a family spokesman said. 
 Dr. Keezer, a pragmatic economist. gained worldwide attention while he was with the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, which he had joined in 1945. He created the department of economics there and developed annual surveys of capital spending and of research and development expenditures by many of the nation's leading businesses.
The annual surveys, which were begun in 1948, were used as indicators of the nation's potential for economic prosperity. With some adjustments for historical experience they were also used for forecasting the business climate, said Douglas Greenwald, who became manager of economic services at McGraw-Hill when Dr. Keezer retired in 1960.
Dr. Keezer, who had been a vice president at McGraw-Hill, remained with the company as an economic adviser until 1971.
"He was the No. 1 person in the business economics field," Mr. Greenwald said.
 
Active in Civic Affairs
 In retirement Dr. Keezer became involved in civic affairs in Truro, on Cape Cod. He was president of the Truro Neighborhood Association and in the mid-1970's campaigned against nude bathing at Brush Hollow Beach. He also served as Truro's representative to the Cape Cod National Seashore Advisory Commission and was a supporter of the Truro Conservation Trust.
Dexter Merriam Keezer was born Aug. 24, 1895, in Acton, Mass. He had been a teacher, journalist and government official before being named president of Reed College in Portland, Ore., in 1934. He was then one of the youngest college presidents in the nation. Previously, he had been a reporter at The Denver Times and at the Washington bureau of Scripps-Howard newspapers and, from 1929 to 1933, associate editor of The Baltimore Sun.
Dr. Keezer graduated from Amherst College in 1920, from Cornell University in 1923 and received a Ph.D. in 1925 from Brookings Graduate School of Economics and Government. He served in an Army machine-gun battalion in World War I and taught at Cornell, the University of Colorado, the University of North Carolina and Dartmouth College.
He was an expert on consumer problems and was executive director of the Consumer Advisory Board of the National Recovery Administration in 1933-34.
 
Service in Various Posts
 After leaving Reed College in 1942, he returned to Washington to serve as deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration. He was also a member of the National Advisory Committee of the National Youth Administration, served as an economic adviser at the United States Embassy in London and was a member of the War Labor Board and of the Emergency Mediation Board.
He was the author or editor of several books, including "Are We Slaves of Some Defunct Economist" and "The Light That Flickers: A View of College Education Which Contrasts Promise and Performance and Suggests Improvements." He was the co-author of "New Forces in American Business" and "Making Capitalism Work."
He was also a director of the American National Theater and Academy and was a trustee of Elmira College.
He is survived by his wife, Anne; two daughters, Anne Read of Washington, and Berthe Ladd of Dover, Mass.; five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Washington Journal;
Picking Ethiopian Food: It's a Political Decision

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
The Asmara Restaurant in the Adams-Morgan neighborhood a few miles north of the White House was once billed as an Ethiopian-Eritrean restaurant. Now it is strictly Eritrean.
The political and ethnic allegiances among the disparate ethnic groups in the thriving 50,000-member Ethiopian community here are being stretched to the limits these days in the wake of last month's ouster of the Marxist Government of Mengistu Haile Mariam. Nowhere is that more apparent than in the community's dozen or so restaurants, concentrated on 18th Street and Columbia Road in Northwest Washington. 
 Eritreans, by and large, go to Eritrean-owned restaurants. Amharas go to Amhara-owned restaurants. Tigreans, Oromos and others from about 80 Ethiopian ethnic groups disperse themselves wherever they feel most comfortable.
There are Ethiopian restaurants that won't play Eritrean songs, and Eritrean restaurants whose patrons turn off Ethiopians of other ethnic groups. The politics among the groups has become so fragmented that some are boycotting one another's restaurants. And whichever one a non-Ethiopian diner tries, he or she may be served up a lesson in political correctness.
Ethiopians are riven by numerous issues: whether Eritrea, a territory that most nations still consider just the northern province of Ethiopia, should become independent; what the makeup of the government in the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa should be; who should control that government, and how other ethnic groups fit into that plan.
"This is a very emotional issue," said Shimlias Asafa, a taxi driver who is Amhara, a member of the minority that accounts for one-quarter of Ethiopia's population but that until last month dominated the country. "We are the same blood, same culture, same people who have been operating under a misguided Marxist-Leninist ideology. We are one country."
But at the Asmara Restaurant on Columbia Road, owned by an Eritrean, Tesfamichel Berhane, such sentiments were derided. "They never cared about a united Ethiopia before," Mr. Berhane said, referring to Amharas.
"They don't come to our restaurants anymore," he added.
These people with high cheekbones, delicate features and dark, expressive eyes may seem of a piece to Americans, who may think of Ethiopia as a land of famine. But their politics separate them.
The political ideology is strongest among the Eritreans, who have fought for independence for nearly 30 years. The province developed a separate identity in the decades it was controlled by Italy, and its inhabitants maintain that Eritrea was unfairly handed over to Ethiopia by the British, who seized it in World War II.
In the crowded coffee bar of the Addis Ababa Restaurant on 18th Street, Gezahegne Bekele, an Amhara and an economist who works for the General Accounting Office, sat at a table of Ethiopians who argued about the separatism of the Eritreans and the new, United States-backed Tigre-dominated Government that now controls Addis Ababa and the southern part of the country.
"Where does this Government get its legitimacy?" he asked. "It doesn't include all the various views of all Ethiopians."
The Tigreans, who make up 10 percent of the country's population, generally favor a unified Ethiopia. The Amharas were glad to see Colonel Mengistu and his Communist Government depart but are wary of the Tigreans and adamantly oppose Eritrean separation.
At the Addis Ababa Restaurant, Mr. Bekele lamented the current fragmentation in Washington's Ethiopian community. "It would be a shame to make the Ethiopian crisis simply an ethnic crisis," he said. "We have eight million people in a country of 50 million close to starvation. We could lose three million people unless we get substantial emergency assistance. The masses of Ethiopians have that in common."

Eritreans, above, gathered at the Asmara Restaurant in the Adams-Morgan neighborhood of Washington. This restaurant, once considered Ethiopian-Eritrean, is now strictly Eritrean. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
