HEADLINE: Work Force In Bridgeport Is Squeezed By 2 Laws

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 24

 BODY:
Bridgeport has cut its work force so deeply that it is caught in a bind between the state's labor laws and welfare laws that threatens to leave the city both dirtier and poorer.
As the city lays off custodians, parks workers and street cleaners, it has little choice but to take away the jobs of the welfare recipients who assist them as part of the state's workfare program. Connecticut, like most states, bars people in workfare programs from taking the place of municipal employees. 
 Already the city has removed more than 300 people from crews helping to maintain parks and schools, and as many as 900 more welfare recipients may be working in violation of labor laws.
But Connecticut also penalizes cities that fail to give work or training to at least two-thirds of those eligible for local workfare. If the city is forced to eliminate hundreds of workfare positions, it could lose hundreds of thousands of dollars in state aid.
 
'A Heavy Commitment'
 "We want to comply with the labor law," said Bridgeport's welfare director, Roberto Garcia. "But there's such a heavy commitment in municipal work sites that we couldn't comply with the labor law without violating the welfare law."
The workfare puzzle is only one example of how Bridgeport is learning what many of its residents have long known: that being poor can be expensive.
Even before Mayor Mary C. Moran turned to bankruptcy court this month, department heads with slashed budgets were searching for ways to get their work done, and finding that they could not turn to workfare participants, or even to volunteers.
Paul Boldin, coordinator for social services for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees at its headquarters in Washington, said that officials of financially strapped cities were often tempted to use welfare recipients as free labor.
"It abuses them as much as it abuses the regular employees," he said.
He said that his union had serious conflicts with workfare programs in New York State, especially around Buffalo, in the early 1980's, and that his union was closely watching New York City, now that recession has returned and city employees are being laid off.
In 1981 Connecticut began requiring able-bodied people on local welfare, or general assistance, either to work or to enroll in education or training programs to remain eligible for aid.
The state offered communities an incentive: if a city found jobs or training for two-thirds of those eligible for workfare, the state would pay 100 percent of their benefits, rather than the usual 90 percent. It would also pay the city $50 a month for each person on workfare, to cover the costs of administering the program.
 
Complaint From Unions
 Over the last three years, as Bridgeport cut 1,000 jobs from a work force of 4,700, the number of workfare participants put to work at city sites grew as the number of men and women on general assistance tripled, to 3,800.
Mr. Garcia, the welfare director, said he had 2,700 people, 70 percent of those eligible, on workfare last month. At that rate, the $50-a-month payments alone would be worth $1.6 million a year to his department.
On May 15, however, the Connecticut State Board of Labor Relations, responding to a complaint from two unions that suffered layoffs in 1990, ordered Bridgeport to stop assigning workfare participants "bargaining-unit work."
In effect, if the city laid off custodians, it also had to "lay off" the workfare participants assigned to help them.
Since then, the question for city officials has been how broadly the order affects the 1,200 welfare recipients working at municipal job sites. The answer, with a work force that is nearly all unionized, could be all 1,200.
Mr. Garcia has plans for what he describes as new "makework" programs. "We could count a lot of things in the city," he said. But if Bridgeport falls out of compliance with workfare, penalties could come due within a few months.
The state, however, has not decided whether it would immediately pursue penalties, said Claudette J. Beaulieu, spokeswoman for the State Department of Income Maintenance.
The penalty is the elimination of state reimbursement for however many welfare recipients the city falls short of the two-thirds level. If, for example, Bridgeport's average annual cost was $6,000 a person and it fell 100 people short, over a year the penalties would add up to $600,000.
Other Connecticut cities are also caught between the two laws. In Waterbury, the welfare director, Debra Shapiro, cut 150 jobs, 25 percent of her total, because of layoffs in the police, parks and adult education departments.
But Bridgeport relies most on municipal work, and therefore will feel the loss of the jobs more and the risk of financial penalties sooner.
Already 259 people have stopped helping school custodians.
Almost certain to go are 712 men on field crews used to clean up littered lots, which abound in Bridgeport's poorer neighborhoods.
And the Parks Department has given up the 50 laborers who, by working 20-hour weeks picking up litter, freed its employees to mow and maintain Bridgeport's more than 40 parks.
The budget that takes effect July 1 halves the money for parks, to $2.1 million, and leaves 28 employees, down from 83 a few years ago. Only 10 are workers who actually care for the parks that gave Bridgeport the nickname of Park City.
So after July 1, said the parks superintendent, Phillip C. Handy, those workers will tend only five parks including the two largest: Seaside, on Long Island Sound, and Beardsley, home to the city zoo.
The other parks will not be mowed and their trash will not be picked up.
"No anything," Mr. Handy said. "The litter barrels will be taken out of there. The grass is going to grow two feet high, so the whole area will be a dump."
Business and neighborhood groups have expressed interest in taking over other parks. But those volunteer efforts appear to be barred by contract provisions that prohibit the city from subcontracting work done by union members.
"I thought there were ways around it," Mr. Handy said, "but every time I find one, I'm told you can't do it that way."
The unions that sought the order, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, and the National Association of Government Employees, are confident that labor law bars both workfare participants and volunteers as replacements for their laid-off members, and in any case they doubt the utility of volunteers.
"What volunteer is going to sweep City Hall?" asked Wayne Gilbert, a national representative for the association. "Who's going to volunteer to clean the toilets? If I see someone doing that, I'll give him a gold badge."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Rosy Accounting At Japan's Banks

BYLINE: By James Sterngold

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
A FUNNY thing happened to Japan's big banks on the way to reporting their annual profits.
For months newspapers have been filled with stories of the huge financial problems at the banks' real estate affiliates and the high level of corporate bankruptcies here. 
 By most measures it seemed that tens of billions of dollars in loans had gone down the drain in the tumult. Yet when the moment came for the banks to come clean, most reported not the big write-offs that have been afflicting their American rivals, but a reduction in their provisions for bad loans.
Take what analysts regard as two of the most illustrative examples, the Sumitomo Bank, a large shareholder in Goldman, Sachs & Company, and the Fuji Bank, the parent of Heller Financial Inc.
Sumitomo reported a 22.3 percent decline in net profits, to $970 million at current exchange rates. Fuji's net profits slumped 18.7 percent, to $860 million. The declines were largely because of falling profits from securities sales and a squeeze on bank margins because of the rising interest rates they had to pay for deposits.
More to the point, each had to stage expensive rescues of affiliates. But both actually reported a large reduction in their provision for loan losses at the end of the fiscal year, which ended March 31.
Welcome to Japanese accounting.
To be sure, some problems do show up, as in the lower profits. But there were no cases like the Bank of New England and no collapses that taxed the deposit insurance fund. In fact, the Government insurance fund has never had to pay out a cent on a failed bank. Analysts say it is not because the banks are impervious to misfortune, but because of lax accounting rules and the fact that regulators emphasize not public disclosure but cooperation with the industry when troubles arise.
"The system is non-transparent in so many areas," said Roger Arner, an executive vice president at the Japan office of Moody's Investors Service. "You have to operate on trust." Added Stuart Matthews, an analyst here for Barclays de Zoette Wedd, "We just don't have the real numbers."
According to a report by Alicia Ogawa, an analyst at S. G. Warburg Securities, the value of bankruptcies jumped last year to 1.99 trillion yen, or $14.3 billion at current exchange rates, yet loan-loss write-offs and provisions for bad debts at big Japanese banks fell by 42 percent from the previous year, to $1.1 billion.
Take Sumitomo's case. It lost its chairman, Ichiro Isoda, when he resigned last year to take responsibility for the bank's role in a huge scandal. Itoman & Company, an old-line textile trading company long affiliated with Sumitomo, had gone on a speculative binge, borrowing heavily and investing billions of dollars in real estate and paintings.
Since then real estate prices have dropped, it has been disclosed that the company paid more than double the value of the paintings, and Itoman has been left with nearly $10 billion in shaky borrowings. Although it had no contractual obligation, Sumitomo stepped in to effectively guarantee Itoman's loans and provide more financing.
In Japan, banks can wait up to a year after a borrower stops paying interest on a loan before it is counted as nonperforming, while in the United States banks generally have only 90 days.
Sumitomo is believed to have nearly $2 billion in direct loans to Itoman and contingent liabilities for most of the rest, but this has not had the slightest impact on Sumitomo's earnings or balance sheet.
That was good enough for Japan's regulators, and even for Japanese stockholders, who have not dumped the bank's shares. But it was not good enough for Moody's. Last week the rating agency said it was lowering the rating on Sumitomo's long-term deposits by two notches, to AA3. Moody's also announced that it was reviewing Fuji's ratings because of the bank's heavy loans to the troubled real estate sector in Japan and abroad.
Fuji has had three well-publicized problems. One involves a construction and real estate company, the Tobishima Corporation. It is currently struggling under what is reported to be about $7 billion in shaky loans. Fuji is Tobishima's main bank, and thus is leading the effort to rescue the company with a restructuring and more credit.
It was also reported recently that a Fuji subsidiary based in the Cayman Islands suffered a $310 million loss from securities trading. Yet that did not appear to have taken a bite of Fuji's earnings.
And Fuji appears to have had some indirect involvement in the Itoman scandal. A credit association affiliated with Fuji, Osaka Fumin, had lent heavily to business partners of Itoman, and is reported to have been near collapse with nearly $900 million in bad loans. Because of its association, Fuji stepped in and reportedly sent 11 of its executives and former executives to take control of Osaka Fumin and lent more than $700 million to the credit association to keep it afloat. Yet, Fuji also reported a big drop in its loan-loss provisions. "Nobody is suggesting that these banks are going bust, but it leaves so much uncertainty about their real positions," said Mr. Matthews, the Barclays analyst. "Japanese investors just have remarkable faith in their system."

HEADLINE: With 7 Days Left, New York City Grapples With Budget Conflicts

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Seven days before the start of its new fiscal year, New York City's political leaders yesterday groped through a maze of conflicting proposals to keep the city budget balanced, including a move to save money by stretching out payments to municipal pension funds.
Struggling with the city's worst fiscal problems since the crisis of the mid-1970's, negotiators for Mayor David N. Dinkins and municipal unions hope the changes in the pension payments could save hundreds of millions of dollars in the coming year, people close to the talks said. 
 Such a move, like refinancing a mortgage, would amount to making the payments over a longer period, effectively burdening future taxpayers. It could also face many legal and technical obstacles and may not be done in time to help now.
 
Fiscal Uncertainties
 At City Hall, in daylong negotiations in the marble corridors and paneled offices, it was far from certain that Mayor Dinkins and the City Council could resolve their half-billion-dollar differences over closing a $3.5 billion gap in the $29 billion city budget for the fiscal year that starts on July 1 and whether the State Legislature would pass needed taxes and aid. Yesterday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo spoke of a plan to restore about $360 million of spending that he had vetoed, including $60 million that he said would help the city.
 "The good news is we're past the name-calling," said the chairman of the Council's Finance Committee, Herbert E. Berman of Brooklyn. "The bad news is we still don't have a budget."
The Council is arguing for deeper cuts to avoid more than half of the $776 million in higher property taxes the Mayor wants. In Albany, prospects for Mr. Dinkins's demands for $335 million in higher city personal income taxes and $328 million in relaxation of mandated spending remained cloudy as lawmakers jockeyed to use the requests as negotiating chips for their own spending priorities.
 
Much Higher Stakes
 At the same time, a leading business group, the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said it could not support the income tax increase because Mr. Dinkins had failed to win union concessions or make significant long-term savings that could avert the need for such taxes.
Confusion and recriminations envelop City Hall every year at budget season, but this year the stakes are much higher and the rumblings much more ominous amid a regional recession and with the state's own budget passed 65 days late and still not fully resolved. Because of the city's brush with bankruptcy 16 years ago, its budget is subject to tight controls and scrutiny by a state body, the Financial Control Board, that could impose binding powers over its spending if it failed to balance its budget.
That makes the next week a high-stakes race against time. But there is also a sense that even if the budget is adopted on time, its effect on life in the city may be so severe as to make the Mayor and the Council immediately start striving again for money from union concessions or from the Municipal Assistance Corporation -- a state body set up to help bail the city out of its last crisis -- in an effort to undo the worst of the cuts.
 
Beyond Tolerance
 The Council leadership contends that by pressing for about $465 million more in cuts in city services than the $1.5 billion Mr. Dinkins has already proposed, it can not only stave off much of the property tax increases he has been seeking but also may help win concessions on wages or benefits from municipal unions that have so far resisted, even if such help come only after the budget is adopted.
Yesterday, the Mayor and his aides again attacked the Council's proposed cuts as beyond New Yorkers' tolerance and urged community groups to lobby against the Council's plans.
The Council leaders said the Mayor's office had rebuffed its demands for a greater say in precisely how money should be appropriated and over what conditions the Council can attach to spending. That is especially important since if new money from union concessions or other sources becomes available after the budget is adopted, the Council worries that it would have limited say in deciding how it should be spent.
"If they'd spent all this energy getting labor and productivity savings, we wouldn't be here," said Peg Breen, a spokeswoman for the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone.
Almost every city agency had a new horror story to tell about what would happen if the worst of the cuts came true, but sorting out just which ones were likely to be made was impossible as both sides continued to debate the potential effects.
Among the specific proposals that mayoral advisers questioned was one to eliminate 75 property-tax auditors, which they asserted would save a few million dollars but cost hundreds of millions, and another to eliminate 160 traffic-control agents from midtown Manhattan, which they said would cost the city up to $200 million in Federal funds because of the air-quality violations likely to be caused by tie-ups in traffic.
 
Health Risks Stressed
 After the City Board of Health warned that some of the proposed cuts in health programs would be so severe as to risk causing a public health emergency and violating various regulations, Mr. Dinkins and the Council leaders said they had agreed in principle to avoid cuts that would jeopardize health or break mandates, though city lawyers said that might ultimately entail relaxing some of the mandates.
But it was clear that the Dinkins administration, rushing to propose its budget last month and hoping to prompt concessions from unions and the state, had included many proposed cuts that could run afoul of legal requirements.
Other city agencies complained that the Council's proposals would cripple their function. The Department of Invesitgation, which reviews allegations of corruption in government, would have its staff cut from 410, to 270 people, virtually eliminating its inspector-general system in which investigators are assigned to monitor particular agencies. The system was created in the wake of the municipal corruption scandals just five years ago.
"A lot of agencies would end up having no real coverage," one department official said.
The City Planning Department said the Council's plan would cut it from 360 workers, to 193, leaving about one planner per 100,000 city residents, instead of three. The 10-member office that handles the city's relations with television production companies and film makers, an important local industry, would be cut in half.
In Albany, Governor Cuomo, under pressure to restore some of the $900 million worth of spending that he vetoed from the state budget earlier this month, outlined yesterday a sketchy plan for adding back roughly $360 million.
"We don't have a plan as such," Mr. Cuomo said, "because I don't see the point of a plan."
He said roughly $60 million of the spending he was recommending be restored would benefit New York City.
The Governor's plan does not call for any new taxes. Rather, it calls for increased tax collections, additional bond sales and further cuts in Medicaid. But legislative leaders, emerging from a meeting with the Governor yesterday afternoon, seemed nonplused by the plan and said only that they were waiting for more details.

GRAPHIC: Chart: 'The Budget Battles'
 
New York
 New York City: A dispute involving less than two percent of the total budget continued to separate Mayor David N. Dinkins and New York's City Council yesterday.
The previously unbudgeable $450 million or so gap between them appeared to narrwing ever so slightly.
Publicly, the climate was conciliatory even as both sides lobbed potshots behind the scenes and marshalled evidence of each other's inadequacies so that the blame for a budget that is unlikely to please anybody could be properly apportioned later.
Mayoral representatives told the Council's finance staff that some of its proposed cuts are illusory. The Council informally agreed to restore up to $60 million in what it called "life-threatening" cuts already made by the Mayor.
Threatened with thousands of layoffs -- 8,000 under the Mayor's plan and 7,000 more under the Council's -- representatives of several municipal unions actually did negotiate yesterday.
 Albany: The stalemate over a state budget continued. But pressure increased on the Republican majority in the Senate to act this week on the tax package Mr. Dinkins has proposed to help close his projected deficit.
 
Connecticut
 The question appears to be not whether there will be an income tax, but how much?
Democratic leaders in the House would close the state's budget gap by making a broad based, progressive income tax the single biggest revenue source. Senate Democrats are mulling a smaller tax.
Most of the plans under consideration would raise state taxes by $1 billion or more. The state would also borrow more than $900 million to cover the deficit for the fiscal year that ends June 30.
 
New Jersey
 Also facing a July 1 deadline -- and a statutory requirement that the state balance its budget -- New Jersey legislators were seeking to close a $1.5 billion gap in the $14.3 billion budget proposed by Gov. Jim Florio.
Mr. Florio wants, among other things, to persuade state employee unions to give back $280 million in wages and benefits.
If the unions balk, Mr. Florio has threatened at least 4,000 more layoffs. But yesterday, Democratic leaders in the Assembly said layoffs could be avoided, offering more optimistic revenue projections and relying on a change in the way Medicaid bills are reimbursed at state hospitals. (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: GERMANY TO HELP SOVIETS OBTAIN AID

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, June 24

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl will meet with Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in advance of the meeting of the seven leading industrial democracies in July to persuade the Soviet leader to accept free-market reforms bold enough to generate a major infusion of Western aid.
A Bonn spokesman said today that the two leaders would meet in Kiev on July 5, 10 days before the seven-nation meeting in London. 
 Mr. Gorbachev has been invited to London to meet with the seven leaders at the end of their annual conference. Although he has been vague on what he hopes to accomplish, Mr. Gorbachev has indicated that he might seek large amounts of economic help, and Mr. Kohl is likely to be his strongest advocate.
Earlier, some Soviet officials were talking of needing $100 billion over five years, but more recently, in the face of skepticism in the West, they have said they did not expect specific aid packages to emerge from London.
The question of aid to Moscow is being debated as Mr. Gorbachev faces a growing challenge from Soviet hard-liners, who charge that moves toward reform are not being reciprocated from abroad. [Page A16.]
Representatives of the seven nations agreed in principle in London on Sunday that the Soviet Union should be offered a limited role in the International Monetary Fund. Such a move would give the Soviet Union access to technical help on economic reform, but would not bring an immediate infusion of money from the fund,
Advisers to Mr. Kohl said they believe the seven industrialized nations will agree to a major aid program only if it is detailed and tied to drastic economic reforms. They are hoping that during his visit to Kiev, Mr. Kohl will be able to impress that point on the Soviet leader, and induce him to present a program of sweeping economic change at the summit in London.
Mr. Gorbachev needs to convince skeptical leaders like President Bush that he is truly prepared to reverse the course of Soviet economic history. Mr. Bush has been reluctant to support major Western aid to the Soviet Union, though he has indicated willingness to provide expert technical advice.
 
Chancellor Kohl's Lobby
 "At first, Gorbachev wasn't going to be invited to the London summit, but various countries spoke up, and after awhile the Americans agreed," said an aide to Chancellor Kohl. "You are going to see the same process at the summit itself. If the right program is presented in the right way, a consensus will develop.
"I can't guess the size of the package," the aide said. "The public likes gigantic figures, but if the proposal is just to commit $100 billion over five years, no one will accept it. We're looking for a continuing investment program, and as each step is successfully reached, we will help support the next one."
In public statements and conversations with leaders, Mr. Kohl has already begun lobbying on behalf of the Soviets.
"It is in our common interests to provide effective help -- aid and self-help -- to the Soviet Union and the young democracies of Eastern Europe in this critical transition phase," he said when he welcomed Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada to Bonn recently.
Participants in the annual economic conference of the Group of Seven, besides Chancellor Kohl, Mr. Mulroney and President Bush, will be the leaders of France, Britain, Italy and Japan.
German officials acknowledge that, because of history and geography, Germany has special reasons for wanting to help the Soviets. But they said Germany would only support an aid package that was accompanied by profound economic reforms. Germany has committed itself to about $31 billion in loans, grants and credits to the Soviet Union, in part because of Moscow's assent to the unification of Germany. Much of the money has gone to provide housing and other aid for Soviet soldiers returning home.
 
'A Partnership of Governments'
 The Germans have traditionally seen large-scale business interests in the East, but besides the profits to be won, they are concerned that a breakdown in the Soviet Union could lead to colossal dislocation, with millions of Soviet and East European refugees.
"We want to make suggestions, but we can't behave as if we were the World Bank going into Uganda, designing a plan for them and then saying they have to accept or else there is no money," Economic Minister Jurgen Mollemann said in an interview. "It has to be a partnership of governments."
Mr. Mollemann and other officials said that the emergence of Boris N. Yeltsin had helped Mr. Gorbachev's position by showing the Soviet Union's progress toward democracy, and that overtures to the Baltic republics or an easing of emigration policies in the next few weeks would help even more.
A Soviet concession to Japan on the disputed Kurile Islands would be necessary before the Japanese Prime Minister could support an aid program, officials here said.
"The reluctance on the Japanese side is even greater than the reluctance on the American side," said Otto Lambsdorff, who heads the Free Democratic Party and is an important ally of Mr. Kohl. "
 
A London Show-Stealer?
 "Without Mr. Gorbachev, we would not have German unification," he said. "We also know that if there is a serious economic collapse in the Soviet Union, there could be mass migration from East to West that would cause great problems in Germany and other countries of the European community."
"Unfortunately, the Soviet Union and Mr. Gorbachev have lost six years, and the situation there has become very bad," he continued. "The list of Gorbachev's economic advisers is longer than the list of Italian Prime Ministers over the last 10 years.
"No money will be given without reforms, but you cannot have reforms without money," Mr. Lambsdorff said. "What Mr. Gorbachev is going to put on the table, nobody knows. One thing for me is clear: he will steal the show at the G-7 summit, because no one is as brilliant at public relations as Mr. Gorbachev."

HEADLINE: Bank Reports On Assets Are Doubted

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
A growing number of economists and analysts are saying that many weak banks, including some of the nation's largest, have overstated the amount of capital they have on hand to absorb loan losses, and that a taxpayer bailout may be a stronger possibility than has been acknowledged by the banks and the Bush Administration.
Because the banking industry's capital is measured by historical prices, which reflect values when the loans were made, not reflected is the fact that many bank assets have deteriorated because of real estate and third world loans and other investments made amid the speculative excesses of the last decade. 
 A recent study of 39 failed banks by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, found that the quarterly reports filed by banks with Government examiners on their financial health "failed to provide regulators with advanced warning of the true magnitude of the deterioration in the banks' financial condition and performance."
The report found that while the banks followed standard accounting practices and recorded reserves of $2.1 billion to reflect the decreased values of their assets, regulators later found that $9.4 billion was actually needed to reflect the market value of the assets when the banks collapsed. In other words, $7.3 billion in asset values simply vanished between the time the loans were made and when the institutions were seized.
Regulators attribute the discrepancy to the fact that bankers have been slow to recognize deterioration in asset values. Banking experts will not even venture a guess on how much the difference might be. Determining it would require re-evaluating bank assets across the country.
The report on bank failures by the General Accounting Office found that bank managers "have a strong incentive" to delay accounting for changing values of assets because it adds to the banks' expenses and reduces their capital. "It is likely that many open financial institutions have overstated the value of their troubled assets," the G.A.O. report said.
Most banks continued to post profits, unlike savings and loan associations. The Bush Administration has portrayed the banks' and saving industry's problems as distinct, and played down any talk of a possible bank bailout by taxpayers.
On Wednesday, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is expected to ask Congress for another $80 billion to continue the savings and loan bailout into next year. He has already asked for $70 billion to be lent to the bank insurance fund. "The truth of the matter" is that the banking industry's capital "has been largely overstated," said R. Dan Brumbaugh, who has written about the savings and loan crisis and is a former economist with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
 
More Banks Experimenting
 While the banking industry has been resistant to market-value accounting because it is more expensive to do and is subject to wide fluctuations, more banks are experimenting with disclosing the market value of many of their assets because of the increasing demand for it from shareholders and analysts.
"Market value is an estimate of liquidation and is of highly limited use to an ongoing concern," said William P. O'Halloran, controller of Suntrust Banks Inc. of Atlanta and the chairman of the American Bankers Association's accounting committee. "It comes up every 10 years but this time it has received a big impetus from the savings and loan mess."
Mr. O'Halloran, whose bank has begun taking steps to perform market accounting of some of its assets, said the official position of the American Bankers Association, the industry's largest trade group, had been to oppose moving from historical accounting to market accounting.
For more than a year, Administration officials have been insisting that the capital of the banks, estimated at $240 billion as of March 31, distinguishes them from the faltering savings and loan industry, whose capital, time has proved, was overstated by officials and savings executives during the 1980's. As Treasury Secretary Brady likes to put it, the two "are as different as chalk and cheese."
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn and a member of the House Banking Committee, bluntly disagrees with Mr. Brady. "The link between the two industries is that both used insured deposits, without adequate regulatory checks, to make dumb investments," Mr. Schumer said. "It's the same fundamental cause."
There is strong disagreement among officials and analysts about the best way to measure the industry's capital, or even whether the current standards have obscured the depths of the industry's difficulties.
Capital means the equity of stockholders, or more simply, the difference between what a bank owns and what it owes. On a nationwide basis the industry has said its capital ratio is $6.65 for every $100 in assets, or more than double the minimum safety standard set by regulators.
Regulators derive the industry's capital figure by taking bank assets and subtracting liabilities and reserves set aside for possible losses. Since bank liabilities are easy to measure and primarily consist of bank deposits, experts look to the value of bank assets as the key to figuring out bank capital. These assets are measured by their value at the time they were acquired and not by the current market value.
The debate over how to measure bank assets is important now because of the record number of large-bank failures expected in 1991 and 1992, depleting the bank insurance fund and leaving it financed for the first time since its creation, during the Depression, by a taxpayer loan. Bank capital, in effect, serves the same function as the "deductible" in an insurance policy: it is paid initially to cover losses before the institution turns to the bank insurance fund.
At the latest count, regulators have identified 1,028 banks holding a record $418 billion in assets that are likely to fail. As more banks fail, the growing body of evidence strongly suggests that the industry's capital is less than the official estimates.
Among regulators, Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which helps to set accounting standards, has been most outspoken in repeatedly suggesting that banks value their assets not only at their historical, or book, value, but also at their current value, as investment banks and securities firms do.
 
Differences in Assets Cited
 On the other side of the issue, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, has maintained that commercial and savings banks deal primarily with different kinds of assets -- notably real estate -- that are more difficult to value readily than the assets of investment banks. Therefore, he says, the commercial and savings banks should not be forced to use the same kind of valuation techniques.
The industry and the Bush Administration have also largely opposed the reporting of bank assets by their current value, which would be far more expensive to perform as an accounting matter than accounting based on historical values.
The Financial Accounting Standards Board is developing new rules that would require banks and other companies to disclose in footnotes the current market value of the financial instruments and loans that they hold. The new rules would not affect the companies' income statements nor would they require the disclosure of the current value of real estate and other fixed assets.

HEADLINE: Higher Rents Approved For New York Tenants

 BODY:
Rent increases affecting at least two million New York City residents were approved last night by the Rent Guidelines Board at a raucous meeting.
The board, by a vote of 5 to 4, approved increases of 4 percent for one-year leases and 6.5 percent for two-year leases for 900,000 rent-stabilized apartments. 
 The board made its decision at a noisy but orderly public meeting at Police Headquarters at One Police Plaza. The increases are less than last year's, which were 4.5 percent for one-year leases and 7 percent for two-year leases.
Public hearings on various proposals were held last week, with tenant groups saying the proposed increases were too big and landlords arguing that they were not big enough.
A study by the staff of the Rent Guidelines Board concluded that building operating costs in the 12 months ending in April rose by an average of 5.1 percent. A study by a building owners' organization came up with a figure of 7.2 percent, citing steep rises in property taxes and water and sewage charges.
The Rent Guidelines Board is composed of nine members appointed by the mayor -- two representatives of tenants, two of property owners and five from the general public. Members must have at last five years' experience in finance, economics or housing.

HEADLINE: Chief of Employment Commission Criticizes G.O.P. Bill on Job Bias

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
The chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission today urged the White House to reject compromise civil rights bills fashioned by moderate Republicans.
In a letter to John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, Evan J. Kemp, head of the commission, said the compromise would make it "extremely difficult for employers to use educational credentials and objective measures of academic achievement" like tests to determine who to hire or promote. 
 Mr. Kemp said precluding such criteria in employment decisions would undermine President Bush's efforts to improve the educational achievements of students and therefore make it more difficult for American businesses to compete.
"Notwithstanding employers' ever increasing dependence on individual competence in order to remain competitive, students, parents and teachers will not be able to point to a reward for learning if employers are for all practical purposes precluded from even inquiring about degree status, much less rewarding academic achievement," Mr. Kemp wrote in the letter, a copy of which was provided by an Administration official on the promise of anonymity.
 
First Senior Opposition
 Mr. Kemp's letter marks the first time any senior official within the Bush Administration has voiced outright opposition to the compromise measures drafted by Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri.
It is not clear whether Mr. Kemp's letter presaged a formal Administration announcement opposing Mr. Danforth's measure or if it indicated a split within the Administration over whether to accept to Missouri Republican's compromise.
When asked about the Danforth proposals two weeks ago, Mr. Bush was non-committal, saying, "Our people are taking a hard look at them," More recently he said he had reservations about them.
The letter was the first time Mr. Kemp has indicated his views on any version of the civil rights legislation, which has become embroiled in a debate over whether it would compel employers to adopt hiring and promotion quotas in order to avoid job discrimination lawsuits.
As head of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Mr. Kemp is charged with the enforcement of Federal employment discrimination laws, but to date he has sat on the sidelines during the heated debates over the measure.
Steve Hilton, a spokesman for Mr. Danforth, said the Senator had not seen Mr. Kemp's letter and therefore would not be able to comment on it.
A version of the civil rights bill supported by the House Democratic leadership was approved by the House June 5 by a margin that was 17 votes short of what would be required to override a Presidential veto.
Democratic leaders in the Senate are reluctant to bring that measure to a vote, and are hoping that a compromise could be worked out that would secure White House support.
Backers of the civil rights bill are seeking to overturn a series of 1989 Supreme Court decisions that made it harder to sue and collect damages in job discrimination cases. They are also seeking to increase the financial penalties employers would pay if they are found to have discriminated intentionally against women.
Mr. Kemp's letter underscores the main philosophical difference between supporters of both the Democrats' bill and Mr. Danforth's compromise and their opponents within the Administration, including C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel.
According to the letter, Mr. Kemp beleives that Federal employment law as practiced during the last 20 years has fallen out of step with the current demands of the economy. In 1971, the Supreme Court that criteria for hiring and promotions like requiring a high school diploma or a college degree must be directly relevent to the job in question.

HEADLINE: Symbols Are Louder Than Action

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, June 25

 BODY:
The sudden resignations on Monday of the presidents of two of Japan's most powerful securities houses, Nomura Securities and Nikko Securities, were clear attempts to use the traditional Japanese technique of self- sacrifice to halt the share-dealing scandal that has engulfed Kabutocho, Tokyo's counterpart to Wall Street.
But it is unlikely that the dramatic developments will put to rest two troubling questions highlighted by the scandal, the biggest to hit the financial industry here in more than two decades: How fair is this huge financial market to those outside its power structure, including foreign investors? Whose interests are the market's policemen protecting? 
 In fact, the regulators at the Finance Ministry are now coming under intense scrutiny, as an outraged public asks how the improper practices could be so widespread and yet not be stopped. The ministry's elite bureaucrats are being regarded with the skepticism previously reserved for Japanese brokers.
 
Impact on Trading
 The Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, said that he was greatly distressed by the events and that his bureaucrats might have to consider toughening their oversight of the market. The Tokyo stock market's Nikkei index rose 141.96 points today, or six-tenths of a percent, to 23,907.42. On Monday, partly as an emotional reaction to news of the resignations, the Nikkei plunged 509.62 points.
Nevertheless, few experts expect big changes at the Finance Ministry, and thus in the industry. The most important reason is that Japan has none of the political oversight of regulators that exists in Washington.
There are no hearings, rarely do indignant legislators call officials on the carpet, and certainly no politicians are demanding that the public be offered better protection. As one foreign securities executive put it, the Japanese securities houses may have more to fear from the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States if it chooses to investigate whether the Japanese firms have engaged in improper practices on Wall Street than from their own securities bureau.
Under Japan's political system, most legislation originates in the ministries before being passed by the Parliament. In addition, the Parliament does not have the direct oversight power over the regulators that Congress has in the United States.
The Finance Ministry's credibility suffered when the stock market crashed last year and again with disclosures this year that several big banks had been involved in speculative lending. The heads of three of Japan's largest banks have resigned in recent months. Now it is becoming clear that the ministry may again be a victim of a scandal.
It was reported last week that Nomura, the world's largest securities house, had discriminated against the majority of its customers by improperly paying a select group of big clients $120 million to compensate for their stock-trading losses. It was also reported that Nikko, Japan's third-largest securities house, had made $122 million in such payments.
The same big institutions that are widely believed to get other favorable treatment, like advance notice of the choicest stock tips, were also given guarantees that they would not lose money, a practice banned here and in most world markets because it discriminates against other investors, particularly individuals.
Nomura first issued indignant denials, only to reverse itself on Friday and acknowledge that it had made the payments, as did Nikko. It has since been reported that the other members of the Big Four securities houses, Daiwa Securities and Yamaichi Securities, provided smaller amounts of improper compensation to their top customers.
Hiroshi Okumura, an economics professor at Ryukoku University and a former researcher at a securities-industry supported research center, said such investment guarantees had been "an open secret" here for years.
Adding to the public concern were disclosures that Nomura and Nikko had each lent more than $100 million to one of Japan's best-known organized crime bosses, and then executed his orders in what appears to have been a share-manipulation scheme.
At 10 A.M. on Monday, a tearful but still defiant Yoshihisa Tabuchi, Nomura's formidable president, refused to confirm details of the scandal or even that Nomura had been responsible for any wrongdoing. He said he was resigning to take responsibility for the firm's having suffered some bad publicity. Every Nomura official who would discuss the shocking development described it as a noble act, rather than a show of penance.
 
A Shadow Play
 Two facts added to the sense that this was a symbolic shadow play. First, Mr. Tabuchi is not leaving the firm -- he said he was resigning as chief executive to become vice chairman without executive powers. Second, his annointed successor is the man closest to him at Nomura, Hideo Sakamaki, who had headed strategic planning.
Also on Monday, five and a half hours later, Takuya Iwasaki, Nikko's chief executive, read from the same script: he resigned the presidency to become vice chairman and was succeeded by his vice president, Kichiro Takao.
Nearly two years after the reported manipulation involving the organized-crime figure, the Tokyo Stock Exchange announced that it would investigate the transaction and Nomura's role in it.
"I can't believe there will be any real change," said Makoto Sataka, a business commentator here. "Those people were cornered. That's why they resigned. It's just a symbol."
He added, "Nothing changes anyway until the ministry changes, and they have said nothing to indicate they will do that."
Commented a securities industry executive: "The ministry has winked at this for a long time. But nobody resigned there, which tells you something."
Perhaps the most damaging admission was that the Finance Ministry's securities bureau had known of the improper compensation schemes since early last year but had taken no punitive measures; the scandal only came to light because tax authorities began to investigate.
Mitsuru Hasegawa, an official in the securities company division, confirmed reports that the brokers had voluntarily told the ministry of the compensation; yet he did not seek to punish them or make the information public.
To some here, the problem is that the ministry's securities and banking bureaus have long been regarded as advocates for their industries. In part, this is because after bureaucrats retire from public service, they are often hired by the industries they regulated. The process is called amakudari, or literally, descent from heaven.
"It's impossible to get evidence, but I cannot help but think that the relationship between the industry and the ministry is too close," said Professor Okumura. "With the prospect of amakudari, the bureaucrats are prohibited from acting strongly."

HEADLINE: Ho-Hum No More, Concrete Goes High-Tech

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
QUIET advances in materials science, coupled with raw inventiveness, are turning the drab, ho-hum stuff known as concrete into a high-technology marvel that has far greater strength and durability than ever before and some surprising new properties, like flexibility.
Such materials are desirable for creating structures that bend rather than break in earthquakes. And with concretes up to 10 times stronger than ordinary, builders are making plans for needle-thin skyscrapers that would rise more than a third of a mile into the sky, towering over today's tallest buildings. 
 Perhaps the most important use of the new materials is concrete of greatly improved durability, which is seen as endowing all manner of roads, buildings, sewers and bridges with long lifetimes. For example, experts say, roads might last 50 or 60 years with few repairs instead of the 10 or 20 years typical for light maintenance.
The economic implications of greater durability are vast. Amid the crumbling of much of America's multitrillion-dollar infrastructure, a large part of which is concrete, increasing durability is viewed as an economic boon that would help make repairs and renovations far more cost-effective.
"These developments are going to be used extensively," said Dr. Sidney Diamond, a materials engineer at Purdue University who works on the new concretes. "The benefits are so apparent, even in simple measurements, that I think a high percentage of the new infrastructure will be affected."
Experts estimate that as much as a trillion dollars will have to be spent in the next two decades to improve and repair the parts of the nation's infrastructure built of concrete, making it one of the biggest financial challenges facing America into the next century.
"We can't do things the way we did the first time around," said Dr. J. Francis Young, an expert on concrete at the University of Illinois. "We've learned the hard way about some of the problems, by watching the Interstate highways fall apart. We don't want to repeat that kind of expensive experiment."
Not all the applications are so pedestrian. Exotic ones under study or accomplished include using concrete and cement to make boats, bottles, brake linings, electronic circuit boards, roof shingles, bottle caps, indoor furniture, engine blocks, loudspeaker cases and bases for computer chips.
For decades concrete fabrication was in the doldrums, beset by complacency and resistance to change. But as potholes, crumbling bridges and leaky water mains increasingly seized the nation's attention in the 1980's and as foreigners made strides in developing new concretes, often using ideas that originated in this country, a consensus formed that it was time for a fresh start.
In 1987, a report by a panel of the National Research Council, a scientific group based in Washington that advises the Federal Government, hailed the potential of new construction techniques and materials, including concrete, as a way to speed renewal and to battle decay. Its report, "Infrastructure for the 21st Century," cited "unprecedented opportunities" for innovation.
 
New Research Center
 One response to the promising developments in concrete came in February 1989 when the National Science Foundation, a main Government sponsor of basic research, founded the Center for Science and Technology of Advanced Cement-Based Materials at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill. The center is to receive $10 million over five years. This tiny investment has changed the field of concrete research, and could ultimately have implications for construction projects worth many hundreds of billions of dollars.
"The aim," said Dr. Surendra P. Shah, director of the center and a civil engineer at Northwestern, "is a new generation of materials."
The center, which finances research at Northwestern, the University of Illinois, the University of Michigan, Purdue University and the National Institute of Standards and Technology, instantly quadrupled the size of the field, with the number of scientists and graduate students investigating new kinds of concrete going to nearly 100 from about 25. New tools of the trade include laser holograms and electron microscopes, which are used to analyze tiny fractures, and nuclear magnetic resonance for probing deeper structure.
The subject of the investigations is complex and versatile. Concrete is a mixture of water, sand, gravel and a binder, usually portland cement, which is made of powdered limestone and clay. It is extremely plastic and easy to manipulate when wet, and it hardens to a stone-like condition when dry. Tough and cheap, concrete is used everywhere and has been for more than a century.
Experts sometimes refer to concrete as a kind of ceramic. But differences between the two materials reveal one of concrete's basic advantages. Ceramic materials, made mainly of clay, must be fired to high temperatures to achieve hardness. That is costly. In contrast, most concretes are produced by chemical reactions at room temperature, making their manufacture relatively cheap and far less cumbersome.
 
A Major Drawback
 One of the main problems with concrete is its porous structure, which is not detectable by the naked eye but is apparent under a microscope. A welter of tiny voids, up to a hundred times finer than a human hair, are left behind after water chemically joins with cement.
These tiny spaces can be the beginnings of fractures. In addition, water that pools on hardened cement can gather in these pores and fractures and then trickle into the concrete's interior. When frozen, the water expands and can cause the cement to burst apart. Water can also carry a host of damaging chemicals, like the corrosive chlorides of de-icing salts.
Over the years, a number of inventors have tried to eliminate concrete's pores and have had growing success. Organic or carbon-based compounds called super plasticizers have cut down on concrete's water content without reducing its fluid nature when wet.
As a result, the porous structure is finer. "Big pores cease to exist," Dr. Diamond explained, "and the total structure is more homogeneous. It's intrinsically stronger and less prone to corrosion. And the durability is better."
The aim of pore elimination has been furthered by the addition of mineral compounds like extremely fine silica, a hard glassy material that fills many of the remaining voids.
"The resulting concrete is almost as strong as you want, depending on the dosage of additives and the care you invest," Dr. Diamond said. He noted that concrete's compressive strength can be raised from 3,000 to at least 20,000 pounds per square inch, making it exceedingly good at holding heavy loads.
 
A Super-Slim Tower
 High-strength concretes are being used by developers and architects to build not only longer-lasting structures but entirely new kinds of structures. Two Chicago developers, Lee Miglin and J. Paul Beitler, are planning a slender, 2,000-foot-high tower that uses nothing but reinforced concrete for its vertical support. The slender structure is to soar past the Sears Tower, which at 1,454 feet is the world's tallest building.
A hurdle for the planned building was passed in April when the Federal Aviation Administration approved the design, finding that it posed no danger to air traffic.
The building, designed by Cesar Pelli & Associates, makes extensive use of high-strength concretes that can withstand stresses of as much as 14,000 pounds per square inch, much higher than usual.
High-strength mixes are also being used increasingly in more common structures, giving them longer lifetimes.
"It has been quite common to see significant distress in parking garages or bridge decks, due to salt, within a decade," said Lawrence R. Roberts, director of technical services for the construction products division of W. R. Grace & Company, based in Cambridge, Mass. "The people who are currently doing the design work are now expecting services of 40 or 50 years or more."
A startling new property for concrete is flexibility. Concrete can support great weight but has low tensile strength, meaning it cracks or breaks when stretched. That is why concrete is often reinforced with steel bars, which have great tensile strength.
To make concrete hundreds of times more flexible, researchers at Northwestern are adding long, thin fibers of steel, glass and plastic until they make up 10 to 20 percent of the concrete. The fibers prevent minor cracks from enlarging, tying them together in an elastic matrix.
To show the flexibility, Dr. Shah of Northwestern keeps on his desk a strip of concrete that he bends like a plastic ruler for visitors. A goal of the research is to explore the possibility of using elastic concrete to make buildings, roads and bridges that would bend, not break, in earthquakes.
At the leading edge of concrete research is an odd, hybrid material known as macro-defect-free cement, which is loaded with polymers like polyvinyl alcohol. Polymers are long chained molecules, including natural ones like proteins and synthetic ones like nylon. Artificial polymers give macro-defect-free cement the remarkable quality of being virtually pore free, endowing it with amazing strength and exotic qualities.
While relatively costly compared with bulk concrete, it is, for example, a very good electrical insulator, leading center researchers to explore its use for low-cost printed circuit boards, the grids that tie together tiny electronic parts. With further refinement, it may become a cheap replacement for plastics and aluminum, opening up a range of potential uses. Easily extruded from mixing machines into precise shapes, it could be formed into bottles, razor-blade handles or loudspeaker cabinets.
 
Support From Industry
 The range of potential uses for the new concretes and cements is reflected in the list of industrial partners of the foundation's center; the list includes W. R. Grace; Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing , a materials concern; and the Gillette Company, which makes shaving products.
Much exploration of the foundation's aims at trying to predict with great precision the capabilities of the new materials, in particular, how long they will last. To do this, researchers are probing deeply into molecular and atomic structure.
"We have lots of strategies," said Dr. Young of the University of Illinois. "But we don't always know how well they work. You've got to understand this stuff from the bottom up. That's going to become critically important as we start to reconstruct and rehabilitate the nation's infrastructure."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Electron microscope view of new defect-free cement made at Northwestern University shows polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) filling pores between cement particles. (David Lange/Northwestern University) (pg. C1)

HEADLINE: ON HORSE RACING;
Intertrack 'Craze' Lands in Florida

BYLINE: By Joseph Durso

 BODY:
The biggest race in horse racing these days is the race for business.
And since the business of racing is primarily the business of betting, the race is on to find new ways to reach you and your betting money before you spend it someplace else, most likely on a lottery or in some casino in Atlantic City or Las Vegas, Nev. 
 In Florida, for example, people who go to the dog track now can sit there in front of a television screen and bet on horses running at a thoroughbred track someplace else.
And people at a jai alai fronton in Fort Lauderdale can bet on a horse race in Hallandale. Crazy? Maybe. But a lot of things in the economics of sports are crazy these days, and some of them work.
Of course, you can always still go to the race track and bet on a horse you happen to be watching. But that's the old-fashioned way of betting. And because fewer people seem to be doing it, "intertrack wagering" has been born.
This type of wagering is known in the board rooms of the business as I.T.W., and it's the hottest thing in racing -- maybe even the secret weapon of racing. It's being tried in several states on a limited basis, and it's being tried for the first time this year in Florida.
"It's just the tip of the iceberg," Douglas Donn, president of Gulfstream Park, said by telephone from his office the other day. "Like many states, we're starting to emerge into new ways to market our product, and intertrack wagering is one of the ways we're doing it. But it's not the whole answer. There are more ways, and better ways. But offtrack betting and intertrack betting may be what we need to expand ontrack betting.
"Every state is struggling with the economics of racing. The bottom line is: We've got to market our product to a much wider audience. I don't know how it shakes out. But nationally we've got to expand our market or we all get hurt."
Donn's track held the fort this year, despite a downward trend in racing plus the impact of the recession and the war in the Persian Gulf. The tourist season was slow, but Gulfstream Park managed to run 88 days of racing with an average daily attendance of 10,866 spectators and an average betting handle of $1.7 million. The attendance was up 1 percent from 1990, the handle was down about 5 1/2 percent.
But the numbers grow if you add the I.T.W. factor: the people who bet on the horses even when they are going to the dogs, so to speak.
This is called "total attendance," meaning people who attend the races plus those who go someplace else but still bet money into the track's parimutuel system through intertrack wagering; they didn't make the scene, but their money did. There were 1,593 of them on the average afternoon at Gulfstream, and they bet an average of $217,933.
At the current meeting at the Calder track in Miami, the numbers are even rounder: About $550,000 a day is being pumped into the track's parimutuel system from other places, and that's half the amount being wagered inside the track.
"It works in Florida," Donn said, "because there are 12 million people spread around the state. We have maybe 4 million in our market and the 8 million others are outside it. We have to market our product to them."
"In the short term," said John J. Brunetti, the owner of Hialeah Park, "offtrack betting in its various forms will be beneficial. In the long term, it's going to make couch potatoes out of everybody. We still don't market our sport nationally. We're the oldest American sport, and we do nothing to promote it."
Hialeah, once the comeliest track in the land, hasn't contributed to the crazy economics of racing since 1989, when it got into a shooting war with the other tracks in South Florida and tried to operate head-to-head with Calder. It was all part of a longtime vendetta over who should be allowed to race during the peak of the winter tourist season. Hialeah drew only 4,114 fans on opening day, and struck out.
Last year, Hialeah stayed shut while Brunetti went campaigning for a better piece of the action. He eventually got it when the Florida Legislature authorized a season of 50 dates this year for Hialeah, which will reopen Nov. 10 and run through Jan. 7. Then, Gulfstream will hold center stage until March 15.
Next year?
"The solution," Donn suggested, "is for the state to buy Hialeah."
"It's not for sale," Brunetti replied.
You get the feeling that Florida racing is on the brink of something. But they should call a truce in the intertrack warring of the past and focus instead on intertrack wagering and all those other new systems, and find out if they can save the sport of kings for us common people.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Dominance Dwindles For Mets' Pitchers

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
Pitching. Lots of pitching. Lots of good young pitching. For the Mets, it's long been their operating philosophy and strategic premise for success in the National League East.
Too much pitching. Too deep to be hurt badly by injury. Too talented to ever be counted out of the race. For the rest of the division, that's been the conventional wisdom in sizing up the Mets. 
 Consider:
Dwight Gooden, 26 years old, record of 7-5, 1991 earned run average of 3.88; Frank Viola, 31, 2,200 innings pitched, record of 7-5, 1991 earned run average of 2.96; Ron Darling, 30, 25-28 record over last three seasons, 1991 earned run average of 3.92; John Franco, 30, 1-6 record, bad back.
"I don't think you can say we've had dominant pitching this season," said Al Harazin, the executive vice president of the Mets. "But we're spoiled because we're used to having it. It's not been subpar. It's just not the kind we've enjoyed."
Indeed, the pitching for the Mets, routinely, almost robotically referred to as the best in baseball for years, qualified as of yesterday as only fourth best in the National League behind the Dodgers, the Pirates and the Braves. And fourth is where the Mets finished in team pitching in 1990 when they had only the third best outfit in their own division.
 
Opportunity Is There
 "Have we performed as the best starting staff?" Viola asked. "No. But we have, the majority of the time, given our team a chance to win."
Perhaps. But the 35-32 Mets have barely won a majority of those games. Gooden, Viola and David Cone, considered and paid as among the top pitchers in baseball, are a combined 20-15 as the season approaches its halfway mark. As well, not one member of the rotation rates in the league's top 10 for earned run averages.
The figures are no more inspiring when broken down individually.
Gooden, whose 3.83 e.r.a. last season was the highest of his career, has been scored on with greater frequency and more ferocity this season, lit up for five or more earned runs in five of his last seven starts. In a game last Thursday he gave up three home runs for the first time ever.
Viola, whose 2.96 e.r.a. is the highest it's been in nearly a year and a half, has won once in his last five starts, having blown leads in four of them. He has given up 112 hits in 109 1/3 innings as opponents have hit .269 against him. And this from a pitcher who is a career 77-46 before the All-Star Game break and 60-64 after it.
"After last year's second half," said Viola, who lost three critical games down the September stretch in 1990, "I have a lot to prove."
Anyone and everyone can be forgiven for having a lot to ask about Franco's season. While his bad back contributed directly to the recent incredible inflation of his earned run average and further deterioration of his record, Franco has all along given up an abundance of hits and allowed an unhealthy number of walks. As a result, opponents have hit .293 against him, amassing 29 hits in 22 2/3 innings.
"There is no other way to look at it other than to say we've struggled with our pitching," said Rick Cerone, the veteran catcher who has worked more games and seen more pitches than any other on the team. "But there's this way to look at it as a result: Doc has struggled; Frank has struggled; John has struggled, and we're not out of anything yet."
The Mets, however, are not exactly in the thick of anything yet, either, stuck for weeks roughly half a dozen games behind the Pirates.
And so while it may be true, as players and prognosticators said before the season, that the makeup of their pitching has prevented the Mets from suffering a prolonged losing streak, it is equally as true that the essential mediocrity of the pitching over all has precluded a long string of triumphs.
The ostensibly deadly combination of Gooden and Viola, for instance, hasn't put together consecutive triumphs since mid-May. Not surprisingly, the Mets haven't won more than four games in a row or as many as two consecutive series since then, either.
There is, as well, something almost humorous in the current clubhouse cliche that Sid Fernandez's return stands to have a great impact. Fernandez, after all, is the left-hander who can be brilliant or baffled, but who most consistently finds ways to lose.
Fernandez, 9-14 last season, is the sensitive soul who is going to be hard-pressed to overcome his own doubts after breaking his arm in spring training much less overwhelm opposing lineups.
Further, the bullpen, with Franco's future health in doubt, Alejandro Pena's right shoulder chronically in question and rookies regularly in position to determine results, is in a shambles.
"I don't think," said Harazin, "that after two and a half months you can panic."
Maybe, though, it's time to rethink this notion that the pitching is too good for the Mets not to be taken seriously.

HEADLINE: New York's Film Office May Suffer Sharp Cuts

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
A proposal by the New York City Council to make severe cuts in the Mayor's Office for Film, Theater and Broadcast has provoked a chorus of criticism from those in the city's film industry, and in the mayoral and police bureaucracy as well.
On Friday, as part of efforts to close the city's $3.5 billion budget gap, the Council proposed that the $450,000 operating budget of the film office be cut to $250,000; that 5 of the office's 10 staff members be laid off, and that the issuance of film permits be transferred to the New York Police Department. 
 Neither the Mayor nor the Council has released details of the Council's plan, but senior mayoral aides said that the film office proposal was part of the Council's proposal for $476 million more in service cuts than the Mayor has suggested, in an attempt to stave off higher taxes.
"Yes, we're looking at possible cuts in all agencies, but we can't confirm these cuts specifically," a City Council spokesman, Michael S. Clendenin, said about reducing the size of the film office.
 
Council Has the Power
 The Council proposals are a matter of intense negotiation at this point, and in suggesting such cuts the Council did not order them. But by law the Mayor does not have the power to veto spending cuts made by the Council.
Last year, the film office issued 7,100 permits to production teams shooting feature films, television programs, documentaries and commercials in the city. The permits are required for the use of city streets and all city property and equipment.
"To save $200,000, it doesn't make sense to jeopardize a whole industry," said Jaynne C. Keyes, director of the Mayor's film office. "Show me another agency that brings in the kind of returns that we do for our little budget."
New York's film industry, a vital part of the city's economy that is estimated to generate from $500 million to $2.3 billion in business as well as an abundance of ancillary jobs, is still recovering from a bitter stalemate between Hollywood producers and New York film unions that virtually shut down major-studio film making in New York City from last November to mid-May.
Ms. Keyes said that film activity after the boycott "had just begun to pick up." Currently shooting in New York is "Light Sleeper," with Susan Sarandon and Willem Dafoe, and expected this summer are "Glengarry Glen Ross," with Al Pacino, Alec Baldwin and Jack Lemmon; "The Pickle," a film written and directed by Paul Mazursky, as well as the new projects of the film makers Sidney Lumet and Martin Bregman.
 
A Producer Objects
 "The one thing that makes New York attractive for film makers is the one-stop shopping for the permit, and the cooperation that the city gives film makers," said Jeffrey Hayes, co-producer of the NBC television show "Law and Order," which has shot in New York for two years.
"If the Police Department handles the street permits, it will be very difficult for us to work here," he said. "We'd keep colliding with the bureaucracy."
Joseph P. Wuensch, the deputy commissioner for management and budget of the New York Police Department, said of permit-issuing that "we can't do it."
He added: "We just sustained a loss of 626 civilians, and we cannot absorb this kind of new function. We know nothing about the film industry, and the permits would be extraordinarily difficult for us to deal with."
The Mayor's office opposes the Council's proposed cuts as well. "Hopefully by the time we get through our discussion, the City Council will see the light and realize that this is not a very smart thing to do to an industry that we came close to losing," said Jeanne Nathan, a spokeswoman in the office of Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Highland Superstores To Cut Management

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
In its latest effort to cut expenses, Highland Superstores, the financially pressured chain of electronics and appliance stores, said yesterday that it was eliminating five vice presidential positions and that Yale Levin, its chief operating officer, was resigning.
The company, based in Plymouth, Mich., said the management reduction reflected a recent curtailing of its operations and an overall expense-cutting program. Early this month, the company, one of the country's largest electronic chains, said that it had ceased paying creditors and was closing 32 stores in Texas, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island to avoid a bankruptcy court filing. 
 The company's statement yesterday said only that Mr. Levin, 50, would join an unidentifed private company in Detroit and that he would remain a Highland director. Ira Mondry, Highland's president and chief executive officer, will assume Mr. Levin's duties as chief operating officer, and John Brownson, vice president and controller, will succeed Mr. Levin as chief financial officer. Mr. Mondry did not return telephone calls yesterday to his Plymouth office.
Like other regional electronics retailers, Highland's growth in recent years has been stunted, as consumers have pulled back on big-ticket purchases, as they often do in a recession.
In December, after reporting losses from the 92 stores it had then, Highland said it had retained Lehman Brothers to seek a buyer or merger partner. Also in December, Highland reported reaching agreement with its banks to defer half its $22 million in short-term debt payments. Total debt amounts to $52 million.
The company lost $11.8 million in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 on sales of $861 million. The year before, Highland lost $12.4 million on sales of $924.6 million. In the first quarter ended April 30, Highland had a sharply higher loss of $90.2 million, compared with a net loss of $6.7 million the year before.
In its statement yesterday, Highland said David Mondry, Ira's father who is a former company chairman and president and who remains on the board, will return as a full-time vice chairman. The vice presidents whose jobs have been eliminated were in charge of regions, and one was responsible for human relations, Highland said. An associate said that Mr. Levin was not available for comment.
One of the oldest of the appliance store discounters, Highland was founded in 1933 by Harry Mondry. Under his two sons, Eugene and David, the company's sales eventually reached almost $1 billion. But after sales began to suffer in the late 1980's with markets saturated for videocassette recorders and microwave ovens, Highland entered into a prolonged period of losses.

HEADLINE: Reduce New York Taxes and Restructure the State Government

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am responding to "New York's Ordeal: The Tax Exit" (editorial, June 13) on behalf of a 20,000-member public policy organization. 
 New Yorkers carry one of the country's heaviest tax burdens. State and local per capita taxes are the second highest among the 50 states. New York has the fifth highest property taxes, the sixth highest sales taxes and the eighth highest corporate income taxes. New York's taxes have grown faster than those of any other state in the Union.
This year the average New Yorker will have worked 146 days -- from Jan. 1 to May 26 -- to satisfy all Federal, state and local tax collectors. The Tax Foundation ranks New York as having the highest tax burden in the country and shows that New Yorkers surrender an astonishing 40 percent of income to taxes.
These calculations spotlight the ever-increasing state and local tax burdens of New York taxpayers. From 1983 to 1989, the New York taxpayer's burden averaged 31 percent higher than the national average, rising from $916 per individual in 1983 to $1,481 in 1989.
In 1989, New York ranked third in state and local spending combined, a full 47 percent higher than the national average.
Furthermore, since 1983, state spending has risen almost three times as fast as the rate of inflation. From 1983 to 1990, inflation was 35 percent, and spending growth was 97 percent. Clearly, spending restraint, not tax increases, is the answer to New York's budget woes.
For the third year in a row, New Yorkers have had their taxes raised more than $1 billion, including last year's increase of $1.8 billion -- the largest in the state's history.
The only true road to fiscal responsibility is to reduce taxes and restructure government, thus eliminating waste.
 
CHERYL E. HILLEN
Director, New York Citizens for a Sound Economy
Albany, June 13, 1991

HEADLINE: Reduce New York Taxes and Restructure the State Government;
How to Raise Revenue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"New York's Ordeal: The Tax Exit" (editorial, June 13) will be welcomed by working people throughout New York State. Last March, the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. released a report, "Taxes We Can Live With," that made the same point. Our study of taxation, produced by an independent economist, concluded that the way out of the fiscal crisis was to increase revenue by making the tax system more progressive and elastic, chiefly the personal income tax. 
 It did my heart good to see you reject the crude argument that we can't raise taxes because business will flee. As you observe, this is a one-sided view of the way in which business makes location decisions. New York State has some room to raise taxes without damaging its competitive position.
Finally, you are correct to point out that long-run structural problems affect the state tax system. The system is inelastic. Tax revenue growth does not keep pace with economic growth, hence recurring, widening deficits. Resorting to borrowing, one-shot gimmicks, such as selling Aqueduct Race Track, harassing motorists with surcharges on parking tickets and imposing regressive taxes on energy products, has put us deeper into the hole.
 
EDWARD J. CLEARY
President
New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O.
New York, June 13, 1991
