HEADLINE: Dow Drops By 52.55, To 2,913.01

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Stock prices plunged yesterday, as the market was buffeted by an unusual combination of a Japanese brokerage scandal and signs of a worsening domestic economy underscored by declining corporate earnings.
 A reduction in the earnings estimates of analysts for several technology companies also weighed on the market, as did a weaker dollar in the face of a stronger German mark and British pound. 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 52.55 points, or 1.77 percent, to 2,913.01. But there was no panic selling, as volume on the New York Stock Exchange shrank to 138 million shares, from 194.6 million on Friday. Still, only 308 Big Board issues closed with gains, while 1,331 posted losess.
 
Heavy Selling in Japan
 The Japanese scandal centers on charges that top brokerage houses guaranteed to repay part or all the investment losses of big clients. The unfolding scandal led to heavy selling on the Japanese stock exchanges and fears that Japanese investors would unload portfolios of largely blue-chip stocks later in London and New York.
 In the wake of the Japanese brokerage scandal, troubling questions remain about Tokyo's financial markets. [News analysis, page D9.]
 Computerized trading programs tended to add momentum to yesterday's decline in New York until 3:48 P.M., or 12 minutes before Big Board trading ends, when the Dow had lost 50 points. Under the exchange's rules, all computer programs must cease when the Dow falls or rises 50 points.
 
Net Program Loss of 19.69
 Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, found only one buy and three sell programs during the day, the net result was a decline of 19.69 points on the Dow. In all, the programs lasted a total of 52 minutes, much of it late in the session when the sell programs were in operation.
 "While both London and New York were depressed, neither market saw any panic selling, or in fact any significant selling by Japanese portfolio managers," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall-21st Advisers. "What we did see was a continued flow of poor company earnings and lowering of projected profits, particularly in the already weakened software and technology sectors. Weak commodity prices also tell us that an economic recovery is not yet in sight."
 Given the low volume, Mr. Stovall continued, it was apparent that more investors moved to the sidelines than were motivated to sell. But those who did sell often found somewhat wider price movements than usual, which is common in days of light volume.
 Partly as a result, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 largely blue-chip issues closed down 6.81 points, to 370.94. The new S.& P. index of 400 middle-capitalized stocks dropped 2.43 points, to 120.92. The much broader Big Board composite index fell 3.37 points, to 203.50.
 Typical of the blue chips that were battered yesterday was I.B.M., which fell 1 1/4, to 98 3/8, and was the Big Board's second-most-active issue on a volume of 2.3 million shares.
 Other losers among the more active issues was General Motors, down 2 7/8, to 41 1/4; Ford Motor, off 1 1/8, to 36 5/8, and Chrysler, which slipped 1/8, to 13 3/4. Waste Management fell 1 1/8, to 36 1/2, and was the fifth most-active issue with 1.5 million shares traded.
 The only gainer on the Big Board's list of the 10 most-active issues was Columbia Gas Systems, which was ravaged last week after its management omitted a divend payment and said it was contemplating bankruptcy. Columbia Gas rose 1, to 18 1/8, and placed fourth in volume with 1.7 million shares traded.
 Among some popular issues that showed declines because of reduced earnings estimates were Motorola, down 1 3/8, to 64 5/8; Tandy, off 1 3/8, to 27 3/4; Lubrizol, down 5 7/8, to 44, on a turnover of 760,000 shares, and Burlington Northern, which lost 3, to 28 7/8. Technology Stocks Depressed
 But the most depressed sector of the market remained the computer, semiconductor and technology stocks. Some fell victim to lowered earnings estimates by analysts and some admitted to having problems filling and shiping orders.
 Those issues weighed down the Nasdaq composite index in particular, because it includes many semiconductor and technology stocks. The index closed down 10.59 points, to 475.23.
 Among the largest losers in the group were Sun Microsystems, down 4 1/8, to 25 1/2; Microsoft, off 4 1/8, to 98 1/8; Control Data, off 1 3/8, to 9 1/2; Intel, down 3 1/4, to 43 3/4, and International Rectifier, off 1 1/4, to 14 1/4.

Although he Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 178.90 points at midday, it surged back to gain 141.96, or six-tenths of a percent, and close at 23,907.42. It lost 509.62 on Monday.

HEADLINE: Quiet Czech Triumph: Russians Out

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, June 25

 BODY:
In a modest ceremony at the Foreign Ministry, a milestone in Czechoslovak history was reached today. Lieut. Gen. Eduard Vorobyov, commander of Soviet forces, and Lieut. Gen. Rudolf Duchacek of the Czechoslovak Army signed a protocol ending 23 years of Soviet military occupation.
The last units of the army that arrived as invaders in 1968 left last week. Only a rock concert on Monday night marked the event; it was attended mainly by people who were not yet born in 1968. 
 The Government issued no declaration. "All these things are so dead now, there's no use to talk of them very much," Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier said in an interview.
Despite this ostentatiously cool attitude, President Vaclav Havel's leadership has from the beginning made the departure of the Soviet Army a top priority. The leaders regard it as much more than a military or diplomatic goal; they see it as the restoration of national sovereignty.
For Czechoslovaks, the presence of Soviet troops was not, as it was for their Polish, Hungarian and East German neighbors, a fact of life resulting from their being liberated from Nazi rule by the Soviet Army in 1944-45. The liberating troops, Soviet and American, left Czechoslovakia at the end of World War II.
 
Architect of the Withdrawal
 Soviet armies did not return until Aug. 21, 1968, when they and the armies of four Warsaw Pact allies invaded to crush the liberalization of the "Prague Spring." The Soviet troops served until now as symbol of the force that reversed the will of the nation and subjected it to physical foreign domination.
"It was a task we set for ourselves as the beginning of the restoration of our national sovereignty," said Defense Minister Lubos Dobrovsky, who, as Deputy Foreign Minister shortly after the overthrow of the Communist dictatorship in November 1989 and in his present post, was the chief architect of the withdrawal.
Mr. Havel placed this mission at the top of the agenda when he assumed the presidency after the revolution that he led, Mr. Dobrovsky said in an interview in his modest apartment in a public housing project at the edge of the city.
"At the beginning of 1990 he formed a group with the task of persuading the Russians to negotiate," he said. By February, that was achieved.
Just as Mr. Havel changed almost overnight from being the most persecuted and imprisoned opponent into the leader of the nation, so did Mr. Dobrovsky become a figure of poetic justice as he negotiated the Soviet Army withdrawal.
When the invasion occurred, he was in Moscow as the Prague radio's correspondent, serving from what had become the enemy capital as a voice of Czechoslovak protest. Information that he was no longer free to broadcast he passed to an American friend to bring to the attention of the world.
In October 1968, Moscow expelled him, and his last contact with the Soviet Union before arriving there 21 years later as principal negotiator was five hours of harassment and search at the border crossing.
"The negotiations were extremely difficult," the minister said. "From the very beginning we had to persuade them to accept our basic position. It was that we were not equal partners. You are occupiers; you have to leave, and you shall also bear the political, moral and material costs of the invasion."
"There were moments that were very tense," Mr. Dobrovsky continued. Czechoslovak diplomacy was restricted by the fact that Mr. Dobrovsky and his associates could not push so hard as to make the Russians walk out, a possibility that he said might have delayed the withdrawal by a decade. Also, he said, there was always a suggestion that Moscow might apply economic pressures. Czechoslovak industry depends on Soviet energy and raw materials.
 
The Turning Point
 At a crucial point, Mr. Dobrovsky said, when the talks in Moscow seemed deadlocked, he proposed an exchange of letters between President Havel and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev "to calm the negotiations." This provided the turning point, he continued, and by spring of last year the rapid withdrawal of the 70,000 soldiers was agreed on.
The minister said the negotiations ran parallel with talks to liquidate the military structure of the Warsaw Pact, an event that took place this year.
"On this protocol there is my signature as Defense Minister," Mr. Dobrovsky said. "I am not very often emotional at such events, but signing this I felt enormous satisfaction. I felt that at that moment the sovereignty of Czechoslovakia as an independent state was fully restored."
Mr. Dobrovsky paid tribute to Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister. "Without his deep understanding for our efforts, the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact and the withdrawal of Soviet troops would have been much more complicated," he said. "Certain political forces in the Soviet Union cannot forgive Shevardnadze for this."
 
No Sense of Revenge
 Mr. Dienstbier, another former journalist, who served four years in prison as a dissident, said he and Mr. Shevardnadze reached a compromise under which Prague gave Moscow up to 18 months to leave rather than one year.
Other than admitting to a moment of emotion at signing the Warsaw Pact into oblivion, the 59-year-old Mr. Dobrovsky said he felt no personal gratification or sense of revenge at his reversal of fortune. His appointment to high office followed 21 years spent as a window washer, boiler-room stoker and victim of political persecution.
"All I lived through was the normal continuity of life," he said. "The fact that I was once a journalist is as fortuitous as that I later became a window washer and am now Defense Minister."
In a response that marks a widespread sentiment among leaders of the former dissident movement, Mr. Dobrovsky rejected special credit for his role in 21 years of illegal opposition.
"It is always misleading when one sees actions of dissent as other than personal actions," he said. "All I did in dissent I did to preserve my own self. If my activities had a side effect, a secondary result that led to conditions to make possible the overthrow of the regime, so much the better. But this was not the principal aim of our activity."
On the contrary, the minister accepted for himself and other dissenters a share of the blame for the years of Soviet domination. "We let it be done to us all too easily," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The signing of a protocol yesterday in Prague formally ended 23 years of occupation by Soviet armed forces that began with the invasion in 1968. Lieut. Gen. Eduard Vorobyov of the Soviet Union, left, and Lieut. Gen. Rudolf Duchacek of the Czechoslovak Army signed the agreement. Czech leaders regard the departure of Soviet troops as a restoration of their country's national sovereignty. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Car Wars: More Bad News

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
HAVE you driven a Ford (or a Chrysler or a G.M. car) lately? As Detroit learned in the 1980's, a customer lost to Japanese car makers is often lost for good.
But according to Fred Mannering and Clifford Winston, that is only the beginning of the bad news, not the end. American auto companies may finally be making cars that are attractive to owners of foreign cars. But the gap in brand loyalty between American and Japanese makes, the researchers conclude, virtually guarantees that the Detroit auto makers will continue to lose sales to their Japanese rivals. 
 The Mannering-Winston analysis, published last week in the Brookings Papers on Economic Activity, is likely to impress professional number crunchers. The big question is whether it will make any waves in the Motor City, which has yet to design a successful defense against the invasion of the Japanese customer snatchers.
In a perfect world, shoppers could ferret out everything they wanted to know about a car before signing on the dotted line. Brand loyalty would not exist because more tangible predictors of quality and reliability would always be available: The year G.M. came out with a better sporty subcompact, customers would beat a path to its door.
But in the real world, solid information is scarce and the choices are bewilderingly profuse. Every car buyer worries that his love affair with those alluring new wheels on the showroom floor will end in bitterness and betrayal. Brands thus serve as a surrogate for what cannot easily be measured: If the aging Camry in the garage delivered the goods, it is only prudent to test-drive another.
Mr. Mannering and Mr. Winston used statistical techniques to isolate brand loyalty from the other factors that determined car purchases over the last two decades for a sample of some 500 households. All six companies with sufficient sales to generate statistically reliable data (General Motors, Ford Motor, Chrysler, Nissan, Honda and Toyota) did engender some degree of brand loyalty. But the differences among makes and the changes in loyalty over time were striking.
Before 1980, loyalty to American and Japanese brands was roughly the same. Holding other factors constant, the owner of a Toyota or a Honda or G.M. car was roughly seven percentage points more likely to buy another than a person lacking experience with the brand. If, for example, G.M. had 35 percent of the market, 42 percent of all owners of G.M. cars could be expected to make a repeat purchase.
But after 1980, loyalty rates diverged. Honda's, Toyota's and Nissan's loyalty edge grew to 14 percentage points, while Ford's and G.M.'s slipped to just 3. And with more owners of Japanese cars sticking by their brands, Japan's share of the market naturally tended to rise.
Brand loyalty is not, of course, the only factor influencing car choices. The Mannering-Winston analysis suggests that Detroit could have kept its share of the market simply by holding down prices. In the one case where Toyota and G.M. split the output of identical cars that the two companies jointly produced in California, G.M. was able to unload its half by underpricing Toyota by $1,600 a car.
But buying market share is an expensive option, one that Detroit has generally been loathe to take. Mr. Mannering and Mr. Winston calculate that the divergence in brand loyalty cost the Big Three roughly 7.2 million car sales over the 1980's. If this gap does not narrow, the researchers estimate that Detroit's 73.5 percent share of the market in 1989 will erode to 62.7 percent by 1999.
The obvious point here -- a point that has become the mantra of business school babble -- is that attention to quality and service pays off. But Mr. Mannering and Mr. Winston suggest some subtler lessons:
*It was probably not in Detroit's long-term interest to match Japanese price increases in the late 1980's. The increases certainly assured big profits for the Big Three and big bonuses for management. But exceptionally high levels of brand loyalty to Japanese cars will make it hard to woo back customers lost during these years.
*Producing good cars is not always enough. To get the most out of hard-earned good will, product lines must evolve with their markets. Honda, for example, has capitalized on the success of the Accord by building bigger, plusher models to match the family sizes, waistlines and buying power of its aging loyalists. The 1991 Ford Taurus, by contrast, is virtually the same as the 1985 version.
*Since brand loyalty is really a soft substitute for hard information, the best strategy for offsetting the loyalty factor is getting more, credible information to customers. One radical approach to that end would be to encourage Washington to collect and disseminate data on vehicle reliability, repair costs and customer satisfaction.
All this assumes, of course, that American cars are now competitive on the merits. If you don't have it, there is no point in flaunting it.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher After Durable-Goods Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly higher yesterday after the Government reported that orders for durable goods were showing more strength than had been expected.
Gold prices also advanced. In New York, gold rose $1.60 to $364.60 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $364.25, up $1.05.
The Commerce Department said durable goods orders rose 3.8 percent in May, the largest gain in more than a year.
The report was considered further evidence of a strengthening economy. An improving economy raises the prospects for higher interest rates, which support the dollar by increasing demand for American investments. The dollar tends to rise on good economic news.
But Kevin Logan, chief economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, said the dollar's gains were limited, in part because "the recovery idea is already built into the market."
"What the market would need to advance," he said, "is stronger news."
 
Pound Drops
 The British pound fell against the dollar, closing at $1.6310 in New York, down from $1.6470 late Friday. In earlier London trading, sterling fell to $1.6280, from $1.6425 late Monday.
But the dollar fell against the Japanese yen. Mr. Logan said the yen was helped by a Japanese news report that said the monetary officials of the Group of Seven industrialized nations had agreed to intervene in currency markets if the dollar rose to 140 yen.
The dollar fell to 138.30 yen in New York from 138.70 yen late Monday. In Tokyo overnight, long before the report crossed news tickers, the dollar fell 1.39 yen, to 138.38 yen. In London, it was quoted at 138.75 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.7935 German marks, up from 1.7830; 1.5498 Swiss francs, up from 1.5345; 6.0890 French francs, up from 6.0545; 1,336.00 Italian lire, up from 1,326.00, and 1.14195 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14255.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, included: 1.7965 German marks, up from 1.7845; 1.5525 Swiss francs, up from 1.5335; 6.0980 French francs, up from 6.0595; 1,337.25 Italian lire, up from 1,328.00, and 1.1419 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1427.
In early trading in London, gold rose to a late bid of $364.20, from $361.20 late Monday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $363.50, from $361.00. In Hong Kong, gold fell $2.29, to close at a bid of $363.63.

HEADLINE: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Off Slightly

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposits and money market accounts continued their slide in the week ended yesterday.
But the Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., predicts the numbers will probably remain stable for a while. 
 "The story is that we are now at the bottom of a 26-month down cycle in interest rates," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of the trade publication. "Investors can expect to see the numbers remain flat for some time because of the weak economy."
Money market accounts at New York area banks and savings institutions averaged 5.35 percent, he said. At commercial banks the average was 5.14 percent and at the savings institutions 5.56 percent. In each case the yields fell 1 basis point. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The yield on Manufacturers Hanover's three-month and six-month certificates had the largest yield change among commercial banks, dropping 11 basis points, to 5.60 percent and 5.65 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Up 3.8% in May

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
New orders for manufactured durable goods rose 3.8 percent in May, the second straight sizable increase and the biggest in more than a year, the Commerce Department reported today.
The rise, combined with other figures released today on home sales, consumer confidence and auto sales, added significantly to evidence that the economy is climbing out of recession. The report also dispelled doubts raised by recent data on unemployment claims and machine tool orders. 
 "I think the economy has turned around," said Carl J. Palash, senior economist at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc., a New York consulting firm. He added that the rise in durable goods orders, which most economists regard as a predictive indicator, "points to a pretty robust recovery in manufacturing."
That was also the message in the day's other data. Sales of existing homes rebounded 6 percent in May to the highest level since December 1989, and the Conference Board's consumer confidence index rose to 78.0 in June, from 76.4 the month before. [Page D2.]
 
April Level Revised Higher
 Not only was the durable goods increase somewhat larger than expected, it was also calculated from an April level that was revised upward to show a gain of 3.6 percent instead of the 3 percent initially reported.
Shipments of durable goods advanced 1 percent in May, the second straight increase after five monthly declines, and unfilled orders edged down one-tenth of a percent.
The rise in orders for durables -- goods from dishwashers to locomotives that are designed to last at least three years -- embraced all leading industries except electronics and electrical equipment. Orders for transportation equipment soared 11.5 percent, those for industrial machinery and equipment jumped 4 percent and those for primary metals rose eight-tenths of 1 percent. Electronics orders fell 2.6 percent after jumping 10.8 percent in April.
"The best element is the widespread increase in new orders, particularly in the critical area of non-defense capital goods," observed Gordon Richards, an economist at the National Association of Manufacturers. This category, which includes factory equipment, posted a 4.2 percent advance after a 10 percent drop in April.
Analysts even found some reassurance in a report that sales of cars and light trucks for themiddle third of this month fell a modest 2.4 percent from levels of a year earlier. The period's annual sales pace of 6.5 million was about the same as the industry's third-quarter production plans.
Nevertheless, a notable minority of economists expect the recovery to abort within months, creating a double-dip recession like four of the previous eight since World War II.
One analyst in this camp, Sung Won Sohn of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, who is head of the American Bankers Association's economic advisory committee, cited high consumer debt, a rising tax burden and continued caution among lenders.
The durable-goods report showed that while the volatile military and transportation sectors had very large increases, these accounted for only a portion of the overall 3.8 percent advance, the biggest since March 1990. Capital goods orders for the military soared 21.1 percent.
 
Non-Military Orders Up 2.5%
 With military orders excluded, new orders still rose 2.5 percent, after a 2.8 percent gain in April and a decline of 3.8 percent in March.
For capital goods industries, the 7.8 percent gain in May contrasted with an average 6.3 percent decline for March and April. Non-military orders, excluding aircraft and parts, rose 2.9 percent after increasing 3.9 percent in April and falling 6.8 percent in March.
Total durable goods orders except for transportation rose 1.4 percent, after a 5.9 percent gain in April that was the first improvement this year. Analysts recognize that the transportation figures are often skewed by orders for the Boeing Company's aircraft. That company's backlog is measured in years.
Total durable goods orders were $120.5 billion last month, or $4.4 billion more than in April. Orders for machine tools, which tumbled 19.6 percent in May, account for less than 1 percent of durable goods.

HEADLINE: Brazilian Leader Acts to Protect the Amazon

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 25

 BODY:
Facing criticism over Brazil's Amazon policies, President Fernando Collor de Mello has dismissed the head of Brazil's Indian protection agency and has unveiled a program to allow foreign financing of environmental projects here.
In another move, he abolished tax subsidies today that had made it profitable to cut down Amazon rain forest for farming and ranching. 
 The steps, hailed by environmentalists here, came after Mr. Collor visited Washington last week and heard eight American senators urge the Brazilian Government "to live up to its commitments on the environment and human rights in the Amazon."
The international criticism comes at a particularly sensitive moment. Next month, at the meeting of the seven leading industrial democracies in London, Brazil plans to submit a proposal for $1.5 billion in grants for a five-year program for conservation of the Brazilian rain forests.
At home, Brazilian environmentalists charge that during Mr. Collor's 15 months as President he has slashed money for Amazon preservation projects and has failed to fulfill promises to demarcate Indian lands.
The annual Amazon burning season is under way, just as Brazil's environmental agency has been paralyzed by a three-week-old strike over low pay. Of $8 million budgeted for a fire prevention program in the Amazon, only $900,000 has actually been disbursed to the agency.
On the Indian issue, Brazil's Constitution stipulates that by October 1993 the Government must survey and give legal protection to 237 areas identified as Indian homelands.
"With the Government one year old, the process of demarcation has practically stopped," reads a new report on Indian lands by the Ecumenical Center for Documentation and Information, a church group.
In Washington, Mr. Collor reportedly was irritated to learn from American lawmakers and environmentalists that up to 8,000 gold miners had reinvaded lands of the Yanomami Indian tribe. Last year, the police expelled as many as 30,000 miners from the area.
On Friday, the day after he returned from Washington, Mr. Collor dismissed Cantidio Guerreiro Guimaraes, president of Funai, Brazil's Indian protection agency. Mr. Collor said the agency head dragged his feet on demarcating a continuous Yanomami reserve in Brazil's northern state of Roraima.
"The miners are a constant menace to the health of the Yanomami," Mr. Collor said in an interview before his United States trip. "We have to guarantee the Yanomami a space so they don't lose their cultural identity or their habitat."
This week, Brazil's federal police are to resume a program of evacuating miners and dynamiting their airstrips.
Claudia Andujar, a longtime critic of Brazil's policies toward the Yanomami, said today that she believed Mr. Collor was now serious about demarcating a reserve.
"We think that with all this international pressure, President Collor is entirely interested in speeding demarcation," said Ms. Andujar, who is coordinator of a private group, the Commission for the Creation of a Yanomami Park.
In another policy turnaround, Mr. Collor announced Monday that he will allow $100 million of Brazilian debt to be exchanged every year for financing for environmental projects.
Under this financing mechanism, a foreign government or private nature group buys Brazilian debt on the secondary market, where it currently trades for 34 percent of face value. The Brazilian Government then retires the debt by paying 70 to 75 percent of its face value into a local currency account for environmental projects.
Last year, Brazilian environmentalists drew up a list of $25 million of potential projects -- training park guards, surveying park boundaries, endowing Amazon study institutes and buying jeeps and helicopters.
Although already in use in several Latin American nations, the so-called "debt for nature swaps" never started here because of opposition by Zelia Cardoso de Mello, Brazil's Economy Minister until early May.

HEADLINE: A REVIVAL IS SEEN FOR 'JUNK BONDS' AS MARKET GAINS

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
The Wall Street market for high-risk corporate bonds, which fueled the corporate takeovers of the 1980's only to collapse after a series of defaults and bankruptcies, is showing signs of life.
More than a year after the bankruptcy of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which pioneered and promoted the market, prices for high-risk, low-grade "junk bonds" have improved sharply, the market seems calmer and major buyers, sellers and underwriters are starting to describe the recovery as viable and real. 
 If a new junk bond market takes hold, the effects will be felt from Wall Street to Washington. Companies in need of credit would be less dependent on scarce bank loans. The owners of junk bonds, including a host of savings and loan institutions and insurance companies, would be able to value their assets more accurately and sell them more easily and at better prices.
 
Rescue Cost Could Be Cut
 That, in turn, could pare the bill for rescuing insolvent savings and loans and ease the strain on the nation's insurance industry.
Junk bonds are corporate bonds whose creditworthiness is at the low end of the grading scale used by Wall Street rating agencies. They came to prominence during the 1980's when they were used by many corporate raiders to stage hostile takeovers that reshaped some of America's largest corporations, and that were blamed for plant closings, job losses and community upheavals.
The collapse of many junk bond deals also caused bruising losses for many individual investors who were initially attracted to their eye-catching yields. With the bankruptcy of Drexel and the criminal prosecution of Michael R. Milken, the head of the firm's junk bond operation, the market shriveled and seemed on the verge of vanishing.
But the market seems to have confounded its critics. It has weathered both the Persian Gulf war and an economic recession, two developments that were widely thought to be deadly for junk bond investors. The market is coping surprisingly well with the junk bond sales conducted as part of the Federal bailout of insolvent savings and loans that were major junk bond holders.
Market research is broader, as firms like Merrill Lynch, Salomon Brothers and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette have stepped in to fill the knowledge gap left by Drexel's demise. And new ways of obtaining current, realistic prices are springing up to guide the traders who are tiptoeing back to the game.
The clearest sign of recovery is the market's ability to absorb new issues. Since January, three major corporations, RJR Nabisco, Chiquita Brands and Johnston Coca-Cola Bottling Group, have been able to find buyers for a total of $1.85 billion worth of newly issued junk bonds. At least three more new issues totaling $675 million have been announced. Last year, by contrast, only $385.8 million worth of new junk bonds were issued publicly, most of it by only two corporations.
 
'Fundamental Reason to Exist'
 "The market has a fundamental reason to exist," said Garrett Moran, managing director of the high-yield bond department at Donaldson, Lufkin. "Companies need to raise money to grow their company or make sensible acquisitions. The market is a lot smaller, the deals will be smaller, and the buyer universe will be smaller. But if the deals make sense you'll be surprised how many buyers there are."
Donaldson, Lufkin did almost $1 billion worth of private junk bond financings last year because "there was so much dislocation in the public market," Mr. Moran added. "If I had those deals to do today, I'd do them as public deals -- there's absolutely no question about it."
Philip Sanford, senior vice president and treasurer of Johnston Coca-Cola in Chattanooga, Tenn., said he would have been leery of trying to raise money in the junk bond market a year ago. " Clearly there were questions created about the marketplace," he added. "Any issuer would have felt less comfortable than now. But our recent issue was very successful. Our underwriters tell us it was oversubscribed, with new buyers as well as repeat buyers."
Those who buy bonds also see a sharp improvement. "The market machinery is much stronger that it was," said Morris W. Offit, chief executive of Offitbank, a New York money manager specializing in bonds. "You have securities firms committing more resources to the area, in terms of trading, research and sales distribution. And institutional portfolios are taking a close look at the issues. There is still enough of a yield differential to give you an incentive to buy, as long as you do your homework."
 
Reminder to Investors
 For now, no one is predicting that this reborn junk market will grow into the behemoth it became in the 1980's, when junk bonds fueled a binge of poorly structured deals that made Wall Street rich and left many American corporations laden with expensive debt. Indeed, the failure of many of those companies to pay their bond obligations today is a constant reminder to investors that junk bonds remain a risky venture. But even major defaults do not rattle the market as they once did, as investors have become better at assessing the debt renegotiation process.
"It's not a completely healthy market yet," said Kingman Penniman, senior vice president in the MCM Investment Research unit at Duff & Phelps, a credit rating agency in Chicago. "But it's certainly been wheeled out of critical care and into the recovery room."
The prognosis was far less encouraging in the months immediately after Drexel limped from the scene. Firm price quotations were difficult to come by, the available quotes were at fire-sale levels, few dealers were willing to make trades, and analysts were leaving the market in droves. Then came last summer, with the threat of war, an economic recession and an uncertain regulatory climate.
 
Surprises on Regulatory Front
 It has helped, of course, that the gulf war ended so quickly, and that the recession's end is almost, if not certainly, in sight. But market analysts say the real surprises have been on the regulatory front, most notably, the skill with which the Resolution Trust Corporation has handled the $9.1 billion portfolio of junk bonds it accumulated in the course of the savings and loan bailout.
Fears that a clumsy liquidation of that portfolio would swamp the unsteady junk market have proved groundless. "I give them all the credit in the world," said Martin S. Fridson, managing director of Merrill Lynch's high-yield research unit. "They have felt their way along to see how much they can sell, and how quickly. They've handled it extremely well, and that has reassured the market."
Market participants have also started to solve some of the information problems that plagued them last year. Duff & Phelps, for example, is offering a new electronic service to provide daily price quotations, based on actual transactions, for 100 junk bonds, and weekly price quotes for more than 200 additional issues.
And a six-month rally has helped push junk bond prices up to levels that are attracting the attention of professional investors. The investment return on junk bonds this year, as measured by Merrill Lynch's high-yield bond index, is up nearly 20 percent, after a 4.35 percent decline last year. The flow of funds into junk bond mutual funds is improving, and some pension funds have been shopping in the higher-grade end of the junk market, portfolio managers report.
Although the economic forecast and the gyrations of the stock market still have a powerful effect on junk bond prices, the tone of the market is so much improved that the chief junk bond analyst at Salomon Brothers reversed his earlier pessimism and endorsed junk bonds early last week as a good long-term investment.
"I had not been bullish for two years," said Joseph C. Bencivenga, the director of high-yield research at Salomon. "But I am definitely optimistic now. When things are fairly priced, it is hard for people to argue with the product."
Mr. Fridson, of Merrill Lynch, is similarly encouraged. "The market adjusted very quickly to all its problems, and now we're in a position where you can do a reasonable level of business," he said. "We're not going to get back to the Drexel days, with $30 billion in new issuance a year. But there's a reasonable flow of business, and people are feeling much better about the conditions in the market."
 
Nervousness on Insurers
 The market is still nervously waiting to see how state insurance regulators handle the insolvencies of the First Executive Corporation and the First Capital Corporation, two insurance holding companies that had invested heavily in junk bonds. "That's the next 800-pound gorilla this market has to deal with," said Mr. Bencivenga. "Together, they have about $14 billion to $15 billion worth of junk bonds and nobody is eager to see that hit the market." But the regulators have indicated that they will not liquidate the portfolio in a hasty fashion, he added, so he is not unduly alarmed.
Not everyone in the market is as confident. Some analysts point out that defaults are expected in about $20 billion worth of junk bonds this year, not counting bond issues that are renegotiated before an official default. That is almost 10 percent of the total market, and five times the default level the market had expected back in the early 1980's.
 
Warning by Magazine
 Investment Dealer's Digest, a magazine serving the brokerage community, recently ran a cautionary cover story warning that the mutual funds that are now investing in junk bonds could flee the market just as quickly at the first sign of trouble, increasing volatility and demolishing prices. The magazine warned traders against becoming overly optimistic.
But for Mr. Bencivenga, this cover story itself was evidence of the market's changed mood; it is unthinkable, he said, that any publication would have felt it necessary or newsworthy to emphasize the junk bond market's weaknesses just a few months ago.
"This is the way markets work," he said. "They overreact in both directions. We're coming off a huge bottom, where investors overreacted in pounding prices down. We've weeded out the players who don't want to be here. What's left are the people who do want to be here. All told, I think we're poised for continued double-digit annual returns, despite the defaults."

HEADLINE: Interstate Banking Provision Survives House Panel Votes

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's proposal to eliminate barriers to interstate banking survived a concentrated assault in the House Banking Committee today.
In the Administration's banking package, the interstate provision is widely considered the plank most likely to succeed in Congress. 
 But there is significant opposition to other parts of the package that the committee will take up this week, including elimination of restrictions dating to the Depression that prevent commercial banks and investment banks from merging and that also limit the ability of industrial enterprises to own banks.
The steady erosion of the fund that insures bank deposits has put the banking legislation on a fast track, and Administration officials hope the insurance fund's plight will provide a political impetus for Congress to adopt its legislation by fall. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress that audits the insurance fund, has said the fund is virtually insolvent -- an opinion not shared by the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, L. William Seidman, who maintains that the fund was worth $8.4 billion at the end of last year.
 
Time Is Running Out
 With Congress in session less than five weeks between now and the middle of September, a growing number of lawmakers say there is not enough time to craft sweeping legislation this year.
At this point, the most likely result seen by lawmakersis a banking bill that would allow a few changes for the industry, such as more liberal rules on interstate banking, and would refinance the insurance fund by permitting it to borrow up to $30 billion from the Treasury. Administration officials fear that once Congress addresses the plight of the insurance fund, there may not be enough political support to muster more changes next year.
Today, the House banking committee rejected a series of amendments that would have either deleted or drastically watered down the interstate banking section of the Administration's legislation.
 
A Hamiltonian Tilt
 While the names were not invoked, the debate today has its roots in almost 200 years of argument going back to Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton over the roles of community banks versus national banks in the economy. The committee's votes strongly endorsed the Hamiltonian view of empowering the national banks to expand into new states at the possible expense of the community institutions.
By a vote of 35 to 15, the committee rejected a measure by Representative Bruce F. Vento, Democrat of Minnesota, that would continue to permit state legislators to determine whether out-of-state banks could open new branches in their states. The measure has been widely supported by organizations representing the states, state regulators and community bankers.
"What the amendment does is restore the voice of states in the area of interstate branching," Mr. Vento said.
Opposing the amendment, Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said that "very few members have a consistent preference for the Federal or the state level."
The committee then rejected by a vote of 26 to 23 an amendment that, among other things, would have given state legislatures three years to opt out of interstate banking and branching.
An amendment by Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, to require banks interested in expanding to have a higher level of capital to absorb losses, was defeated 25 to 24.
 
A Break for Low-Cost Accounts
 The committee also adopted a measure that would reduce the Federal insurance fund premiums for banks that provide loans to distressed neighborhoods and offer low-cost accounts to low-income customers.
The amendment, introduced by Representative Thomas J. Ridge, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Representative Floyd Flake, Democrat of New York, passed by a vote of 37 to 11. It would reduce bank premiums to 11.5 cents per $100 for all low-cost, limited accounts now offered to lower-income customers. Beginning next month, banks are to pay 23 cents per $100 in deposits.
The amendment would also provide banks with a discount in their premiums equal to 5 percent of all increased deposits and loans provided in distressed neighborhoods. The discount is capped at 20 percent of the bank's total assessment.

HEADLINE: Few of the Working Poor Get Houses in S.& L. Rescue Plan

SERIES: Vanishing Homes - First of two articles.

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
It's a tale of dreams gone awry.
When Congress created the Resolution Trust Corporation in 1989 to clean up the savings and loan mess, it decided to set aside thousands of foreclosed houses and apartments as low-cost housing for low-income people. 
 The notion was elegant in its simplicity: housing for the needy, thanks to the savings and loan crisis. The Government could provide decent shelter without spending a dime on new public housing. And the working poor, at long last, could own a home at a price they could pay.
It has not worked out like that. Virtually everyone agrees that the program has fallen short of its goals, though how far short is in dispute.
 
Harsh Views Expressed
 "It's an unmitigated disaster," said Richard Jordan, a former board member of the Texas Housing Authority and a real estate investor. "The Government had the unprecedented opportunity to disperse people into single-family detached homes and it hasn't. Why? Because the program stinks."
Mr. Jordan is not alone in his view. Members of Congress and advocates of affordable housing say the Government has failed almost completely to exploit an important and rare opportunity.
Resolution Trust acknowledges that thus far only a small portion of the houses in the program have gone to the poor. But officials insist they have labored to devise policies to tackle an extremely difficult task, and they say that such a program cannot be established overnight. Stephen S. Allen, the corporation's head of affordable housing, said that under the circumstances "what we have accomplished has been remarkable."
 
Middle Class Gets Bargain
 At any rate, thousands of inexpensive homes that could have gone to low-income buyers under the program have, in fact, been siphoned off and bought by investors. Middle-class buyers, who could otherwise afford housing, have been flocking to take advantage of bargain prices. And the working poor who could benefit the most from this program have been virtually shut out by, among other things, a lack of mortgages for them.
The program's critics contend that the Bush Administration, which fiercely opposed the program when it was initially set up by Congress, has actively tried to scuttle it through policies that discriminate against the poor.
Among them was a program that offered bigger discounts and better financing to sophisticated investors than to low-income buyers. Some of these policies have changed, housing advocates say, but the basic problems still exist.
"This has been a tremendous lost opportunity," said Frank H. Shafroth, director of Federal relations for the National League of Cities in Washington. "Something wonderful could have happened to a lot of families in America. But it didn't."
Representative Bruce F. Vento, a Minnesota Democrat who was chairman of a special Congressional task force on Resolution Trust, said he was disappointed. "The Administration and the R.T.C. had to be dragged kicking and screaming into the affordable-housing program," he said. "They have a basic reluctance to implement the law."
Mr. Allen of Resolution Trust said the expectations of the critics were unrealistic. "You can't help lower-income people buy when you have a mandate to return the maximum dollars to the Government," he said, "and it's a conflict. So it's an ongoing challenge for us to reach our target market."
 
The Program
Social Policy Vs. Top Dollar
 To carry out the program, Resolution Trust has hired an impressive array of bureaucrats with a long history of service to the poor. But they find themselves caught between the agency's conflicting goals: Selling real estate at top dollar to reduce the cost of the savings and loan bailout for all taxpayers, and selling small houses at affordable prices. The agency is working at the juncture of social policy and quick real estate sales, and money talks.
Under the program as set up by Congress, a 90-day window was created in which low-income buyers and nonprofit organizations have the exclusive chance to buy Resolution Trust properties appraised at less than $67,500. If there are no takers, the houses are offered on the open market.
As of the end of April, 17,372 houses and 489 apartment complexes with 65,097 individual apartments have fallen within these guidelines. This represents $1.6 billion in real estate, or 10 percent of Resolution Trust's entire portfolio. And more housing will be added as the agency continues to take over insolvent savings and loans.
Besides social policy, there are strong economic incentives behind the affordable housing program. The Government estimates that it costs $18.25 a day, or about $6,600 a year, to carry a foreclosed house. At the same time, new public housing costs anywhere from $60,000 to $100,000 a unit.
 
No Problems of Location
 In one fell swoop, the Government could lop off hundreds of millions of dollars in real estate carrying costs and provide new public housing on the cheap. And, since the houses already exist, there are none of the "not in my backyard" problems that often arise when new public housing projects are planned.
"If you believe the Government should intervene to help low and moderate families, this should be the way," said Representative Barney Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat and advocate of the program. "It's the lowest per-unit cost to the Government."
But sales so far have been agonizingly slow. Only 2,500 houses had been sold by May 1 and, by the end of that month, 13 apartment buildings had been sold. Critics contend that few of the houses have actually gone to low-income people.
At the same time, 3,300 houses and 174 apartment complexes have passed through the 90-day window unsold. In Texas, where nearly half the affordable properties are, brokers say many of these have since been snapped up by investors eager to take advantage of the prices, which for houses taken as part of savings and loans failures are substantially lower than those on the general real estate market.
An additional 3,998 houses appraised at less than $67,500 never even got into the program and were sold to other buyers because of a rule, only recently changed, that excluded houses of savings and loans associations the Government had declared insolvent but had not yet seized. These houses were placed on the open market.
 
Trying to Qualify
Most Refused As Credit Risks
 Such numbers take on real meaning for DeeDee Cyphers, a single mother of three in Austin who is stretching to make ends meet on the $19,000 she earns as a senior accounting clerk for Travis County.
Ms. Cyphers is one of the people the program is intended to benefit. But, as with many like her, it has failed to reach her. "It's like the American dream is not coming true for the working poor," she said.
One day, a fellow employee showed Ms. Cyphers a flier for the Resolution Trust program. Intrigued, she got a list of properties and, with a broker, found a $26,000 house in a neighborhood she fell in love with. Her offer was accepted and a "sold" sign sprouted by the house. At night, she would drive by just to look. "It wasn't a mansion but it was cute," she said, "a nice place to raise my kids that wasn't trashed with drugs."
Even more attractive was the monthly mortgage payment of $308, much less than the $425 she struggles to pay in rent.
 
The Bank Says No
 But Ms. Cyphers was turned down at the bank. This happened even though she had the down payment, had held the same job for five years and was applying under a special program of the Texas Housing Authority, which issued bonds specifically to provide mortgage money to local banks for low-income buyers of agency properties.
But the bank, in this case Guaranty Federal Savings, and not the housing authority makes the final credit decision. And the bank did not like the fact that seven years ago, when Ms. Cyphers and her former husband were laid off, they returned a leased car to a dealer who wanted the payments instead.
For Ms. Cyphers, this disappointment turned into "heartbreak," in her words, when she learned recently that Resolution Trust was planning to give away to nonprofit agencies up to 3,000 houses it said it could not sell. Some of these are in bad shape but can certainly be fixed up.
"The R.T.C. is trying to give away houses and here I want to pay for one," she said. "I think they should try to help the working poor who are trying to get back on their feet. The houses are supposed to be affordable -- to help the people out. If I were rich, I wouldn't need the R.T.C."
 
Oversight
Critics Say Board Hampered Program
 Much of the program's poor showing has been attributed by critics to restrictions in the initial law and to implementation policies of Resolution Trust's Oversight Board, whose members include Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Jack F. Kemp, Housing and Urban Development Secretary.
The board allowed the agency to make big discounts in all properties except those in the affordable-housing program until just three months ago when Congress halted the practice by threatening to withhold the agency's funds. The effect was that people were buying houses outside the program cheaper than the poor could get them within the program during the 90-day period.
And seller financing had been offered by the agency to buyers of all other properties -- except in the affordable-housing program, where Resolution Trust two years later is beginning to develop a limited program of financing for low-income buyers.
"There was just an ideological objection to helping poor people," Representative Frank said. The Bush Administration, he charged, "felt that poor people were a pain and they don't need them."
 
Board Defends Actions
 Not so, say members of the Administration and the Oversight Board. "We've been pro-active in affordable housing," said Peter H. Monroe, president of the board. "In terms of the dollars the R.T.C. will collect from real estate, maybe 1 percent will come from residential affordable real estate."
Alfred A. DelliBovi, Under Secretary for Housing and Urban Development, said, "I can assure you there has been no foot-dragging by the Administration to carry out this law."
Critics acknowledge that some of the flaws in the program have been corrected but say the low-income citizens who were to have been given preference are still for the most part missing out.
 
The Texas Experience
Few of the Poor Get Houses
 Nowhere are the problems more apparent than in Texas, where real estate prices have fallen so drastically that nearly every house that falls into the the agency's hands meets the affordable-housing guidelines. And, nearly half of all affordable houses to be sold by the agency are in Texas, where the Texas Housing Authority estimates that 60,000 people are homeless. In Dallas, there is a two-year waiting list for public housing.
Potential buyers and nonprofit organizations said in interviews that accurate information on what houses were available had been almost impossible to get. The bidding process is described as a nightmare of paperwork that discourages real estate brokers from even showing properties.
Before putting down a $500 earnest-money deposit on a house in the program, a prospective buyer must fill out a 25-page form. Until recently, the agency's real estate contract was 45 pages long instead of the standard 3 pages. "I've sold commercial property for the R.T.C. and that was a pain in the neck," a Houston broker said. "But it's nothing like the affordable-housing program. It's more of a headache than it's worth."
 
Mortgages Hard to Get
 More important, mortgage financing for low-income people has been hard to come by, despite the housing authority's bond issue, which raised $142 million to fund 8.35 percent mortgages through banks that would lend to the low-income buyers.
So far, only 384 such loans have been made, leaving the agency with $122.5 million in unused mortgages. This comes despite a telephone hotline that has been getting nearly 800 calls a day, newspaper and radio ads and a mailing to more than 14,000 homes.
"The consumer is tearing down our door," said Richard H. Garza, former acting executive director of the authority. "Every time we put out a news release our telephone lines go haywire."
Much of the problem is that low-income people are not perceived as good credit risks. "If a low-income buyer has anything shaky on his credit record, he gets tossed out," said Elizabeth Wolff, head of the Dallas office of the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, or Acorn, a nonprofit agency. "Only the squeaky clean can qualify."
Resolution Trust was authorized by Congress to help provide financing for low income people but so far has done little. The banks, for their part, have been generally quick to turn down low-income applicants, although housing advocates argue that lending to big investors is often chancier, as illustrated by the savings and loan disaster. At any rate, if the program is to work, the process of getting mortgages will have to be made easier for those with low incomes.
 
Disappointed Callers
 "I was naive to think that this program could work for the low income," said Skip Beaird, executive director of the Housing Resources Association, a nonprofit Austin agency. "We get 60 calls a day from people excited that there might be something for them. But there isn't."
Each Wednesday night, Mr. Beaird and an assistant, MaryLee Claborn, sit in a conference room at the Travis County Human Services Building painstakingly counseling low-income people on where to get a Resolution Trust property list, how to find a broker and where to apply for a mortgage.
But they can recall only 3 people ever getting a house of the 1,000 or so they have counseled.
"The R.T.C. has a brochure that says, 'If you're paying $250 a month or more in rent, the R.T.C. wants to help you own your home,' " Ms. Claborn said, "And every time I see that, I get angry, its so misleading."
 
Speculation
Hawaiian Investors Find Texas Deals
 The Resolution Trust office in Dallas is in a gleaming high-rise in an exclusive neighborhood, where Jane Keefe, head of the agency's Southwestern Regional Affordable Housing Office, oversees the program. Through the program, she said, 1,134 Texas houses have been sold at an average price of $41,000.
About half these sales, she said, were to people below 80 percent median income, or under $35,000 a year for a family of four. "For us to have half our sales to the really low-income families, I'd say we're successful," she said. Ms. Keefe said that 900 houses that passed through the 90-day window and gone unsold would be re-listed to give low-income people another chance.
But housing advocates question just how successful Resolution Trust is, even by its own tally. And they question who exactly is buying the homes.
Through the Freedom of Information Act, John J. Henneberger, director of the Texas Low Income Housing Information Service, a nonprofit corporation, obtained lists of houses that the agency said it sold in Texas under the program.
 
 
Bought for Cash
 By comparing the Resolution Trust lists with courthouse deeds, Mr. Henneberger said he found that many of the properties the agency said it sold were never sold at all. Other properties, he said, were purchased by investment groups from as far away as Hawaii and many were bought for cash -- in amounts up to $30,000. Many of these properties had passed through the 90-day window and were sold to investors.
Mr. Henneberger and other housing advocates suspect that brokers are lying low until after the 90-day period and then pushing these properties to buyers with ready cash.
In Austin, for instance, Mr. Henneberger's spot check turned up condominiums with initial appraisals as high as $95,000 being sold to Hawaiian investors at prices in the $20,000 to $30,000 range. These were then listed as affordable-housing sales.
Mr. Henneberger said many questions were raised by the data: How did condos with high appraisals got into the program in the first place? Why were investors getting such good deals and not low-income people?
"What's emerging is a lot of confusion," Mr. Henneberger said. "The R.T.C. doesn't know what sold under the program -- so how can they continue to turn out reports to Congress." "
Ms. Keefe said the lists might have bookkeeping errors and denied that houses were slipping with any frequency into the hands of rich investors during the 90 days.
But houses have slipped through.
Recently, Resolution Trust agreed to sell 36 Texas homes in the affordable-housing program to a Houston real estate broker who had formed a charity -- the Lung Transplant Foundation Inc. -- just a day before he submitted his bid. The houses were being sold to the broker for $500 each and his son was to have collected a $500 commission on each sale -- or some $18,000 in all. But after an article about the transactions appeared on June 6 in The San Antonio Light, the agency canceled the sale.
About 20 percent of the Texas sales have been in cash, according to the agency's Dallas office. It said low-income people were often suspicious of banks and kept their money at home. Deborah Kroupa, a housing specialist with Acorn, disputed this. Low-income people, she said, rarely have more than $1,000 or $2,000 in "mattress money."
Ms. Kroupa said the money came from speculators who could get a friend or a relative to qualify for the program, buy the property and pay cash so there was no paperwork. Several months later, the buyer moves out, the house is refinanced and is converted into valuable property.
Ms. Kroupa should know. She said this was work she once did herself as a real estate buyer but stopped because she said her conscience bothered her. "It's a legal loophole," Ms. Kroupa said. "All it takes is knowledge and money."
How to reform or refine the program?
Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, said for one thing he would introduce a measure in Congress to extend the 90-day window to 180 days. Nearly all nonprofit agencies would like to see the trust corporation streamline its marketing and sales process and offer financing help and greater price discounts to low-income families.
And some individuals and groups have already started to work with private banks to broaden credit standards to make more low-income persons eligible for mortages.
As Mr. Jordan, the Austin developer, put it: "It should be as easy for a low-income person to buy a house as it is for a low-income person to buy a car."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Beazer Shifting to U.S. In Sale of Europe Units

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, June 25

 BODY:
Beazer P.L.C. said today that it planned to sell its European house-building, real estate and contracting operations to concentrate on its building-materials businesses in the United States.
The conglomerate, which owns the Koppers Company in Pittsburgh, a building-materials concern, said it would offer all of its European operation to the public and would list the stock on the London Stock Exchange, probably in late September. It had said on April 23 that it was considering such a move. 
 The spinoff would probably raise about $880 million, analysts said.
Beazer also said it was considering whether to move its headquarters from Bath, England, to the United States after the sale.
Beazer said it intended to use the proceeds to repay some of its $1.63 billion in debt, some of which was incurred when it bought Koppers for $1.8 billion in 1988.
Beazer also said it had been working with its primary bankers, National Westminster Bank P.L.C. and Citibank, to refinance its debt.
The company said its European business was suffering from economic weakness and the effects of a strong dollar.
More than 75 percent of the company's assets and 60 percent of its operating earnings are in the United States, and about 34 percent of its ordinary shares are held in the form of American depository receipts.
The A.D.R.'s fell $1.875 today on the New York Stock Exchange, to $7.75. The 19.4 percent drop was the Big Board's largest in percentage terms.
In the fiscal year that ended on June 30, 1990, Beazer had after-tax profits of about $116 million on revenues of $3.8 billion.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Dropped 2.4% In Mid-June

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 25

 BODY:
Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks fell 2.4 percent in mid-June, but the decline did not dampen hopes that the auto market is recovering.
The nine United States and Japanese auto makers that assemble cars in North America sold 212,116 cars in the June 11-20 period, a drop of four-tenths of a percent from the 212,910 cars sold a year earlier. 
 For the period, the seasonally adjusted annual rate of domestic car sales was 6.5 million, still a good deal lower than the 7.4 million trend of the last few years, but significantly higher than the 5.5 million rate for April, when the market seemed to reach a trough. The rate was 6.3 million in early June.
 
'Very Encouraging' Numbers
 The light-truck sales of the six American and Japanese truck manufacturers dropped 5.7 percent, to 121,364, from 128,718 a year ago.
Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, called the sales figures "very encouraging."
John Casesa, automotive analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York, said: "The automotive recovery definitely is coming in fits and starts. This period I would characterize as better than expected."
The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest producer, sold 101,743 cars, a drop of six-tenths of a percent from a year earlier, and 50,248 light trucks, down 1.9 percent. But for the first time in five years G.M.'s Chevrolet division could boast of higher year-to-date car and truck sales than its chief rival, the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company.
David Hudgens, a Chevrolet spokesman, said the division planned to send congratulatory messages by computer to its 4,700 dealers. G.M.'s Buick, Oldsmobile and GMC truck divisions posted gains, while sales of Cadillacs and Pontiacs were down.
Joel Pitcoff, a Ford sales analyst, said Chevrolet had been selling heavily to fleet buyers, like car-rental companies, while Ford sold proportionately more cars at retail. Ford, the nation's No. 2 auto maker, sold 51,091 cars, a 14.8 percent decline from a year earlier, and 40,071 light trucks, a 13.7 percent decline.
Ward's Automotive Reports estimated that the Chrysler Corporation, which reports its sales only by month, sold 21,750 cars in mid-June, a 12.5 percent drop, and 25,250 light trucks, a 6.4 percent drop.
The three largest Japanese producers all posted sharp increases in sales of cars and light trucks built in North America. In recent months Japanese auto makers have begun to use dealer rebates and subsidized leasing plans more aggressively in an attempt to continue to increase their share of the weak market.
The Honda Motor Company sold 18,077 cars, up 60.3 percent from the 11,280 sold a year earlier. Sales of Honda's Accord model, which carries dealer rebates of up to $750, reached 12,203, compared with 5,973 in the 1990 period. Earlier this year, Honda's inventory of Accords became uncomfortably swollen.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's sales of domestically built cars rose 31 percent, to 10,387, from 7,936 a year earlier. Camry sales were up 36.3 percent, and sales of the smaller Corolla model rose 22.9 percent. Toyota said its total vehicle sales, including imports, were up 25 percent in mid-June. The auto maker said sales of its recently introduced Paseo coupe and its redesigned Tercel subcompact had been strong.
The Nissan Motor Company said its car sales advanced 14.9 percent for the period, to 3,634, while light-truck sales gained 7.8 percent, to 3,737.

HEADLINE: Sales of Existing Houses Rose 6 Percent Last Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Lower mortgage rates continued to lure home buyers in May, lifting sales of existing single-family houses by 6 percent, to their highest level in 18 months, a real estate trade group said today.
"Low mortgage rates and increased consumer confidence are fueling momentum in the housing market and allowing entry-level buyers to finally get up the courage to dive into the market," said Harley E. Rouda, president of the National Association of Realtors. 
 The group said sales of previously owned single-family houses were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.51 million in May, the highest since the 3.56 million rate in December 1989.
 
Low Point in January
 Sales of existing homes plunged to a 2.9 million rate in January, but have increased each month since then, including gains of 9 percent in February and 1.9 percent in March. New-home sales and housing starts as well as applications for building permits have also increased since January.
John A. Tuccillo, the trade organization's chief economist, said that as the recovery takes hold, sales of existing homes "should be healthy for the remainder of 1991 and robust in 1992."
According to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the interest rate for 30-year conventional fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.47 percent in May, down nearly one percentage point from the same month in 1990.
The median price of an existing home was $99,700, up 4.7 percent from the May 1990 price, but six-tenths of a percent below that of April. The median price means half of the homes cost more and half cost less.
Sales in the Northeast, which rose 2.8 percent in April, slipped 1.9 percent in May to an annual rate of 530,000 units. The median price in the region was $143,600, 1.9 percent above that of May 1990. Sales rose in the Midwest, West and South.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Wells Fargo's Wall St. Shocker

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 25

 BODY:
Wells Fargo & Company stunned Wall Street today by announcing that it would increase its reserve for loan losses in the second quarter to about $350 million, or more than four times the $85 million it set aside in the first quarter of 1991. The increase will sharply lower earnings.
The announcement confirmed some investors' fears that the recession and the real estate slump would drag down California banks as it has banks in the Southwest and Northeast. 
 But Wells Fargo said real estate loans were not material to the bank's second-quarter results. It said the majority of the nonperforming loans were commercial loans for deals that involved large amounts of debt.
 
Stock Slumps
 "Real estate was not a significant contributor to our second-quarter results," Rod Jacobs, Wells Fargo's vice chairman and chief financial officer, said in an interview. "That's not to say there was no increase in real estate nonperforming loans -- it was just not material." The $400 million in loans put on nonaccrual were commercial industrial loans, not secured by real estate, much of it the senior debt involved in leveraged buyouts or other restructurings.
Wells Fargo's increased loss provision was in part the result of a review by Federal regulators of its loans. Results for the quarter will reflect the recent Shared National Credit Regulatory Examination for all commercial and real estate loans of $20 million or more held by two or more banks, Wells said.
The company's stock fell $6.50, to $74, on the New York Stock Exchange today, after a delay in trading caused by large imbalances between buy and sell orders. The stock had dropped $6.50 on Monday in anticipation of the problems. The announcement hurt the stocks of other banks as well, including Wells's biggest California competitors. BankAmerica was down $1.50, to $35.875 a share; Security Pacific dropped $1.375, to $23.25, and First Interstate fell $2.25, to $34.
Critics have been predicting for months that Wells Fargo would be the next big bank to stumble, noting that it has a much higher exposure to real estate loans than its California competitors. Real estate loans, including residential mortgages and home equity loans, account for 53 percent of Wells Fargo's portfolio, compared with 35 percent at BankAmerica.
But supporters, like the Omaha investor Warren E. Buffett, who last month sought regulatory approval to raise his holdings in the bank from 9.7 percent, to as much as 22 percent, have argued that California real estate is not the same as Texas real estate and will not be severely hurt by the recession.
Wells said it expected loan losses in the second quarter to be about $180 million, up from $67 million in the first quarter. Because of the loan-loss provision, the company estimated that it would earn about $15 million, or 20 cents a share, in the second quarter, compared with $232.4 million, or $4.40 a share, a year earlier. Analysts had estimated that the bank would earn as much as $2.95 a share.
"Even with this large provision, Wells Fargo is still going to produce earnings for the quarter," Carl E. Reichardt, Wells Fargo's chairman and chief executive, said. "If we had not made this loss provision, our earnings in the second quarter would have exceeded $3 per share."
Wells Fargo said it would place about $400 million in commercial loans, about half of which involve deals with heavy debt, on nonaccrual. That means that although the loans are current, they are not considered good credit risks. Wells said its total nonaccrual and restructured loans would increase by about $450 million. The increase in the loan-loss provision will result in a total reserve of more than $1 billion, compared with $905 million last March 31.
 
'We Remain Cautious'
 "The increase in nonaccruals this quarter reflects national economic trends," Mr. Reichardt said. "There is some evidence of an upturn in the economy, but we remain cautious and expect continued pressure on the loan portfolio at this point."
After Wells Fargo made its announcement, Fitch Investors Service said it had placed the bank's $450 million in AA senior debt and $1.7 billion in AA- subordinated debt on an alert with negative implications. Fitch said that an increase in the company's problem assets was expected during 1991, but that the jump in nonperforming assets during the second quarter was well outside the range Fitch anticipated.
While Wells's loan portfolio had a high-risk profile, measurements of asset quality had not shown meaningful deterioration until now, Fitch said.
