HEADLINE: 2 YUGOSLAV STATES VOTE INDEPENDENCE TO PRESS DEMANDS

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, Wednesday, June 26

 BODY:
The Parliaments of the Yugoslav republics of Slovenia and Croatia overwhelmingly passed declarations of independence Tuesday that could lead to full secession if their demands for a new, more loosely bound Yugoslavia are not met by Belgrade.
After an emergency late-night meeting, Yugoslavia's federal Government responded early this morning by calling the republics's actions illegal and ordering national army and police units to seize control posts along Slovenia's borders. 
 It remains uncertain when the military and police forces would attempt to take control of Slovenia's border crossings, which now include posts along the republic's border with Croatia. A Slovene government official reached by telephone this morning said that the federal troops had not yet taken such action,
It is clear, however, that the battle of wills between federal authorities and the leaders of the two renegade republics has entered a new phase that raises the possibility of bloodshed.
 
Army Intervention Sought
 Leaders in both republics have said that federal authorities, including the national army, would be required to ask for permission to move across the republics' territories.
"We still favor negotiations," President Milan Kucan of Slovenia said Tuesday. "But in order that real negotiations take place, we have opted for independence."
Even though the Slovene and Croatian leaders clearly prefer to remain in a decentralized Yugoslav federation, the political atmosphere is charged because of the possibility of bloodshed and instability through miscalculation.
Citing such concerns, the European Community and the United States have both said they will not recognize the independence of Yugoslavia's two most pro-Western and wealthiest republics. Many Western leaders have recalled that World War I had its roots in the fiery nationalism of this region.
In response to the action by the two republics, the federal Parliament in Belgrade asked the national army Tuesday evening to intervene immediately to prevent the country's dismemberment. The national Parliament, however, has no power to order the army into action.
Prime Minister Ante Markovic has repeatedly warned that he would resort to all legal means to prevent the republics from becoming truly sovereign states, as the declarations say they now are.
Both Slovenia and Croatia have warned for a year that they would secede from Yugoslavia if the country was not recast as a loose confederation. But even now leaders of both republics are insisting that despite the independence declarations they are still eager to discuss creation of a new Yugoslav union with the other four republics.
Both independence declarations spoke of "disassociation" from Yugoslavia. A draft of the Croatian version, obtained by The Associated Press, proclaimed a "sovereign and independent state" and declared: "By this act the Republic of Croatia initiates the process of disassociation from the other republics."
Slovenian and Croatian leaders maintain that the national army, whose Serbian-dominated officer corps commands a multi-ethnic force, would disintegrate if it were ordered to put down the movements toward independence.
 
'A Few Armored Cars'
 "Any military action would amount to occupation," said Janez Jansa, Slovenia's defense minister. "It would take more than a few armored cars."
Yugoslavia's currency, the dinar, will remain the sole legal tender in Slovenia and Croatia for the time being, although the parliaments of both republics have adopted laws providing for the creation of their own currencies and national banks.
The Yugoslav Army will also maintain bases in Slovenia and Croatia for the present, But both republics have already organized their own armed forces and plan to negotiate the army's withdrawal in discussions that they are already likening to the German-Soviet talks on the Red Army's withdrawal from what was East Germany.
 
Warnings From the West
 Republican leaders say Ljubljana will recall Slovenian representatives from the federal Parliament and bureaucracy and replace them with officials designated to negotiate and oversee a gradual breaking of ties with the Belgrade Government.
In the last week, the European Community and the United States have warned Slovenia and Croatia that they would not extend diplomatic recognition to the republics as independent states nor would they offer any economic aid.
"This was to be expected," said President Kucan at a news conference here Tuesday morning. "Under international law, the legal entity is still, for the time being, the Socialist Federated Republic of Yugoslavia."
Croatia's president, Franjo Tudjman, in a speech to his republic's parliament Tuesday night, said: "We understand completely the worries of individual states and the entire European Community about the Yugoslav crisis. But we must take our own interests into consideration first."
Mr. Tudjman also said that Croatia would redouble its efforts to gain international legitmacy by sending representatives to foreign capitals and appealing to international organizations.
In contrast with the demands of Slovenia and Croatia's for a loose confederation, Serbia, the largest and most populous Yugoslav republic, has called for strengthening the Yugoslav federation. Serbia's Government of renamed and reconstituted Communists is often blamed for undermining Yugoslavia's market-based economic reform program. Serbia's government has said that a confederation is acceptable only if all of Yugoslavia's Serbs are brought within the borders of a single state. Croatia, which has a large Serbian minority, strongly opposes this.
Leaders here in Slovenia admit that they were driven to take their step to independence in part by a desire to escape the costs of conflicts between Serbs and ethnic Albanians in southern Yugoslavia as well as those involving Serbs and Croats, which have claimed several dozen lives in the last five months.
"Slovenian leaders hope that independence will lead to an improvement in the republic's political-risk assessment and pave the way for new private investment," said Joze Mencinger, a top economist and former Slovenian vice president, adding that the republican government is not counting on economic aid from foreign governments.
Subjects of Austria for about 800 years, the Slovenes chose to join Yugoslavia after the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire in the waning days of World War I. This alpine republic, which has few minorities and is predominantly Roman Catholic, will find little internal resistance to moving away from the Yugoslav federation, which has been eroding since the 1980 death of Tito, the country's postwar Communist dictator.
 
'Soft Border Crossings'
 Slovene workers are already erecting what republican officials are calling "soft border crossings" at eight points between Slovenia and Croatia. Officials said the border guards would make only cursory identification checks.
Croatia, which was connected with Hungary from the beginning of the 12th century until its leaders chose to join newly formed Yugoslavia after World War I, has already met stiff opposition to its independence move from a large portion of its Serbian minority. The Serbs in Croatia have a vivid memory of mass killings by Nazi-backed Croatian nationalists during World War II and strongly oppose coming under the complete control of the Zagreb government.
Voters in Slovenia and Croatia have passed popular referendums calling for the republics to become sovereign states.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Croatians waving their national flag in Zagreb yesterday after Croatia and Slovenia passed declarations of independence from Yuguslavia. (Associated Press)
 
Map: Map of Yugoslavia showing locations of Croatia and Slovenia. (pg. A1)
 
Chart: "Steps to Independence: Two Yugoslav Republics"
 Croatia and Slovenia have approved declarations of independence in their campaign for a looser Yugoslav federation.
 
Slovenia
 
Geography
 The northernmost of Yugoslavia's six states, covering 12,584 square miles and accounting for nearly 8 percent of the federation's territory.
 
People
 Population: 2 million, about 9 percent of Yugoslavia's inhabitants. There are small Italian and Hungarian minorities.
 
History
 Slovenia war ruled by a succession of German princes until the Middle Ages, when it was incorporated into the Austrian Empire. In 1918, Slovenia joined the new kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes that later evolved into Yugoslavia. It first gained limited autonomy in the 1930's. After Yugoslavia was reconstituted as a Communits federation in 1945, all states were granted considerable self-governmemt.
 
Economy
 Traditionally one of the poorest parts of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, Slovenia developed rapidly after it joined Yugoslavia and became its economically most prosperous region after World War II. Its industgries, including the Elan ski factory, were badly hit by free-market reforms and unemployment has risen.
 
Government
 Ruled by demos, a coalition of six center-right parties that defeated the reformed Communits, was elected president.
 
Currency
 Yugoslav dinar. A paralled currency is planned.
 
Army
 Yugoslav national army is present. A Slovenian territorial defense has 70,000 members, not all mobilized.
 
Foreign Affairs
 Representative offices in several European capitals and in Washington.
 
Passports
 Yugoslav passports, Slovenian in preparation.
 
Croatia
 
Geography
 Yugoslavia's second-largest republic, covering 35,132 square miles from the Adriatic coast to the agricultural heartland of Slavonia.
 
People
 Population: 4.8 million (including 500,000 ethnic Serbs), or about 20 percent of the federation's 23.5 million people.
 
History
 The Croats created a small kingdom in the 10th century that united with Hugnary in 1102. The Turks occupied much of it before being ejected by the Austrians in the 18th century. With the fall of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, Croatia joined Serbia in forming Yugoslavia. Croatian secessionists set up a Nazi puppet state that murdered hundreds of thousands of Serbs and Jews during World War II.
 
Economy
 The Adriatic coast accounts for about 80 percent of Yugoslavia's $3 billion annual earnings from tourism. Leading industries are shipbuilding, petrochemicals, food processing and agriculture. Tourism has been halved by a rebellion of ethnic Serbs near the main resorts. About a quarter of the work force is unemployed.
 
Government
 Governed by the Croatian Democratic Union, a nationalist party. The party's leader, Franjo Tudjman, a former Communist general, was named president by the legislature. Serbs have declared independence for Krajina in western Croatia.
 
Currency
Yugoslav dinar. A new currency is planned.
 
Army
 Yugoslav national army is present; a republican army is in training. It consists of a 10,000-member National Guard and 10,000 to 20,000 police.
 
Foreign Affairs
 Representatives in European capitals and the United States, Canada and Australia.
 
Passports
 Yugoslav passports, Croatian in preparation.
 
(pg. A6)

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
Lower-Fat Foods Vs. U.S. Standards

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
"LIGHT butter" is a world-class oxymoron. Right up there with sweet sorrow, jumbo shrimp and military intelligence.
The existence of a product that calls itself light butter is the result of a clash between late 20th-century technology and early 20th-century law. The former, which is an effort to accommodate modern-day health concerns, has rendered the latter obsolete. 
 Back when Americans thought eating butter, prime steaks, heavy cream and Cheddar cheese were healthful pursuits, when they were appalled that someone had watered their cream and adulterated their ground beef with soy protein, the Federal Government established standardized recipes to define the permissible ingredients in a long list of food products including butter and cheese, sausages and canned chili.
Most of the standards were established before 1940, when people were more concerned with adulteration and economic deception than the hazards of a high-fat diet. How times have changed.
Now these "standards of identity," as they are called by Federal agencies, stand in the way of making nutritional improvements in processed food, according to a report released today by Public Voice for Food and Health Policy. The report from the group, a consumer-advocacy organization that is based in Washington, is called "No License to Label: How Federal Standards Restrict Lower-Fat Foods."
"From a public health perspective," the report said, "the most troublesome standards of identity are those that impede the development of lower-fat products."
That is because many standards require minimum fat levels. And any product that does not meet that minimum fat level is not allowed to use the traditional name for the product.
The group wants the Government to change food standard policies to make lower-fat products more readily available and to establish a uniform definition of words like light.
The Food and Drug Administration seems willing to comply. "The situation is not as bleak as Public Voice presents it," said F. Edward Scarbrough, acting director of nutrition and food sciences at the F.D.A. "We are interpreting the Nutrition Labeling and Education Act to have latitutde to establish new standards for foods with less fat," he said. The Act takes effect in 1993. The Department of Agriculture, responsible for meat and poultry products, said the regulations are under review.
Under existing standards, the innovator who produces a lower-fat product is faced with some unpleasant choices: defy the regulations, as some have done, and hope the Government looks the other way; call the product imitation, as in imitation cheese, or call it by some fanciful name, like Simple Pleasure, the frozen dessert made with a fat substitute instead of milk fat. Consumers might call Simple Pleasure ice cream, or nonfat ice cream, but its manufacturer cannot.
"Consumers," the report said, "are often confused by unfamiliar product names and tend to view the products as either synthetic or of lesser quality than standardized higher-fat products that are permitted to use the traditional name." That puts the innovator at a competitive disadvantage, the report said.
Butter must contain 80 percent milk fat to use the name. In 1990 there were two petitions before the F.D.A. One, from the American Butter Institute, asked the F.D.A. to permit the use of the term "light butter" for a product that contains 52 percent milk fat instead of 80 percent. Land O' Lakes Inc. makes such a product. Johann Farms also asked the F.D.A. for a new standard for "light butter," one that contained 35 to 40 percent milk fat.
The F.D.A. has not approved either petition. And, Public Voice said, "neither of the petitions warrants approval by F.D.A."
Butter, even with a reduction in milk fat to 39 percent, is hardly a "light" product. For many other products, manufacturers are free to use the term light because no regulations govern its use.
Earlier this month the F.D.A. told Land O' Lakes that if it didn't change the name of its product, the agency would take regulatory action, which could mean seizure.
Clearly consumers should be protected against misleading labeling like "light butter." But what benefit is it to consumers who are looking for lower-fat products not to have "butter" with less fat on the market?
It would make more sense for the F.D.A. to issue a permit that allows butter with less fat to be called "reduced-fat butter."
Now if the F.D.A. would enforce the law across the board. Even as it pursues light butter, the agency seems to be looking the other way at light and reduced-fat Cheddar, Monterey Jack and Muenster cheeses. Consumers are further confused by such inconsistencies.
Setting aside all the legal and technical mumbo jumbo involving standards, the consumer group makes a good case for broadening them.
Take mayonnaise, salad dressing (such as Miracle Whip) and French dressing. All have standards that require a certain amount of fat.
But for inexplicable reasons, there are no such standards for ranch-style dressing or Italian dressing. They can be marketed as light or reduced fat with their familiar name. Mayonnaise, salad dressing and French dressing cannot.
The problems are different at the Department of Agriculture, but the results are the same: few reduced-fat products. The department prohibits or strictly limits levels of ingredients like water, carbohydrates and vegetables that may be added to products as substitutes for fat.
But it permits amazing levels of skin and fat in processed meats. Many consumers would probably be surprised to learn that up to 25 percent of the content of boneless chicken breast can be skin, which is mostly fat. They would probably be horrified to learn that there is no limit to the amount of fat in what is considered meat.
Even when the standards require spaghetti with meat sauce to contain 12 percent meat, the so-called meat can be mostly fat. Which solves a mystery: why there never seems to be meat in canned spaghetti with meat sauce.
Until such time as nutritonal Nirvana arrives in the supermarket, the only recourse for shoppers is to get beyond the funny names, to ignore phrases like imitation, light, reduced fat and X percent less fat and go for the nutrition labeling panel where they can find the real skinny.
And if a product that purports to offer less of something or other has no nutrition labeling, perhaps it ought to grow stale on the shelf.

HEADLINE: Study Questions Routine Molar Removal

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE

 BODY:
AMERICAN dentists and oral surgeons are extracting far too many wisdom teeth, a new study suggests.
If surgeons removed only those wisdom teeth that actually caused problems, researchers say, the nation would save at least $150 million a year in medical expenses with no ill effects. And tens of thousands of people, mostly teen-agers, would be spared the aches, pains and complications that can result from the surgery. 
 As things stand now, teen-agers, especially those in families with dental insurance, lose their wisdom teeth by the time they reach college age, as a matter of routine.
 
Studying Medical Procedures
 The study is part of an expanding effort to identify ineffective or wasteful medical procedures. It was financed by the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, a new Federal agency, and conducted by Dr. Alexia Antczak, an assistant professor at the Harvard School of Public Health and School of Dental Medicine and Dr. Joan Tulloch, a professor in the Department of Orthodontics in the School of Dentistry at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
The nation's 6,000 oral surgeons extract 2.25 million wisdom teeth each year, according to the American Society of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons. General dentists probably take out many more than that, but no one is keeping track, Dr. Antczak said. Costs range from $70 to $175 per tooth, she said, not counting anesthesia or painkillers. Wisdom tooth extraction is the bread and butter of oral surgery, and some surgeons spend almost all their time on it.
Today, 9 out of 10 American teen-agers whose parents have insurance have their wisdom teeth removed, Dr. Antczak estimated. Oral surgeons say that it is easier to remove teeth in younger people because the roots are not formed and the bone is less dense, she said. They also say, "Let's do this before you go off your parents' insurance," she said.
But the researchers said that removing wisdom teeth because they might cause problems some day, as a matter of course, makes about as much sense as removing everyone's appendix just because some people develop appendicitis.
The wisdom of removing wisdom teeth has been a topic of contention for years. The practice was based on good intentions, Dr. Antczak said, "but there is now a strong economic incentive to keep it going."
But oral surgeons say there can be good reasons for removing widsom teeth that are not causing problems. Several studies have shown that older patients suffer more complications from the surgery, said Dr. Thomas Osborn, an oral surgeon in Birmingham, Mich., speaking for the American Society of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons.
"Also, so many kids go through orthodontics and then the wisdom teeth come plowing in like pistons," he said. "There's real concern that some damage will be done to the orthodontia."
 
Most Third Molars Are Healthy
 Wisdom teeth, or third molars, generally erupt between the ages of 17 and 21, according to the American Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons in Rosemont, Ill. Most are healthy and can be an asset. About 28 percent become impacted, unable to move into their proper place, often because the jaw is not big enough to accommodate them. The teeth may grow sideways, break partway through the gum or remain trapped beneath gum and bone.
Many impacted teeth do not cause problems, Dr. Anczak said. But when they do, the problems can be serious. When food lodges in partly erupted teeth, infections and cysts can form, she said, damaging bone, neighboring teeth and nerves. In extremely rare instances, tumors can develop, leading to the loss of part of the jaw.
Anticipating such problems, Dr. Antczak said, many dentists and oral surgeons remove wisdom teeth as a preventive measure.
But is the surgery necessary? Most of the medical literature about wisdom teeth consists of anecdotes about particularly troublesome teeth, Dr. Antczak said. It is far from clear, she said, that removal in general saves more money and misery.
Because so many teen-agers have their wisdom teeth pulled, it is difficult to find enough adults to study wisdom tooth problems that might arise later in life, Dr. Antczak said. Instead, she studied the problem, using research methods that break down a medical decision, like opting for wisdom tooth removal, into its component parts, like cost, risk or side effects. Then each part is analyzed to see what role it plays in the overall decision.
She and Dr. Tulloch compared three hypothetical strategies: In one, all wisdom teeth are removed from all adolescents before roots are formed. In a second, only impacted wisdom teeth, including healthy impacted teeth, are removed. In the third stratgey, only those wisdom teeth that have become infected or troublesome are removed.
 
Method of Study
 Costs, surgical complications and "days of standard discomfort," a measure of pain, swelling, bruising and malaise, were compared in the three strategies. Complications include tingling nerves, infection, jaw spasms and painful sockets left in the bone after tooth extraction.
Universal extraction of wisdom teeth would cost more than $278 million and would result in three million days of misery for America's teen-agers, Dr. Antczak said. Removing only problem teeth would cost an estimated $51.5 million and create 776,000 days of misery. Removing impacted teeth falls in between.
Current practice makes the majority suffer to protect the minority who might run into trouble, Dr. Antczak said. She said a search of the medical literature turned up no data from other countries on what happens when wisdom teeth are left alone.
Dr. Osborn, who works closely with the oral surgery association, said his research showed that early removal had important benefits. A study, published in 1985 in the Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, examined 16,000 wisdom teeth extractions in three groups of patients with average ages of 19, 28 and 45. Most of the teeth were removed because they were nonfunctional, he said, but some were causing problems. The study showed that as patients got older, they suffered more complications from wisdom tooth surgery, Dr. Osborn said. Orthodontists also put pressure on oral surgeons to remove wisdom teeth to help keep teeth straight, Dr. Osborn said.
But Dr. Earl Rosenberg, a prominent Boston oral surgeon, said there was no evidence that wisdom teeth tend to ruin orthodontia.

HEADLINE: Arts Festival a Success, Early Reports Suggest

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The second New York International Festival of the Arts lasted half as long as the first festival three years ago, cost $3 million less and had only a third as many events.
But judging by an informal sampling of festival administrators, presenters, performers and devoted -- albeit weary -- audience members, this year's version was more successful than the previous, mammoth undertaking, which drew almost as much criticism as applause. 
 "Particularly in a time when we're doing so much belt-tightening, the festival was very much a success," said Barbara J. Fife, Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development, who was the festival's liaison with Mayor David N. Dinkins. "I think it was good for New York. The timing was particularly good for us, because it was a clear statement that New York is a destination point for the arts."
The festival ended its 16-day run on Sunday night, although a few festival productions, like that of the State Theater of Lithuania, are continuing. The festival organizers had originally predicted that total attendance would be 300,000, and that 150,000 to 175,000 tickets would be sold to more than 60 performing-arts events from 23 countries at 28 sites.
The individual producers of each event have not yet forwarded ticket-sales statistics to the festival, but based on verbal reports, over-all attendance goals were achieved, festival organizers said. "I think that the audiences for artists and programs which had never been heard of before, by most New Yorkers, exceeded all of our expectations," said Martin E. Segal, chairman of the festival.
Among the sold-out events, according to the festival, were "Cole Porter's 100th Birthday Celebration," "Pongsan Masked-Dance Drama," "Immigrant Voices," "Miss Julie," "A Doll's House," Compagnie Philippe Saire, The Reduced Shakespeare Company, Olodum and Friends, "Muestra Espanola: La Fura dels Baus," Compagnie Philippe Genty and "Cricot 2: Tribute to Tadeusz Kantor."
No events were canceled after the festival began. "We didn't have any catastrophes of any kind, and we wound up in the black," Mr. Segal said. He meant that the $5.69 million cost of mounting the festival was more than covered by contributions from private sources.
The festival did not share in the box-office receipts from the events, which went to the individual producers. None of the money came from the Federal, state or city governments.
The general tenor of critical opinion has been that the festival was more selective in its artistic choices than in 1988, and that the productions, overall, were of higher artistic quality. For example, reviewers unanimously acclaimed the three productions directed by Ingmar Bergman that appeared at the Brooklyn Academy of Music: the United States premieres of his "Miss Julie," "A Doll's House" and "Long Day's Journey Into Night."
"In terms of audience demand, overall enthusiasm, and critical response, we've seen nothing like it here for years," said Peter B. Carzasty, a spokesman for the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which presented the Bergman imports.
"Immigrant Voices," a critically praised theatrical and musical evocation of the immigrant experience, was sold out on both of the nights that a Circle Line sightseeing boat delivered 750 passengers to Ellis Island.
Not every event sold out, though. "We're a little disappointed," said Bernard Gersten, executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater. In association with the Joyce Theater in Manhattan, it presented "Uncle Vanya " and "The Square," as performed by the State Theater of Lithuania. "We're under our box-office projections," he said, "but we hope to pick it up in the next couple of weeks. We're getting really good word of mouth." The company is performing at the Joyce until July 7.
 
A Sore Point: Tickets
 Most of the criticism of the current festival centered around the lack of availability of tickets to sought-after performances. This was especially true of the Cole Porter tribute, a one-night-only affair; the "Ascap Salute to Cabaret" at the Hotel Pierre, and the Bergman-directed dramas, whose cast members were unable to stay longer because they had prior commitments.
There were things that went wrong, too: for example, the opening night production of "Immigrant Voices" was delayed so that the audience in the Grand Registry Hall missed the full harbor fireworks display celebrating the return of the troops from the Middle East on June 10.
But if ticket scalpers' prices are any rough gauge of a festival's worth, the extravaganza was at times a stratospheric success. For example, the June 9 musical revue at Carnegie Hall celebrating the 100th anniversary of Cole Porter's birth, found scalpers selling $100 tickets for $250. Tickets for "Miss Julie" and "A Doll's House" went for as much as $150 from scalpers outside the door.
 
A Boost to the Economy
 Tickets to other events weren't scalped, but were in great demand nevertheless. "We never expected that our entire run would sell out," said Reed Martin, one of the three members of the Reduced Shakespeare Company comedy troupe. "And thanks to the festival, we've got another booking in New York, and we're coming back next year."
Mr. Segal said preliminary estimates showed that the festival had a positive economic impact on the city. "We're going to be completing analyses that will calculate the secondary financial effect on the city in regard to tourism, hotel occupancy, restaurants, things like that."
The original plan was to have a festival every two years, but Mr. Segal let three years lapse after the last festival "to take enough time to adequately appraise the first festival," he said.
"Another festival in two years is a possibility," Mr. Segal added. On Sunday night, the festival had its wrap-up party, attended by a polyglot gaggle of several hundred performers, producers and staff members who gathered at Laura Belle, the Manhattan night club. "We thank you all for what the festival has been, and what it will be in the future," said Mr. Segal.
What the festival organizers hope it will be, in the future, is a predictable feature of Manhattan's cultural life. "The idea that this can be a recurring event is a really good one," said Ms. Fife, the deputy mayor. "If we institutionalize it in alternate years, it will develop a following and audience and a presence in other countries, so that they will begin to plan on coming here."

HEADLINE: The Poorest Americans;
A Bold -- Flawed -- Remedy for Children

SERIES: First of two editorials

 BODY:
Six words stand out from the 30 months of work and 390 pages of report just issued by the bipartisan National Commission on Children: "Today, children are the poorest Americans." Of all the obstacles and miseries the commission addressed, the highest priority attaches to the fact that one of every five children lives in poverty. It's a shaming fact, one that calls for a bold response, and the commission gives one. It proposes a dramatic tax credit worth $1,000 for every child.
The commission, headed by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, also calls for health insurance for all pregnant women and children, a test of child support insurance and other programs. 
 But the unquestioned centerpiece is the proposed $40 billion-a-year tax credit, which would help poor children especially but go to all families. The commission thus makes its recommendation prohibitively -- and unnecessarily -- expensive. Fortunately, there is a way to restructure the credit and open the way for Congress to embrace it.
The commission's child tax credit would lower every family's taxes by $1,000 per child. The cost would be offset in part by eliminating the personal deduction. The net impact would be highly progressive: A family in the 15 percent tax bracket would save almost $700 per child; a family in the 31 percent bracket about $300. The credit would be refundable; families too poor to pay taxes would receive $1,000 per child in cash.
The proposal is similar to one proposed by two Democrats, Thomas Downey and Al Gore, to provide an $800-per-child tax credit and pay for it by raising the top tax rate from 33 to nearly 40 percent.
Congress would undoubtedly pay for a child tax credit along some such lines, soaking the rich. That would be fine, if the shift in tax burdens would stick. But that isn't likely. Congress would probably couple a boost in the top tax rate with lower taxes on capital gains and reinstatement of wasteful tax shelters. In the end, few citizens' tax burdens would change much. The tax code, however, would be wrecked and the economy damaged.
There is a way out. Two analysts at the Urban Institute, Eugene Steuerle and Jason Juffras, propose paying for a $1,000-per-child tax credit by trimming welfare payments and benefits for non-disabled children of Social Security retirees -- aid that would duplicate the new credit. They would keep the top tax rate at 34 percent, rather than let it drop as scheduled after 1995, and would raise excise taxes to levels prevailing in the early 1980's.
This package solves a number of interrelated problems. At present, welfare parents who marry or go back to work lose benefits. But by relying on tax credits, the Steuerle-Juffras plan would provide substantial relief to poor families without discouraging work or marriage. And by keeping income tax rates at current levels, their plan offers no reason to meddle with the tax code.
The Rockefeller Commission report swims in platitudes ("We recommend that parents be more vigilant and aggressive guardians of their children's moral development . . ."). Its strategy, of trying to appeal to a large swath of the public, won't work once Congress is forced to face up to the cost. The answer is to preserve the tax credit, but to pay for it along the lines of the Steuerle-Juffras plan.
Next: Poor children need more than money.

HEADLINE: The New York Bloc

BYLINE: By James Rouen; James Rouen, who practices international law, was an assistant for economic development in the Mayor's office and a municipal bond lawyer.

 BODY:
While the privatization of city services is one of the hottest topcs in municipal finance, the privatization of the Florida prison system and the Fort Worth Zoo is dwarfed by the return to private hands of the enterprises of half of Europe. The experience of those who've returned from trying to privatize Eastern Europe's industrial base may offer useful insights -- or at least a bit of perspective -- to those hoping to privatize city services in the U.S.
The Eastern Europeans have found that creating a new system of controls and incentives to replace old patterns of direction and command is time consuming and leaves little room for error. As one Polish commentator has observed, it's easy to make an aquarium into fish soup but hard to go in the opposite direction. 
 When I worked for the Koch administration in the early 80's, it struck me that many criticisms of the Communist system were also leveled at us -- and with some justification. Municipal government too often shows little concern for the consumers of its services. And the time needed to change bureaucratic procedures, like the time needed to create the Himalayas, is measured in geologic terms.
If you want to understand how Soviet agriculture works, take a morning off to get your driver's license from the Department of Motor Vehicles. Two hours and three lines later, you will have it, and your photograph will look as if it was taken off the reflection on a dented hub cap.
There are at least three areas where the problems of privatizing Eastern Europe and American municipal services appear to converge:
* Accounting. One of Ronald Lauder's 10 commandments for doing business in Eastern Europe is, "Thou shalt believe no numbers except those provided by Western auditors."
But the problem is even deeper. The financial accounts of the American municipality and Communist state enterprise are remarkably similar: Neither one provides information that is especially useful to a private owner. The city agency and the state enterprise use "fund accounting," which is supposed to show compliance with legal and social mandates, not profits and losses.
For example, an American city's highway trust fund is intended to show that state and Federal requirements are being met; gas tax receipts and road building expenditures will be reported. But the accounts will not show depreciation, even when motorists fall through bridges.
Notice the striking similarity between the backward Eastern European industrial base and the crumbling American urban infrastructure. In neither case will the balance sheet tell you the value of what you are buying, or the cost to put it right.
In Poland, fixed assets are valued by taking their 1945 value and multiplying by 46 years of inflation. Similarly, parts of the New York City water system, constructed in 1841, are valued by their historical cost.
* Employment. You cannot go east of the Elbe without noticing the immense overstaffing. A client who bought into a Hungarian steel mill told me that its workforce was three times that of a comparable mill in the West; this ratio appears to be typical.
Many American public services and Eastern European enterprises are uneconomic because they have burdened themselves with excess labor and pension costs. Many enterprises cannot be privatized until those burdens have been removed, by bankruptcy or closure, at great political cost.
* Unexpected claims. In the East, many businesses carry hidden claims: owners who want to recover what was expropriated by the Communists, state employees whose "equity" was recognized at least in theory by socialist law, and the public at large, which often expects to receive its "share" of anything privatized.
While these claims are absent in an American municipal privatization, the principle remains: there are hidden parties with expectations you will inherit. Public employees and their dependents are accustomed to a certain level of pay, benefits and performance. And many citizens will object to any change in service or pricing. They can't complain if General Motors raises its prices, but if a highway toll rises, it's World War III. So it is essential to analyze any proposed privatization to see what improvements and changes will make it work, and to scout around for hidden parties with a perceived right to maintaining the status quo.
Not only will there be strangers at the dinner table -- there may be more of them than you think.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A Nuclear Ripoff?

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Even as the Administration moves to cut the nuclear weapons stockpile almost in half, Congress continues to vote billions annually to fund nuclear warheads programs. The program exceeds $7 billion, when the White House and Congressional leaders are saying they have no new money for children and cities.
 And at the very time when extra Energy Department dollars should be going to clean up the dangerous pollution from past nuclear weapons production, a pivotal Senate subcommittee has taken $108 million away from cleanup programs and added these funds to weapons research and development programs already exceeding $2 billion. 
 To be sure, substantial sums are necessary to design new warheads, maintain production facilities, insure safety and hold onto scientific talent. But in the small community that follows these intricate affairs, the feeling mounts that perhaps billions are being squandered in what amounts to a full employment program for the nuclear weapons laboratories.
These labs, like many old cold war institutions, are scrambling to find new justifications to live and spend in the old cold war style. Lab leaders are particularly well connected in Congress to powerful figures like Senator Pete Domenici, the top Republican on the Appropriations Committee, who knows how to protect New Mexico's weapons-making jewels in Los Alamos and Sandia.
 Even a little probing will show that neither these legislators, nor many Pentagon officials (who determine nuclear warhead requirements) or key Department of Energy officials (in whose budget all these monies reside), have a clear picture of how these billions of dollars are being spent or why.
 The U.S. nuclear weapons stockpile now totals about 20,000 missile warheads and bombs. The Joint Chiefs of Staff project reductions to about 12,000 -- not counting further cuts from arms control treaties under negotiation with Moscow. That decline alone should be driving operation and maintenance costs way down, but the budget reveals no dramatic savings.
 In years past the Energy and Defense Departments designed about 10 new warheads at any one time. Now about two new ones are under development. Yet the number of lab personnel is down by only about 20 percent from cold war highs. And the labs continue to resist designing standard warhead models to fit any new weapon. As John Tuck, a senior Energy Department official, told me, "Building each warhead uniquely has meant much greater expense than necessary."
 The Pentagon, he added, has "no hesitancy" about paying the extra bill since it is an Energy Department expenditure. "We are the small tip of a tail of a big dog," he explained. But Pentagon officials say they are not sure what the Energy Department and labs do with the money.
 To read the report of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Energy and Water Development does not clarify much. The subcommittee added nuclear cleanup funds to the Administration's relatively small request, but not as much as its House counterpart. Instead, it shifted over $100 million from environmental management to an already hefty post-cold-war R & D effort.
 One subcommittee justification was "weapons safety," without citing how many hundreds of millions are already devoted to that task. Another was to maintain "strong" labs without discussing how big and strong the labs need to be when new warhead development is sharply decreasing. The labs eat up a fortune in "overhead," and no one seems confident what that means.
 The third, and juiciest, justification is "new opportunities for strengthening [lab] support of generic precompetitive technology research deemed critical to future U.S. economic competitiveness." Translated, that means Federal help for private industry. But the report does not cite specific technologies or suggest what nuclear weapons labs might know about civilian market needs. It also fails to consider the risks of potential "nuclear mercenaries" spreading valuable nuclear weapons technologies to private enterprise.
 The weapons labs are understandably eager to divine new missions and bolster old ones. But billions of tax dollars are at stake, and it is far from clear that the Administration and Congress have taken a hard look at what is going on.

HEADLINE: High-Tech Medicine Pays Physicians Best;
'A Killing on AIDS'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You sound a necessary alarm about the growing practice of physicians referring patients to health-care facilities in which they have a financial interest (front page, June 2). However, you overlooked an area of health care in which this practice is extensive and expensive: home infusion therapy, particularly for AIDS patients. 
 Infusion therapy -- medications and nutrients delivered intravenously or through feeding tubes -- used to be available only in hospitals. But since the early 1980's, these treatments increasingly have been provided to acquired immune deficiency syndrome patients in their homes, enabling them to avoid costly and debilitating hospital stays.
But as home infusion companies began to compete for patients, they offered physicians financial incentives to refer patients to them. As documented in our recent report, "Making a Killing on AIDS: Home Health Care and Pentamidine," these deals include limited partnerships, stock options and clinical consulting fees. Especially in those cases when physicians provide the home infusion treatments, the potential exists for overuse because the doctor has an incentive to perform more procedures than are necessary. Such arrangements elevate physician profits over patient care.
Take the example of T2 Medical, a Georgia-based national home-infusion company with local offices in New York City and on Long Island. T2's partnerships with physicians enrich doctors and help the company enjoy 50 percent gross profit margins, but they inflate the cost of patient care. Cytovene, a drug that prevents virally induced blindness in AIDS patients, costs $4,000 for two weeks when provided by T2 in Atlanta; a local competitor charges $1,100.
To protect vulnerable people with AIDS, and to curb health care inflation, Congress should prohibit by law physician partnerships in infusion companies, and indeed, in all health-care facilities. Such conflicts of interest are medically and morally offensive.
 
MARK GREEN
Commissioner of Consumer Affairs
New York, June 12, 1991

HEADLINE: Why Bridgeport Had To File for Bankruptcy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Needless Bankruptcy in Bridgeport" (editorial, June 14) observes that bankruptcy should not provide an easy alternative to municipal deficits, but should be resorted to only when all else fails. Unfortunately, you fail to note that protective legislation pending in the Connecticut Legislature would have precluded Bridgeport from filing for bankruptcy. Political observers believed that such legislation would have been passed on the final day of the Legislature's regular session, and if the option were ever to be available, it had to be exercised before such enactment. More than 35 states now preclude such a filing without state consent. 
 Mayor Mary Moran evaluated the bankruptcy option with her closest advisers for many months and filed only when it appeared there would be no assistance from labor, state or Federal sources. Bridgeport's tax rate, already the highest effective tax rate in the state, would have increased by 18 percent this year and 25 percent more the following year. A tax rate of that magnitude would have made the city an economic catastrophe and incapable of competing for new development. Bankruptcy was Mayor Moran's reluctant last resort and, it is to be hoped, will spur a full and fair reorganization for Bridgeport.
 
RICHARD D. ZEISLER
Bridgeport, Conn., June 17, 1991
 
The writer is a special bankruptcy consultant to the City of Bridgeport.

HEADLINE: 600 Hasidim May Be Evicted From Suburban Enclave

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.Y., June 25

 BODY:
Malka Taub, a mother of 10, moved with her family from the Borough Park section of Brooklyn 11 years ago to help establish a yeshiva in this heavily wooded suburb of northern Westchester, escaping what she remembered was a "rough city."
 Now, with 600 others -- faculty members and students of the K'Hal Adas Kashau yeshiva and their families -- Mrs. Taub faces eviction from this 169-acre site that has been transformed into a Hasidic enclave, because the yeshiva failed to meet its mortgage payments. 
I'm very nervous and upset," she said. "I can't pick myself up and go back. I want to raise my children here, not exposing them to drugs and problems in the city." But that may be her destination after the City of New York offers the site at auction at 10 A.M. on July 17 in the lobby of the courthouse in White Plains.
 
Rabbi Blames New York City
 It will be the fourth attempt in 15 years to sell the property, which was built as a turn-of-the-century tuberculosis sanatorium for Montefiore Hospital and converted to a home for delinquent boys in the 1920's. The city tried to auction it off in 1977 but nobody wanted it for $3.5 million or for $2.754 million, the minimum bids set by the city. At the third auction in 1977, it was sold for $1.625 million to the yeshiva, the only bidder.
 A few days later, said Rabbi Abraham Blum, the Hasidic community's leader, the city, in an effort to economize, shut down the main boiler and removed the security force guarding the 16 buildings on the property. They were quickly vandalized, with thousands of window panes broken and copper gutters removed.
 That left the buildings vulnerable to rain damage, which remains as vivid today as it was a decade ago, as does the dispute between New York City and the yeshiva over who should bear the cost and responsibility for the repairs.
 Throughout years of disputes in the courts, the yeshiva has taught Jewish religious law and traditions to students who Rabbi Blum said were "anywhere from 16 and 17 years old to 30 or 40, some married with their own families." It also has a full range of classes for the younger children of religious students and faculty members.
 Classes are continuing despite the possible eviction, the rabbi said.
 The yeshiva made only two payments to the city, at the auction and at the closing, each amounting to $162,500, or 10 percent of the purchase price. It has sought to have the city declared responsible for the repair costs.
 
$1 Million in Repairs Cited
 "We have spent more than $1 million, or nearly the cost of buying the site, to repair the damage caused by the city's abrupt removal of its security force," Rabbi Blum said.
 But in 1979, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court upheld a lower court ruling that the yeshiva could not recover money from the city because it had failed to file an official complaint within the necessary 30 days after the auction.
 Andrea Roschelle, an assistant corporation counsel for New York City, said, "We've tried to settle with them many times and finally obtained a judgment of about $2 million plus interest; the total due us is in excess of $3 million."
 "We've bent over backwards but it only leads to protracted negotiations," she said. "In the meantime they haven't paid a penny." The property was returned to the city by Justice Vincent Gurahian of State Supreme Court in 1988 after eight years of foreclosure proceedings.
 
'Adding Insult to Injury'
 Rabbi Blum said that city's position reminded him of a phrase in I Kings 21;19: "Hast thou killed, and also taken possession?" He said this was "adding insult to injury, to a higher level."
 The yeshiva residents keep to themselves, shopping in Bedford stores but not socializing in the village. Miriam Blum, a resident for 13 years, said: "The police never have to come, we don't use the parks, we strive to stick to our traditions of a very modest life."
 Despite its separateness, the yeshiva has had some conflicts with neighbors. When it built a cemetery on yeshiva property, neighbors said the Hasidim bulldozed property outside its borders during the construction. This month, the yeshiva was charged by New York City with operating a faulty waste-water treatment plant.
 In the yeshiva kitchen, Jesus Rivera, an employee of six years, said, "New York City is right, but where will all the families go?"
 He said he was convinced that the dispute would be resolved. "I'm a man of faith," he said. "I believe in miracles."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 22, 1991, Monday

 CORRECTION:
Articles published Wednesday and on June 26 about a yeshiva in Bedford, N.Y., referred incorrectly to an earlier occupant of the site. It was a home for dependent and neglected children that was known as Hillcrest, not a home for delinquent boys, according to a former director.

HEADLINE: Spending for 1988 Campaigns Set a Record

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
Spending at the local, state and Federal levels in the 1988 political campaigns reached an all-time high of $2.7 billion, an analysis of the campaign made public today has found.
But at a news conference here, Herbert E. Alexander, an author of the analysis and a political science professor at the University of Southern California, argued that the trouble with how campaigns are financed is not the overall cost but where the money comes from. His view differs from that of many advocates of changing the way campaigns are paid for, who argue that the rising costs of seeking and staying in office are out of control. 
 "The fact is," Mr. Alexander said, "while $2.7 billion sounds like a lot, it is about the same as the two leading advertisers, Procter & Gamble, and Philip Morris, spent in 1987."
Mr. Alexander said the limits on spending by Presidential candidates are meaningless because campaigns find back-door means to help their drives, including efforts by state parties to increase voter participation, which benefit the party's candidates.
"The chicanery, the illusion is saying that you have to have expenditure limits," Mr. Alexander said, "All you're doing is crippling the candidate."
Mr. Alexander, who is director of the Citizens' Research Foundation, a private group that studies that role of money in politics, wrote the book "Financing the 1988 Election" with Monica Bauer, an assistant professor of government at Western New England College.
The book found that almost two-thirds of the $2.7 billion, or $1.6 billion was spent on campaigns for President and Congress. The total was a 50 percent increase over the nearly $1.8 billion in spending in the 1984 campaigns, when a President was also elected.
Mr. Alexander said a major reason for the higher spending in 1988 was not only inflation but also the increased use of technology in campaigns and the fact that the Presidential race drew so many contenders on the Democratic and Republican side because there was no incumbent running.
Of the $2.7 billion spent, the analysis found, $500 million was for Presidential campaigns. That included money spent in the primary and general elections as well as direct spending by national parties on behalf of their nominees. Of that, an estimated $233.5 million was spent by or on behalf of candidates seeking the nomination; $42.1 million on the two major party conventions, and $28.3 million in the general election.
The $500 million does include roughly $43 million in money that is not federally regulated that was collected to help the Presidential candidates even though it was not donated to their campaigns directly. It also does not include spending by political action committees that were established by some candidates.
An even larger share, $540 million, was spent on campaigns for state office such as governor and state legislator, plus another $365 million for campaigns for county and municipal employees.
Another $457.7 million was spent by all candidates for Congress; $328.3 million by the national party committees on costs not including direct donations to campaigns; $224 million by political action committees and other groups not directly linked to the parties; $87.5 million by state and local party committees, and $225 million on campaigns supporting or opposing local ballot propositions.
The book also found that President Bush's campaign spent more to buy advertising time than the campaign of Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee who was Governor of Massachusetts. Not counting many of the production costs, the Bush campaign spent $31.4 million on advertising, while the Dukakis campaign spent $23.5 million.
Mr. Alexander, whose book is the eighth in a series on financing campaigns, predicted that far less money will be spent in the 1992 Presidential race because there is essentially no contest on the Republican side.
"Spending in 1992 will be more like in 1984," he said. "Even the Democrats' spending will be down because they're getting a late start."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Broad Decline; Gold Rises in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined yesterday amid speculation that interest rates would rise in Germany. The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, is expected to raise rates in hopes of cooling inflation, analysts said.
Gold rose $1.30 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $365.90 an ounce. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $366.00, up $1.75. 
 The dollar tends to fall when interest rates rise in another country, as emand increases for investments denominated in that country's currency. Other currencies also traded lower against the German mark.
John McCarthy, chief dealer with Algemene Bank Nederland in New York, said the dollar traded within a narrow range, from 1.7800 to 1.8150 marks. He said the foreign exchange markets were thinning out as traders began to take their summer vacations.
The dollar fell to 1.78725 marks in New York from late Tuesday's 1.7935. In earlier European trading, it fell to 1.7840 German marks from 1.7965.
The mark also advanced against other currencies, particularly the Japanese yen. Cross trading, deals involving the other currencies, also helped depress the dollar, analysts said.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, testified before Congress yesterday, telling lawmakers the Fed was spending a significant amount of its time wrestling with the country's credit crunch. Mr. McCarthy said, however, that Mr. Greenspan's appearance had little effect on the dollar.
Analysts also said the Government's latest report on the gross national product's peformance in the first quarter did not affect trading. The Commerce Department said the G.N.P. fell at an annual rate of 2.8 percent, weaker than an earlier 2.6 percent estimate.
The British pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.6385 in New York from $1.6310 late Tuesday. Earlier in London, sterling rose to $1.6390 from $1.6280.
The dollar slipped to 138.275 yen in New York, from 138.30 Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to a closing 138.53 yen, from 138.38 yen at Tuesday's close, and in London, it fell to 138.40 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5475 Swiss francs, down from 1.5498; 6.0685 French francs, down from 6.0890; 1,332.75 Italian lire, down from 1,335.00; and 1.14215 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14195.

HEADLINE: U.S. VOICES REGRET ON YUGOSLAV CRISIS

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
The Bush Administration expressed regret today that Croatia and Slovenia had announced moves toward secession from Yugoslavia and declared that the United States would ignore those "unilateral steps" in future dealings with the country.
In statements by Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, and Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, the Administration said it believed there were "still opportunities for compromise" among the contesting forces in Yugoslavia. 
 President Bush, saying the United States position on Yugoslavia's unity was very clear, said this afternoon: "What we don't need is more violence in the world. We do need some more peace and tranquility and people sitting down and talking about their differences." He commented during a picture-taking session at the White House.
"Instability and the breakup of Yugoslavia could have some very tragic consequences," Mr. Fitzwater said at his regular briefing, adding, "The United States still believes that there are opportunities for compromise within Yugoslavia acceptable to all six republics."
Reiterating the United States policy that despite the declarations of independence on Tuesday, Yugoslav unity is of utmost importance, the spokesman said, "We believe it is a union, that it is best maintained in that state, that it can achieve its economic growth better in that situation."
Citing Prime Minister Ante Markovic of Yugoslavia by name, Mr. Fitzwater said the United States supported his efforts "to preserve the unity of his country."
At the State Department, Miss Tutwiler read a statement prepared by policymakers saying: "We regret that the Croatian and Slovenian republics made unilateral assertions of independence from Yugoslavia."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Yugoslavia Moves Upset Banks
 LONDON, June 26 (Reuters) -- Declarations of independence by Slovenia and Croatia unsettled bankers today and set off a sharp fall in the price of Yugoslavia's foreign debt traded on international markets.
"It's looking pretty sick," said a trader at a British merchant bank. "But the truth is there isn't a lot of business going through."
The price of Yugoslav debt slumped 3 3/4 points and was bid at 34 3/4 percent of face value after the news. Some dealers said the rate was likely to fall further in the near term.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
In Hartford Tax Talks, Calm Reigns

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 26

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has repeatedly warned Connecticut lawmakers that if they fail to pass a budget by Sunday at midnight, when the next fiscal year begins, much of the state government will come to a grinding halt. Sometimes he clasps his hands in front of him when he says it, as though in prayer. Other times he hitches up his pants, in an apparent gesture of assertive bluster.
But even Mr. Weicker's theatrics seem unable to break the calm -- verging on paralysis -- that has settled over the Capitol. The special legislative session that many had expected would be filled with shouted debates, angry demonstrations and passionate public protests about Mr. Weicker's proposed income tax has produced nothing of the kind. 
 Even though most lawmakers seem to agree that the state is facing a historic crisis in its budget, and a historic crossroads as well in deciding whether the crisis will be resolved with a long-avoided income tax, the realizations appear to have numbed people more than anything else. Mr. Weicker proposed his income tax plan in February as the only option to resolve the fiscal crisis and stimulate the economy, then last month he vetoed the Legislature's alternative budget, which had no income tax, forcing the special session.
"It's not high anxiety, which is something you would expect at this point," said James J. Finley Jr., chief lobbyist for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, and a 10-year veteran under the gold-leafed Capitol dome. Mr. Finley said he believes some lawmakers are pushing the brink with ice-water in their veins, while others have simply been frozen already.
Issues of personality -- specifically antagonism toward Mr. Weicker and his sometimes imperious style -- add the spice.
"There's going to have to be some compromise," said Representative John Wayne Fox, an anti-income tax Democrat from Stamford. "There's going to have to be a situation where it isn't just the governor sitting back and saying, 'I'm right, you're wrong. Do what I tell you."
 
Insider's Paradise
 Listen carefully. It's the sound of a closing door.
From the Governor's office to the legislative office building to Senate Majority Leader Cornelius O'Leary's living room in Windsor Locks on one rainy day last week, most of the business of government has been conducted out of sight and sound. And that's exactly how many lawmakers want it, especially the select group of 20 to 25 moderate Democrats in the House and Senate who are being courted by both those favoring the income tax and those opposed.
Like a rumor on Wall Street that sets off a bidding war, the latest word on lawmakers and their leanings on the income tax question has become inside information. Mr. Weicker's office has gone so far as to refuse to release the list of people who have been filing one-by-one into the executive chamber for persuasion on the matter. The daily count of votes for an income tax is issued after a day's horsetrading like the closing figures of the Dow Industrial Average.
Today's House count: about 60 in majority Democratic caucus, up about 5 from Tuesday's close. Passage of a budget requires 76 total votes in the 151-member House and Democrats have said they would need five to 10 Republican votes.
Today's Senate count: roughly 14 to 17 votes for some kind of income tax, unchanged from Tuesday's close. At least 18 firm votes are considered crucial for passage with all 36 Senators present. That would result in a tie, with Lieutenant Governor Eunice S. Groark casting the deciding vote.
 
Honeymoon From Hell
 Honeymoon watch: Senator Stephen R. Somma, a Republican from Waterbury who opposes the income tax, left this week for a honeymoon in Bermuda. Mr. Somma said last week before his departure that, much to his new bride's dismay, he would fly back to vote against the income tax if he could get sufficient notice to make the connections. Getting generous notice, however, would also depend on the majority Democrats who are trying to pass an income tax package over Mr. Somma's objections.
 
Thanks, but No Thanks
 Meanwhile, lawmakers remain less than impressed with the Governor's efforts to win them over. A former Republican, Mr. Weicker was elected last year as a third-party governor with no party allies in the Legislature, and no control over the traditional means by which party members are brought into line. He has reportedly offered to campaign on behalf of some lawmakers, but with the Governor's image now so closely linked to the income tax, a Weicker campaign appearances offers little allure.
Representative Richard T. Mulready, a pro-income tax Democrat from West Hartford, said he had talked with one colleague who was offered that plum and apparently wanted no part of it. "I said you should have got him to go out and campaign against you," Mr. Mulready said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Budget Battles"
 
New York
 
New York City: The City Council began drafting its own version of the budget to increase pressure on the Mayor and municipal unions.
The Dinkins administration escalated its campaign against the Council's proposed economies -- making public a list of the cuts and belittling many of them as unlawful or counterproductive. Jockeying for parity, the Council pressed for more discretion over spending.
 The Mayor and Council leaders decided against going back to Albany today without any agreement between them on how much to raise property taxes or with the unions on givebacks and other savings. Both agreements were deemed pivotal to the State Senate's approval of more state aid and a city income-tax increase.
 
Albany: Bargaining to restore some of the spending vetoed by the Governor was driven by New York City's budget deadline and by the Legislature's rush to adjourn, but neither was enough to get anybody off the dime.
Legislative leaders insisted, though, that the budget they approved earlier this month was balanced.
 
Connecticut
 Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. vowed to shut down all non-essential state services at midnight Sunday if lawmakers cannot agree on a budget he considers acceptable. The House Speaker, Richard J. Balducci, met with legislators to win converts for an income tax.
 
New Jersey
 The Florio Administration drafted plans for at least 4,000 additional layoffs to save up to $125 million. Senate Democrats predicted that layoffs would be necessary but expressed hope that the number would be smaller. Negotiations with unions on alternatives to the layoffs broke off last week.
The Senate President, John A. Lynch, criticized fellow Democrats in the Assembly for their budget proposal, which includes no layoffs. Assembly Democrats hope to protect the state's 70,000 unionized workers, many of whom live in districts represented by key legislators. -- June 27, 1991
