HEADLINE: Housing Earmarked for the Poor Is Enriching Big Investors Instead

SERIES: Vanishing Homes: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
A Federal program of housing for the poor is turning into profits for big real estate investors, led by one of America's business giants, the General Electric Company.
General Electric is about to become the biggest buyer under a Federal program in which nearly 500 apartment complexes taken over from failed savings and loan institutions are being sold by the Resolution Trust Corporation at discount prices to investors who agree to set aside 35 percent of the units for low-income families. 
 In real estate circles, all eyes are drawn to the G.E. deal. The company's financial and investment arm, the General Electric Capital Corporation, has agreed to buy 28 complexes with a total of 5,959 units in four Texas cities and six cities outside Texas -- at a price estimated at nearly 50 percent of market value.
 
Mandated by Congress
 Such discounts are meant to encourage sales of apartment complexes with limited rent controls under an affordable-housing program, mandated by Congress two years ago, to provide apartments and houses at prices the working poor can afford and without requiring the Government to pay for public housing.
In fact, in the portion of the program involving single-family homes, relatively few residences appear to have gone to the poor. But in the separate apartment program, a further complication emerges. Big investors, including General Electric, have figured out ways to obtain whole complexes and make hefty profits by adhering to the letter, if not the spirit, of the new law.
Critics contend that the Government is selling far more of its apartment complexes to for-profit investors than to nonprofit organizations whose primary mission is to help provide proper housing for the poor.
Moreover, they say, a plan by General Electric and other large buyers to lump the low-income units together and segregate them from the rest will inevitably create slums of the future.
Resolution Trust denies it is discriminating against lower-income groups in the apartment sales but it also says it has a duty to realize as much money within the bounds of the law as possible to minimize the costs of the savings and loan bailout.
The General Electric purchase, seen by investors as the model for future deals with Resolution Trust, is part of the first major package of apartments put out for bid under the agency's affordable-housing program. The package has 193 Texas apartment complexes, built originally by private developers and foreclosed on by the Government.
 
Going to Large Buyers
 Of that batch, more than 100 received no bids, and the largest number of the rest are being sold in bulk to large buyers, whom the trust corporation declines to identify. A number of other complexes, some too small to attract big investors, are being purchased by nonprofit agencies.
With a cost estimated at $75 million, the General Electric deal is the largest real estate transaction negotiated by the trust corporation not only in the affordable-housing program, but in sales of all property taken over in the savings and loan crisis. It exceeds the $65 million sale in March of a Palm Springs hotel to a group of Japanese investors and the $44 million sale of the Centrust building in Miami last month.
By agreeing to set aside apartments for low-income tenants and by buying in bulk, General Electric gets 40 to 50 percent taken off the purchase price -- a far steeper discount than General Electric would have received if it had bought the same complexes outside the trust corporation's affordable-housing program. This discount reduces the amount the Government will get back to trim the costs of the savings and loan bailout.
 
The Critics
Segregating The Poor
 Advocates of low-income housing contend that the General Electric arrangement is not socially sound or, in the long run, economically beneficial to the taxpayer.
They say the company's plan to segregate -- "aggregate" in real estate parlance -- poor residents into a few of the complexes miles away from the others runs counter to the policy goal of mixing low-income families with other income levels in the same complexes to provide what is regarded as a generally healthier community mix.
"The big players are making some great real estate deals, and in five years what they will have done for affordable housing is zilch," said James Ervin, a consultant to the Volunteers of America, one of the nation's largest nonprofit corporations. "This loophole allows private developers to sneak to the front of the line, pull out the cream properties, throw the rest back and create new slums."
Charles B. Gough, a consultant to the Dallas Housing Authority, said: "I don't believe aggregating affordable-housing tenants is the intent of the law."
 
G.E. Defends Proposal
 General Electric and the trust corporation disagree, contending the plan is both necessary and legal. Brown Thurman, a G.E. special projects manager who represented the company in the transaction, said: "The R.T.C. needs to have flexibility, or I won't bid. I will provide housing for the low income, but don't tie my hands. We're here to make a profit. If you restrict me as to what I can do and cannot do, I may or may not want to play."
Stephen S. Allen, head of the trust corporation's affordable-housing program, agreed on the importance of flexibility and aggregation.
"Aggregation," he said, "is permitted in the law. We'll be at this forever if we sell assets one by one. Our goal is to get a range of services to sell in bulk."
Yet the law permits only the big buyers to "aggregate." Buyers of just one apartment complex are specifically required to scatter low-income tenants throughout all buildings in that complex and not relegate them to a single building. The ability to aggregate was specifically put into the law to entice large private investors to buy properties in bulk to help move Resolution Trust's assets quickly, Mr. Allen said.
 
An Excellent Return
 Based on the numbers, Texas real estate experts said General Electric could expect an annual operating return of 13 to 15 percent under current market conditions -- a return regarded as excellent in the current market.
This compares with the return of 8 percent to 10 percent investors are receiving on similar apartment complexes bought without the large discount. Should rents rise, G.E. could earn as much as 15 to 18 percent.
Under aggregation, a buyer can quickly sell the complexes unencumbered by rent controls to another buyer for an immediate profit. In G.E.'s case, the company may further reduce its commitment to low-income housing and improve its return through a plan to sell the rent-controlled complexes to a nonprofit agency, which is trying to raise about $27.6 million to buy the units from G.E.
One of the reasons General Electric is able to bid on this deal is that it is a sophisticated, well-capitalized company with deep pockets. Resolution Trust is providing seller financing for many of its commercial properties but so far little in the affordable-housing program. In the Texas package, it accepted only all-cash offers. The net effect, according to Mr. Thurman of G.E., is that "only those with money can play."
 
Obstacles
Tough Going For Agencies
 Though Resolution Trust says it is working to improve the program, the nonprofit groups say that doing business with it has thus far been tough going, indeed. Of the few nonprofit groups that have managed to buy in, many have found that the agency has driven such hard financial bargains that they cannot fill their units with the extremely poor, as they would like, and still cover their debts.
"You can't house the homeless and pay a mortgage," said Louis Kurtz, housing development director at the Austin-Travis County Mental Health Center, which has purchased two small properties. "If the R.T.C. were committed to housing the homeless, that would be reflected in the purchase price."
Mr. Gough, the consultant, is currently bidding on a 280-unit complex and a 296-unit complex for the Dallas Housing Authority. He said he would like to fill his units with more than 35 percent low-income people, which he would not aggregate, but cannot unless some Government agency provides rent subsidies. No such money is currently available.
He estimates that it will cost $250 to $275 a month to cover the operating costs on each of his units. That is nearly $200 a month more than the average rent paid by tenants in Dallas public housing. "There is no way that I can fill 20 percent of the complex with very-low-income tenants," Mr. Gough said.
 
50 Tries, No Deals
 One agency that has had a particularly difficult time is the Volunteers of America, the nation's 22d-largest charity, founded nearly a century ago to provide housing to the poor. After two years of trying to buy some 50 trust corporation properties, it has been unable to close a single deal.
The organization says it has had financing problems and, in many cases when it finally learned what properties were available, the properties were no longer in the program for some reason -- or were not yet available for sale.
"We see this as a large opportunity to take care of housing for a large number of people," said Mr. Ervin, the Volunteers consultant. "But we've got limited resources."
Volunteers has tried to persuade the R.T.C. to help provide financing to buyers in the affordable-housing program by submitting a bid on some properties in the Texas package but with a second mortgage provided by the R.T.C.
The organization reasoned that the law required the trust corporation to provide financing to nonprofit buyers. But Resolution Trust turned down the bid.
"Affordable housing is the law," Mr. Ervin said. "It's a commitment from Congress and there should be an emphasis on making sure that what is the intention of the law occurs, and that's not happening. The R.T.C.'s job is to create affordable housing, not to find ways not to allow it."
 
Financing
Program Planned To Aid Agencies
 Resolution Trust says it is working with the Federal National Mortgage Association to develop a financing program that will help the nonprofit groups. Resolution Trust's Oversight Board has now adopted a policy allowing the agency to offer financing to nonprofit agencies with as little as a 5 percent down payment.
Still, although financing is important, the nonprofit groups said it could not alone solve all their problems with Resolution Trust.
Mr. Kurtz of the Travis County Mental Health Department has $2.5 million in foundation grants to buy apartment complexes for his clientele -- whose average income is about 17 percent of the area's median, or about $400 a month. The department has purchased 129 individual Austin apartments in eight locations on the open market.
But the Mental Health Department has also purchased one 20-unit apartment complex for $192,000 from Resolution Trust and has bid $320,000 for a 26-unit Austin complex. In the first case, Mr. Kurtz bid 85 percent of the agency's asking price, in the second one, 87 percent, hardly great discounts in his opinion.
Mr. Kurtz said he was not prepared for just how slow and confusing the process of buying would be. When he tried to submit a letter of intent to make a bid, the trust corporation asked him to get a resolution from his board authorizing him to look at the property.
Another resolution was needed to authorize him to bid. Another was needed to prove the agency was nonprofit. After Mr. Kurtz tried to submit the bid, he said he had to register with the trust corporation in order to do so. Then, after he thought he had a contract, the agency lost his down-payment check. A file clerk eventually found it.
To get information on other properties in the area, Mr. Kurtz said he had to know the name of the failed savings and loan that had owned the property.
Once his first bid was submitted, he said no one at the trust corporation could tell him whether it was accepted. And when he wanted to buy a second property, Mr. Kurtz could not resubmit some of the identical documents from the first time, but had to start all over again.
"It's driving me crazy," he said.
Nor, in Mr. Kurtz's opinion, did he get any break on price for his troubles. And, after bidding on the two properties, he saw an ad placed by Resolution Trust in The New York Times for a property next door to one he was buying that was better designed for his mentally ill tenants.
When he called the broker, he found that the property had already passed through the 90-day window during which properties are set aside exclusively for buyers agreeing to the affordable-housing restrictions and that some 10 investors had already put in bids.
Mr. Allen of Resolution Trust said things are getting better. "I don't think our procedure is bureaucratic or has a lot of red tape," he said, "and we are looking at ways the process can be improved."
But Mr. Kurtz remains skeptical. "I go to homeless conferences, and I see the faces of R.T.C. people there," Mr. Kurtz said, "But the R.T.C. is doing nothing to house the homeless."

HEADLINE: House Panel Approves Wider Bank Ownership

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
The House Banking Committee agreed today to permit industrial companies like retail chains and even automobile manufacturers to own banks.
This gave a tentative lift to the Bush Administration's plan to overhaul the nation's banking system. But the overall measure that would also let commercial banks operate across state lines, merge with investment banks and in some cases sell insurance, would have to clear many further hurdles before it could become law. 
 The committee plans to try to complete work on the measure tomorrow. It then must go to the Energy and Commerce Committee, where significant opposition has developed, before being taken up by the full House of Representatives.
In the Senate, the Banking Committee has not begun work on the measure officially. Senate committees often do not begin drafting controversial bills in public until all the important deals have been struck in private.
Still, the slow pace in the Senate makes it increasingly unlikely that broad legislation revamping the 60-year-old banking rules will be enacted this year.
 
A Need for Expansion
 Since the Depression, banks have been limited basically to taking deposits and making commercial loans. The Administration and its supporters maintain that in today's financial world, banks can attract sufficient capital to compete and prosper only if they are permitted to expand into other lines.
The legislation includes what its supporters say are thick "fire walls" that would separate banking from other businesses under the same ownership. For example, insured deposits could be used only in traditional banking activities, and banks could not lend money to their commercial affiliates.
Nonetheless, opponents contend that savvy bankers and their lawyers will find ways to breech the fire walls, and that taxpayers will be left paying for the banks' bad investments. "You're playing with fire," said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa.
The key vote today came on a proposal by Mr. Leach to continue to prohibit ownership of banks by commercial concerns. The proposal was rejected, 32 to 20.
There was no discernible pattern to how the lawmakers voted. Eleven Democrats and nine Republicans supported Mr. Leach; 20 Democrats and 12 Republicans opposed him.
Some liberal Democrats, like Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, the committee chairman, and Joseph P. Kennedy 2d of Massachusetts, voted to prohibit industrial enterprises from buying banks. Others like Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn and Barney Frank of Massachusetts supported the Bush Administration, voting to permit such purchases.
One proposal that was rejected tonight seems likely to provoke a partisan fight when the measure reaches the House floor.
This was Mr. Schumer's amendment that would have created two categories: core banks offering insured deposits paying only a limited rate of interest and that could lend no more than 3 or 4 percent of their equity to any one borrower; and other banks operating with uninsured deposits that could pay higher rates of interest and lend as much as they wanted to any depositor.
The proposal was rejected by a vote of 28 to 23, but Mr. Schumer vowed to offer it again to the full House.
The Bush Administration and most Republicans opposed the idea, mainly on the grounds that it might stifle competition or cause banks to lose deposits.
But many Democrats supported it as a way to guarantee that insured deposits were not used for risky activities like big loans to underdeveloped countries or for leveraged buyouts. That, the Democrats said, would lessen the likelihood of taxpayer bailouts.
No other issue this year has generated so much lobbying. The meeting room was jammed with representatives from dozens of interests, the hallway outside was clogged, and proceedings were piped into another room on the floor above so lobbyists who were too late to get into the Banking Committee's room could hear what was going on.
The ghost of the savings and loan disaster hovered over the debate today. Those who want to let banks get into other lines of business said that was the only way banks could survive and prevent another costly taxpayer bailout.

HEADLINE: Pickens Sells Japan Shares

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 26

 BODY:
T. Boone Pickens has formally ended his quixotic mission of opening corporate Japan to American corporate raiders by selling his shares in the Koito Manufacturing Company.
Mr. Pickens, the Texas oilman, acquired 26.4 percent of Koito, an automobile lighting manufacturer affiliated with the Toyota Motor Company, in 1989. He then waged a futile battle to gain several seats on the board. 
 Koito fought back with name-calling, unyielding resistance, open letters to the public seeking sympathy and, at the company's annual meeting last year, harassment during questioning.
In Dallas, Jay Rosser, a spokesman for the Boone Company, which Mr. Pickens heads, said today that Mr. Pickens had sold his Koito stake to Kitaro Watanabe, a Japanese stock speculator from whom he purchased the 42.2 million shares in 1989. He declined to disclose the price, but Koito's shares closed today at 2,390 yen, or about $17 at current exchange rates. Mr. Pickens is thought to have paid more than 3,300 yen a share.
In April, Mr. Pickens said he would give up his battle and sell the stock to Mr. Watanabe.
"There is both a tremendous sense of accomplishment and failure," Mr. Rosser said. "We have succeeded in putting the spotlight on Japan's closed economy and its anticompetitive bidding practices."

HEADLINE: First-Quarter G.N.P. Plunged by 2.8%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
The economy contracted at a sharp 2.8 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year, while corporate profits posted their biggest decline since the spring of 1989, the Commerce Department said today.
The first-quarter decline in the gross national product followed a 1.6 percent drop in the fourth quarter of 1990, thus meeting the traditional definition of a recession as two consecutive quarters of declining G.N.P. 
 The decline in the gross national product for the first quarter represented a downward revision from an estimate last month that put the decline at 2.6 percent. The Government attributed the weaker G.N.P. showing to an even bigger drop in consumer spending than previously estimated and a larger rate of inventory liquidation by businesses.
 
Squeezed by the Recession
 The 6.3 percent decline in after-tax profits was the largest setback since the spring of 1989. It followed a 1 percent fall in the fourth quarter and emphasized that businesses were continuing to be squeezed by the recession, a situation that analysts said was likely to continue for some time.
In the first quarter, consumer spending fell at an annual rate of 1.5 percent. Business investment was down 16.5 percent and housing construction, the most depressed sector of the economy, fell 25.3 percent.
A crucial clue on the economy's second-quarter performance will come on Thursday when the Government releases its estimate of consumer spending for May. Based on a good retail sales report, analysts are looking for a sizable gain of around seven-tenths of 1 percent.
If they are right, it would provide a strong signal that a sector of the economy that accounts for two-thirds of total G.N.P. activity is rebounding.
The various changes left the gross national product in the first quarter at a level of $4.12 trillion, after adjusting for inflation.
Economists said the worse-than-expected figures, while surprising, did not shake their belief that the economy resumed growing in the current April-June quarter at a weak annual rate that many estimated at five-tenths of 1 percent.
The Bush Administration, meanwhile, indicated it was still concerned that the economy was being choked by a lack of available bank credit, and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the Fed was devoting considerable time to wrestling with the credit crunch.
Mr. Greenspan, who appeared with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp at a Congressional oversight hearing, said that so far he had seen little improvement in the slowdown in bank lending. He did not say whether the Fed was considering further moves to lower interest rates to combat the problem.
 
Weakest Recovery in History?
 Most economists are not looking for more interest rate cuts from the Fed in light of various statements by Fed officials expressing concerns about aggravating inflationary pressures at a time when the recession appears to be ending.
But many private economists are forecasting that the recovery will be the weakest in history, with G.N.P. growth in the July-December period averaging around 3 percent, less than half the normal rebound following a recession.
Other analysts said growth might not even reach that level, given the number of problems facing the economy, from failing banks to debt-burdened consumers. They said the rebound could falter after a quarter of growth and the recession could resume in full force in the second half of the year.
"With the ending of the negative shock from the Persian Gulf war, the economy did rebound in the spring," said Allen Sinai, the chief economist of the Boston Company. "But the question is whether that rebound can be sustained."
 
More Bankruptcies Seen
 The severity of the recession was also highlighted today when the American Bankruptcy Institute predicted that bankruptcy filings this year would exceed one million for the first time in history, representing a 30 percent increase over 1990.
From January through March, personal bankruptcies were up 26 percent and business bankruptcies were up 14 percent from a year earlier. Only farm bankruptcies showed any improvement, declining by 6 percent, the institute said.

HEADLINE: A Marked Change in Style For Nomura's Leadership

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 26

 BODY:
Hideo Sakamaki is scheduled to become the Nomura Securities Company's president and chief executive at the firm's annual meeting on Thursday. But this quiet man was in many ways the least likely choice to succeed Yoshihisa Tabuchi as head of the scandal-plagued brokerage, the world's largest securities house.
In a company full of men with quick, sharp tongues, the 56-year-old Mr. Sakamaki is thoughtful and soft spoken. 
 Traditionally, Nomura's leader has come from its core sales operations; Mr. Sakamaki has devoted himself to strategic planning.
And in a business where firms have prospered simply by doing what they have always done best, selling securities, Mr. Sakamaki has been prodding Nomura to expand abroad, learn new businesses and change its very culture.
For these reasons Mr. Sakamaki, perhaps more than anyone else, represents what Nomura and the rest of the Japanese securities industry have been struggling to become but -- as the current scandal indicates -- have not yet achieved.
Mr. Tabuchi was forced to resign in humiliation on Monday after the disclosure that Nomura practiced favoritism toward big investors, a practice that is considered endemic to Japan's domestic financial market, but which has been rejected in many foreign markets, including the United States.
Nomura admitted it had improperly compensated some big customers more than $120 million for stock market losses. The other three members of the Big Four securities houses -- Daiwa, Nikko and Yamaichi -- have made similar admissions.
What the scandal seems to have demonstrated is that, despite fresh oratory and a stated desire to expand overseas, Nomura remains a domestically oriented firm wedded to peculiarly Japanese practices.
"Could this kind of thing happen in another market?" asked one foreign securities executive here. "Yes," he said. "Could it have happened on that scale? No. It is hard to imagine anyone else earning enough from a customer to consider paying him back so much."
Another foreign executive characterized the disclosures as "a peek into the flow of the lifeblood of Japan Inc."
Mr. Sakamaki has important qualifications for the chief executive's job. For one, he was regarded as an indispensable lieutenant to Mr. Tabuchi, who was highly respected at Nomura. Mr. Sakamaki has also been the firm's key liaison with the powerful Finance Ministry bureaucrats who regulate the securities industry.
At the same time, his distance from the sales operation means Mr. Sakamaki has been personally untainted by the current scandal, which goes beyond the improper reimbursement of losses.
Nomura is regarded as the principal link between the billions of dollars churning around in the stock market here and those who are willing to pay for a chance to get some of that money. This includes not only individuals, politicians and big corporations but also, as the current scandal has shown, people with links to organized crime.
Nomura has confirmed that it provided more than $100 million in financing to one of Japan's best-known organized crime bosses and then helped him carry out what was apparently a stock-manipulation scheme.
Mr. Sakamaki has not been available for interviews this week, but in a long talk earlier this year he shared his views of where Nomura should head. And, in frank language, he admitted the firm's shortcomings.
He could not have foreseen the present firestorm, but his remarks captured the source of Nomura's current problems: the company's sense of itself as a sales machine of unparallelled power, doing whatever necessary to sell investment products and round up more clients.
Nomura does offer a full range of securities services, from underwriting and trading to merger advising, asset management and options and futures dealing. But the largest portion of its revenue by far comes from sales commissions.
"Nomura's strong suit is the marketing side," Mr. Sakamaki emphasized. "That is the heart of a good business, and it is what we have."
He added that in all the ventures he has helped Nomura form with American specialty firms -- with Wasserstein, Perella & Company in mergers, with Eastdil Realty in real estate and with Babcock & Brown in leasing -- he believed that Nomura's biggest contribution was its ability to sell products. What the venture partners could offer Nomura in return, he said, was an understanding of how to conduct new businesses and operate in different countries.
"I know we're not as creative as the United States, but that is something we hope we can learn," he said. "It's our attitude that needs some adjustment."
The unyielding nature of the Nomura culture, Mr. Sakamaki admitted, made learning new skills a difficult process -- one he compared to "running a hundred-meter hurdle race."
Mr. Sakamaki's desire to propel the culture forward is one reason he said he had put great emphasis on building up Nomura's broker training program. Last year he spun the training operations off as a separate business to give them autonomy and some identity, he said.
"We're still a few steps behind the U.S. in this area, but we're headed in the same direction," he said.
 
'Investors Have Lost Faith'
 "Japan has a very fair and open market," Mr. Sakamaki said, adding that it "has not been as well organized as the United States."
He noted that individual investors had been fleeing the market because of last year's stock market crash and a sense that the market was unfair to the smaller investor. "We know a lot of investors have lost faith because of what has happened," he said.
Mr. Sakamaki repeated that remark almost verbatim at a news conference on Monday, when his appointment as president of Nomura was announced.
"That has to be our job, to renew that faith," Mr. Sakamaki added. This time, though, he said nothing of Nomura's mission to build itself into a global firm.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Jackson May Not Be Running But He's Still a Front-Runner

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
The Presidential campaign looms ever closer over the horizon. Racial politics are in the air. A dominant Democratic candidate has yet to emerge. All this leads to one thing: the Rev. Jesse Jackson is back.
Or at least he wants to be. 
 After two years of aimless wandering in a political Sinai, Mr. Jackson is moving to capitalize on recent events, sowing hope among his loyal followers and agita among some Democratic moderates.
The moderates had been hoping Mr. Jackson would continue on the arc of diminishing visibility that he has followed since declining to run for mayor of Washington, D.C., and settling for the obscurity of the make-work position of "shadow senator" for the District of Columbia. Instead, Mr. Jackson is raising the possibility of another run for the Democratic Presidential nomination, all the while declining to say that that is his plan.
"I have to look at all the political options for 1992 because I am the front-runner," he said.
In a few days of frenetic activity this month, Mr. Jackson put his political and personal strengths on display, as well as his weaknesses. He pointed out that the agency managing the savings and loan bailout was failing to award some contracts to black-owned businessess, as required by Federal regulations. He directed a disappointed bidder with internal documents detailing the practice to The New York Times in an effort to publicize what he considered an injustice. He criticized President Bush for his opposition to the civil rights bill, spelling out his differences with Republicans in ways few Democrats of weight have so far undertaken and with an oratorical passion few others can match.
"Race is a decoy that sets America against America," Mr. Jackson said in a recent speech castigating Republicans for what he said was using the quota issue for political gain. "It is a way for a politician to win, and the people to lose. It is morally wrong to polarize the country this way. Moreover, it is economically destructive. Race-baiting is a smokescreen that hides how vulnerable Americans really are."
At the same time, Mr. Jackson showed he is not above indulging his own ego and political jealousies. Sitting in his office, ticking off the bevy of Democratic heavy-hitters that would attend the five-day convention of the Rainbow Coalition, the political group he founded and heads, he sounded more like a youngster comparing his baseball card collection to that of his rival. In Mr. Jackson's case the rival is the Democratic Leadership Council, a moderate group that declined to invite Mr. Jackson to address its meeting last month.
"We've got Tsongas coming, Harkin coming, Gephardt coming, Simon coming, Gore coming, Graves coming, Rockefeller coming, Cardenas of Mexico coming," Mr. Jackson said. The references were to Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa, Paul Simon of Illinois, Al Gore of Tennessee and John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia, all Democrats; former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts, a Democrat; Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader; Earl Graves, president of Black Enterprise Magazine, and Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, a former Mexican presidential candidate for the left-wing Democratic Revolutionary Party.
 
A Prominent Non-Invitation
 Mr. Jackson said that his conference, held this month, was "far more substantive, far more diverse," than the Democratic Leadership Council meeting. One possible Democratic candidate not invited was Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the chairman of the leadership council. "He is not a candidate," Mr. Jackson said when asked why Mr. Clinton was not asked to attend. "It's nothing personal. I have appreciation for his work."
Inquiries about Mr. Jackson's own plans for 1992 bring forth coy demurrals, but his actions speak louder than his demurrers. When newspapers fail to record Mr. Jackson's own view of himself as the front-runner, he is quick to provide polls showing that he is at or near the top of Democratic candidates in terms of name recognition and initial support.
For example, he has referred repeatedly recently to a nationwide poll of 355 Democrats, conducted in April for Time Magazine and Cable News Network, in which Jackson scored higher than any other Democrat mentioned as a potential Presidential nominee.
Whatever renewed attention Mr. Jackson may be getting must be enormously satisfying to a man who just a few months ago seemed dangerously close to what all politicians fear most: irrelevancy.
 
Wilder's Tribulations Help
 Not a few Democrats have been saying that Mr. Jackson's role as chief spokesman for blacks within the party was being eclipsed by Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia. Even the contract Mr. Jackson signed with Time Warner Inc. to host a syndicated television talk show was canceled.
Yet if the gods seemed to have been frowning on Mr. Jackson in the recent past, they have in recent days changed their expression. The recent tribulations of Mr. Wilder, who has been engaged in a nasty feud with Senator Charles S. Robb, a fellow Virginian, could eliminate him as a rival to Mr. Jackson for the position of most influential black politician in the Democratic Party.
Even the snubbing by the Democratic Leadership Council and the White House opposition to the civil rights bill may help catapault Mr. Jackson back into the news.
"There is clearly a leadership void in the progressive wing of the party," said David Axelrod of Chicago, a Democratic consultant. The party's only other marquee liberal, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, is bogged down by his state's fiscal crisis, Mr. Axelrod noted.
Seated amid half-filled packing boxes at the Rainbow Coalition headquaters, on Vermont Avenue a few blocks from the White House, Mr. Jackson strenuously disputed the idea that he was losing stature or that he has been lying low. "We've been speaking out all along," he said, the back of his right hand tapping a visitor's knee for emphasis. "I speak to more people about the economic crisis in my country than any single leader in America today. Travel more and speak to more people."
Mr. Jackson is still dogged by the question of whether celebrity is viable substitute for experience. Despite his durability in the polls, Mr. Jackson enters this Presidential season with the same glaring shortcoming that dogged him in 1988: the lack of any administrative or legislative experience.
That shortcoming raises the question of whether Mr. Jackson made a watershed decision in his political career by failing to run for mayor of Washington, a post many believe he could have had for the asking.
 
Working Outside Spotlight
 Mr. Jackson would have none of such second-guessing about his political tactics, and the comparisons he reached for showed that he has come through the political wilderness with no self-doubt. He compared his political experience with that of people like Lech Walesa, the President of Poland, Vaclav Havel, President of Czechoslovakia and Nelson Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress.
Mr. Jackson insists that outside the news media spotlight he has been forging links with union leaders and environmentalists, seeking to expand his base beyond blacks and white-collar suburban liberals who were his core support in 1988.
"I was here the other day working on this convention when a judge came down with a ruling that affects workers in a major way in the Northwest country -- owls and lumber workers there," he said, referring to a Federal court decision that limits the cutting of ancient forests. "I was the first person they called for help. They called here. The carpenters up in the Northwest."
If that sounds familiar, it is the 1992 version of the Rainbow Coalition rhetoric of 1988. It may not get Mr. Jackson to the finish line, but it almost certainly guarantees him a place at the starting line if he wants it. A former adviser to Mr. Jackson said, "He has no intention of going gently into anyone's good night."

HEADLINE: Renewed Trade Benefits for China Run Into a Roadblock in Congress

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
President Bush's push to renew trade privileges for China is in serious trouble in Congress, with approval almost certain to be tied to conditions China vehemently opposes.
The hostility in Congress leaves the Administration in a quandary, lawmakers and Administration officials said. The most likely course is for the President to veto the bill from Congress and make a series of concessions to key senators to insure that the veto is not overridden. Even supporters of the Administration acknowledge that if the concessions are made, a successful override of a Presidential veto would be very difficult. 
 Another choice would be for Mr. Bush to abandon his complete opposition to any conditions and accept a bill with as few conditions as possible.
The President's decision to renew most-favored-nation trade status again this year has stirred even broader resistance than last year, when lawmakers were responding to the military crackdown on the democracy movement in June 1989.
China has refused to release many political prisoners jailed after the crackdown, and has further antagonized members of Congress by refusing to impose greater controls on its arms exports, accumulating a $10.3 billion trade surplus with the United States last year and reportedly exporting products made with prison labor.
Mr. Bush told a group of senators today that he would prefer to deal with problems in United States-Chinese relations individually, instead of tackling many issues with the conditional renewal of China's most-favored-nation status.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today that the President was negotiating with Senator Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat. Mr. Baucus is leading a bipartisan group of 15 senators who would be willing to support the President on an unconditional renewal of lower tariffs for China in return for other trade and financial sanctions.
The senators favor Taiwan's application to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a club of countries that commit themselves to obeying a long list of free-trade principles. They would also continue to bar China from receiving loans from international lending organizations like the World Bank.
The status of Taiwan is the subject of a bitter debate within the Administration because of the State Department's concern that its entry into GATT would infuriate China.
The intensity of Congressional distaste for the Chinese Government was apparent in today's debate and votes in the House Ways and Means Committee. Two leading opponents of unconditional renewal, who disagreed bitterly last year over how stringent conditions should be, reached a compromise before today's session, only to watch as the committee attached four more conditions.
The Senate Finance Committee is scheduled to vote on the issue Thursday morning, and the full House and Senate are expected to take it up after the Fourth of July recess.
 
'On a Veto Strategy'
 The Administration has mostly lobbied the Senate and paid less attention to the House, perceiving opposition to the President as stronger there. "We're still on a veto strategy," a senior official said. "I don't think we're looking at winning 50 percent, we're looking at winning 33 percent" in the Senate.
But a move on Tuesday by Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine and the majority leader, to make his proposed conditions less stringent has prompted the Administration to begin reviewing its position, the official said. The question is whether the Senator's conditions are better from the Administration's point of view than the concessions demanded by Senator Baucus.
The Democrats, while more united than last year, face a quandary comparable to the President's. They must decide whether to approve a bill with conditions addressing each of their concerns or settle for a more limited bill that would be more likely to win enough support to override a veto.
Conditions of both bills include curbs on Chinese exports of nuclear technology and intermediate-range ballistic missiles and an end to exports to the United States of products that some lawmakers and rights groups say are made with prison labor.
The Senate bill also requires that China cut off aid to the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, while the House bill was amended today to require that China not permit forced abortions and involuntary sterilizations and that Taiwan be admitted to the GATT.

HEADLINE: California Nears Budget Deadline $14 Billion Short

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 26

 BODY:
The nation's largest state is staggering toward the start of the new fiscal year Monday with an enormous budget shortage and growing signs that an elaborate compromise worked out by Gov. Pete Wilson may be starting to unravel.
An air of deepening crisis descended over the state capitol today as the Governor, a moderate Republican, closeted himself with leaders of the Democratic-controlled Senate and Assembly over the $14.3 billion shortage, which is by far the largest gap between spending and expected revenues ever faced by any state. The shortage is 30 percent of the state's general fund, which is the primary source for most essential services. 
 Last Thursday, the Assembly passed a $56 billion spending plan for the year beginning July 1, but lawmakers are now trying to reach accord on the taxes and cuts needed to balance the spending with the expected revenue. If that is not done by next Wednesday, the spending plan, by law, must die. At that point, the state would be plunged into a still deeper fiscal crisis that could threaten its bond ratings and cause layoffs of thousands of state workers.
The budget gap is nearly five times what California faced last year, a shortage that was made up by some taxes, along with bookkeeping devices to balance the budget, as the law requires. The huge shortage is the result of a combination of a recession-weakened economy, the effects of the voter-initiated referendum that limited the ability of local governments to raise taxes, Proposition 13, along with a huge population increase that placed big burdens on services for children, the elderly, AIDS patients and prisoners. The state now has a population of 30 million people, one in every nine Americans.
 
Wait Means Erosion of Plan
 As the talks dragged on today, elements of the Governor's plan that included a combination of taxes and spending cuts were eroding. Lobbyists were picking away at many of the new taxes the Governor had proposed, like broadening the sales tax to newspapers, magazines, candy and snacks, and imposing a 6 percent levy on telephone and cable television bills.
"The longer it goes on, the more deals start to fall apart," said one Assembly staff member.
The Governor and the four legislative leaders met until late this evening and left without disclosing whether they had made any progress.
 The messy climax to the California budget crisis has begun to dull Mr. Wilson's image as a pragmatic consensus-builder and problem-solver. He had been the subject of several upbeat reports by national news organizations touting him as a possible Presidential contender.
 
5% Tax Surcharge Proposed
 More people are suggesting that the solution to California's budget problems may be a "temporary" surcharge of 5 percent on the income tax owed the state. California's income tax is already among the highest in the country, with a top bracket of 9.3 percent.
The suggestions have come mainly from Republican Assembly members, who, despite their ideological aversion to higher taxes, find it preferable to other taxes. This puts the Republican Governor in a difficult position because he has vigorously opposed any general increase in personal or business income taxes.
Governor Wilson's efforts have also been snagged by the national political uproar he caused, perhaps unwittingly, when he proposed 10 days ago to take $1.6 billion from the $62.3 billion California Public Employees' Retirement System to help bridge the budget gap. He also proposed to revise the makeup of the system's board of directors to give himself control. The system is the largest pension fund in the world.
The Governor's proposal unleashed a fierce lobbying campaign by pension fund officials and state-employee unions that has threatened Mr. Wilson's entire budget package. Democratic leaders have balked at the Governor's proposals regarding the system, which was a main topic of today's meeting in the Governor's office
Governor Wilson's press secretary, William Livingstone, conceded that there would be modifications in the plan; it was widely expected that the Governor would be forced to drop his plan to take control of the pension system's board before any further progress could be made on the budget.
In addition to the $1.6 billion from the pension fund, Mr. Wilson had proposed to solve the budget shortage with $7.7 billion in higher taxes, the largest tax increase in state history, and nearly $5 billion in spending cuts, including a proposal to cut back welfare payments.
 
Assembly Members Balk
 The State Senate has accepted most of the package. But Governor Wilson has had trouble in the more fractious Assembly, both from the Republicans, most of whom refuse to vote for any new taxes without what they call "structural reforms" in government to cut spending permanently, and from liberal Democrats who are balking at cuts in welfare and other programs.
Uncertain about what to expect, state and local agencies have begun to make plans to lay off workers, shut hospitals and cut services. Supervisors in Alameda County, near San Francisco, voted Tuesday to lay off 200 county workers and close a mental health clinic and officials in Yolo County, near Sacramento, have decided to close Yolo General Hospital, which serves mainly the poor. Nearly all the campuses of the California State University plan to lay off faculty and staff members.
 
Governor Returns Two Cars
 Even the Governor has had to sacrifice. As he was asking the Legislature last week to cut welfare payments to women with young children, he received delivery of two $30,000 Lincoln town cars, official vehicles that his staff hastened to explain were ordered by his predecessor, George Deukmejian, a Republican who was a stern foe of government waste and spending.
Ultimately, the Ford Motor Company rescued Mr. Wilson from this embarrassment by taking the cars back, at the Governor's request, even though they had been specially modified to burn methanol fuel.
The plan for a 5 percent income-tax surcharge came from Assemblyman William P. Baker, a Republican from Alameda. It would raise more than $1 billion a year and would eliminate the need for the new telecommunications tax and some of the sales tax increases.
Governor Wilson has said he opposed such tax increases as damaging to a faltering economy. "There could be a push for higher income taxes, but it's hard to imagine it will work," said Mr. Livingstone, his spokesman.

At the meeting were, from left, Assemblyman Ross Johnson, Senator David Roberti, Assemblyman Willie Brown and Senator Kenneth Maddy. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 2 Southern Banks Discuss Merger To Form the 2d Biggest in the U.S.

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The NCNB Corporation, a fast-growing banking powerhouse from the Southeast, is negotiating to acquire another large Southeastern banking company in what would be the largest merger in American banking history, setting the stage for a decade of consolidation in the troubled industry.
Directors of the C&S/Sovran Financial Corporation, which itself is the product of a merger last year, could decide as soon as today to accept NCNB's offer to combine and become the nation's second-largest banking organization. Its operations would stretch from the coastal cities of Baltimore and Miami to the oilfields of West Texas, and it would have assets of $116 billion.
 
Bigger Than BankAmerica
 It would surpass the BankAmerica Corporation, which had $111.9 billion in assets as of March 31. Only Citicorp, with assets of $216.9 billion, would be larger in the United States. 
 If NCNB can bring off the deal, it would open a new realm for super-regional banks, which began in the early 1980's as some states opened their borders to interstate acquisitions.
NCNB, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., has grown rapidly into Florida, and five other states including Texas -- where it wrangled billions of dollars in Federal assistance in 1988 to take over the failed First Republicbank, the state's largest.
In a decade, Hugh L. McColl Jr., NCNB's fiercely competitive chairman and chief executive, has taken his little-known bank with big ambitions and created a banking behemoth by acquiring a hodgepodge of community banks, failed banks and savings and loans as well as regional institutions.
NCNB has grown into one of the nation's 10 largest banking companies, has $66 billion in assets, from the North Carolina National Bank with $7.7 billion in assets in 1981.
In addition to NCNB, other strong regional banking companies include Banc One, of Columbus, Ohio; Fleet/ Norstar, of Providence, R.I.; NBD, of Detroit; Norwest, of Minneapolis and Suntrust, of Atlanta.
The prospect of an NCNB-C&S/Sovran merger "is potentially a catalytic event for the banking industry," said James J. McDermott, Jr., president of Keefe, Bruyette, Woods Inc., a bank research firm in New York.
William M. Isaac, the former head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said, "It is enlarging and redefining the emerging super-regional banks." He added that the strong earnings power of regional banking organizations like NCNB allows them to make acquisitions of weaker institutions.
Many industry experts believe 10 to 15 super-regional banking organizations will emerge before the decade is out, ranging from $100 billion to $200 billion in assets. "We are going to see the banking industry continue to consolidate," Mr. Isaac predicted.
Banking experts have long anticipated that some hard-charging regional banks would come to rival some of the nation's biggest banks in money centers like New York, Chicago and San Francisco. Word of a possible merger moved C&S/Sovran's stock on the New York Stock Exchange to close as $22.75, up $3.375. NCNB's shares on the Big Board closed at $38.25, up 12.5 cents.
A person close to NCNB said the deal would be worth almost $4 billion in stock for shareholders of C&S/Sovran.
A spokesman for C&S/Sovran, which has headquarters in Atlanta and Norfolk, Va., Scott Scredon, said yesterday that the company's chairman and chief executive, Bennett A. Brown, had been authorized to meet with NCNB's Mr. McColl, "to discuss the North Carolina bank's proposal to merge." It said that Mr. Brown would discuss NCNB's offer with the C&S/ Sovran board today.
In a statement, NCNB confirmed "preliminary and exploratory" discussions between the companies and added it looked forward to continuing the talks.
Mr. McDermott, the banking analyst, said investors were unconvinced by Wednesday's announcements that NCNB would eventually succeed in adding C&S/Sovran to its growing network. "We are in the early stages," he cautioned. In the past, big bank mergers have hit snags and Mr. McColl's blunt, outspoken style has a reputation for rubbing some people the wrong way.
 
Earlier Takeover Proposal
 C&S/Sovran was forged last year from two regional companies, the Citizens & Southern Corporation, based in Atlanta, and the Sovran Financial Corporation, of Norfolk, Va., after Mr. Brown of Citizens & Southern rejected a hostile takeover offer from NCNB in 1989.
For NCNB, C&S with or without Sovran had some attractive strategic advantages. Since, 1985, when NCNB bitterly lost out in a bid to acquire a big Atlanta bank, Mr. McColl has been minor player in Georgia and Atlanta where C&S dominates the market and the economy grew robustly in the mid-1980's.
Now with Sovran, NCNB would get a large franchise in the suburban Washington market. That area is mired in a real estate recession, but Mr. McColl has perceived the region as a lucrative consumer banking market with long-term growth potential.
Besides Georgia and Washington's suburbs in Maryland and Virginia, a C&S/Sovran deal would include banks in the deal Tennessee, South Carolina, Kentucky, Maryland and Florida.
 
Problems From Earlier Merger
 For C&S/Sovran, a combination with NCNB may be the best solution for a merger that had its problems. Many C&S/Sovran shareholders have been disappointed with the results. Wall Street analysts faulted company executives earlier this year for moving too slowly to trim payrolls and exploit other cost-cutting opportunities that usually provide the economic appeal for regional banking mergers.
The company reported a 72 percent drop in earnings in the first quarter along with a jump in nonperforming assets to $1.1 billion, or more than 3 percent of loans outstanding -- an unhealthy level. The recession was a factor, but the main problems included bad loans on several commercial real estate projects in the Washington area.
The company continues to pay a dividend and has adequate capital, but its stock value has plunged. Mr. Brown, who is 62 years old, postponed his retirement planned for the end of this year and agreed to stay for at least another year.
 
Change of Attitude Possible
 But some individuals believe that Mr. Brown, who refused in 1989 to meet with NCNB's Mr. McColl, to discuss the earlier takeover offer, is more willing to bargain now because a takeover by NCNB would bring a more rapid payoff for C&S/Sovran shareholders than would be required if the company remained independent.
John S. Poelker, a financial consultant in Atlanta who worked with Mr. Brown for eight years as president of Citizens & Southern between 1978 and 1986, said the big question facing directors on Thursday will be how fast the company's earnings and stock value can rebound on their own compared with the bid NCNB puts on the table.
"Clearly, the combination of C&S/ Sovran with NCNB creates a very powerful entity with a lot of resources," Mr. Poelker said. He said C&S/Sovran would require as many as three years before the stock could recover from the recent setbacks.
A person close to NCNB said Mr. McColl's offer was to exchange each common share of C&S/Sovran for three-quarter share of NCNB stock. C&S/Sovran has 133.4 million common shares outstanding.
Figured at the closing price Wednesday for NCNB's shares, at $38.25, the deal would be worth $28.69 a share for C&S/Sovran shareholders, a 26 percent premium over C&S/Sovran's closing stock price of $22.75 yesterday on the Big Board.
In a separate announcement, NCNB said its earnings for the second quarter would fall slightly, to $1.20 to $1.25 a share, compared with $1.26 a share in the corresponding period last year. Profits will be flat or slightly higher than the $1.20 a share earned in the first quarter this year, the company said, with nonperforming loans rising $20 million to $50 million.

HEADLINE: ALBANY OFFICIALS WEIGH BORROWING FOR NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
As New York City's budget stalemate worsened yesterday, state officials weighed with renewed urgency proposals for long-term recovery that could avert some of the pain and spread the rest over several years.
The goal would be to let the city borrow to cover deficits -- which is strictly forbidden now -- without the stigma of invoking the authority of the State Financial Control Board, whose binding powers over the city's budget largely lapsed after the city recovered from its fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's. 
 Another goal would be to enlist the support of Mayor David N. Dinkins, who earlier this year briefly mulled the notion of borrowing to cover recurring deficits but has fiercely opposed the challenge to his prerogatives by a reinvigorated control board, which deficit financing would trigger.
 
Union Concessions Needed
 Any successful long-term strategy would be contingent on concessions from municipal unions so that the borrowing would not merely substitute for proposed layoffs and increased productivity. Moreover, the strategy would have to pass muster with the municipal bond market, which last month signaled its opposition to one version of borrowing proposed by Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
The Mayor's chief spokesman, Leland T. Jones, responded cautiously to the latest proposals. He said yesterday that the city could balance its next budget with the cooperation of the State Legislature and the City Council but warned that any suggestion of deficit financing would make the bond markets "wacky."
That apprehension was shared in Albany. At stake in the delicate maneuvering are not only the city's precarious finances but also the political reputations of Mr. Dinkins and of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is reluctant to be perceived as usurping the city's first black mayor.
 
Start of New Fiscal Year
 As state officials, including members of Mr. Cuomo's administration, and economic advisers searched for a long-term solution, the city's effort to balance its budget by Monday, the beginning of its new fiscal year, was complicated on two fronts yesterday.
Adamant City Council leaders announced last evening that they would draft their own alternative to the Mayor's $29 billion budget by today without the $476 million more in property taxes, proposed by Mr. Dinkins, than the Council has been willing to endorse. [Page B4.]
In Albany, the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Nassau County Republican, and the six Republican senators from New York City in effect allied themselves with the Council by declaring that they would reject the city's request to raise income tax rates unless other proposed tax increases were rescinded.
Those developments contributed to concern at City Hall that any budget adopted by next week would include most of the severe cuts that Mr. Dinkins and other politicians had hoped to avoid. Yesterday, the Governor convened a meeting of the Financial Control Board for Tuesday to review the city's progress on its budget.
"I have only one desire: cooperation, not control," Mr. Cuomo said yesterday.
But with the budget talks deadlocked, several state officials and city and state economic advisers have been discussing the need for a broader recovery plan to get the city past its latest fiscal crisis -- presumably by assembling a bailout that would, among other things, allow the city to rescind some cuts that are to go into effect next week.
 
Lukewarm Reception
 Similar plans received a lukewarm reception from the Governor earlier this year after they were viewed, particularly among some black political figures, as a challenge to Mayor Dinkins's control over city finances.
One official familiar with the latest effort said it could only succeed with the Mayor's full support. It would seek to somehow avoid another period of control by the state board -- at least to the extent that it was exercised when the board was first created -- to spare Mr. Dinkins the seeming loss of political face and to spare the city the stigma associated with deficit financing.
It was unclear whether the borrowing would be by the Municipal Assistance Corporation, created in the mid-1970's to issue bonds on the city's behalf, or some other mechanism.
Edward V. Regan, the State Comptroller, agreed yesterday with proposals for a multiyear plan to address structural problems in the budget but cautioned that some oversight authority would be necessary.
 
A Long-Term Plan
 By imposing a long-term recovery plan, the city could avoid further savaging services because it would have more time to bridge recurring deficits. The plan would also require the cooperation of municipal unions in shrinking the city's work force and making it more efficient.
Existing inefficiences were raised in Albany yesterday as one reason for the Senate's reluctance to pass a tax package that Republicans denounced as excessive.
"In a city that has been criticized for putting only one out of three of its education dollars in the classroom and finds money to have supervisors supervising the supervisors who supervise the actual workers," Mr. Marino, the Senate majority leader, said, "it is clear that Albany must not hand the Mayor a blank check on taxes."
While they disagree over the city's tax package, Mr. Marino and the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, concurred yesterday in their opposition to the Governor's veto earlier this month of $900 million worth of expenditures in the budget belatedly approved by the Legislature.
The legislative leaders indicated that they would pass new bills next week to spend the $800 million surplus that they maintained the vetoes had created. Mr. Cuomo, who has threatened to veto any bills that he does not believe are backed by sufficient revenues, said yesterday, "If the statements by the legislative leaders today are meant to warn us that they are seriously considering spending money they don't have, then, regrettably, they have placed us on the road to fiscal chaos."
Representatives of the Mayor and the Council traded recriminations and agreed on only one thing yesterday: not to bother returning to Albany today to lobby for a $335 million city income tax increase. They still lacked the two assurances that the State Senate was demanding before it considered the increase -- an agreement between them on how much property taxes would be raised and an agreement with municipal unions on "givebacks."

HEADLINE: Hilton Cleared to Operate A Casino in Atlantic City

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, June 26

 BODY:
The hotelier Barron Hilton, denied a license to operate a casino in Atlantic City in 1985 because of connections to a reputed organized-crime figure, received a green light from casino regulators today to return to the city.
The decision prompted speculation that Mr. Hilton would try to win back the financially tottering Castle Casino, which he lost to Donald J. Trump six years ago. 
 "We could have a new baron in the Castle," quipped a Casino Control Commission staff member just before the commission voted.
The five-member commission certified unanimously that Mr. Hilton and the worldwide hotel chain that he heads now had the financial backing and the unblemished integrity required to operate a casino here.
 
A Setback in 1985
 That was not the case in 1985 when Mr. Hilton, chairman of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, applied for a casino license to operate a casino hotel that the chain had built in the Marina section of Atlantic City.
The commission decided then that neither Mr. Hilton nor the corporation could be licensed because they did business with a California lawyer, Sidney Korshak, who was described by the commission as someone "reputed to be a 'fixer' for organized crime." The commission also said that some Hilton hotels had been involved in kickback schemes and other improprieties.
But today, in granting Mr. Hilton and Hilton Hotels permission to run a casino here, the commission found that both had purged themselves of any questionable associations. Both severed their relationships with Mr. Korshak in 1984, the commission said, and now display "good character, honesty and integrity."
The commission said a license would be granted when Hilton acquired a casino property in Atlantic City, a step that Mr. Hilton said he planned to take.
 
A Switch in Casino Names?
 In 1985, when the Hilton chain found itself unable to open the casino hotel it had already completed in Atlantic City, there were quick negotiations with Mr. Trump. These resulted in sale of the property for $320 million, which was about what Hilton had invested, and Mr. Trump took down the Hilton logo on the front of the casino and put up his own: Trump's Castle.
Mr. Trump's subsequent financial tumble fueled speculation today that Mr. Hilton might be planning to put his name back up there again.
Mr. Trump, who sharply increased the casino's debt with a 100-room, $100 million expansion in the late 80's, has missed recent bond payments of more than $40 million on the Castle, one of three casinos he owns in Atlantic City.
Last week the commission ruled that Mr. Trump had enough financial stablity to retain his licenses at his two other casinos, the Taj Mahal and the Plaza, but deferred action on the Castle.
The commission laid down a series of deadlines today that Mr. Trump must meet to complete the financial restructuring he has pledged will save the Castle from financial collapse. If he does not meet them, he will lose his license to operate the casino.
Gregory R. Dillon, vice chairman of the Hilton Hotels Corporatin, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said today that there have been no negotiations with Mr. Trump or anyone else. He said, however, "It would be much easier to go down the street and buy a hotel rather than build one."
One dissident holder of bonds on the Castle, who has refused Mr. Trump's current offering of a restructuring, said he would be delighted if Mr. Hilton took over. The bondholder, Mort Cohen of Margate, N.J., said: "I can't tell you how thrilled I would be with the Hilton corporation."
In another action today that underscored the difficulties afflicting the gambling and tourist industries in a time of economic downturn, the commission agreed to a debt restructuring proposal involving the Bally's Park Place and Bally's Grand casinos in Atlantic City. The parent company, Bally's Manufacturing, is having financial difficulty in its Las Vegas gaming operation and must reduce its involvement in Atlantic City as a result.

HEADLINE: Roland Van Zandt, 72, Writer And Historian of the Catskills

BYLINE: By ELEANOR BLAU

 BODY:
Roland Van Zandt, an author and historian who was concerned with the preservation of the Catskills, died on Monday at the Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Shandaken, N.Y.
He died of cancer, said Deborah Allen, co-publisher of the Black Dome Press. 
 The Black Dome Press recently issued a special edition of Mr. Van Zandt's first book, "The Catskill Mountain House," on the 25th anniversary of its publication by Rutgers University Press.
The book is about a famous Greek revival hotel and the early development of the area. Reviewing it in The New York Times in 1967, Henry Christman said the author had "re-created the fascinating history of the upper Catskills to give a large and illuminating view of America's 19th-century cultural, social and economic growth."
Mr. Van Zandt wrote two other books, "The Metaphysical Foundations of American History" and "Chronicles of the Hudson." He also wrote a play, "Wilson in the Promise Land," which ran briefly on Broadway in 1970, as well as articles and reviews.
He was the director and then an adviser of the Catskill Center for Conservation and Development.
A graduate of Rutgers University, he received a master's degree from Harvard University and a Ph.D. in American studies from the University of Minnesota.
Surviving are his wife, the former Leona Thompson; two daughters, Caroline and Carla, both of New York City; a son, Carter R., of Shandaken, and four brothers, Henry, of Madison, Conn., Harvey, of Morristown, N.J., Richard, of Laguna Beach, Calif., and Harry, of Clifton Knolls, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Making Child Care America's Business

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
WHEN the good times rolled in the 1980's, business school graduates could not get to Wall Street fast enough. Just about the last venture on graduates' minds was the child-care industry, a business that operates, at best, with fragile profit margins.
But Linda A. Mason and Roger H. Brown, who hold degrees from the Yale School of Organization and Management, are not typical business school graduates. This husband-and-wife team had worked with children as managers of large-scale relief programs for Cambodian refugees in Thailand and famine victims in the Sudan. To them, the child-care business made perfect sense. 
 "We wanted to combine our business backgrounds with our interest in social services," Ms. Mason said last week in her small office here, decorated with photographs of her two young children. "I know this sounds hokey, but we wanted to do something idealistic."
In 1987, they started Bright Horizons Children's Centers , which designs and operates work-site child-care centers for corporations, hospitals and real-estate developers in several states, primarily in the Northeast. Bright Horizons runs 39 centers with a total enrollment of about 2,500 children and a staff of 500 employees.
Its clients include the Prudential Insurance Company of America, Dun & Bradstreet, Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company, the Army Corps of Engineers, International Business Machines and several hospitals in New England, including Beth Israel in Boston, where the newest center opened in April.
Beth Israel spent $2.4 million to build its 9,700-square-foot center, an addition to a hospital building, plus an outdoor playground of 8,000 square feet. The center, which is carpeted throughout, is spacious, clean and cheerful. It has a series of rooms and play spaces to meet the needs of children of different ages. The staff of 35 can care for as many as 114 children, from 6 weeks to 5 years old. There are 103 children enrolled, but there is a waiting list for Bunny Bungalow, the infants' area.
"We have had a lot of positive feedback from parents," said Lisa Fiering, a benefits specialist in the hospital's human resources department. "They are able to visit their children during the day. Some come down for lunch or to nurse their babies."
Ms. Mason, 36, and Mr. Brown, 34, began with the goal of operating on-site centers to suit the needs of individual corporations. They wanted to defy the conventional wisdom that a child-care company that operates multiple centers cannot maintain quality. Child-care experts say they have succeeded.
"They have an excellent reputation for running very fine centers," said Dr. Susan Ginsberg, an associate dean at Bank Street College in Manhattan who directs the college's Work and Family Life seminars for corporations. "They have high standards and a staff of very good people."
Dr. Edward F. Zigler, a Yale psychologist and an author of "Child Care Choices" (The Free Press, 1991), said he was so impressed by Bright Horizons that he accepted a nonpaying position on its advisory board. "They pay a decent salary and make sure the staff is trained and qualified to care for children," Dr. Zigler said.
Maintaining quality is difficult because of competing economic pressures. "You have to charge fees that parents can afford, yet you must pay wages that teachers find attractive," Mr. Brown said.
The child-care industry is known for low wages and high turnover of employees. In 1988, the National Child Care Staffing Study found, the average hourly wage for chains was $4.10 an hour and the average annual turnover of staff was 74 percent.
Ms. Mason said the annual turnover at Bright Horizons is between 20 and 30 percent. She refused to disclose hourly wages "because it upsets teachers who make less," but she said Bright Horizons pays "significantly above the national average."
Ms. Mason and Mr. Brown decided at the outset that they would require corporate subsidies in the form of free or low-cost real estate. By saving money on rent, they reasoned, they would be able to spend more on salaries. The companies for which they operate centers provide space rent-free, although in some cases Bright Horizons pays for utilities, taxes and maintenance.
It offers its directors and teachers a variety of benefits not commonly found in the child-care industry, including medical and dental insurance, stock options, life insurance and partial tuition reimbursement. And it continues to train staff members after hiring and has experts to monitor and development curriculums.
The fees at Bright Horizons centers typically range from $90 to $225 a child a week. Fees are highest in urban areas.
At six of the 39 Bright Horizons centers, employers subsidize the fees for low-income families. At Beth Israel Hospital, for example, employees who earn less than $20,000 a year pay $33 a week. The hospital pays the rest of the tuition, which is $140 a week for pre-school children and $225 a week for infants.
But even with subsidies, child care is a tough business. "There is little room for error," said Ms. Mason, who is on maternity leave after the birth of her son two months ago. Her other child, a 2-year-old daughter, is enrolled in a Bright Horizons center in her office building.
Bright Horizons was begun with $2 million that Ms. Mason and Mr. Brown raised from family members, private investors and Mr. Brown's former employer, Bain & Company, a management consulting firm in Boston. They were joined by Anne Whitman and Jack Reynolds, a Cambridge couple who could not find decent child care for their infant daughter, and Lois Baker, who had been a teacher and child-care center director. Mr. Reynolds remains on the board, but Ms. Whitman and Ms. Baker are no longer with the company.
Before the first center opened in 1987 in the Prudential Building in Boston, Ms. Mason said, there was "a harrowing year" of searching for business. "The on-site, corporate-sponsored center was a very new concept, and a lot of corporations saw no benefit in it," she said. "They did not understand that a child-care center would cut down absenteeism and help to retain employees."
Ms. Mason said that at the urging of the pediatrician Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, who is also an unpaid adviser, Bright Horizons has made a point of involving parents. "Every day, parents of infants and toddlers get a written note from the teacher, telling them what the child did," she said. "Twice a year, there are formal parent-teacher conferences, to go over the child's development."
Mr. Brown said the idealism that he and his wife share stems from their small-town backgrounds. He grew up in Gainesville, Ga., which calls itself, he said, "the chicken capital of the world." Ms. Mason comes from the upstate New York town of Homer, which, he noted, "has more cows than people."
"It's easier to be idealistic in a small town because you feel you can do something about a problem, that you can make a difference," Mr. Brown said.
Ms. Mason said that recently she returned to Yale for a reunion and found "all my friends making huge salaries." She did not have second thoughts.
"I love running my own company, and I love having my family be part of it," she said. "I can't imagine leaving for a more secure position on Wall Street."
"Secure?" Mr. Brown retorted in his Georgia drawl. "All my friends on Wall Street are watching their backs."
