HEADLINE: A Family Affair: Paying for the Wedding

 BODY:
GONE are the days when only the father of the bride picked up the wedding tab. In these tight economic times, splitting the wedding bill is very much a family affair.
"It's no longer shameful to say you're having financial difficulties, and very often the parents of the bride will let that be known," said Marcy Blum, a wedding consultant in New York. 
 Although they lack hard numbers, wedding planners say the recession has led to an increase in the number of "pooled weddings," which are paid for by a number of people, including friends who chip in for parties and even the honeymoon.
For many families, however, a pooled wedding often leads to strained relations or even disputes during what is supposed to be a sweet season of celebration. Nearly everyone who pays a share of a wedding wants a say in what goes on.
"Asking both sides of your families to contribute to your wedding is a very touchy issue," said Barbara E. Kirby, 37 years old, who is getting married this weekend in Hyannis port, Mass.
Ms. Kirby, an interior designer, and her fiance, Ford V. Swick, 35, a real-estate developer, are unemployed.
"In the beginning, lots of family members were willing to help, but the reality is that no one hands you a blank check," said Ms. Kirby, who plans to dip into her dwindling savings to pay for a third of the wedding costs. Her father and her fiance's family plan to contribute an equal amount.
"The whole thing was such a strain, with both of us unemployed, that we almost called the wedding off; our family convinced us not to cancel," said Ms. Kirby, who will have 150 guests, six bridesmaids and a buffet dinner at her wedding. "We started planning at a time when we assumed we'd get jobs."
Lavish weddings remain popular, said Cele Lalli, editor of Modern Bride magazine, and for couples who want them, trimming costs or getting financial help from family members or friends is often a necessity.
Earlier this year, 20 friends of a Manhattan couple paid for their honeymoon, a night in a suite at the Royalton Hotel on West 44th Street.
Regan M. Botts, a wedding consultant in Washington, said 75 percent of the couples she works with finance their own weddings because of shifting family relationships and finances. Many parents have divorced and remarried, and many fathers of the bride, now with new families, cannot afford a large wedding.
Since engaged couples today tend to be older, with established careers, Ms. Botts said, "it doesn't make sense to ask Dad to dole out all the money." The median age of first-time brides and grooms has risen from 20 and 22 years old, respectively, in 1965, to 24 and 26 years old last year. More working couples have been paying for all or part of their weddings in recent years, but their ranks have been low until now, wedding planners said.
"There is a definite trend in which couples are financing some portion of the wedding," Ms. Lalli said. "Times are tough; it's the reality."
Ms. Blum said that about 65 percent of the couples she sees share the wedding expenses.
"It's no longer the bride sitting in my office, pouting and saying, 'But Daddy, I wanted the silver Rolls Royce,' " she said.
According to Modern Bride, the average wedding and reception cost about $16,000. In its next market survey, the magazine will ask how couples split the bill, Ms. Lalli said.
Where traditional etiquette reigns, the groom's family pays for the rehearsal dinner, flowers at the ceremony, clothes for the groom's attendants and sometimes for the alcohol at the reception. But for many couples and their families, that tradition is far from practical.
Sheryl Nance, 30, a reporter for The New York Law Journal, was torn between a quick jaunt to City Hall and a large wedding in her hometown of Oakland, Calif.
"Our major consideration was price," said Ms. Nance, who opted for a small ceremony at a chapel in Brooklyn. "My original budget was completely unrealistic: $3,500. We came in at about $6,000, which is cheap!"
Ms. Nance and her husband, Collin Nash, 46, a newspaper reporter, who had a combined income of about $50,000 when they started planning the wedding, had to limit their guest list to 75 for the wedding and a reception at a friend's house. Two friends gave them a $500 cocktail party as a wedding gift.
"So many of their friends couldn't come to the wedding that we thought a party would replace the reception," said Kris Oser, a friend of the couple.
Gale Lance, 26, a marketing assistant in Redondo Beach, Calif., is very organized. One week after Jeff H. Gould, 26, a marine superintendent for a shipping company in San Pedro, Calif., proposed to her, she opened a separate bank account and had $250 deducted from her paycheck each week and placed in the account.
"We didn't want to go into debt, especially during a recession," said Ms. Lance, who cut costs by planning a wedding brunch instead of a large reception. "There's no way I could expect my parents to come up with the money, and we didn't want to go to his parents for all of it, so everyone is giving a little bit."
Ms. Lance's father paid for the invitations, her mother bought the wedding dress and her future in-laws are paying for the liquor and the disk jockey at the reception.
"Both families will be paying the same amount, so no one's nose will get out of joint," said Ms. Lance, who acted like the captain of a baseball team, arranging for each player in her family to pay for something.
"We're picking up the rest of the tab," said Ms. Lance, who is also defying convention by having her mother accompany her down the aisle.
Who pays for what is not the only thing that's changing about weddings. For example, many couples want top billing on their invitations, a spot traditionally reserved for their parents.
"The whole gestalt has changed," Ms. Blum said.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Trim Fat at the Top

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
There is a management style you might call bottom up. It suggests that when a company wants to build a better mousetrap, the first place to look for proposals is not in the office of the vice president for strategic planning. It is on the factory floor, where the men and women who build mousetraps can testify to what works, where a 25-year veteran can say, "We always thought that if you wound the little metal thing around just one more time, you'd have the sucker perfected."
There's very little evidence that the City of New York ever used the bottom-up technique when it was planning its latest budget, a budget that promises to leave thousands of people without jobs and hundreds of thousands without services. 
 There is little evidence that department heads went to the factory floors, to hear from the nurses' aides, the teachers, the sanitation workers and the secretaries about where the fat could be trimmed. Perhaps they knew what one answer would be. At most corporations, I would wager the $21,000-a-year workers would tell you there's room at the top for economy.
In city government they would certainly be right.
The city Personnel Department reports that there are 150,000 employees in agencies directly under the mayor's jurisdiction, almost 4,000 of those management. The Personnel Department says 8,000 workers would be laid off under the Mayor's budget plan.
Only 49 of the management types would lose their jobs.
Libraries, preschools, drug rehabilitation programs and playgrounds will close because of this budget. Streetlights will dim; potholes will deepen. Health care will deteriorate. One sanitation worker got his pink slip and jumped from the roof of the housing project where he lived with his wife and two young sons.
But most management jobs will be protected.
Harsh measures are required to close this deficit now. But like the people on the factory floor who listen to the boss poormouth and then become angry when they discover he's negotiated a golden parachute the size of the Hoosier Dome, the line workers in city government deserve to know that harsh measures are egalitarian.
The use of cars and drivers, what we now call Sununus, should be cut to the bone, because of expense and because the subway would help commissioners and elected officials keep in touch with the city. The boondoggle of extra pay for Council committee chairmanships must end. Someone might argue that this would lower the caliber of people in the Council; it is important that someone make that argument because in bad times we all need a good laugh.
The president of the battered borough of the Bronx has a staff of 140 people, 41 more than the Manhattan borough president and probably twice as many as he should have.
And the City Council president, with staff, costs almost $4 million a year. The job is not unlike that of the Vice President of the United States; it provides an attractive suite of rooms for someone looking to run for higher office. (The Council president has also been designated city ombudsman. The borough presidents can ombuds, with their 100-plus staffs.) The city can no longer afford a luxury like the Council president when it is losing homeless shelters, summer job programs and meals for senior citizens.
There should be significant cuts in management positions in every agency, for three obvious reasons: because the managers will have fewer people to manage, because any exhortation to do more with less must be fulfilled first at the highest levels, and because it serves the taxpayers to have more people on the street and fewer behind desks.
 Next year, the fiscal wizards might start by asking the workers where the fat can be found. (The workers, not the union leadership. That's just more fat management, guys who haven't made a mousetrap in a decade and who sit in air-conditioned offices and wax poetic about the lot of the mousetrap worker.) One school nurse's aide suggested the other day that any city employee making over $100,000 should return 10 percent to the till, a gesture of good faith that would be a kind of tithing to the municipal gods. Praise the Lord and pass up the perks.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: How to Read the Black Migration to the North

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I think it's significant that Mitchell Duneier's "Black Migrants Have Done Better" (Op-Ed, June 11), criticizing my book "The Promised Land," never actually quotes from the book. That's because Mr. Duneier's real objection is to an article I wrote five years ago, and his search for offending material in the book leads him into the shadowy realm of impressions and implications. 
 I am well aware that studies comparing black migrants from South to North with blacks born in the North show that migrants' incomes are higher. I mention several of these studies in the book and in the footnotes, as Mr. Duneier acknowledges. He triumphantly announces that there is a study I didn't cite -- but there are dozens of studies I didn't cite that make the same basic point as the ones I did cite. I'm also well aware of William Julius Wilson's objections to my 1986 articles. I had them in mind as I researched and wrote, and I asked Dr. Wilson to read the book in manuscript (which he generously did, raising no objections to what I say about migration).
"The Promised Land" argues that the great black migration was an enormously important shaping event in American society. I made a point of including in it the stories of middle-class migrants and of discussing at length the growth of the black middle class; I didn't want to leave the impression that the migration was made up only of the rural poor or that most of the migrants didn't succeed in the North.
Still, I chose to make Ruby Haynes, a former Mississippi sharecropper who lived in Chicago for three decades, the book's main character. She was born to a teen-age mother in 1915, didn't meet her father until she was grown up, had children out of wedlock herself and had a poor education. In all this, she was typical of the sharecropper society she grew up in, as a wealth of firsthand scholarly material on that society will attest.
In telling the story of her life in a high-rise, low-income housing project in Chicago, I spent many pages describing how the city's politics, the economy, Federal social policies and urban demography affected her. I never said or suggested that her background was the sole determinant of her fate -- quite the contrary.
I know that impulses exist to dismiss the black migration as a failure, to impute all the problems of the ghettos to migrants and to be blind to the black middle class. But none of those impulses animated my book. Since the book was published, Mrs. Haynes has been treated as a heroine in her hometown of Clarksdale, Miss.
I was trying to break stereotypes with my writing, not reinforce them. Published response to the book contains none of the negative or hostile reaction to the African-American experience Mr. Duneier worried it might set off.
 
NICHOLAS LEMANN
Pelham, N.Y., June 11, 1991

HEADLINE: How to Read the Black Migration to the North;
Evidence From the 30's

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Mitchell Duneier raises some very important questions as a sociologist in "Black Migrants Have Done Better" (Op-Ed, June 11), questions that have interested, troubled and fascinated not only sociologists, but also the public and the press for more than 60 years. 
 Mr. Duneier criticizes Nicholas Lemann's book "The Promised Land: the Great Black Migration and How It Changed America" for neglecting the beneficial effect of a Northern environment on Southern blacks who migrated North, particularly on economic success.
Psychologists have been concerned for many years in evaluating the effect of Northern exposure on mental performance on tests.
The 1930's saw significant research on the borders of sociology, psychology and anthropology, notably by Franz Boas, his former student, Otto Klineberg, later professor at Columbia, and Ruth Benedict. I had the good fortune to earn a master's degree at Columbia in a joint study with Elsie Wallach (1932) under Dr. Klineberg.
That study, of 314 Binet I.Q. (intelligent quotient) tests of 10-year-old African-American boys and girls who migrated North from the South, compared with New York City children, showed a valid, conclusive, significant rise in I.Q. the longer Southerners went into the superior schools of the North.
Clearly, the total environment, school and society, economic and psychological, was in the 1920's and early 30's superior to the schooling and social environment of the South. This might not be true today!
Evidence from the psychological studies of the 1930's gives credence to Mr. Duneier's thesis that black migrants have done better and may help dispel the mythologies that continue to surround the study of race in this country.
 
H. ROGIE ROGOSIN
Laguna Hills, Calif., June 12, 1991

HEADLINE: Saving a New England 'Grande Dame'

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

DATELINE: BRETTON WOODS, N.H. June 26

 BODY:
The Mount Washington Hotel, the majestic 89-year-old structure that was the site of the Bretton Woods international monetary conference in 1944 and once a summer playground for the Vanderbilts, Astors and Rockefellers, was auctioned by banking regulators today and sold for $3.15 million to a group of local New Hampshire investors. They pledged to preserve the historic hotel while preparing it for the next century.
"This is not a bell tolling for the grande dame of the White Mountains," said Wayne Mock, the auctioneer, as he opened the bidding on the venerable 250-room hotel and resort that has had a history of ups and downs and was rescued from bankruptcy today and the clutches of the New England banking crisis. 
 The hotel where world economic leaders established monetary cooperation, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, was seized by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation last year. That is when the hotel's latest owners, the Eliot Savings Bank in Boston and its subsidiary, Eliot Partners Inc., failed. Eliot Savings had lent the subsidiary $7 million to run the hotel. The F.D.I.C. foreclosed on the property last month to set up the auction.
From the beginning, the success of the hotel, the largest structure in New Hampshire, seemed in doubt -- even on its opening night in 1902. Joseph Stickney, a New Hampshire coal baron who built the hotel, raised a toast that night "to the damn fool who built this white elephant." Mr. Stickney, according to a local historian, George McAvoy, built the hotel with the aid of 250 Italian laborers because he wanted to give something back to the state.
Eventually, Mrs. Stickney managed to convince her socialite friends to visit the hotel and it became a favorite for movie stars, sports heroes like Babe Ruth, and dignitaries like Winston Churchill.
The hotel fell into disrepair and was closed in 1943 when World War II cut off needed supplies. Then President Franklin D. Roosevelt chose it as the site of the world monetary conference. More than $1 million was poured into the hotel to prepare it for the conference, at which the gold standard was set and the dollar standardized as the international currency. Today's sale was completed on the same mahogany table in the room where the conference took place.
The new owners face a costly job, with estimates of needed repairs exceeding $10 million. The hotel, which is open from May to October, needs a 55 percent occupancy rate to break even, said Joel Bedor, the head of the investment group that purchased the property. He said the group planned to winterize the hotel to keep it open year-round.
Mr. Bedor and his partner, Wayne Presby, also own and operate the nearby Mount Washington Cog Railway, a leading tourist attraction that takes passengers to the top of Mount Washington, the highest mountain in New England. They said the hotel would fit into an overall plan to take advantage of ski resorts and local New Hampshire beauty to make the investment profitable.
The auction, which attracted five bidders and news media from as far as Sweden, included the hotel, two neighboring ski lodges and a restaurant -- a parcel totaling 97 acres in the Presidential Range in Mount Washington Valley.
The F.D.I.C. had already pumped $1.2 million into the hotel to prepare it for this year's summer season. The decision to open was not made until late March, said Charles Nehme, the hotel's manager, and he and his staff were given two weeks to prepare. Mr. Nehme said the hotel was profitable in 1989 but fell into disrepair in 1990, when its owners ran into financial trouble.
The new owners, which have set up the Mountain Properties Preservation Corporation, tried to buy the property six months ago, but were rebuffed by the F.D.I.C. Mr. Presby said the group was "very pleased with the price of the hotel," which had been appraised at a higher price by the Property Research Group of Boston, a real estate appraisal firm.
Mitchell Ashear, liquidation manager for the F.D.I.C.'s office in Franklin, Mass., would not disclose the appraised value of the properties but said he was pleased with the sale price. "Driving up here, I had no idea what to expect, but I didn't think we would get this price," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Mount Washington Hotel at Bretton Woods, N.H., which was auctioned by banking regulators yesterday. The hotel was bought by a group of New Hampshire investors for $3.15 million. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Higher But Declines Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished higher yesterday against all major currencies except the Japanese yen.
Gold prices mostly declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $366 an ounce, unchanged from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 20 cents an ounce, to a late bid of $365.80. 
 Despite the dollar's gains, many investors were disappointed that the currency did not put in an even stronger showing, given new information that underscored the economy's emergence from the recession.
 
Three Reports
 The Labor Department reported that the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell by 17,000 in the second week of June. The Commerce Department said consumer spending surged 1.1 percent and personal income rose five-tenths of a percent in May.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 138.65 Japanese yen, from 138.53 yen on Wednesday. But later in London, it fell to 138.10 yen, and in New York, the dollar settled at 137.80 yen, down from 138.28 yen on Wednesday.
Many investors were motivated to buy the dollar because of the unrest in Yugoslavia. The dollar is historically seen as an investment haven during world turmoil.
Randolph Donney, research director at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., noted, however, that the dollar was unable to rise above the critical level of 1.80 German marks.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6325, from $1.6390 late on Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.6325 to buy a pound, less than Wednesday's $1.6385.
Other late dollar rates in New York compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.7950 German marks, up from 1.7873; 1.5503 Swiss francs, up from 1.5474; 6.0890 French francs, up from 6.0685; 1,336.50 Italian lire, up from 1,332.75, and 1.1428 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1421.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $365.25 an ounce, from $366.30 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $365.00, from $366.50. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 54 cents, to $365.82.
Silver prices were unchanged to higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for current delivery settled at $4.385 an ounce, up from $4.355 on Wednesday. In London, silver was unchanged at a late bid of $4.37.

HEADLINE: FOR CHILDREN

BYLINE: By Dulcie Leimbach

 BODY:
What a paradise Central Park can seem! Especially this summer, when the recession threatens New York City's cultural institutions. In the last few years, the park has developed free children's programs from hat-making workshops to a wake-up aviary tour. These activities -- especially the ones conducted by the Urban Park Rangers, whose numbers were recently depleted by layoffs -- are likely to suffer. But some of the park's more interesting spots are used for workshops and adventurous pursuits, some of them sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy and others by the Department of Parks and Recreation, that will be offered this weekend and
should be in place
for the summer. Call the Parks Department at (800) 834-3832 to check on any last-minute changes. In any case, there's always the Sheep
Meadow, if all that's wanted is some splendor in the grass. 

 
Belvedere Castle
 79th Street, west side of the park, south of the Great Lawn
 Recommended ages for workshops: 5 to 11
 (212) 772-0210
 Tomorrow
Belvedere Castle stands on top of craggy Vista Rock like an imperious mother, looking down on the childlike Belvedere Lake below. You have to climb a seemingly endless trail of stairs; don't even think of going up with baby strollers. Restored in 1982, the castle is now surrounded by shrubs, grasses, meadows and flowers, and seems to have been created as a setting for a dark Bavarian fairy tale in which love is lost and never found. It often serves as the meeting point for family workshops or adventures, also sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy. But nothing too sinister or frightening happens.
Tomorrow "Ninja Turtles vs. Park Turtles" will be the topic of a discussion led by Allen Salzberg of the New York Turtle and Tortoise Society. Mr. Salzberg will begin by asking what Ninjas eat, where they live, how they protect themselves, where they get their skills and why they say "Cowabunga, dude!" Children, naturally, will have all the answers. Then Mr. Salzberg will ask them about real turtles and, presuming the audience will not be as informed about these creatures, he will fill in the blanks. Real live turtles will be on hand for children to draw. The free workshop, which runs from 1 to 2:30 P.M., requires registration. Adults need to remain with their children. All materials are included.
 
Urban Park Rangers
 Walks and talks
 (212) 427-4040
 Recommended ages: 8 and up
 Sunday
The Urban Park Rangers are kindly experts on the history, design, geology, wildlife and botany of the city's parks. On weekends, in the large city parks, the rangers conduct tours and workshops -- walking, nature, sky gazing, you name it -- that not only enlighten children but also instill respect for igneous rocks, centipedes and trees like viburnum.
The rangers also have a sense of humor and of romance. On Sunday, they will inspire participants with poetry, the nature kind, with a workshop called "Kindred Spirits." The rangers will lead a walk while reading selections from Shakespeare to Whitman, but they ask that participants bring their own, too, including original poems. The walk will start at 100th Street and Central Park West at 2 P.M. and end up at the Sheep Meadow about two hours later.
 
Hans Christian Andersen Storytelling Hour
 West side of Conservatory Water, entrance at 72d Street and Fifth Avenue
 (800) 834-3832 or (212) 794-6564
 Recommended ages: 5 and up
 Saturdays through Sept. 28
For 34 years stories have been told under the paternal, almost melancholy eye of the Hans Christian Andersen statue. The large bronze sculpture, which is kept company by an attractive Ugly Duckling, was financed with the pennies of Danish and American schoolchildren and Danish businessmen to keep the spirit of Denmark alive in New York City. Installed in 1956, the site is a literary cul-de-sac at the otherwise buzzing boat pond.
Diane Wolkstein, a professional storyteller and writer who leads the program, was first given an audition for the job in 1967 by the Baroness Ida-Gro Dahlerup, a Dane whose mother had proposed the statue. Children and adults (who are asked to remain during the storytelling hour) sit on chairs provided by the Parks Department while Ms. Wolkstein spins stories from memory, with a dash of improvisation. Tomorrow's story is "The Emperor's New Clothes." The readings begin at 11 A.M. and last about an hour.
 
The Dairy
Midpark at 65th Street, north of Wollman Rink
 (212) 794-6564; Friday and Saturday afternoons, (212) 794-6565
 Recommended ages for workshops: 5 to 11
Tomorrow
The Dairy is so charming and quaint that you look back at it as you walk away to make sure it's real. With its Hudson River Gothic style and romantic loggia -- which offers a good escape from the sun -- the Dairy seems to have been pulled out of an Edith Wharton story. In fact, it was built in 1870 -- about 20 years before Wharton published her first collection of stories -- to distribute fresh milk to children. Nowadays, it's the locale for Central Park Conservancy's free family workshops. It's also a restful visitors' center with a 12-foot model of the park under glass inside. Under the loggia is a map of Central Park to help you get your bearings.
Tomorrow's workshop is "Design-a-Park." Participants will become landscape architects by role playing and enacting the events that led up to the creation of Central Park. Some will be asked to play Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the masterminds who designed the park. Even adults may test their acting skills by becoming, say, the person who dynamites boulders. Then, under the tutelage of the Master Stonebuilder (Dina Friedman, the assistant manager of the Dairy), children will be challenged to create their own three-dimensional parks out of recycled materials, paper, crayons and markers. There may even be a ribbon-cutting ceremony at the end. If the weather is fair, the workshop, which is from 1:30 to 3 P.M., will be held under the loggia. Adults are asked to stay with the children during the entire workshop, and reservations are required.

HEADLINE: World Bank Pact Seen On Private-Sector Policy

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
Executive directors of the World Bank have reached a tentative agreement in a bitter dispute over whether the international lending agency should do more to help the private sector in the developing world, Administration and World Bank officials said today.
The 22 directors will vote on the agreement at a 10 A.M. meeting Friday, the officials said. A vote in favor would resolve, for now, a rancorous division between the United States and most other countries over whether an increase in World Bank lending to private businesses would better help the three billion people living in the world's poor countries than bank lending to state-run projects.
 
Essentially Revives U.S. Proposal
 The agreement essentially revives a United States-backed proposal that the bank's board refused to endorse at a bitter meeting on June 20. That plan called for modest changes in the management structure to make bank officials more aware of private-sector considerations. The United States has insisted on the changes as its price for contributing $250 million of a $1 billion rise in the capital of the bank's private-sector lending arm. 
 Some delegates at that meeting, notably those from northern Europe, contended that the bank might be abandoning its goal of alleviating poverty in order to help some politically connected third-world business executives.
A senior Treasury official who asked not to be identified said the directors agreed to back the United States plan in return for a pledge by the United States to support a policy statement that the alleviation of poverty remains the bank's primary goal. The Treasury Department represents the United States in World Bank deliberations.
A World Bank director who does not represent the United States confirmed that an agreement had been reached. The director spoke on condition that he remained anonymous.
The agreement came after a week of informal negotiations among small groups of executive directors seeking a consensus. Some directors agreed reluctantly, the Treasury official said.
The main change under the agreement involves the creation of a committee to conduct quarterly reviews of the bank's progress in encouraging the private sector in the third world. The bank's president would be the committee's chairman. The bank would also hire 20 executives to monitor this progress, and would review the effect of the bank's lending on the balance between the public and private sectors in 20 countries.
Finally, the directors have agreed that the staff of the bank should review its charter and determine whether it allows adequate flexibility in lending to third-world businesses.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Chasing Yields In Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan

 BODY:
FRUSTRATED with money market yields, investors continued this month to seek out slightly riskier, higher-yielding bond funds and more conservative stock funds, investment managers said this week.
Two big winners appear to be those funds that specialize in either Federal agency obligations or long-term Treasury securities. Those funds are considered good values because they are only slightly riskier than money market funds and yet offer yields that are two to three percentage points higher. 
 "Especially as interest rates have come down, people have focused on getting the highest income they can, income that short-term instruments like certificates of deposit are not providing anymore," said Richard Barone, the chairman of the Maxus Investment Group in Cleveland.
Mr. Barone's company sells its products directly to the public. But even mutual fund sponsors that sell their products through brokers, and therefore are slower to feel some trends, have noticed how sensitive to yield investors have suddenly become.
"There's been some opportunities in the bond market to capture higher returns than people are seeing from money market funds," said Steve Radis, a spokesman for Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago, whose products are sold through brokers. He noted that Kemper's money market fund was yielding 5.68 percent, slightly higher than conventional savings accounts, while its United States Government Fund, which invests in agency obligations and Treasury securities, yields 9.01 percent.
At the same time that investors are accepting a slight increase in risk on the bond side, managers say that with investors remaining cautious about the sputtering economy, there has been a noticeable shift away from the highly speculative stock funds that proved so popular in the heady days after the Persian Gulf war.
"The theme you're seeing is while the small investor is still committed to the stock market, they're taking a slightly more conservative approach to it," said Neal Litvack, a vice president of marketing for Fidelity Investments in Boston. "The growth and income funds and the larger brand-name funds like Magellan are definitely the major recipients of the new equity sales dollars this month, and that contrasts with the three months prior when small-cap funds and sector funds were the most popular."
Even before this week's reports, the year was shaping up as one of the best ever for bond funds, a report released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute confirms.
 According to the institute, $5 billion poured into bond funds in May, when all new purchases, redemptions and transfers among funds are counted. That net cash flow figure was down slightly from the $6 billion that came in April. Nonetheless, it means that a total of $21 billion has poured into bond funds so far this year, more than twice the $8.5 billion those funds attracted in all of 1990.
Equity funds surged by $3.5 billion in May, versus the $2.9 billion increase reported in April, the institute said. Of that, $1.3 billion flowed into growth-stock funds and only $762 million into aggressive stock funds, a shift in preference that seems to have intensified in the last few weeks.
Interestingly, one area where investors generally seem unwilling to expose themselves to higher credit risk, even in exchange for higher yields is in the tax-exempt municipal area.
Though municipal bond funds are selling well because of growing concerns about higher taxes, investors have favored the nationally diversified funds, which are only tax-exempt at the Federal level, over the state-specificfunds, which typically offer additional tax savings to residents of the state that issued the municipal bonds. Fund managers attribute that preference to the well-publicized problems of Bridgeport, Conn., Philadelphia, New York and other cities and states.
"What's interesting is people who have high state tax rates have chosen to forgo the additional tax savings at the state level to insure credit quality or lack of credit risk," Mr. Litvack said. "The more popular funds right now are nationally diversified. They're not state-specific funds, and much of that is because of problems New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts are having."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Oil Production At 5-Year Low

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HOUSTON, June 27

 BODY:
Domestic oil production in 1990 declined to the lowest point in five years, according to an oil and gas survey released today.
Production declined for the fifth straight year, falling 5 percent, to two billion barrels, said the 1991 Arthur Andersen Oil & Gas Reserve Disclosures survey. Spending for oil and gas exploration and development outside the United States reached a high of $20.9 billion last year, the survey said. 
 Also last year, United States gas production increased for the fifth year in a row, reaching 10.3 trillion cubic feet.
"Both the major oil and gas companies and independents are focusing their exploration efforts either on high-potential foreign prospects or on areas in the U.S. where they can gain a competitive advantage through advanced drilling technology, operating efficiencies or economies of scale," said Victor A. Burk, managing director of the oil and gas industry services for Arthur Andersen.

HEADLINE: Report on Foreign Aid

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 27

 BODY:
The United States surpassed Japan as the world's leader in foreign economic aid in 1990, partly because the yen fell in value, the Foreign Ministry said Wednesday. Japan had passed the United States as the world's largest aid donor in 1989, when it provided $8.97 billion, compared with $7.7 billion from the United States. The ministry, quoting preliminary statistics compiled by the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, said Japan disbursed $9.24 billion in official development assistance in 1990. The amount was behind the United States' estimated $10 billion and ahead of third-place France's $6.5 billion, it said.

HEADLINE: Bank Fund Outlook Is Bleaker

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that the fund that protects bank deposits would need to borrow more than previously expected this year because it is short of cash.
L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C., said in his latest estimate that the liquidity problem meant the fund would have to borrow at least $4 billion more in 1991 than the $14.5 billion estimated in January and that it was likely to become insolvent some time in 1992. 
 The fund, which protects deposits of up to $100,000, was worth $18.3 billion in 1987 but has been battered by the growing number of large bank failures.
 
Reserves Are Lower
 "We have to borrow more heavily because we have much less in the way of reserves," Mr. Seidman told reporters after he testified at a House Budget Committee hearing. "We are now borrowing for the working capital on all transactions."
Mr. Seidman said that he did not expect the fund would be insolvent until sometime in 1992 but that since most of the fund's assets are not readily marketable, the fund was forced to borrow more.
Politically, the plight of the insurance fund is viewed as critical to the survival of the Administration's banking legislation. To the extent that lawmakers see the fund as needing immediate attention, they are more likely to provide new money quickly and less likely to complete action on the Administration's broad legislation that would permit banks to expand into different businesses and across state lines.
Some Democrats on Capitol Hill have asserted that the Administration is seeking to underplay the deteriorating condition of the fund until after the 1992 elections.
 
'A Continuing Black Hole'
 "All of the estimates on the size of the problem have not turned out to be accurate," said Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California and chairman of the Budget Committee. "The banking crisis appears to be a continuing black hole. What we would like to know today is how deep, how long, how much."
As part of the legislative package, the Administration has asked that the fund be kept afloat by increasing its borrowing authority to $70 billion from $5 billion. The loans, $25 billion of which would come from the Treasury, would be repaid through bank contributions and the sales of assets from collapsed institutions taken over by the Government.
In addition to the fund's $5 billion credit line to the Treasury, it also has the authority to borrow up to nine times its net worth. The House Banking Committee is completing a measure that would permit the fund to borrow $30 billion from the Treasury and an additional sum based on the amount of assets seized by regulators from failed institutions.
The Banking Committee spent most of today on the legislation, failing to meet its schedule for completing work on the package. The chairman of the committee, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, said the panel would return on Friday with the hope of completing work on the bill.
Mr. Seidman, who has endorsed most of the Administration's package, said Congress should provide new money for the insurance fund by the end of the year.
At latest count, the insurance corporation listed 1,030 banks, with assets of $430.8 billion, as likely to fail. Never have so many troubled assets been on the F.D.I.C.'s problem list, a sign that the larger banks, particularly in the Northeast, have been facing greater difficulties, largely because of commercial real estate loans that have soured.
The bank insurance fund is now at its lowest level compared to deposits since its creation in 1934, though there is significant disagreement about its net worth. Government auditors have said the fund is virtually insolvent. Mr. Seidman, lowering an earlier figure, said today that it was worth between $8.4 billion and $6.4 billion at the end of 1990, depending upon the resolution of a disagreement between the F.D.I.C. and auditors at the General Accounting Office.
Mr. Seidman said that so far 1991 had been a better year than expected, but that 1992 would be significantly worse than previously anticipated.
 
Short-term Improvement
 He said that based on the first-quarter results of 1991, he expected the insurance fund to be worth about $3.2 billion and not likely to be lower than $1.7 billion at the end of this year. He said that significant losses next year were likely to leave it with a negative net worth of $3 billion to $11 billion.
"Short term we are experiencing fewer failures and lower costs than previously predicted," Mr. Seidman said. "However, our expectations for 1992 have dampened and are less favorable."
He once again rejected assertions that regulators were leaving weak banks open to retain the insurance fund's existing net worth.

HEADLINE: More Signs of Waning Recession in May Consumer Data

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Consumers apparently had the wallet and the will to spend their way out of recession last month, a Government report issued yesterday said.
The Commerce Department report showing that consumer spending surged 1.1 percent in May prompted the President's chief economic adviser, Michael J. Boskin, to declare again, less equivocally than he had in the past, that the recession was over. 
 "These figures are further evidence that a recovery is under way," Mr. Boskin said.
The level of consumer spending in May was $41.8 billion, the highest monthly amount since last fall. The increase, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.8 trillion, followed a revised four-tenths of 1 percent contraction in April.
Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economy, which fell into recession according to traditional definitions when the gross national product registered two straight quarters of contraction -- a 1.6 percent drop in the fourth period of 1990 and a 2.8 percent decline in the first period of 1991.
Yesterday's Commerce Department report also showed that Americans' personal incomes before taxes rose one-half of 1 percent in May, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.78 trillion. It was the biggest monthly advance this year and the fourth straight monthly gain since January.
The income advance cheered private economic forecasters, who took it as a sign that the rebound in consumer spending would continue.
"A virtuous cycle has set in," said Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman Sachs & Company. "Income growth will tend to support spending by stimulating more production."
The burst of spending was broad-based, encompassing everything from clothes to cars to services.
The stronger car buying followed a decline in April that dragged total consumer spending down by $15.2 billion in the month. Robert Dennis, an economist at the Congressional Budget Office, said he thought car buying would show another rise in June. Sales of new cars in the first 20 days of this month are running ahead of the May level.
Yesterday's report also showded that the savings rate of consumers fell in May to 3.6 percent of after-tax income, from 4 percent in April. The decline was the fourth since January, when the rate was 4.5 percent, and the May rate was the lowest since September, when it was 3.5 percent.
But economists took the lower savings rate as a positive sign.
"That suggests that consumers are confident and that they feel better about their balance sheets, especially home prices," said Mr. Dennis of the Congressional Budget Office.
A Labor Department report yesterday also showed that intial claims for unemployment insurance fell in the second week of June, to 431,000, after an increase in the previous week.
The recession will not be declared officially over by the Business Cycle Dating Committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research for months to come. But Mr. Boskin cited encouraging "coincident indicators" that the committee usually uses to help mark the end of recessions.
 
Some Turning Points
 For example, the number of Americans on payrolls, Mr. Boskin said, reached its low point in April; industrial production and store and factory sales touched bottom in March, and, according to today's report, Americans' incomes reached a trough in February.
The data could yet be revised, which is one reason the business cycle committee holds off its final pronouncement for a time. But Mr. Boskin's analysis of the current data suggests that the recession may have ended in April or May.
Since the recession of 1990-91 was more shallow than most, Mr. Boskin said, the recovery is likely to be modest by past standards. The next indicator of the recovery's momentum will come a week from Friday, when the Labor Department will report on the number of jobs gained or lost and hours worked in June, which is the first clue of whether incomes rose or fell in the month.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Outweek, Gay and Lesbian Magazine, Ceases Publication

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Outweek, the New York-based gay and lesbian magazine, ceased publication this week as a result of infighting among its principals and because it could not pay its bills, officials of the magazine said yesterday.
A notice signed by Kendall Morrison, president and co-founder of the magazine and its majority shareholder, was tacked to the locked office door yesterday telling staff members that the magazine was closed but expressing the hope that it would publish again soon. 
 Calls to Steven Polakoff, a Florida realtor who is listed as publisher, were not returned.
Mr. Morrison, who said he is hospitalized with AIDS, said in a telephone interview yesterday that Mr. Polakoff was no longer the magazine's publisher.
"One of my partners, Steven Polakoff, resigned as publisher and then went and started illegally seizing my assets and withholding them from me," Mr. Morrison said.
The magazine, with offices at 159 West 25th Street, was founded two years ago this week by Mr. Morrison and Gabriel Rotello, who became editor in chief. Outweek established itself from the start as the most progressive of the gay publications. Its controversial practice of "outing" -- exposing public figures who are gay and lesbian -- and its support of Act-Up and Queer Nation, two activist gay organizations, brought it national notoriety.
In December Mr. Polakoff took over daily control of the magazine from Mr. Morrison. Earlier this month Mr. Rotello was dismissed as editor in chief by Mr. Polakoff over differences in management and over what the tone of the magazine should be. Mr. Rotello said yesterday that the magazine had been losing thousands of dollars a week and was "enormously in debt."
"Steve Polakoff didn't know anything about the publishing business," Mr. Rotello said, noting that the magazine went from being "slightly in the red" to much more in the red.
 
Efforts to Save Magazine
 Mr. Rotello said that in an effort to return the magazine to a sound financial footing, he drew up an austerity plan that would have dismissed about one-third of the 27 employees. As a result staff members then demanded his ouster and he was dismissed by Mr. Polakoff.
People familiar with the gay press throughout the country say that Outweek gave voice to a new generation of AIDS activists who had not previously had a public voice and provided a rallying point for the more militant members of the gay community.
The magazine's circulation is not audited and its executives give varying numbers for it, somewhere in the 30,000 to 40,000 range.
Joe Di Sabato, president of Rivendell Marketing Company, a firm that represents 175 gay publications to advertisers, said that the financial problems of Outweek should not be seen as typical of the financial health of the gay press in general. He said that Outweek's controversial policies made it difficult for the magazine to generate sufficient revenues.
"Gay papers in general are probably making more money than ever, despite the recession," he said. "Outweek, however, had the effect of shaking up a lot of gay publications out of their complacency."

HEADLINE: Weekly U.S. Jobless Claims Down by 17,000 in Mid-June

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new unemployment claims declined in the second week of June, the Labor Department reported today, supporting hopes the nation's jobs market is on the upswing.
For the week ended June 15, some 431,000 Americans filed new claims for unemployment, 17,000 fewer than the previous week's 448,000. 
 Jobless claims had been on a downward trend during May but surged 47,000 in the first week of June.
"That trend was interrupted briefly," said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "But it has been trending lower, suggesting that at least in some sectors, the jobs market is improving."
Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, said, "We're having a gradual ebbing, and that's consistent with the idea of recovery and further evidence that it's manifesting itself in a better labor market."
 
Recovery in Economy Seen
 The jobless-claims report, which can be erratic from week to week, helps economists analyze whether companies are adding or laying off workers. The latest number shows that jobs are probably on the rise, but only slightly, said Sam Kahan, chief financial economist at Fuji Securities.
"Things are unfolding pretty much per script," he said. "The U.S. economy is in the process of recovery, and the recovery appears, at least today, to be modest and anemic."
Many analysts played down the early-June spurt because it was the week following Memorial Day, which could have caused more people to wait a week to file. Others, however, said it raised fresh doubts about the recovery.
The 431,000-level is a marked improvement over March levels, when claims topped the 500,000 mark for three straight weeks and peaked at 550,000.
In another sign of an improved labor market, the percentage of the nation's labor force who were receiving unemployment benefits for the week ended June 8 decreased to 3.3 percent, from 3.4 percent, as the number of recipients fell by 105,000 to 3.5 million.
The state posting the biggest decrease in jobless claims during the second week of June was Illinois, where first-time claims fell about 6,100, as a result of improvements in manufacturing services and the wholesale and retail trade sectors.
California's initial jobless claims fell about 3,500 because of increased hiring in agriculture and electronics. Missouri, the only state with a big increase in claims -- about 2,300 -- attributed the new claims to layoffs in transportation and public utilities.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
BRIEFS

 BODY:

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Kohlberg, Kravis Planning Cable Venture

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and Cablevision Industries Inc. are considering investing $250 million and borrowing another $750 million to buy cable systems, David Testa, Cablevision's vice president, said yesterday.
"Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts had been looking to get into the cable market and our expertise includes management of systems," Mr. Testa said. Cablevision, which is based in Liberty, N.Y., would manage the systems that are acquired. 
 Kohlberg, Kravis would put up $215 million and Cablevision Industries $35 million.
 
Hunting the 'Best Systems'
 "Given all the aspects of the market as it exists today, this may be a propitious time to get back into cable," Mr. Testa said.
Cablevision is the 10th-largest cable company in the country with 1.1 million subscribers in 18 states, primarily along the Eastern seaboard but also in Los Angeles. It is not affiliated with the Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, L.I., which provides cable services including Sportschannel.
Mr. Testa said Cablevision Industries and Kohlberg, Kravis were not committed to buying systems contiguous to ones Cablevision already owns. He added: "Given the pool of acquisition money, the company is well positioned to target the best systems over all for acquisition."
Despite the recession and the fact that cable stocks have been hurt by investors' concerns about the debt they have taken on to expand, the cable business itself is healthy and cash flows have not been badly hurt. While advertising revenues at the television networks have been under pressure, ad revenues for cable have remained strong.
Stocks of some major cable companies rose yesterday, with Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, up 50 cents, to $14.50, and the Comcast Corporation up $1, to $14.75.
Trading in media properties in general has picked up lately, sparked in part by Kohlberg, Kravis's own activities. Its K-III Holdings recently bought a group of magazines from Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation for about $650 million.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Soft Landing, Soft Recovery?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IS the recession over? Has the recovery begun? At least to the nation's most influential economic prophet, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, these are not two sides of the same question but two separate questions.
During his Congressional testimony last week, Mr. Greenspan answered the first question by saying that although the data might be revised up or down, "it's very difficult to get around the data of the last several weeks, which are strongly suggestive that the bottom is somewhere in the second quarter." Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, took the same position yesterday. 
 Since the second quarter ends this weekend, even with minimal Greenspanian and Boskinian hedging, the recession is officially over.
But on the second question, of whether the recovery has begun, Mr. Greenspan said, "We don't yet see any measurable upward thrust." To non-economists, especially workers still looking for jobs or businesses hoping to escape failure, an economy that has not started to recover is still in recession.
But the Government's caution on the recovery is consistent with the consensus forecast of private economists that the recovery will be sluggish and weaker than most recoveries. The economists seem to have a principle similar to Sir Isaac Newton's third law of motion: that "action and reaction are equal and opposite."
Hence, most expect the soft landing of 1989-90 to be followed by the soft recovery of 1991-92. Neal M. Soss, managing director and chief economist of the First Boston Corporation, said in Tokyo earlier this month: "Although a dispute within the Fed over short-run monetary policy tactics attracted much notoriety this spring, I think there was always a strong consensus at the Fed on strategy for the economy: The same people at the Fed who implemented the soft landing in 1989 and 1990 are now intent on delivering a soft takeoff in 1991 and 1992."
The Fed's slowness to ease in the last few months, he said, is intended to avoid giving the economy too vigorous a recovery, lest it regenerate inflation. "The Fed doesn't want to give the economy any more boost than is absolutely necessary to clear the treetops," he said.
In his Congressional testimony, Mr. Greenspan seemed to reinforce this, saying he was "confident that we can come out of this with a recovery without reigniting inflationary forces, which inevitably, within a reasonably short period, create the next recession."
But many economists see other reasons than Fed policy for expecting a subpar recovery. Greg A. Smith of Prudential Securities summarizes the case for a slower-than-usual recovery as involving tax increases from state and local governments, little or no stimulus from the Federal Government's fiscal policies, a slower rate of increase in exports and a consumer lacking "the wherewithal to mount a sustained important increase in consumer spending."
Some economists even expect the economy, after a short spurt of growth, to relapse into recession, in what is being called a "double-dip" or "W-shaped" pattern. Adolphe Warner, economic consultant to the Deutsche Bank, said the double-dip forecast is gaining ground, and spreading a "holy fear that, though the third quarter may be up or neutral, the fourth quarter will be down again."
Their feared model is what happened in 1980-83, when the economy slumped, recovered, slumped and recovered again in a perfect W. A former Fed economist, Roger Kubarych, who is now with Henry Kaufman & Company, said in an interview yesterday that the two recessions of that period should be regarded as one "engineered by the Fed to wrench inflation out of the system."
But Mr. Kubarych does not think the present and the 1980-83 period are comparable. "We don't have the inflation now," he said. He does, however, expect a sluggish recovery, and he sees the possibility that the economy will move ahead in fits and starts, hampered by the inability of the financial system to support a more vigorous recovery.
Though the recession appears to be generally over, some industries, including housing, banking, savings and loans, insurance, publishing, retailing, the airlines and computers, are still plagued by structural problems or hampered by weaknesses in other sectors.
The economy is like a vast network or matrix. Troubles in one industry cause troubles in others: The computer industry depends on banks, insurance, retailing and the airlines. Publishing, hard hit by a falloff in advertising, depends on financial services, retailing, airlines and computers.
The recovery now getting under way must still overcome such structural resistance. But there appears to be little reason to expect an inflationary upsurg or tightening of Fed policy that would cause the recovery to collapse.
Financial strains are likely to make the expansion slower than usual. But, barring a worsening credit squeeze, unlikely with an election year ahead, the recovery, after an 11-month recession, appears destined to follow through -- like nearly all the cyclical recoveries before it.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Silo's Account Is Awarded To Unit of Saatchi & Saatchi

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
SILO INC., the country's second-largest consumer electronics and home-appliance chain, yesterday handed Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising North America its estimated $75 million account. It has previously handled almost all its advertising in-house.
The unexpected announcement gives Saatchi an account that will be "well up there, one of our top 10," a delighted Edward L. Wax, the agency's president and chief executive, said in a telephone interview. If the billings estimate by industry executives is accurate, Silo's spending would equal what a retailer like the J. C. Penney Company spends annually on national advertising. 
 Silo operates 232 stores in 21 states from its headquarters in Philadelphia and has annual sales of $1 billion, ranking it second behind the industry leader, Circuit City Stores Inc., which has sales of $2.4 billion.
Both Silo and Saatchi are subsidiaries of British companies that do business together at home. Silo is owned by Dixons Group P.L.C., which operates consumer electronics stores in Britain. The Dixons account is handled by Saatchi's parent, Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. of London.
Indeed, it was advertising produced by the British agency for the British retailer that helped lead to yesterday's announcement. "We certainly have demonstrated to Silo our creative ability," Mr. Wax said of the British work, "and we're learning from that model."
Silo's initial foray into moving to an outside agency came in July, when Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Pacific, in Torrance, Calif., was hired to handle Silo's entrance into the Southern California market. A $5 million campaign, with the theme, "The Silos are coming!" was "tremendously effective in terms of generating traffic" in Silo stores, Mr. Wax said.
Silo's strategy in the current difficult retail climate is "to get the maximum productivity from our present stores," Tony Dignum, the chain's president, said in a telephone interview, adding, "A key ingredient there is an effective advertising campaign."
While Silo was satisfied with its in-house work, he said, "it did not include a strong creative element, which is necessary to drive advertising programs."
Consumer electronics is a tumultuous and crowded field, with countless products and models in every category. It requires constantly changing print campaigns, as well as image-building broadcast campaigns.
Saatchi will be creating a torrent of advertising: hundreds of print ads a week, running in 125 daily newspapers; color inserts, also for newspapers, and television and radio commercials. The agency has previously created such campaigns for clients including Toyota and Burger King.
The competition is intensifying among consumer-electronics retailers for two reasons. More local chains are expanding across state borders. Since being acquired by Dixons in 1987, Silo has entered Chicago, Pittsburgh and other cities, as well as Los Angeles, though not the New York City area. And shoppers are not visiting these kinds of stores the way they used to, because of the recession and the lack of hot products like VCR's.
Silo's multistate presence is the reason why the account was awarded to Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising North America instead of to the Torrance office or to Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, the New York office.
While the executive heading the account -- David Basch, an executive vice president and executive management director -- is based in New York, he will report to Richard O'Brien, vice chairman of the Saatchi North America unit.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Salomon Names Head Of European Banking

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
As an investment banker in the United States, William H. Strong was an adviser to Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier, and Lord Hanson and Lord White, leaders of Hanson P.L.C. of Britain. Now, Mr. Strong, who is 39 years old, is hoping that his association with these Europeans will help him shine as the London-based head of European investment banking at Salomon Brothers, a job he will assume Sept. 1.
At least in mergers and acquisitions, Salomon seems to need a man with good contacts in Europe. Last year, Salomon was an adviser on only 15 cross-border deals involving the acquisition of European companies. The total value of the deals -- $2 billion -- ranked an unimpressive 19th, far behind Goldman, Sachs, which was No. 1, and sixth-ranked Morgan Stanley. according to Acquisitions Monthly, a British magazine. 
 "They're not on a par with firms like Goldman and Morgan Stanley in cross-border m. and a., but they're strong in certain markets like France and Spain," said Joanna Gant, deputy editor of Acquisitions Monthly.
Mr. Strong is now co-head of Salomon's global mergers and acquisitions operations in New York. In his new job, he will head a staff of 151 professionals in Europe, where he said he would be responsible for "the full range of investment-banking products that Salomon has to offer" in Europe.
He is succeeding Ronald M. Freeman, who is becoming a senior executive at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Mr. Strong boasts that Salomon has a competitive advantage because of its big presence in financial centers around the world and the way it has organized its staff into industry specialists who can offer clients a full range of global services. These "franchises," he said, include energy, telecommunications, forest products, consumer products and retailing, chemicals, transportation and media. But some competitors are adopting a similar approach, he concedes.
"We very much see Europe as a growth area," he said. "Demand for our services in Europe exceeds supply right now."
He declined to break down what portion of Salomon's revenues and earnings come from Europe.
Mr. Strong graduated from Purdue, earned a master's degree in management from Northwestern and worked as an accountant and consultant at Price Waterhouse before joining Salomon in 1979.
He and his wife, Sandra, have three young children. What are his hobbies? "My biggest has been Salomon for the last 10 years," he said, adding that he also plays golf and skis. "One of the benefits" of his new job, he said, "is being closer to the slopes than you are in New York."

HEADLINE: City Council Budget Plan Resists Dinkins Cuts

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
As a bitter fiscal stalemate continued at City Hall, the New York City Council released an alternative city budget yesterday that rolled back $476 million in proposed tax increases and restored some of the biggest cuts proposed by Mayor David N. Dinkins to balance the recession-ravaged city budget. 
 The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said that the Council still hoped to reach an agreement with the Mayor on a common budget, but that if they could not agree, the Council would adopt its own version before the start of the city's new fiscal year on Monday.
The Council's move yesterday was a serious setback to the Dinkins administration on the eve of the layoffs of nearly 10,000 city workers who are due to report to work for their last time today. It followed an intensive effort by the administration to press city commissioners and community leaders to lobby the Council against its plan to cut city services.
Although Mr. Dinkins can challenge parts of the Council budget, his powers are restricted mainly to vetoing spending increases, meaning most of the Council's plan would go into effect.
The developments came as negotiations with municipal labor leaders remained stalled over concessions that could avert the need for some layoffs and as no apparent progress was made in efforts to get the State Legislature to approve $335 million in income-tax increases and $328 million in state aid and relief from state mandates.
 
Shadow of Control Board
 If the city fails to come up with a balanced budget soon, the State Financial Control Board could step in to oversee the city's finances, as it did during the city fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's.
The Council plan would at least partly reverse most of the more dramatic cuts highlighted by Mayor Dinkins in what had become known as his "doomsday budget" for city hospitals, museums, zoos, libraries, prenatal programs and drug treatment. And a Dinkins administration proposal to turn off one in four street lights was reversed.
But to pay for the restorations the Council planned more cuts aimed, it said, more at city management and less at essential services that could result in the cutting of more than 8,000 jobs on top of the 10,000 job losses proposed by the administration.
The plan also resorted to more than $150 million in higher estimates of revenues and to the use of surplus and reserve funds certain to be challenged by the administration in the days ahead. But the Council's action yesterday made it increasingly likely that most, if not all, of the restorations it proposed would be carried out.
"Yes, there are painful cuts in our document," Mr. Vallone, the Council Speaker, said at a budget briefing yesterday in a Council committee meeting room, flanked by his negotiating committee. "But we do not allow life-threatening cuts and we keep vital services and institutions intact."
The administration might complain about the Council's choices, he said, but "it is better to cut lawyers and middle-managers than school health programs and library branches."
 
Pressure From Landlords
 Dinkins administration officials have said they were willing to talk around the clock to resolve the budget dispute with the Council. But they made clear that any agreement would have to include far more than the $300 million in property-tax increases that the Council has already agreed to pass. The Council has been under heavy pressure from landlords and small homeowners, and Mr. Vallone, who represents a middle-class neighborhood in Queens, has long championed the interests of owners of small homes.
"What balances a budget on paper does not always balance it in practice," a solemn Mr. Dinkins said as he read a five-page statement at a City Hall news conference last night. "They've made purchases without putting down the check."
Mr. Dinkins then took credit for some of the restorations that the Council had adopted, and he assailed the Council for the additional cuts it called for, from the elimination of 3,000 summer jobs for teen-agers to the elimination of 80 traffic-control agents.
While Mr. Dinkins said the Council's plan called for 3,700 day-care slots to be cut, the Council said it hoped that cuts in day-care funds could be spread out across many programs and that no classrooms would have to be closed.
Since last October, the administration has struggled to stay ahead of worsening fiscal problems that have strained its resources and sapped its energies and forced the Mayor to acknowledge in a radio talk program yesterday that his best hope was to merely "tread water."
Mr. Dinkins cut short the radio interview to return to City Hall, saying, "I can't very well solve the problems of the city if I'm sitting here chatting on the radio while Rome is burning."
Asked last night at the news conference if city workers facing layoffs today would still be laid off, he grabbed the lectern with one hand, somberly nodded his head and said, "Yes."
As for the control board, even if its legal powers are not triggered, some state officials have talked about a bailout plan that would allow the city to stretch out budget cuts over several years by borrowing to cover deficits for the first time since the 1970's.
For the Council the preparation of the half-inch-thick amended budget showed new self-confidence a year after it received new budget powers under a revision to the City Charter.
The Council's budget staff, headed by Marc V. Shaw, a former State Senate budget aide, stayed up through most of the night preparing the document and a financial plan that shows how the Council's effort will maintain a balanced budget. The result was a budget plan that gave most Council members a politically appealing document, a budget that rescued both threatened tax increases and cuts to life-threatening city programs, and it appeared to have broad support among Council members.
The Council's briefing was not unlike countless budget briefings by mayors and budget directors over the years at City Hall, and at times Mr. Vallone sounded more like a representative of the executive branch than the legislative. He paused several times to remind reporters that he had no power to negotiate with municipal labor unions.
The Council's plan is vey likely to have an impact on negotiations with Albany and with the city's unions, especially if the Council convinces legislators and union leaders that it is serious about forgoing further tax increase.
For months, the unions have said they could not make concessions without knowing the parameters of the budget, including the level of tax increases. If they are convinced the Council cannot be budged, they might be willing to offer concessions.
But the Council plan also includes savings from a $130 million early-retirement program for nonuniformed city employees, in which the jobs of half the retirees would be dropped and half would be filled by lower-paid workers. The unions are hoping to use a similar plan to avert the need for layoffs of regular Civil Service employees.
State Senate Republicans have held up approving the income-tax rise proposed by the Mayor until they see the level of tax increases and government restructuring in the budget. The Council document issued yesterday may go a long way toward reassuring them.
The Council's plan would reduce property-tax increases by $476 million below the level called for by Mr. Dinkins's $28.7 billion budget and incresae spending by $220 million to restore some of the $1.5 billion in cuts called for by the Mayor.
These measures would be offset by about $700 million in other savings, including $330 million in cuts added by the Council, $120 million in savings from the early-retirement program and $19 million from a 1.5 percent cut in management at large city agencies.
 
Other Savings
 Other savings would come from $70 million in the nonpersonnel budget, including a $40 million saving from new professional purchasing units at large city agencies and a $20 million cut in consulting contracts.
In addition, the Council planned to spend a $50 million surplus it expected this year and $50 million out of $150 million in reserve funds the administration had set aside in its new budget.
Even before the Council put out its alternative budget yesterday, there were signs that at least some of the most damaging and life-threatening cuts proposed by Mayor Dinkins would not go forward.
Amid a flurry of lawsuits, the board of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation decided yesterday to keep open city pharmacies, dental services and walk-in clinics at city hospitals. The move would save 409 jobs and cost $56 million that would have to be made up in other cuts.
The Council plan would provide funds for each of these programs, but only 40 percent of the funds lost in city pharmacies. But in lobbying against the cuts, city pharmacists said the city could make up the difference by setting up a new billing system.
If the pharmacies closed, doctors had threatened to admit patients needing only medications to hospital beds.

Chart: "The Budget Battles"
 
New York City: Nobody blinked. The City Council released its own version of the budget, restoring $220 million in cuts made by the Mayor but making about $330 million more, requiring at least 4,800 more layoffs than he did and 3,500 early retirements, and holding the property tax increase to $300 million. The Council threatened to approve its alternative budget by the July 1 legal deadline unless an agreement is struck with the Mayor.
The Dinkins administration prodded community groups and other constituents to lobby against the Council's cuts. Municipal unions, fuming over what they complained were administration constraints being placed on an early retirement plan, were pressed by the Mayor and Council to make contract concessions before the budget deadline.
 
Albany: The State Senate refused to budge on the city's request for authority to raise its income tax until the labor and property tax pieces of the city budget are resolved.
Albany's own financial picture was further clouded when the Court of Appeals invalidated a wage deferral plan imposed on state employees.
 
Connecticut
 Various options were floated to woo support for a compromise income tax package. One would slap an income tax on wages onto the current tax structure for dividends, interest and capital gains -- already among the highest such taxes in the nation.
That was denounced as a soak-the-rich plan, though, by the handful of Republicans whose votes are also considered crucial to a compromise.
 
New Jersey
 The General Assembly approved a plan that the Democratic Speaker, Joseph V. Doria, said would balance the budget without layoffs and without any new taxes. But the President of the State Senate, John A. Lynch, and Gov. Jim Florio still insisted that Assembly plan overestimated revenues and would bring down the state's bond rating. The vote was 43 to 36 along party lines.
 Behind closed doors, the Democratic leaders who control both houses were still trying to reach a compromise that would meet the constitutional requirement for a balanced budget by midnight Sunday. -- June 28, 1991
