HEADLINE: Dinkins Goal: To Survive a Fiscal Quagmire

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In the greatest challenge of his career, Mayor David N. Dinkins is waiting for a miracle. Four days before the start of New York City's new fiscal year, his goal in handling its overwhelming fiscal problems has boiled down to a single word: survival.
 So grim are the Mayor's prospects that he would count as a victory the adoption of a budget whose painful service cuts he called unbearable just a month ago. Instead, he is struggling desperately to stave off deeper cuts proposed by the City Council to hold down property taxes. And in the best case he would lose something. 
 Mr. Dinkins originally proposed cuts in an array of city services, including many dear to him, to prompt concessions by municipal unions, aid from the state and taxes from the Council. But one by one those parties rejected him, and yesterday the last of them, the Council, said it would simply pass its own version of the budget over his objections.
The Mayor says the Council's plan would not produce the revenues it claims and would leave the budget out of balance, forcing him to impound funds and make still deeper cuts. But since Mr. Dinkins wants to avoid cuts, the Council's gambit leaves him little choice -- if he hopes to preserve his priorities -- but to force concessions from the municipal unions that were the bulwark of his electoral victory.
Dogged optimism has been the hallmark of Mr. Dinkins's political life, and he said yesterday that he still believed the unions, to whom he recently gave raises, would help. But in explaining why he could only take two questions on a radio call-in show yesterday afternoon, he also showed his worry as he groped his way into an unintentionally unflattering metaphor.
"I can't very well solve the problems of the city if I'm sitting here chatting on the radio while Rome is burning," he said in the broadcast on WBAI-FM.
On the same program, Mr. Dinkins may have given an even better indication of what the fiscal problems have meant for his ambitions for governing. "What we've got to do is sort of tread water," he said.
With his prerogatives chipped away by his own missteps and an economy that has tripped him at every turn, Mr. Dinkins has steadily lowered his sights. However the budget winds up being adopted, and with whatever cuts, the best he could hope for might be greater scrutiny of his management by state and city officials, in exchange for a package of emergency financing to soften the pain and longer term changes in the size of government.
Whether that would take the form of formal controls on the city's spending by the state's Financial Control Board, headed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, or some kind of more informal kibitzing and bargaining, is unclear. The Control Board could assume binding powers if the city failed to balance the budget, and there is always the risk that a dispute between Mr. Dinkins and the Council over the validity of the budget would invite the board to referree.
Mr. Dinkins recalled with anger this week that only the threat of immediate bankruptcy finally impelled cooperation by unions, the business community and politicians, in the fiscal crisis of 1975. Asked what could prompt agreement this time, he said: "Concern for our city and the welfare of its residents, and the knowledge that tremendous reductions of services will impact on everyone. There is no one that will escape, because it will cost in one way or another everyone of us."
But in the city's lurching course to its current crisis, no sword as sharp as impending default has emerged, and the city has maintained steady access to the credit markets that are its lifeblood, though paying ever higher interest rates. The Mayor has been reduced to fighting a series of holding actions, with plenty of criticism from the sidelines, but little tangible help.
This week, he mounted an aggressive battle to prod the Council to pass $776 million in higher property taxes, led by the architect of his mayoral victory, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch. Mr. Lynch has been riling up community groups that a week ago were attacking the Mayor for his cuts -- hoping to turn their more strident attacks against the Council's cuts instead.
It is a sign of the perpetual disarray and disagreements among the Mayor's top aides that only in this darkest hour has Mr. Lynch -- nominally in charge of relations with the Council -- taken an active role in negotiating with its leaders. And he has done so in the wake of a bruising fight over drawing new districts to expand the Council to 51 seats, in which he spoke openly of trying to elect insurgents congenial to the Mayor and hostile to the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone of Queens.
That is important to Mr. Lynch and much of the rest of the coalition of minorities and liberals that elected Mr. Dinkins, as a way of institutionalizing the legacy of the city's first black Mayor, whatever his individual fate.
Senior mayoral advisers say it is now up to their friends in labor, who can play a role in Council elections as well, to put pressure on them to raise taxes, to match the pressure and thousands of postcards members have received in an anti-tax campaign by the real-estate industry. "It's going to be a real test of their political strength," one aide said.
But Mr. Vallone has taken understandable umbrage at this approach. And it has made the Mayor's task in negotiating all the more difficult, since he has chosen not to try to co-opt the Council, but to beat it. And under the revised City Charter that abolished the Board of Estimate and greatly enhanced the Council's powers, that would be a challenge for a mayor at the height of popularity and power, which Mr. Dinkins is not.
 
'Of No Consequence to Me'
 Moreover, some Council members say the Mayor has had trouble making the case that its cuts would really be so much worse than the ones he had already proposed himself. They also said that the administration's lobbying tools had not been precisely matched to their targets and that Mr. Vallone has managed to control his members.
"Sending 1199 is of no consequence to me," said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens, referring to the health care and hospital workers union that backed Mr. Dinkins. "If they sent the Electrical Workers union, that might be another thing."
Nor does Mr. Dinkins's style of lordly dignity always work to his advantage. Yesterday, he cut short without explanation a news conference he had called to respond to Mr. Vallone's latest barrage. His aides said later that he was late and rushing to a barbecue at Gracie Mansion honoring the planners of the ticker-tape parade for veterans of the Persian Gulf war.
Some mayoral advisers say that Mr. Dinkins clings to such ceremonial events -- which have larded his schedule in recent days -- as islands of reassuring calm amid his troubles, and as a reminder that he is still Mayor, with all the powers and perquisites that office commands.
In his duel with the Council, Mr. Dinkins has the power only to veto spending it adds, not to restore spending it cuts. That makes his biggest power the one he has always hesitated most to use: The power to say no.

HEADLINE: VIETNAM APPEALS FOR FOREIGN HELP

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, June 27

 BODY:
Vietnam's ruling Communist Party announced today that it had elected a new leader, Do Muoi, a 74-year-old party loyalist who used his first news conference to plead for international help to end Vietnam's long years as a "poor and backward nation."
Mr. Do Muoi's remarkably blunt request for aid for his tattered nation came as the party replaced more than half of its policy-making group, the Politburo. The new, younger members, while no less committed to the party's absolute power, appeared to be more likely to support moves toward a free market in Vietnam. 
 Western diplomats said the selection of Mr. Do Muoi as the party's General Secretary probably meant that Vietnam would continue or step up its efforts to expand economic and diplomatic relations with former enemies in the developed world, especially with the United States, which has refused to lift a 16-year trade embargo on Hanoi.
Mr. Do Muoi, replaces Nguyen Van Linh, 76, who told colleagues during the Communist Party Congress in Hanoi this week that he was stepping down as General Secretary because of age and poor health.
 
Praise for Retiring Leader
 Mr. Linh was hailed at the party congress for his role as architect of a series of market-oriented reforms -- known as renovation -- that ended decades of economic planning in Vietnam.
Despite the praise for Mr. Linh, not all of his close associates survived today's party leadership changes.
Among those removed from the Politburo was Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach, a Linh ally who had been criticized in the party for pushing too hard for political changes like those that have convulsed the Soviet Union. A new Foreign Minister has not been named. Another one of those dropped from the Politburo was Interior Minister Mai Chi Tho, one of the nation's most powerful men.
Mr. Do Muoi, who was Prime Minister under Mr. Linh and who has adopted Mr. Linh's pro-market economic views, vowed today that economic liberalization would remain the party's "keynote" concern, even as the party continued to retain total control of political life in Vietnam.
 
'The Only Correct Path'
 "Our party and our people are unshakably determined to follow the path of socialism, the path chosen by President Ho Chi Minh, our party and people, the only correct path," he said in a closing speech to the four-day congress.
At a later news conference with Vietnamese and foreign reporters, Mr. Do Muoi, without prompting from the press corps, described Vietnam as a "poor and backward nation -- there's no need to explain it."
He said his Government would seek to expand ties with other nations to help Vietnam "escape" from years of economic stagnation. For the same reason, he said, the nation would avoid foreign military adventures.
Although he did not say so explicitly, Mr. Do Muoi appeared to suggest that Vietnam would not repeat anything like its 1979 invasion of neighboring Cambodia, in which the Vietnamese-backed Government of Premier Hun Sen was installed.
 
U.S. Terms for Better Ties
 The United States has said that it will not improve relations with Vietnam until Hanoi presses Mr. Hun Sen to sign a United Nations peace plan that calls for free elections in Cambodia and a role for rebel groups that are trying to topple the government. The American embargo has deprived Vietnam of badly needed help from the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and private investors.
In many ways, Mr. Do Muoi's remarks today amounted to an admission that Vietnam's revolution has failed to provide the country's 66 million people with anything like a reasonable standard of living.
Despite the advances under the renovation policies, Vietnam remains one of the poorest nations in Asia, with an annual per capita income estimated last year at less than $500.
According to an official biography released today, Mr. Do Muoi was born on Feb. 2, 1917, to a peasant family in Hanoi. While working as a house painter in 1936, he joined the budding Vietnamese nationalist movement and three years later was admitted to the Communist Party of Indo-China.
In 1941, he was arrested by the French colonial government in Vietnam and sentenced to 10 years in prison. He escaped in March 1945 and, according to the biography, rejoined the party and pursued the struggle for Vietnamese independence.
 
Named to Politburo in 1982
 After the war, Mr. Do Muoi held a series of posts in the Communist Party. He was elected to the Politburo in 1982 and named Prime Minister in 1988.
As General Secretary, Mr. Do Muoi will lead a 13-member Politburo. Of the other members, eight will be new to the panel. With their addition, the average age for a Politburo member fell from 71 to close to 60.
"Have no doubt that the new members are absolutely committed to having the Communist Party remain in power," said an Asian diplomat, speaking on condition that he not be named. "I think you will find, however, that these are younger men who are better schooled in modern economic theory, and that will be a great help as Vietnam tries to dig itself out of this economic mess."

HEADLINE: America West Airlines Files For Chapter 11 Bankruptcy

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PHOENIX, June 27

 BODY:
America West Airlines Inc. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from its creditors today, joining three other airlines that have fallen on hard times since the Persian Gulf war.
The filing in Federal Bankruptcy Court followed months of extreme financial difficulty for the debt-ridden, expansion-minded carrier. 
 America West said that it would continue operating as usual and that the filing would have no immediate impact on passengers or employees.
"We have explored many alternatives in the last few months to arrange financing to see us through the most difficult time in the airline industry's history," Edward R. Beauvais, the company's chairman, said in a statement. "Unfortunately these endeavors have not been successful thus far."
America West serves 54 cities with 735 flights and employs 15,000 people, including approximately 9,000 in the Phoenix area. Its service area is mainly in the West and Midwest but includes destinations in the Northeast, Canada, Hawaii and Japan.
The company said it would go forward with plans to start service to St. Louis and Atlanta, but on Sept. 7 will drop service to La Guardia Airport in New York; the Grand Canyon; Edmonton, Alberta, and three California airports: Bakersfield, Palmdale and Santa Barbara.
The eight-year-old carrier joins Continental Airlines Holdings, Pan Am and Midway Airlines in bankruptcy court. All four, stung by higher fuel prices and fewer passengers during the gulf war and the recession, are seeking to reorganize their businesses while the court protects them from creditors.
The statement did not provide details about the filing, and a spokesman for the airline, Dick Shimizu, said he could not elaborate.
On June 17, America West announced it would skip a $6 million interest payment due on $100 million in corporate bonds. That news followed the company's June 6 announcement that it was suspending aircraft lease payments. America West leases 80 of its 115 airplanes, mostly Boeing jets.
America West reported losses of $50 million in 1991's first quarter and $75 million for 1990.
Ansett Airlines, based in Australia, owns 20 percent of America West.

HEADLINE: Bank Vault Keeper Held in $16.3 Million Theft

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
The infamous bank robber Willie Sutton supposedly said he robbed banks because "that's where the money is." John DiGiovanni knew where the vault was. He was its manager.
Law-enforcement officials say that Mr. DiGiovanni, 31 years old, stole $16.3 million in Treasury bonds while he was in charge of the underground vault at the Bank of New York branch at One Wall Street. He handed them over to a friend who needed to settle some gambling debts, the officials said. 
 The friend, identified as John Gentile, a 22-year-old unemployed construction worker, was said to have ordered 11 other defendants to find ways to sell the bonds, which had face values of between $100,000 and $1 million.
Mr. DiGiovanni and the other suspects were charged in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday with conspiracy to steal and sell 28 bonds that disappeared from the vault between December and April. Prosecutors said all but one bond -- a $1 million note -- had been recovered.
The bank lost no money because it placed stop orders on the securities, making them non-negotiable, law-enforcement officials said. They said Mr. DiGiovanni, of Brooklyn, had been dismissed from his job at the bank.
Court papers contend that Mr. Gentile divided the stolen bonds among four of the other defendants: Anthony Dagnone, 54, of Mahopac, N.Y.; Frank Bitetto, 62, of Staten Island; Frank Satturo, 44, of Brooklyn, and Frank Tufariello, 47, of Manhattan. The prosecution says they tried four scams to unload the stolen bonds, including transferring them to people or institutions in New York, New Jersey and Florida.
The prosecution says that Mr. Satturo told an employee of Oppenheimer & Company that he had inherited two $1 million Treasury bonds and wanted to sell them to make other investments.
Law-enforcement officials said that Oppenheimer agreed to buy one of the bonds for $264,688, but filed proof-of-ownership documents that turned out to be fraudulent. The Government is not accusing Oppenheimer of acting improperly, law-enforcement officials said, noting that Mr. Satturo tried to sell Oppenheimer several other bonds and that it turned him down.
The other defendants were accused of sending or receiving the stolen securities. They are Gregory Segnit, 41, of Buchanan, N.Y.; Arnold DiGregoria, 44, of Brookfield, Conn.; Joseph Lipson, 47, of Madison, N.J.; Robert Destasio, 34, and Joseph Conetta, 45, both of Brooklyn, and Frank Rossano, 42, and Joseph Palma, 35, both of Staten Island. If convicted, the defendants face a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

HEADLINE: Anxious Town Might Say Yes to a Nuclear Waste Dump

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST VALLEY, N.Y., June 27

 BODY:
The offer to any rural community in upstate New York: $4.2 million in benefits that would include a new town park, trust funds for the library and the Fire Department, road improvements and a scholarship fund for local youths headed to college.
The catch: the town has to agree to be the home to a dump for low-level radioactive waste. 
 West Valley is interested.
Members of the Town Board of Ashford, which surrounds this village 35 miles south of Buffalo, had been on the verge of making the decision themselves on whether to accept the package, which was negotiated by the president of the local Chamber of Commerce and a consortium of waste generators.
But at a raucous meeting at a sweltering Town Hall here Wednesday night, the five board members decided instead to put the matter to an advisory vote before the whole town of 2,100 people on July 9. The board members said they were reluctant to make the decision themselves because they had received hundreds of letters in recent weeks indicating an equal division of opinion about the package -- one of a variety of offers being made around the country as states search for waste sites. "Regardless of the vote now, you've got friend against friend, neighbor against neighbor, and it's all for the sake of a few dollars," said Robert J. Lukowski, a dump opponent who says that the bright blue "Just Say No" placard in his front yard was burned by a vandal Saturday night.
 
It's Not Fisher-Price
 Directly across the street from Mr. Lukowski, Kelly Wheeler set up her own little sign. "Say Yes to Progress," it reads.
"Sure, it would be a lot better if Fisher-Price wanted to come in here," said Mrs. Wheeler, a dairy farmer. "But that's not happening. The bottom line is, it's a business and it's going to create an economy in this town."
That anybody in West Valley is interested might be a surprise to the commission that had been searching for a place to put the waste -- a search that has taken creative twists elsewhere in the nation. Its members have been run off some potential sites and burned in effigy elsewhere.
Paradoxically, West Valley is one of several places in the state that is now prohibited from taking nuclear waste. It is already the site of an inactive high-level radioactive dump that the Federal Government is spending $1.2 billion to clean up, and of an inactive low-level dump that had to be stabilized in the early 1980's after radioactive leachate was discovered on the site.
But legislation has already been offered in Albany that would allow the state to build a new dump on the 3,300-acre site. Several lawmakers from the Buffalo area and elsewhere said they would support it if the townspeople here said they were willing to take the waste.
Among supporters of the package, there has been an apparent debate over the effects of putting off a vote. Some said it could allow the town to negotiate an even better deal, but others worried that some other community would be enticed to negotiate a package of its own.
While the problems this town has experienced with nuclear wastes have clearly inflamed the fears of those who do not want the dump, many others feel that the operators of the new waste site will have learned from past mistakes and that, in any event, there is so much nuclear material at West Valley now that taking some more might not be so objectionable.
 
Until the Right Site Comes Along
 "This low-level stuff shouldn't bother us a bit, because we have a lot hotter stuff in there already," said Maurice Gentner, the town fire chief. As he talked, he was fixing a broken radiator hose on a 24-year-old pumper truck that, he noted somewhat longingly, could be replaced if the benefits package were approved.
New York is one of a small but growing number of states that are offering inducements to communities to accept low-level waste, said Edward L. Helminski, publisher of The Radioactive Exchange, a newsletter that tracks the efforts.
He said towns in Colorado and South Dakota had passed resolutions saying they would be willing to take the waste if they were paid eough money, but neither town had the appropriate geologic criteria for a site and the plans were dropped.
In Maine, officials there said, at least nine private landowners have offered their property for sale to the state commission looking for a site, but all have done so in the face of bitter community opposition.
In Illinois, the State Legislature specifically required that the community be willing. The state spent several million dollars advertising the benefits and taking other steps such as arranging trips to France to inspect nuclear waste sites for members of interested communities.
Every state is under a Federal mandate to find a place to store its own waste because the only existing disposal sites, in South Carolina, Nevada and Washington, plan to close their borders to out-of-state waste.
 
80,000 Cubic Feet of Waste
 Earlier this month, Connecticut identified three potential sites for storing its waste, all in the north-central part of the state. New Jersey plans to identify possible locations later this year.
Low-level waste consists of materials used in connection with radioactive isotopes and nuclear power -- things like tools, workers' clothes, resins and products used in hospital radiology departments -- but not the high-level rods from nuclear reactors.
While much of the material decays within a few months, some will remain radioactive for hundreds of years. New York State generates about 80,000 cubic feet of waste a year, enough to fill an Olympic-sized swimming pool.
New York officials first identified five possible sites in Allegany and Cortland Counties in 1989, but eventually the state suspended research work there because scores of protesters interfered with it. The state has now developed plans for interim storage sites in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn and in Peekskill in Westchester County, choices expected to generate more protests.
West Valley officials got the idea for storing the waste here last year after word surfaced that those who generate the waste would be willing to pay for the benefits package. On top of the $4.2 million in benefits, the town would receive $1.5 million annually in new taxes and fees, roughly doubling its present tax revenues.
Roberta Lovenheim, executive director of the New York State Low-Level Waste Group, which represents utilities, hospitals and other users and generators of nuclear materials, said that storage would pose no health risks.
She also said that the material that would come to West Valley would add just a fraction of radioactivity to what is already stored there: about 100,000 curies added annually to an existing total at the West Valley site of 30 million curies of high-level waste and 400,000 of low-level waste. A curie is the unit used for measuring radioactivity.
But such assurances have failed to reassure many people in the community.
The town meeting here was a dramatic affair, with one protester dressed up as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo throwing fake $100 bills in the air as he circulated through the crowd and several others dressed up as yellow radioactive waste storage drums.
"This package is a bribe, plain and simple," said Beverly Zimmerman Spross, a town resident who was wearing a black button that read, "Plutonium Is Forever." She said that the community is poor -- the per capita income here in Cattaraugus County ranks 58th of New York's 62 counties -- and that the waste generators believed they could foist the waste on "gullible and naive" citizens.
But despite the protesters, some of whom sang "America the Beautiful" as the Town Board deliberated, many citizens turned out to support the package.
And despite objections from one board member, Roy D. Engels, who described it as "the chicken way out," the board wound up voting 4 to 1 to put the whole issue to a townwide vote.
The Town Supervisor, William T. King, declined to say how he would have voted had the board been forced to decide the issue Wednesday night. "I really can't tell you," he said with a rueful smile. "I think I would have asked a little prayer for the answer to come down to my ears."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A low-level nuclear dump site has been proposed for West Valley, N.Y., along with enticements that include a new town park, road improvements and trust and scholarship funds. Bob Potter, a local resident, addressed the town board meeting Wednesday night about the proposal. (Mike Groll for The New York Times) (pg. B5)

HEADLINE: Control Borrowing, Contain Pain

 BODY:
Borrowing is a dirty word in New York City, and no wonder. It evokes the not-so-distant 1960's and 70's, when City Hall thought it could solve every problem by spending borrowed billions -- and brought the city to the edge of ruin. Even so, as the city faces its new fiscal crisis, people are daring again to use the dirty word.
The economy is so troubled, the huge budget cuts so onerous that under strict conditions, borrowing could help provide a humane and efficient alternative. But it's too soon. It is premature to consider deficit financing, at least until the city meets its Monday deadline to adopt a balanced 1992 budget that contains no borrowing. 
 That will require concessions of at least $300 million from the city unions, and cooperation from obstructive politicians. City Council Speaker Peter Vallone would force even crueler cuts to avoid higher property taxes and restore some cuts he dislikes in Mayor David Dinkins's budget; the Senate majority leader, Ralph Marino, is withholding support for the Mayor's tax package to extract more school aid from Gov. Mario Cuomo.
The Monday deadline is real, and must be met if the city is to maintain its standing in the credit markets. Then Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Cuomo can look to the future and ways of turning short-term pain into long-term recovery.
 Borrowing cannot be responsibly considered unless it is tied to a strict, multi-year plan of budget cuts, tax restructuring, streamlining, productivity savings and structural changes in government. Otherwise the borrowed money provides a lazy way to avoid discipline, an excuse to maintain wasteful rules and an inefficient, inflated work force. Only if borrowing is contingent on a long-term plan that locks in reforms with legislation, legally binding promises to bondholders, or both, can the public be reassured that the city will not revert to the path of least resistance.
Many practices have to change. There is, for instance, no justification for maintaining a work force that grew by more than 50,000 in 10 years. Why should sanitation crews continue to be paid for eight hours while working three? Where is the logic in allowing three agencies to deliver emergency medical services? There's every reason to privatize some services, to shift Medicaid and welfare payments to the state, to revise civil service laws to make the work force more competitive.
These and other reforms belong in any deficit financing plan, just as Felix Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said when he first raised the idea months ago.
It was quickly rejected then. Indeed, deficit financing is still a sensitive subject because laws passed during the last fiscal crisis prevent the city from going into debt. If it does, the Financial Control Board's advisory powers over the city budget would become binding.
Mayor Dinkins thinks the return of the Control Board would harm the city's reputation and usurp his authority. But the Mayor could take the initiative by presenting his own comprehensive plan and calling on the board to institute it. If he remains opposed to using the board, other forms of oversight might be devised.
New Yorkers are just now coming to understand the harsh depth of the new budget cuts. At least 10,000 people will lose their jobs -- many more if Mr. Marino and Mr. Vallone don't come around. Hundreds of thousands will lose important services. The choices are so onerous, so likely to fray the social fabric, that prudent citizens have to consider borrowing. But only as one carefully controlled part of a unified program.

HEADLINE: Rev. Lord MacLeod, 96, Founder Of Church Community in Scotland

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, June 28

 BODY:
The Rev. Lord MacLeod of Fuinary, who founded an ecumenical religious community on the Scottish island of Iona, died on Thursday at his home in Edinburgh. He was 96 years old.
The cause of death was not announced, but his son, Maxwell, said he had been ill for some time. 
 George F. MacLeod, a minister in the Presbyterian Church of Scotland, left his ministry in the Govan shipyard district of Glasgow in 1938, during the Depression.
With a dozen unemployed craftsmen and members of the clergy, he set off for Iona -- a bare, wind-swept island, three miles long and a mile and a half wide -- where the Irish missionary St. Columba landed with 12 companions in A.D. 563. It became the base for St. Columba's ministry to Scotland and Iceland.
The minister and his followers restored the ruins of the 13th-century Benedictine abbey, putting into practice his ideas for people of contrasting backgrounds to live and work together for at least part of every year.
The island, off Mull on the Scottish west coast, has a population of only 103, but last year 200,000 visitors went to see the restored monastic buildings.
The community has 204 members worldwide, half clergy and half laity, and 900 associates who make donations on St. Columba's Day, June 9.
Members try to live by a fivefold rule: prayer and Bible study, sharing money, sharing use of time, meeting with fellow members and peace and justice commitments.
In 1989 Lord MacLeod was given the Templeton Prize, the major award in the field of religion, for adapting "the monastic ideal and spirit to modern life and religious activity."
He was a captain in the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders in World War I and was decorated for bravery with the Military Cross and the French Croix de Guerre. By the time of World War II, he had become a pacifist and Socialist and later was vice president of the Scottish Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament.
He led the Iona Community until 1967. He was the first holder of the Fosdick professorship of the Rockefeller Foundation at Union Theological Seminary in New York.
His wife, Lorna, died in 1984. He is survived by their children, Mary, Maxwell and Neil.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mostly Up, but Mark Is at Center of Day's Activity

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher on world currency markets yesterday, but most of the day's activity centered on the German mark.
Gold prices advanced worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $368.10 an ounce, up $2.10 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $2.20 an ounce to a late bid of $368. 
 Investors began selling marks on concerns that Germany was planning to reinstitute a withholding tax on interest income. Germany's Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, said the tax would not be introduced anytime soon, but that failed to stem a mark-selling spree.
"Worldwide investors got a whiff" of that tax and decided to cut back their holdings in the German bond and stock markets, said Andrew Busch, a trader at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Frankfurt's DAX stock market index shed nearly 44 points, to close at 1,622.18.
"The mark has been under pressure all day," said John McCarthy, chief dealer at the Algemene Bank Nederland.
In New York, the dollar jumped to 1.8115 marks, from 1.7950 marks on Thursday. Still, the currency's advance was not considered that sigificant, Mr. McCarthy said.
Traders said nervousness over what impact the political unrest in Yugoslavia might have on the German economy also stimulated a flight from marks. The dollar benefited from the Yugoslavia situation, since the dollar is perceived as a safe haven in times of world turmoil.
The activity in the mark overshadowed a Commerce Department report showing the index of leading indicators rising eight-tenths of 1 percent in May, its fourth consecutive advance.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 138.15 yen, down 0.50 yen. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 137.85 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 137.53 yen, down from 137.80 Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6185 from $1.6325 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.6218 to buy a pound, less than the $1.6325 of late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.5525 Swiss francs, up from 1.5503; 6.1380 French francs, up from 6.0890; 1,346.25 Italian lire, up from 1,336.50, and 1.1418 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1428.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.5580 Swiss francs, up from 1.5485; 6.1470 French francs, up from 6.0825; 2.0425 Dutch guilders, up from 2.0195; 1,348.00 Italian lire, up from 1,335.75; 1.1423 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1436.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $369.25 an ounce, from $365.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to $368.40, from $365. Gold in Hong Kong was up $1.63, to $367.45.
Silver prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for current delivery settled at $4.424 an ounce, up from $4.385 on Thursday. In London silver rose to a late bid of $4.46, from $4.37.

HEADLINE: Thatcher Will Leave the Commons But Plans to Keep Speaking Out

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 28

 BODY:
After 31 years in elected office, Margaret Thatcher, who resigned as Prime Minister in November, said today that she would not run for her seat in the House of Commons in the next election, which must be held within a year.
But Mrs. Thatcher, who is 65 years old, immediately squelched any idea that she intended to assume a low profile. 
 Mrs. Thatcher, who was forced from 10 Downing Street after 11 years by a rebellion in her Conservative Party, said she thought that she would be able to speak out more forcibly on subjects like the political and economic integration of Europe if she was not a Member of Parliament, where she has represented Finchley, a middle-class section of London. She would then not have to worry so much about undercutting Prime Minister John Major, who was her favorite to succeed her.
 Leaving Commons, she said, will "make it easier for me to say exactly what I think."
Since she left office, politicians and the press have dissected her every comment, looking for dissatisfaction with Mr. Major. In a departure from Mrs. Thatcher, he has tried to seem constructive on the issue of European integration and has nurtured a caring image to woo voters who had become disenchanted with the strong but often seemingly insensitive Mrs. Thatcher.
 
'A Strong Ally' of Major

"It is my purpose to continue to be a strong ally and friend of Prime Minister John Major and the Government he leads," Mrs. Thatcher said today.
Mrs. Thatcher, a grocer's daughter, said she would like a seat in the unelected House of Lords so she could have a forum. A peerage, which is bestowed by the Queen, is virtually automatic for a former Prime Minister. She also plans to write, and recently hired Marvin Josephson of International Creative Management Inc., to find a publisher for her memoirs. She said she also intended "to play an active part" in the next election campaign.
Mrs. Thatcher recently stepped back into the limelight here by renewing her campaign against turning the 12-nation European Community into a United States of Europe with a strong central government. The French, Germans and Italians are leading a movement to do that. Mrs. Thatcher has long feared that a federal Europe would lead to the reimposition of socialism on Britain. As Prime Minister, she sold off many state-owned enterprises, weakened the unions and slashed taxes -- policies aimed at encouraging competition.
 
Speeches of Warning

Ending seven months of relative silence, she made impassioned speeches in the United States and Britain in the last two weeks on the dangers of a federal Europe. They inflamed the debate between federalists and anti-federalists in the Conservative Party. She warned that a federal Europe could become a protectionist bloc that could slow the reconstruction of Eastern Europe, set off global trade wars, undermine the NATO military alliance and endanger world peace.
Mrs. Thatcher's stand on European integration and her introduction of an unpopular household tax led Michael Heseltine, a former member of her Cabinet and now Environment Secretary, to challenge her leadership. She resigned after the first ballot in which she won a majority of the votes cast by the Conservative Members of Parliament but failed to secure a big enough margin to prevent a second round.
Mr. Major is replacing the tax and says he would accept greater European integration if it evolved slowly. He hopes these policies will unify his party for the next election. The Labor Party now leads the Conservatives by 8 to 10 percentage points in opinion polls.

HEADLINE: Indicators Index Posts a 4th Gain

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
The Government index designed to forecast the direction of the economy rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in May, the fourth straight monthly advance after six straight declines, the Commerce Department reported today.
The increase solidified expectations of a rebounding economy during the second half of the year. But most economists still say they believe the recovery will be relatively weak, and some analysts, in fact, contend it will be short-lived. 
 Nonetheless, the May rise in the index of leading indicators displayed remarkable breadth, with 8 of the 11 components moving higher.
"This makes us feel comfortable," said Maria Ramirez, head of a New York consulting firm bearing her name. "All the numbers point to a second-quarter bottoming out."
 
 Growth of 3.9% Predicted
 A separate gauge, the experimental index of leading indicators compiled by the National Bureau of Economic Research, predicted today that the economy would expand at an annual rate of 3.9 percent over the next six months. The bureau, a private group that has become the nation's official designator of expansions and contractions, also figured that there was only a 1 percent chance that the economy would still be in recession in November.
The Government's index, though failing to warn of recession last summer, is still widely watched, and few were inclined today to dismiss the implication of a fourth straight advance after negative readings from August through January.
Analysts also noted that the Commerce Department's index of coincident indicators, those that move at the same time as the economy, rose for the first time since last June.
 
 Big Plus Factor: Jobless Claims
 The biggest positive contributor was a drop in the number of initial claims for state unemployment insurance. The others were a rise in the number of building permits, higher new orders for factory-made consumer goods, more contracts and orders for plant and equipment, a lengthening of the average workweek, a rise in the price of materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle, slower deliveries to companies by their suppliers and an expanded money supply.
The three components holding the index back were lowered consumer expectations, a decline in factory backlogs and falling stock prices.
Upon recalculation, the index's advance for April was trimmed to four-tenths of 1 percent, from six-tenths, mainly reflecting new data on factory orders for consumer goods. This correction, however, was offset by an upward revision that raised the March gain to nine-tenths of 1 percent, from seven-tenths.
The department's index of lagging indicators tumbled nine-tenths of 1 percent in May, its fourth straight decline. This drop helped produce a second consecutive increase in the ratio of the coincident index to the lagging index, a ratio considered an alternate forecaster.
 
 Other Indications of a Rebound

Other private-sector indexes also pointed to an economic rebound. The composite forecasting index assembled by Safian Investment Research in White Plains rose 1.23 percent in May, to its highest level since October, as 16 components rose, 6 fell and 1 was unchanged.
With financial components eliminated, the Safian index in April and May posted the sharpest back-to-back increases since late 1983.
The leading index of business activity in the service sector, compiled by the Columbia Business School's Center for International Business Cycle Research, posted an annualized growth rate of 3.4 percent in May, compared with a revised 1.9 percent rate in April.
"Service-sector activity has bottomed out and is now poised for healthy growth," said Geoffrey H. Moore, the center's director.

HEADLINE: House Panel Approves Sweeping New Bank Rules

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
The House Banking Committee voted today to sweep away more than six decades of laws, dating to the Depression, that have prevented banks from expanding into new businesses and across state lines.
The legislation now heads to an uncertain fate before the Energy and Commerce Committee before moving on to the floor of the House of Representatives. The bill is intended to address the growing problems of the banking industry, which although largely profitable is confronting its greatest crisis since the 1930's. Members of the Banking Committee are far more sympathetic to the banks than the House as a whole. 
 The industry's problems are rooted in a pattern of lending without restraint in highly speculative ventures that many critics identify with the financial excesses of the 1980's.
 
'The Morning After'
 "What we did today is the morning after the night before," said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the committee.
The Bush Administration's prescription for the industry's ills, which was largely embraced by the committee today, is to clear the banking landscape of barriers to the ownership of banks by industrial companies and to the mergers of investment banks and commercial banks. The restrictions were enacted after the banking industry collapsed in the 1930's.
The package would also eliminate state barriers that have made it difficult and costly for banks to open new branches, and acquire other banks, in other states.
"We must revitalize our outdated banking system," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said after the committee voted. "Our goal should be to draw private-sector capital back into the system and not risk the chance of calling on the taxpayer."
The 31-to-20 vote was a significant, though not complete, victory for the Administration. The committee followed the recommendations of Mr. Brady on interstate banking, industrial ownership of banks and the expansion of banks into businesses like securities and insurance.
But the committee also rejected two cornerstones of the Administration's package. They would have imposed modest restrictions on the coverage of bank deposit insurance and significantly changed the way Washington now regulates the industry through four different agencies.
The decision not to change the coverage of deposit insurance, in particular, drew criticism from both the committee chairman and the ranking Republican, and some committee members predicted that some restrictions would be imposed on the House floor.
"Though the bill has many positive aspects, by placing no limits on deposit insurance or on activities banks can engage in, it makes an S.& L.-type crisis more likely in the next decade," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, who said he voted for the measure simply to get the issue before the full House.
"The familiarity is chilling," he added. "We are poised on the brink of repeating a mistake that never should have been made in the first place."
The fund that protects deposits is at its lowest level since it was created in 1934, largely because of the unprecedented number of bank failures -- more than 1,000 in the last five years. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said this week that the fund would be insolvent next year and could face an $11 billion deficit.
Like most of the votes on the legislation, the final vote sending the measure to the floor did not follow any discernible political pattern. Rather, it reflected more complicated preferences on consumer interests, big banks, small banks and other industries.
Nineteen Democrats and 12 Republicans voted in support of the measure, which drew opposition from 12 Democrats, 7 Republicans and the only independent in the House, Bernard Sanders of Vermont.
Despite a nearly universal aversion on Capitol Hill to going before the voters with another bailout on the Congressional records, committee members today took the first step toward a taxpayer rescue of the banks, by voting to allow the deposit insurance fund to increase its borrowing line with the Treasury to $30 billion, from $5 billion. The insolvency of the savings and loan insurance fund led to the establishment of the Resolution Trust Corporation in 1989. The savings and loan bailout could cost $500 billion over 40 years.
Mr. Brady insists that the loans to the bank insurance fund will be repaid by the banks. But the banks are already complaining about a large increase in their premiums that will take effect on Monday. The increase will raise bank contributions to the fund to 23 cents for each $100 in deposits, from 19.5 cents.
The House is not expected to consider the bank legislation until September, about the same time it will be deliberating on an Adminstration request for an additional $80 billion to continue the savings and loan bailout.
Administration officials are privately concerned that the timing could put the banking package in jeopardy, particularly because of the portion that would give banks new authority to expand into securities and insurance. Lawmakers are expected to argue that it is dangerous to encourage banks to look for new capital in two industries suffering their most difficult period in years.
But before it reaches the floor, the measure faces a difficult road in the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The committee's chairman, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, has already challenged many of its most significant elements.
The Senate has not indicated when it will consider banking legislation. Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, has not scheduled a time to draft legislation. He has indicated that it will be done this summer.

HEADLINE: Prices of Long-Term Treasury Bonds Soar

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury securities suddenly soared yesterday after being largely dormant for days. Dealers said the initial demand for Treasury bonds reflected a stronger dollar and weaker stock markets in both Tokyo and Europe earlier in the day.
The demand grew as domestic stock prices began to drop along with commodity prices, a key barometer of inflation, which is the bane of the market in fixed-income securities. 
 "While these factors were enough to ignite the bond market, which opened with the long bond up a quarter of a point, the rally was then carried forward by strong hints that the economic data for June may not be as rosy as May's," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. "On top of all this was the usual buying for statement purposes on the last day in June."
 
 Rally Fueled by Rumors
 Further fuel was added to the rally by rumors that Olympia & York, a major real estate developer, and the Chase Manhattan Bank were having financial problems. Officials of both companies dismissed the rumors as unfounded.
"The rumors aside," Mr. Sullivan continued, "we saw quite a bit of nervous money move out of equities and into the longer Treasury debt issues, even after the stock market began recovering."
Despite the inevitable profit taking that occurs after a strong rally and before a weekend in summer, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in May 2021, were being offered late in the session at 96 27/32, up 27/32, after being as high as 99 31/32 in the morning. The long bond's yield fell to 8.40 percent, from 8.48 percent the day before and 8.50 percent a week ago.
 
 Long Notes at 8.22%
 The long notes, the 8 percent issue maturing in May 2001, climbed 16/32, to 98 13/32, for a yield of 8.22 percent. The new 7 7/8 percent notes of 1996 rose 9/32, to 99 30/32, for a yield of 7.87 percent; the new 7's of 1993 gained 4/32, at 100 5/32, for a yield of 6.90 percent.
Shorter-term Treasuries also benefited from the shift of money out of stocks, Mr. Sullivan noted. Late in the day, the discount rate on the 90-day bills was unchanged, at 5.53 percent, but the six-month yield fell 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.67 percent, and the outstanding one-year bills lost 6 basis points, at 5.92 percent.
"The Fed tried to make sure that the end of the quarter and first half would not cause credit problems for the banking system by adding $2.5 billion of reserves," Mr. Sullivan added.
But a last-minute credit squeeze among some banks sent the Federal funds rate to 8 percent at the close.

HEADLINE: Stocks Off Sharply; Dow Loses 28.18

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply yesterday in lethargic trading as investors brushed aside a report by the Government that its index of leading indicators increased in May for the fourth consecutive month.
The Commerce Department report was merely the latest evidence that an economic recovery is under way, and together with yesterday's rally in bond prices, it ordinarily would have augured well for stock prices. 
 Instead, the Dow Jones industrial average, which had tumbled as much as 55 points earlier in the day, closed off 28.18, at 2,906.75.
 
 Nagging Concerns
 Analysts chalked up the market's willfulness to nagging concerns on a slew of issues that suggest that the recovery may not be robust enough to save, let alone lift, corporate profits. In addition, five buying programs and five sell programs lasting a total of 104 minutes accounted for a net drop of 18.12 points, according to Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading.
"What's troubling is the stock market did not do well in the face of good news, and the question is why," said Hugh A. Johnson, the chief investment officer of the First Albany Corporation. "One big message that the market might have issued today is it may be sure we're going to get a recovery from the economy. That's clear from the leading-indicators index. But the recovery will not be strong enough to give us the earnings that will validate stocks at current levels."
The gloom went well beyond the closely watched Dow, though the blue-chip stocks were generally the hardest hit. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 3.24 points, to 371.16, while the Nasdaq composite index fell 0.32 points, to 475.92. The American Stock Exchange's market-value index fell 1.31 points to 358.12, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.47 points, to finish the week at 203.47. Also on the big board, 901 issues declined and only 677 issues advanced.
 
 Volume Remains Modest

Trading activity on the Big Board was a modest 163.8 million shares, about even with Thursday's 163.1 million.
"The only encouraging feature of the market today is the volume is so very, very low," Mr. Johnson said. "But no matter how you look at it, the failure of the market to respond to seemingly good news is troubling, and I think that will bother people over the weekend when they reflect about it."
One area of persistent concern all week has been bank stocks. Investors became anxious earlier in the week because of an announcement by Wells Fargo that its second-quarter earnings would be weaker than expected, and again yesterday by rumblings of possible financing problems at Chase Manhattan Bank, one of the nation's largest banks. A Chase spokesman told Reuters that the rumors were "totally unfounded." Nonetheless, Chase stock fell 1 1/8, to 16 1/4, down 6.5 percent, and was the second-most-active issue on the Big Board.
 
 Concerns About Banking

"Concerns are resurfacing as people are realizing that the recovery is not bailing out some of the credits in the bank sector," said Charles W. Peabody, a bank analyst at Kidder, Peabody who recently circulated a list of 370 financially troubled banks, the largest of which is Chase. Those banks share some characteristics with banks that have already failed and therefore warrant special caution, he added.
Other companies whose stocks got nicked yesterday because of questions about their future earnings were Monsanto and Winnebago Industries. Monsanto, a chemicals concern, closed down 1/4, at 66, after it announced that it would take a charge of $325 million, or $2.54 a share, and eliminate 2,500 jobs as part of a restructuring. Winnebago, which makes recreational vehicles, fell 1/8, to 4 7/8, after it reported a fiscal third-quarter loss of $2.2 million, or 9 cents a share, because of lower sales.
Among airline stocks, America West Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy late Thursday, fell 3/4, to 2 1/2, in heavy over-the-counter trading.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Monsanto Cutbacks To Cost 2,500 Jobs

 BODY:
The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it would eliminate about 2,500 jobs, close three plants and take a $325 million after-tax restructuring charge in the second quarter to improve efficiency and earnings.
The company, based in St. Louis, said it hoped to achieve most of the job cuts through a voluntary program that includes early retirement or help in finding other jobs, said Scarlett L. Foster, a Monsanto spokeswoman. She said if not enough people agreed to leave voluntarily then the company would begin making layoffs. 
 The restructuring primarily affects the company's largest unit, the Monsanto Chemical Company, which accounts for about 44 percent of Monsanto's sales. The unit will lose about 1,750 jobs, Ms. Foster said.
Monsanto also plans to cut 130 jobs from its American corporate staff and 75 jobs from its international corporate staff, the spokeswoman said. The remaining reductions will come from other parts of the company.
The restructuring does not come for lack of performance from Monsanto Chemical, said A. Nicholas Filippello, the company's chief economist. "The chemical company was able to demonstrate back in the latter part of the 80's that it is capable of reaching very nice returns on capital. They were returning about 20 percent."
To maintain that performance level, he said, "It is necessary to do some trimming."
The three plants to be closed employ a total of 200 people, Ms. Foster said. The plants are in Carson and Long Beach, Calif., and in Everett, Mass.
Production of Monsanto Chemical's detergent ingredients will move from the Carson plant to one in Alvin, Tex., and production of phosphoric acid and salt will move from Long Beach to plants in Missouri, Michigan and Georgia, Ms. Foster said. No decision has been made on the Everett plant, which makes water-treatment chemicals, paper chemicals and other products.
Monsanto deferred a $108 million fourth-quarter charge last year on a restructuring of its agricultural unit, folding the charge into the $325 million one announced yesterday. Revamping the unit affected about 300 employees, most of whom participated in voluntary programs similar to those being offered in the current restructuring, Ms. Foster said.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Monsanto's stock fell 25 cents a share, to close at $66.

HEADLINE: Suffolk Votes a Sales-Tax Rise, to 8%

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I. June 28

 BODY:
Running out of money and fearful that further downgrading of its bonds was imminent, Suffolk County adopted a $152 million financial plan today that includes a request for a half-cent increase in the county sales tax, to 8 percent.
The plan, proposed by County Executive Patrick G. Halpin, also freezes county property taxes through the end of 1994 and requires an outside audit to certify that future county budgets are balanced before they are adopted. The county faces a budget deficit estimated at $150 million through the end of 1992. 
 The plan was approved by the County Legislature at 1 A.M. after an emergency session that lasted 14 hours. The vote was 14 to 4.
Mr. Halpin and other Suffolk officials headed to Albany before midday to ask the State Legislature to authorize the sales-tax increase before the current legislative session adjourns.
 
Halpin Asks Albany Leaders
 The county would keep half of the sales tax revenue, with the rest going to the state.
Edwin L. Crawford, the executive director of the New York State Association of Counties, said that Suffolk is the first county to ask for authority to raise the sales tax in this legislative session, which is expected to end next week.
Steven A. Greenberg, a spokesman for Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, said Mr. Halpin met today with Mr. Miller and Democratic state assemblymen from Long Island to press for the sales-tax authorization. "The Speaker is likely to look favorably on the county's request," Mr. Greenberg said.
Mr. Halpin said the additional half a percent tax would generate $23 million in new revenue this year and $63 million in 1992. He said he abandoned his former position that the increase would be "premature" after the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced on Monday that it was lowering its rating of Suffolk bonds to a speculative category, which would increase the interest rate paid by the county.
"After that it was no longer premature," said Mr. Halpin. "We have a situation where we are completely shut out of the credit markets." Mr. Halpin said that without immediate new revenues the county would run out of money by August. "If we default on our bonds, by definition we are in bankruptcy," Mr. Halpin said. "Then a judge will take over. He will raise property taxes as high as is necessary for us to meet our obligations, and that will cost our taxpayers dearly."
County officials tied to the financial crisis to sagging sales-tax revenues and sharp increases in the county share of costs for programs mandated by the state. Mr. Halpin said mandates increased by $40 million this year.
In addition, the plan asks for a two-week payroll lag for county employees, for a $12 million saving this year. Under the plan, paychecks would be delayed two weeks sometime this year, and employees would recover the money within six years. Mr. Halpin said that if employee unions agreed to the lag, a program to furlough county employees for up to twenty Fridays this year would be canceled. The unions are polling their members on the pay-deferral proposal.
Maury M. Cooper, a senior vice president at Standard & Poor's in Manhattan, said it was encouraging that the county had enacted the plan. But she said the rating agency would await approvals of the sales-tax increase and the payroll change before reconsidering the Suffolk bond rating.
John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, said Republican state senators from Long Island raised "a number of concerns" during a meeting today with Mr. Halpin, a Democrat. Mr. McArdle said he did not expect any decision on the sales tax issue today, but called the concerns "not insurmountable."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
A Renovation Keeps Alive the Flush 80's

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 28

 BODY:
A walk from one end of the State House to the other these days is a bit like a trip from Oz to Kansas.
In a section closed off for renovation, sunlight pours through stained-glass windows into chambers replete with gold-leafed pillarets and silver-plated candelabras. 
 A short distance away, the Governor and the Legislature bemoan the state's penury in chambers about as sumptuous as a subway station. The Governor's staff works in cramped, threadbare offices; the Assembly meets in what used to be the cafeteria.
The $63 million renovation project was intended to restore the Legislature's chambers to the glory of the Gilded Age. But the renovation project, begun in 1987, illustrates the change in New Jersey's fortunes since the 1980's, when a flush and self-confident state could afford to buy historically accurate mahogany desks at $7,000 a pop.
When reconstruction began, New Jersey was riding a wave of economic growth. State coffers were filled with cash, and its politicians were filled with confidence. This week, with the state $1.5 billion in the red and the renovation one month away from completion, the project seems less a monument to the 1890's than to the 1980's.
 "We want to retain that feeling, the richness of the 19th Century," said Matthew Shalifoux, the preservation architect charged with restoring the State House to its former grandeur. "It's really unfortunate the way these buildings have been treated all these years."
The State House, by the banks of the Delaware River is something of an architectural mishmash, Mr. Shalifoux said. It began as a modest mansion in 1792 and grew, piece by piece, style by style, well into the 20th century.
 
What's Today's Rumor?
 The Assembly chamber, built in 1891, is a gem, Mr. Shalifoux said. Beneath its 45-foot-high ceiling, the room contains Arabesque stained glass windows, a Roman arch, and a carpet dotted with images of the official state bird (the Eastern Gold Finch), the state tree (the red oak), and the state insect (the honeybee). The only complaint about the chamber so far has come from an equestrian society, offended by the absence of the official state animal, the horse.
Next door, the Senate chamber, built in 1903, is more sedate, with murals depicting figures of Liberty and Prosperity.
In bleaker sections of the State House, politicians, lobbyists, union officials and reporters mill about in hallways, exchanging rumors about the three-way tug of war involving the state's top Democrats.
Mr. Florio, who is now pursuing the cause of smaller government with the same passion that he pursued tax increases last year, has said that to save the state's bond rating, public employee unions must either make concessions under their existing contracts or face layoffs.
Months ago, after saying he had heard public outrage over his tax package of last year, the Governor promised there would be no new taxes in his $14.3 billion budget.
On Monday, the Assembly Speaker, Joseph V. Doria, undermined the Governor by declaring he could balance the budget without layoffs, without union concessions, and without severe cuts to popular programs like higher education.
So incensed was the Governor by Wednesday evening that he ordered his aides to begin a public attack on Mr. Doria with the fierceness he usually reserves for Republicans. Mr. Florio's assistants were told to draft a public statement calling Mr. Doria's budget so unbalanced that it would force the state to lay off an additional 6,000 workers. At the last moment, cooler heads prevailed.
The third player in all this is the Democratic President of the Senate, John A. Lynch, who has taken a position somewhere between the other two. Mr. Lynch said that some layoffs were inevitable, but that there need not be as many as the Governor has in mind.
In private, Mr. Lynch has told Mr. Doria that with some of the desperate fiscal devices the state is using to balance the budget this year -- like the $400 million sale of a highway to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority -- the three men can't suddenly announce they have found enough money to pay everyone's salary and finance popular programs.
"The Assembly budget just doesn't make sense," said one Senate Democrat. "How can you do something so loony as the road sale, and then act as if we are not in a crisis? We have to show blood. We have to show broken bones."
 
 The Budget Myth

By late today, Mr. Lynch and Mr. Doria were still bickering over a $200 million difference between their budget plans, and, their aides said, both men were becoming increasingly agitated that they happen to live in the same state.
One saving grace, all sides agreed, was that New Jersey always approves its budget by the July 1 deadline. It is a common understanding in the State House that the 1947 New Jersey Constitution, unlike New York State's, leaves no provision to run the state without a new budget in place.
In fact, that may just be a useful myth.
Albert Porroni, the executive director of the Office of Legislative Services, a nonpartisan arm of the Legislature, said that there is a provision in the state's appropriation law that allows the state to operate without a new budget for another month, although the state could not enter any new contracts or spend money not appropriated in the previous fiscal year. While not impossible, Mr. Porroni said, slipping by the deadline would be very messy.
"The question is one of tradition and precedent," Mr. Porroni said.
 
 Pennies From Heaven?
 In 1891, Gov. Leon Abbett ordered the construction of a glorious new General Assembly Chamber, using money whose source was never documented, at a cost no one knows, said Mr. Shalifoux, the preservation architect. A century later, Governor Abbett's successor would undoubtedly welcome such a mysterious windfall.

(Photographs by Laura Pedrick for The New York Times) (pg. 26)

HEADLINE: New Policies, Old SLogans in Ethiopia

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEKELE, Ethiopia

 BODY:
When they took power in Addis Ababa, the national capital, in May, the Ethiopian guerrillas of Tigre Province insisted that their policies were democratic and capitalist, and skeptics pointed to the guerrillas' longtime espousal of Communist ideology.
But here in their provincial capital, where they have ruled for two years, the guerrillas appear to be making good on their newly adopted word. 
 People in Mekele say the Tigrean administrators have established a popularly elected local legislature, cut business taxes, abolished price controls and repealed many of the travel restrictions on merchants enforced by the ousted Communist Government of Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam.
 
An Economic Rebound
 Local merchants say Mekele's economy is rebounding from the stagnation it suffered under the Mengistu Government, though the people in this city, once known for fine castles, mosques and churches, travel the unpaved streets in horse-drawn buggies and wear clothes made of burlap sacks.
But the new policy line is not consistent with many of the symbols and and language still heard here and in the capital. Banners and signs on major streets and Government offices in Mekele still depict a hammer and sickle intersected by a Kalashnikov rifle, the insignia of the Marxist-Leninist League of Tigre, which seems to be in no hurry to change its name. Invective against "anti-people elements" and "the ruling class" creeps into radio broadcasts and newspaper articles here and in Addis Ababa. Journalists in the capital say that every word they write must follow a line set by the provisional Government.
Officials insist that the banners and names and phrases are misleading.
 
'Don't Be Confused by Symbols'
 "The hammer and sickle are the symbols of workers and peasants, which are the primary classes of the democratic struggle," said Aregash Adam, one of 10 members of the Tigrean movement's administrative committee governing the province. "But don't be confused by symbols. We believe in a multiparty system and we believe that farmers and merchants should be free to work as they wish."
The Tigrean acting president in Addis Ababa, Meles Zenawi, announced with much fanfare on his arrival in the capital in early June that his movement now supports a market economy, multiparty democracy and broad civil liberties. Mr. Meles has repeatedly expressed interest in forming close ties with the United States, and Washington has reciprocated by providing timely humanitarian aid and endorsing Tigrean efforts to broaden their provisional Government by including other political groups.
Although the Tigrean leaders have left all major policy decisions pending for the coming transitional government, there have been hints of Tigrean pragmatism in their control of the provisional Government. The Tigreans have retained the civil service of the old Government and told at least one international humanitarian agency to buy food from individual peasants rather than from a state farm.
 
Albania Was Model
 These same Tigrean rebels used to look to Albania for ideological guidance. But the Tigreans say that after fighting for 15 years they have won their victory at a time when Communism has been discredited throughout Africa and the third world.
The Tigrean rebel group originated among Tigrean students at Addis Ababa University who felt that they were discriminated against by members of the Amhara ethnic group who dominated the Mengistu Government. Mr. Meles, a medical student, and other young Tigreans took to the mountains of their home province to mount a guerrilla war in the mid-1970's.
Their stated goals were for creating a peasant-based form of Communism and autonomy for their province from the central Government. They eventually formed a loose alliance with Marxist guerrillas fighting for independence in neighboring Eritrea province.
 
Overthrow of Mengistu
 After overthrowing Colonel Mengistu in May, the Tigreans formed a provisional Government in Addis Ababa while the Eritreans formed their own provisional Government in Asmara. The Tigreans, Eritreans and other political groups are scheduled to hold a conference in July to create a transitional government that will lead Ethiopia until elections can be held.
The provisional Eritrean government says it will hold a separate referendum within two years to decide whether the Red Sea province should become independent, according to an agreement reached between the Eritreans and the Tigreans.
Tigrean leaders here said that while fighting in the mountains they learned that such practices of the Mengistu Government as forming cooperatives and forcibly relocating peasants to more fertile lands, incited resistance from farmers. The rebels won popular support by promising the peasants that they could migrate at will and farm their land without interference.
"We are byproducts of the 1960's and 1970's, when Marxism-Leninism was fashionable on university campuses everywhere," noted Yemani Kidane, a central committee member of the Tigre People's Liberation Front. "There are aspirations to have a socialist state, but that cannot be installed until the people accept such a policy. The democratic revolution must be consolidated first."
 
Rebels' Victory Celebrated
 While the Tigrean-dominated provisional Government was received with coolness and even hostility in Addis Ababa, the takeover of the capital was greeted here with a 36-hour citywide party complete with dancing in the streets and celebratory shooting into the air.
Much of the enthusiastic support seems to be expressed in Mekele's central market, a very un-Marxist setting where peasants sell grass weavings and coffee beans or trade their produce for used clothes.
"I don't worry about the Marxist talk," said Abdela Badrik, 32, sitting behind the counter of his hardware store chewing a narcotic leaf called chat, popular in Ethiopia. "They meet with the merchants and traders every month and whatever we want, we get."
Tesfalidet Demssie, a 34-year-old pharmacist, said that under the old Government he was always short of medicines. "Now there are no restraints," he said. "We bring what we need from Asmara, Sudan, wherever."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Mekele,the provincial capital of Tigre, where Ethiopian guerrillas have ruled for two years, the economy is said to be rebounding and democratic and capitalist policies working. But moderate policy lines are not consistent with banners and signs, above, seen on major streets and Government offices everywhere. (Clifford Krauss/The New York Times)
