HEADLINE: Iraqis Fire to Bar U.N. Inspectors; 'We Can't Allow This,' Bush Says

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 28

 BODY:
Iraqi soldiers defied United Nations inspectors today for the third time this week, firing warning shots over the inspectors' heads and again preventing them from investigating machinery that the United States says Iraq is using to make nuclear weapons, diplomats said.
The move caused concern in Washington, where President Bush said, "We can't allow this." He hinted at the use of force to make Iraq cooperate fully with the United Nations plan to destroy its weapons of mass destruction as part of the cease-fire agreement that ended the Persian Gulf war. 
 Mr. Bush said the evidence that Iraq was violating the United Nations accord was "incontrovertible, unarguable, clear."
At about the same time, in Baghdad, the Iraqi Information Ministry said President Saddam Hussein had ordered all ministries to cooperate fully with the United Nations inspectors.
Tonight, the United Nations Security Council issued a unanimous statement ordering Iraq to hand over immediately the equipment that the United Nations inspectors wanted to examine. The Council sent a high-level team to Baghdad and warned that any further Iraqi resistance would have "serious consequences" for Baghdad.
The shooting incident occurred early this morning at the town of Fallujah, east of Baghdad, when United Nations inspectors, acting on a tip from American intelligence, tried to enter a military compound to examine trucks parked there. They were refused admission and then chased off with gun shots as they sought to photograph the convoy's hurried departure.
 
Bush 'Very Concerned'
 United Nations officials and Western diplomats here say they believe that the machinery on the trucks is the same that an earlier team sought to inspect when it unsuccessfully tried to enter an army barracks north of Baghdad on Sunday.
"We're concerned about it, very concerned about it," Mr. Bush said in Washington, after he met with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser.
"From the U.S. standpoint, we can't allow this brutal bully to go back on this solemn agreement and to threaten people that are there under U.N. jurisdiction," Mr. Bush said later, referring to Iraq's earlier pledge to cooperate with the identification and destruction of all its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons as well as ballistic missiles as part of the cease-fire agreement.
Asked what the United States planned to do, Mr. Bush said, "Stay tuned."
While Administration officials would not say what, if any, decisions the President made today, they made it clear that the Administration would not let Iraq hold on to its nuclear bomb-making equipment and that Washington feels that it has the legal and political justification for taking any action.
The last paragraph of the Security Council's cease-fire resolution says members can take "such further steps as may be required for the implementation of this resolution and to secure peace and security in the area." The language appears to leave the door open to virtually any action if Iraq refuses to hand over its weapons of mass destruction.
In Baghdad, the Information Ministry said Mr. Hussein had "authorized the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to order at once that all parties and organs concerned allow, with no hesitation, the United Nations representatives to see or inspect what they wish."
"The President has ordered all responsible authorities to cooperate in full with the United Nations representatives and make their mission easy in line with commitments given by Iraq," the statement continued, adding that Mr. Hussein gave these orders today at a meeting of the ruling Revolution Command Council.
 
'Flagrant Violations,' U.N. Says
 The statement approved unanimously by the Security Council at its meeting tonight expressed "grave concern" at Iraq's "flagrant violations" of its cease-fire terms this week.
The statement said the inspectors must have "immediate and unheeded access" to any site they wish to investigate and warned of further consequences for Baghdad if it failed to comply.
The United Nations team sent to Baghdad tonight includes Rolf Ekeus, who is head of the special United Nations commission overseeing the destruction of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction; Hans Blix, Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, which is assisting the commission, and Yashushi Akashi, the United Nations Under Secretary General in charge of disarmament affairs.
 
Sanctions Remain in Force
 As long as Iraq is in violation of the cease-fire terms by not cooperating with the destruction of its most dangerous weapons, the Security Council's economic sanctions will remain in force.
The incident today is the third in which Iraq has hindered United Nations experts from inspecting a consignment of heavy equipment that American officials say they believe contains machines called calutrons. The calutrons can be used to enrich uranium up to weapons-grade level by an electromagnetic technique now considered obsolete.
On Sunday and again on Tuesday the inspectors, acting on another tip from American intelligence, were denied entry to the army barracks at Abu Gharaib, north of Baghdad, although they could see equipment being loaded by crane and forklift onto trucks.
When the inspectors finally got into the site on Wednesday, the trucks had vanished and the barracks was empty.
At a closed Security Council briefing Wednesday, American officials showed reconnaissance photographs to back their assertion that Iraq has been moving and sometimes burying equipment used in making nuclear arms, apparently to conceal it from the inspectors.
 
Convoy's Route Traced
 After the inspectors were refused admission to the Abu Gharaib barracks until the trucks had left, American intelligence apparently succeeded in tracking the convoy to a military transport base at Fallujah on the Euphrates River about 40 miles west of Baghdad, officials said.
An inspection team lead by Acting Chief Inspector David Kay, an American nuclear safeguards expert on loan from the International Atomic Energy Agency, sought entry to the base early this morning. While the 18-member team waited outside, some inspectors climbed a watertower overlooking the camp and saw drivers rushing to their heavily loaded trucks and driving off through a back gate.
Several inspectors then dashed to the far side of the camp and started photographing and filming some 60 trucks as the moved out of the camp to the south.
But Iraqi soldiers drove the inspectors away by firing pistol and rifle shots over their heads, although the inspectors were all wearing United Nations insignia and driving white vehicles with United Nations markings.
United Nations officials say they believe that the trucks were carrying the calutrons.

HEADLINE: New Limits Set On Job Hours For Students

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 28

 BODY:
The Legislature voted today to make New York's child-labor law one of the strictest in the nation, sharply limiting the number of hours youths can work while in school and prohibiting them from working past 10 P.M. on school nights without permission from their parents and teachers.
The new regulations, which Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is expected to sign into law, stem from recommendations made three years ago by a task force appointed by State Labor Commissioner Thomas F. Hartnett. The panel cited several national studies that concluded that the homework of many students suffered because of excessive work hours. 
 Similar bills had failed in the last two legislative sessions. This one succeeded in part because negotiatiors were finally able to agree on a provision that would allow youths to work later if they demonstrated that they could keep up their grades.
 
Something Done for Schools
 But in a year in which budget problems forced lawmakers to slash aid to local school districts, the new law also appeared to serve as a cost-free way for legislators to assert that they had done something to raise students' academic performance.
The new regulations could prove burdensome to at least some businesses, like fast-food restaurants, that heavily employ youths. The rules could force the businesses to juggle work schedules and look for older workers for their late shifts, some industry officials said today.
Lawmakers and educators hailed the bill's passage, but many working teen-agers interviewed today seemed less than appreciative when they learned of the new regulation.
"Oh, great," said 16-year-old Keith Waters, who works at the salad bar at a Wendy's restaurant in the Albany suburb of East Greenbush and who said he was working to save money for college. "If they lowered college tuition, then maybe we wouldn't have to work so much, but that's not what they're doing."
The new rules "stink," said another 16-year-old, Jim VanVorst, who works at a Dunkin' Donuts in the same town. He said teen-agers should be allowed to work as long as they want, provided they can handle their schoolwork as well. "They should have asked us how we feel about it," he said of the lawmakers' plan. "They're not a kid. They don't know what's going on."
The manager of the Wendy's Restaurant, William McKeel, said the new law could be a giant headache, making it difficult for him to find people to work past 10 P.M. "A lot of people in the 20- to 50-year-old bracket don't want to work for fast-food wages," he said.
Fast-food jobs in some parts of the state have often proved hard to fill, although the recession has eased that somewhat, and employers have had to offer salaries above the minimum wage. Commissioner Hartnett has said that the higher wages make long hours of work all the more appealing to youths, and therefore make the restrictions more urgent.
In a separate development here today, the Legislature left town for the weekend without extending the state's 15-year-old item-pricing law, which requires that supermarkets put individual price stickers on most items they sell. But some consumer groups said they were not disappointed because, they said, the lapsing of the state measure means that officials may now enforce more stringent local laws in New York City and surrounding counties that the state law had superseded.
 
48 Hours to 28
 The provisions of the new child-labor bill vary depending on the age of the youth, but in most cases they put new limits on both the length of time and the particular hours of the day a student may work.
For 17-year-olds, for instance, the present limit of 48 hours a week would be cut to 28. That would be the lowest figure any state except for California and Pennsylvania, which have the same limit as New York, said Leonard Durski, New York's coordinator of child-labor laws.
All of New York's neighboring states -- New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and Vermont -- allow 16- and 17-year-olds to work at least 40 hours a week while in school, and until at least 11 P.M., except in Massachusetts, where they must stop at 10 P.M.
And while New York's students are now allowed to work until midnight when school is in session, under the new law they would have to stop at 10 P.M. unless they had written permission from their parents and school officials to work later.
Tennessee, Indiana and New Jersey have also set up parental-approval provisions for allowing youths to work late, but New York is the first state to require school authorization as well, said Kathleen Meehan Do, the spokeswoman for the Labor Department.
The bill does not force students to meet specific schoolwork requirements in order to work later, but it stipulates that schools provide employers with certification that the students are in "good academic standing."
Federal regulations limit 14- and 15-year-olds to 18 hours of work a week while they are in school.
 
Summer Is an Exception
 Because school is out for summer, the effect of the new law will not be felt until the fall: 17-year-olds will continue to be allowed to work for 48 hours a week when school is not in session.
The chief sponsors of the bill are the chairmen of the labor committees in their respective houses: James J. Lack, a Republican State Senator from Suffolk County, and Frank J. Barbaro, a Democratic Assemblyman from Brooklyn. They have said that while work can be beneficial to youths, too much of it could sap their zeal for studying.
Governor Cuomo praised the bill in a statement today, saying it "insures that work obligations will not lessen the energy and commitment young people should bring to their school work."
But the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, Norman Siegel, said the new laws appeared overly broad. "It's not the government's role to tell students and parents how to live their lives," he said. He said he anticipated that some youths may file legal challenges.
The item-pricing law that covers supermarket goods will expire on Sunday at midnight. New York City has a stronger law, which essentially requires grocers to put price stickers on everything they sell, and the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Mark Green, has pledged to enforce that law once the state requirement expires.
Consumer advocates favor the item-pricing laws, saying they help shoppers to compare prices and to verify that the price marked is what they pay at the checkout counter. Grocers say it adds unnecessary costs to the goods.

The Economy
Millions of prescriptions that American doctors write each year are for treatments that lack the F.D.A.'s approval as safe and effective, physicians and Government scientists say. [Page 1.] The F.D.A.'s campaign against the promotion of unauthorized treatments is part of an effort to enforce laws restricting advertising and publicity for prescription drugs. [9.] 
 The House Banking Committee voted to sweep away more than six decades of laws, dating to the Depression, that prevent banks from expanding into new businesses and across state lines. [35.]
The Government's index of leading indicators rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in May, the fourth straight monthly advance after six straight declines, the Commerce Department reported. [35.]
Prices farmers received for raw products rose 2 percent from May to June, and the overall commodity index was also 2 percent above its level of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said. [36.]
The Government will introduce a Federal standard for authenticating electronic data later this summer, but the announcement prompted an angry reaction from one of the leading private providers of software that protects computer data. [46.]
 
 International
Japan's stock market scandal took on a personal edge as Nomura Securities and the Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, each blamed the other for the wrongdoing and public outrage. [35.]
 
 Companies
America West Airlines will continue in service while seeking to reorganize its finances and business under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws. [35.] United Airlines will make an announcement on Monday that it says will have a "dramatic impact on Orlando and Florida." [45.]
American corporations raised $139.5 billion in the second quarter, up 67.3 percent from the $83.4 billion that was raised in the second quarter of last year, according to IDD Information Services, a New York research firm. [39.]
The F.T.C. has begun an investigation into Intel's business practices, the company said. Intel said that it was notified by a letter received on Thursday, and that it would cooperate fully and immediately with the investigation. [37.]
Monsanto will eliminate about 2,500 jobs, close three plants and take a $325 million after-tax restructuring charge in the second quarter to improve efficiency and earnings. [37.]
A cable company in Tyler, Tex., plans to take MTV off the air because of moral objections to the shows. [46.]
 
 Markets
Stocks fell sharply in lethargic trading as investors brushed aside a report by the Government that its index of leading indicators increased in May for the fourth consecutive month. The Dow closed off 28.18, at 2,906.75. [38.]
Prices of long-term Treasury securities suddenly soared after being largely dormant for days. Dealers said the initial demand for Treasury bonds reflected a stronger dollar and weaker stock markets in both Tokyo and Europe earlier in the day. [38.]
The dollar settled mostly higher, but most of the day's activity centered on the German mark as investors began selling marks on concerns that Germany was planning to reinstitute a withholding tax on interest income. [43.]
Soybeans futures prices sank to three-and-a-half-year lows as traders interpreted a Government report and weather forecasts to mean a record crop this fall. [43.]

HEADLINE: Conflict in Yugoslavia;
EUROPEANS SEND HIGH--LEVEL TEAM

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUXEMBOURG, Saturday June 29

 BODY:
Scrambling to forestall further worsening of the Yugoslav crisis, the European Community sent a high-level mediation team Friday to Belgrade aimed at bringing the federal Government and the rebel republics of Slovenia and Croatia back to the bargaining table.
After meeting Friday night with Prime Minister Ante Markovic of Yugoslavia in Belgrade and with Presidents Milan Kucan of Slovenia and Franjo Tudjman of Croatia in Zagreb, the capital of Croatia, the mediation team announced early today that all parties had agreed to measures to end the conflict. 
 Before the meetings, European officials here said the mission would warn Belgrade that almost $1 billion in economic aid would be suspended if its military offensive against Slovenia and Croatia continued. Officials said the mission would also reiterate that the 12-nation community favors the preservation of Yugoslavia as a single entity.
The officials added that most community governments believed it would be necessary for the Yugoslav Army to return to its barracks and for Slovenia and Croatia to suspend their declarations of independence to create conditions for a resumption of negotiations. These were among the terms that the Yugoslav leaders agreed to this morning.
The mission formed by the foreign ministers of Luxembourg, Italy and the Netherlands was sent by a summit meeting of Community leaders, who postponed a debate on European integration to take up the Yugoslav crisis.
 
'The Hour of Europe'
 Shortly before leaving here Friday, Luxembourg's Foreign Minister, Jacques Poos, said European governments had a special responsibility to act in a crisis that threatened European stability. "This is the hour of Europe," he said. "It is not the hour of the Americans."
Mr. Poos also disclosed that the mission, which is expected to report back to European leaders here late today, would offer community assistance in redrafting the Yugoslav Constitution in such a way as to preserve a single federation and to grant ample autonomy to Slovenia and Croatia.
Community leaders had been expected to issue a statement Friday on Yugoslavia, but action was suspended because of disagreements over the relative importance it should give to the potentially contradictory principles of self-determination and territorial integrity.
The German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, whose Christian Democratic party has close ties with Slovenian and Croatian Catholic parties, reportedly wanted to stress the right to self-determination along with human and minority rights. He also wanted an immediate cutoff of aid to Yugoslavia.
But President Francois Mitterrand of France responded that a suspension of aid would be more effective as a threat at this stage and he insisted, with strong British, Italian and Spanish support, that Yugoslavia's territorial integrity be defined as a priority.
"The Community should not be opposed to self-determination, but it should also not be accused of threatening territorial integrity," French officials quoted Mr. Mitterrand as telling his European colleagues.
It was eventually agreed that the three Foreign Ministers -- Mr. Poos, Hans van den Broek of the Netherlands and Gianni de Michelis of Italy -- would decide how to phrase the message.
Mr. van den Broek stressed that the mission would warn the Yugoslav authorities that they risked being isolated internationally as a result of the military offensive. "Yugoslavia is an important economic partner, but we will suspend aid if it continues like this," he said.

HEADLINE: The Fine Craft of Selecting a Piano That Isn't a Holiday for Strings Inside

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Piano season, that time of year when children and adults begin lessons, starts in the fall, and thousands of people are beginning their search through the classified ads or visiting piano showrooms to find a suitable instrument. Anyone who wants to get a jump on the busy season should start now.
Being an informed consumer when buying a piano is harder than it is for almost any other big-ticket item. And first-time buyers often want a used piano, facing greater pitfalls. 
 "It's a horse market; it's worse than buying a used car," said Kenneth Sloane, director of the Department of Piano Technology at Oberlin College Conservatory of Music in Oberlin, Ohio. "I've seen perfectly fine instruments given away many times," he went on, "and I've seen instruments that people have had in families for years represented as priceless pieces of art, and they're just junk."
First, experts say, even if the piano is meant for the living room, do not think of it as furniture. Yes, an attractively styled case with few dents or gouges looks best, but that may have little to do with the way the piano works and sounds.
 Second, it takes an expert to get a good idea of the piano's condition. A thorough guide to buying a new or used piano, "The Piano Book," by Larry Fine, says, "Those readers who love Rube Goldberg-style mechanical contraptions will find a piano action absolutely captivating."
Each piano has its individual character, even two of the same brand and approximate age. Play the piano to see if its tone and action (the hammers, dampers and pedals) are pleasing. At the same time, the experts say, bring along a piano technician; that is what most of the people who used to be called piano tuners now call themselves. Typically, a technician will spend half an hour to 45 minutes examining an instrument, and will charge the same as for a tuning, about $50 in most cities, sometimes more in places like New York.
 This can be good advice even if you are buying a new piano. The market is full of new low-cost pianos from Asia and, more recently, eastern Europe, but the quality is variable.
 Some people bring their piano teachers. Piano technicians say teachers can determine the action or tone of a piano, but may not spot some of the manufacturing pitfalls like plastic parts, which were popular in the 50's. By now, those pianos' parts may be ready to fall apart, requiring expensive repairs.
 Many dealers offer a "finder's fee," or commission, to a piano teacher who steers a student to a purchase. The commission can take the form of a cash payment of 1 or 2 percent of the piano's cost, or a discount for the teacher on a future purchase. If you are not sure about the teacher's motivation, ask.
 As with used cars, the best values can be found in the classified ads, but so can the lemons. If you are buying from a dealer, get a warranty of six months or a year. Do not be put off by age; a piano built 60 or 70 years ago according to high standards, and has since been rebuilt, can be better than a new low-quality piano.
 
More Costly Than New
 Prices are highly variable. Frank LaPiana, of LaPiana Piano Sales Ltd., 211 West 20th Street in Manhattan, said that $1,000 to $1,700 can buy a good used vertical ("upright," studio, console and spinet) piano, but he sells used Steinway grands for up to $24,000. That is far more than some good new grands cost.
The biggest consideration for many buyers is size. A piano is about 5 feet wide. Vertical pianos are 2 to 2 1/2 feet deep, from the keyboard to the back; grands range from 4 1/2 to 9 1/2 feet deep. Both kinds need another 2 feet for the piano bench and, of course, the pianist. In measuring available space, also consider placement; grands look silly if they are crammed in with other furniture, and no piano should be in direct sunlight, near a radiator or draft, or near a window.
If you have the space and the budget, the experts advise a grand. It has better tone, and because the action relies on gravity, not springs, it permits smoother control. Grand or vertical, bigger pianos generally sound better than smaller ones.
As for electronic keyboards, most professionals in the piano industry speak of them with disdain. Mr. Sloane takes a kinder view, saying they have had one beneficial effect on acoustic pianos, squeezing low-quality instruments, "piano-shaped objects," out of the marketplace. Still, a keyboard is not generally considered a substitute for a piano.
Pianos may cost a lot, but good ones appreciate in value. Manufacturers will sometimes say pianos are a good investment; indeed, some have proved a better place to put a few thousand dollars than a mattress. Mr. Fine, in a telephone interview, said his parents paid $3,500 for a Steinway Model M grand (5 feet long) in 1966, and that it was now worth $10,000 to $12,000. A new one costs about $25,000, depending on finish.
But the investment value can be exaggerated. Mr. Fine said, "If you want to make money above inflation, you don't buy a piano. You can always make more money in a bank."
For beginners who are not sure they will stick with the instrument, a compromise is a rental. Mr. LaPiana offers pianos for rent for $65 to $75 a month, depending on size, and collects a round-trip moving fee in advance, which varies by piano and location but within New York City is $95 in buildings with no elevator. After six months, he will apply the entire amount to the purchase of that piano or another one.
 
 
PIANO LESSONS FOR THE BUYER
 Pianos are complicated, but not inscrutable. A detailed guide to new and used pianos, "The Piano Book" ( Brookside Press , 1990, $14.95) by Larry Fine, offers information at all levels, for a nonmusician shopping for the first time or for a serious pianist who doesn't know how the keyboard's mechanism works.
Mr. Fine's book lists dozens of gimmicks used by sales personnel and tips on what to look for. In diagrams, it explains the difference between an upright, studio, console and spinet, and the pricing practices of piano dealers.
The book also offers detailed directions for taking a piano apart to examine it, typical sale prices for used pianos, tips on moving a piano and brand-by-brand rundowns on quality.
Many companies, the book says, have sold "stencil pianos," pianos made by others onto which the companies stenciled their names. And used Steinways are in a category by themselves. Included is a table allowing a potential buyer to determine, by a serial number, the approximate year any Steinway was built.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: 'Kicking the Tires' on a Piano," shows how to inspect a piano. (Adapted from "The Piano Book")

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
2 Economic Advisers Leaving Bush Council

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:
Two of the three members of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers are leaving the Government to resume academic careers.
John B. Taylor announced yesterday that he was resigning effective Aug. 2 to return to Stanford University. Last week, Richard L. Schmalensee submitted his resignation to return to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 
 Michael J. Boskin is staying in office as chairman of the council.
Among the leading candidates to fill the vacant seats are David F. Bradford, an economist at Princeton University who specializes in taxation, and Paul Wonnacott, who was the chief staff economist at the State Department and is now at the University of Maryland.
Mr. Taylor and Mr. Schmalensee are among several academicians who took leaves of absence to come to Washington at the beginning of the Bush Administration and must resume their teaching careers or relinquish their tenured university positions. Another prominent White House official who left recently is Condoleezza Rice, who went back to Stanford after working two years on the National Security Council's staff as the chief specialist on the Soviet Union.
Robert R. Glauber, the Under Secretary of the Treasury, gave up his tenure at the Harvard Business School so he could stay in the Government. He is leading the Bush Administration's drive to revamp the nation's banking system.
Normally, universities limit leaves of absence to two years, but occasionally exceptions are made. For example, Mr. Boskin's leave from Stanford was extended, and he maintains his tenure.
At the Council of Economic Advisers, Mr. Taylor concentrated mainly on economic forecasting, international trade and the financial markets. Mr. Schmalensee specialized in regulation and Eastern European affairs.

HEADLINE: A Plan to Curb Measles

 BODY:
This week a Department of Health and Human Services task force drafted a $90.9 million-a-year plan to stop the resurgence of an old scourge, measles. The plan, to take effect in October 1992, would strengthen sadly depleted immunization services for poor children. It deserves support by the President and Congress.
Measles, a disease that affected fewer than 1,500 Americans only eight years ago, claimed nearly 28,000 in 1990. Eighty-nine of them died. There are many reasons for the resurgence of measles -- medical, environmental and economic -- but no good excuse. 
 In January, to his credit, President Bush asked for $258 million, an 18 percent increase, for the Federal immunization program that protects children against diseases like measles, mumps and diphtheria. Just last week he announced he would send a team of officials to six cities "to learn why kids aren't getting immunized."
But people like Dr. David R. Smith, director of primary care at Dallas's Parkland Memorial Hospital, already know why. Too much red tape -- and too little money. In Dallas, with 3,000 cases and 12 deaths in the last 10 months, 95 percent of the children who got the disease had been in the health-care system. But they hadn't been vaccinated. That would have cost about $45,000 in public funds. Not having done so will cost at least $1 million in public funds, for Medicaid bills.
As Dr. Smith says, "If we can't fix measles, we might as well give up."

HEADLINE: Europe Shops for a Ballot Box

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
First, catch a rabbit. This instruction for rabbit stew also applies to democracy. First decide on it and acquire the major ingredient: freedom to choose. Then the recipe is still needed, but its contents are not so obvious. East European countries are confronting the recipe problem, with serious tensions in Poland. So are older democracies, including Italy.
Poland, which is to have its first completely free parliamentary vote in October, is disputing the electoral law. President Lech Walesa, chosen by direct universal suffrage, wants legislative candidates to run only on party lists, a way he considers sure to exclude former Communists. Solidarity and ex-Communist deputies want people listed by their names only, giving independents a chance. 
Presidential powers were significantly strengthened as part of the compromise that provided partly free elections in 1989, leading to a Solidarity Government. Mr. Walesa's stand derives from his personality: he wants still more power. The issue he chose is the method of electing legislators.
Earlier in the century, political theorists looking for a formula to make voters' choices more effective came up with proportional representation. Tried in a few American states, it caught on widely in Europe. The theorists argued that single-member constituencies distorted election results by giving equal rewards to a tiny margin or an overwhelming majority of voters and permanently blocking smaller parties or those with geographically diffuse supporters.
 In practice, proportional representation has turned out to favor too many splinter parties, often forcing unnatural coalitions or paralyzing governments and giving decisive power to party apparatuses rather than the citizens' chosen candidate.
Under this system, opportunities for election depend on a candidate's place on the party list, not on individual popularity. Israel adopted the most extreme form of the system and has never been able to reform it because incumbents don't bite the system that feeds them.
Eastern Europeans are surveying the West's assorted methods of governing and trying to figure out what will suit them. Experimentation is risky, all are going through social and economic crises, but they can't wait very long for decisive government.
The systems of various countries are being studied as models and one way or another are found wanting. France has the world's most powerful presidency, more powerful than America's because there is no clear separation between executive and legislative branches. France's experiment with proportional representation was abandoned.
Italy, with a president that essentially is a figurehead and an intricate proportional representation system, has just resoundingly demanded basic political reform in a referendum. The system is thought to help entrench the Mafia, and there is a strong feeling that the president should be elected directly in order to strengthen him.
The appeal of a directly elected president has been demonstrated in in the Russian Republic. Boris Yeltsin has greatly reinforced his standing in the face of Mikhail Gorbachev, President of the Soviet Union by virtue of a vote of the Supreme Soviet, although Mr. Gorbachev retains all the major levers of state power.
The U.S. system of checks and balances with only single-member constituencies has not attracted imitators because it is considered cumbersome and inappropriate for most countries.
People everywhere want to participate in power and they want responsive, effective government. Is that a contradiction? The answer has to be no. But generalities and pious pledges give no assurance. Existing structures are disappointing, and there is a search for better solutions. Fortunately, the greatest strength of democracy over all those methods of government Churchill found worse is that it can try, err and correct.

HEADLINE: $139.5 Billion in Securities Issued in Quarter

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Corporate America found the public markets to be a trove of cash in the second quarter, as the economic euphoria that followed the end of the Persian Gulf war continued in the capital markets.
And bucking a two-year trend, fees paid to investment firms went up. 
 American corporations raised $139.5 billion in the second quarter, up 67.3 percent from the $83.4 billion that was raised in the second quarter of last year, according to IDD Information Services, a research firm in New York.
In the first six months of 1991, corporations issued a $249.7 billion in domestic securities, a 52.4 percent increase over the $163.8 billion raised in the first half of 1990, according to IDD.
 
Drop in Interest Rates

The determining factor in the push to raise capital was the decline of interest rates, underwriters said, as well as the end of the uncertainty in the five months before the Persian Gulf war. Companies had been holding out for lower rates as long as a year, and, when the drop came, they plunged into the markets. For their part, institutional investors, uncertain of the direction of the markets, sat on hoards of cash until the conflict was resolved. As time passed, those investors became more selective.
"The market at the beginning of the quarter was indiscriminate," said Dave Komanski, executive vice president of global equity markets at Merrill Lynch & Company. "We did see a change throughout the quarter from what I would classify as a feeding frenzy at the beginning to the point where the buy side became very selective by the end of the quarter."
 
The Biggest Changes
 For the quarter, the biggest changes in business were in the secondary-issue market for equities and in the "junk bond" market. Some $13.6 billion in such equity was issued, compared with $3.1 billion in the second quarter of 1990.
And the once-moribund junk bond market showed strength, with $2.5 billion raised in the quarter, compared with $706.7 million in the second quarter of last year.
That frenzy and subsequent continued purchasing pushed Wall Street fees upward for the first time in years. In the first six months, fees grew faster than new issues, according to IDD. Fees increased 60 percent in the first six months of the year to $1.95 billion, from $1.21 billion in the comparable period in 1990.
The size of the rebound is partly a result of the markets' poor performance last year, when Wall Street slipped into the weakest environment since 1974. And the first six months of 1990 saw the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the former powerhouse that led the junk bond market. That market began to recover only in the last six months.
Also, contributing to the growth in fees was the explosion of equity issues, both initial public offerings and secondary offerings. With Duracell, Ann Taylor and other companies coming to market with huge offerings in the last quarter, fees were virtually guaranteed to climb rapidly.
The fees for secondary offerings rose to $691.4 million from $252.6 billion in the comparable period last year.
Fees from preferred stock offerings also grew rapidly to $139.1 million, from the $54.2 million raised in the first six months of 1990.
Holding onto the spot it won from Salomon Brothers three years ago, Merrill Lynch continued as the biggest underwriter on Wall Street.
For the first six months, Merrill underwrote $47.9 billion in domestic securities, giving it 19.2 percent of the total market, an increase from $26.6 billion in the first six months of 1990, according to IDD. Goldman, Sachs & Company was second, underwriting $33.8 billion of securities for 13.5 percent of the market.
Lehman Brothers was the surprise of the top underwriters, jumping from No. 6 to No. 3. The firm underwrote $25.4 billion for 10.2 percent of the market. Morgan Stanley & Company, which was No. 3 a year ago, dropped to sixth place this year.
 
Up From $145.3 Billion
 The vast majority of the cash was raised through debt securities. The total amount of nonconvertible debt raised during the six months was $213.4 billion, up from $145.3 billion a year earlier, according to IDD.
While the dollar volume of intial public offerings rose during the period, the number of such offerings fell. During the six months, 133 of such offerings went to market, raising $8 billion,compared with 137 raising $6.9 billion in the first six months of 1990.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 863 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
BREAK AND ENTER, by Colin Harrison. (Avon, $4.95.) While his mother is suffering from cancer and his marriage is falling apart, an assistant district attorney in Philadelphia tries to solve a double murder. "In this intensely felt first novel, Mr. Harrison heroically balances the philosophical drama of a man's crisis of faith with the puzzle-narrative of a legal whodunit," Marilyn Stasio said here last year.
THE POLITICS OF RICH AND POOR: Wealth and the American Electorate in the Reagan Aftermath, by Kevin Phillips. (Harper Perennial, $9.95.) Like the Gilded Age of the 1880's and 90's and the Roaring 20's, the 1980's were a time of tax cuts, deregulation, weakening of the unions, financial speculation, runaway debt and an increase in the number of millionaires. And now as then, Kevin Phillips predicts, the excesses of the rich will lead to a backlash of populism. "Drawing on an array of basic economic data, Mr. Phillips succeeds in placing the carryings-on that make headlines against the background of a wider trend toward markedly greater inequality of income and concentration of wealth," Dennis H. Wrong said here last year. 
 WHAT I HAVE TO TELL YOU, by Mary Elsie Robertson. (Laurel, $8.99.) Jessie Farquarson makes no progress in her search for her missing husband, Dwayne, until she consults a psychic who lives on an island near Seattle. In 1989 our reviewer, Regina Weinreich, said the author is "at her best when describing the down-to-earth -- for example, in telling how Jessie is wooed by the hapless Dwayne, whose idea of a good time is collecting ants and watching them race across the kitchen table."
WHAT'S THAT PIG OUTDOORS? A Memoir of Deafness, by Henry Kisor. (Penguin, $8.95.) The book editor of The Chicago Sun-Times tells what it was like for a deaf person to pursue a career in journalism. "Henry Kisor's book, with its solid core of Emersonian self-reliance, may well become an American classic," Carlton Lake said here last year.
A SMALL TOWN, by Shelby Hearon. (Warner, $9.95.) As seismologists roam the town, trying to predict when the next big one will come, the people of Venice, Mo., find diversion in the scandalous goings-on of Alma van der Linden, the doctor's daughter who married her high school principal and is now working as a reporter on the town newspaper. In 1985 our reviewer, Elizabeth Tallent, said " 'A Small Town" is fine in dealing with the funny malaise of childhood, those small-town seizures of ennui."
GORBACHEV: Heretic in the Kremlin, by Dusko Doder and Louise Branson. (Penguin, $9.95.) "The central paradox of Gorbachev's rule," the authors write, is that "the more he sought to disperse power, the more he found it necessary to concentrate power in his own hands." Last year our reviewer, Marshall D. Shulman, said this book provides "a useful reminder for general readers of the roller-coaster volatility of the tumultuous events of the last five years."
L.A. CONFIDENTIAL, by James Ellroy. (Mysterious Press, $5.99.) This novel about Los Angeles in the 1950's centers on the stories of three corrupt policemen, each obsessed with a different crime. "There must be a hundred characters -- give or take some fractional body parts -- embroiled in all the interlocking plots and subplots about the 'astounding audacious perversion' of the period," Marilyn Stasio said here last year.
THE THROWING MADONNA: Essays on the Brain, by William H. Calvin. (Bantam, $13.) A neurophysiologist speculates that women, clutching their babies with one arm and throwing stones with the other, may be responsible for the development of right-handedness, language and sequential reasoning. The author provides "a great deal of information in bite-sized essays that are easy to read," Maya Pines said here in 1983.
BONES AND SILENCE, by Reginald Hill. (Dell, $4.50.) While rehearsing to play God in a local mystery play, Andy Dalziel, a police superintendent in Yorkshire, tries to catch a murderer and find an anonymous woman who keeps making heartbreaking suicide threats. "No other genre author, P. D. James and Ruth Rendell included, writes with such feeling and understanding of silently unhappy women," Marilyn Stasio said here last year.
BITTER VICTORY: The Battle for Sicily, 1943, by Carlo D'Este. (Harper Perennial, $14.95.) Gen. Sir Harold Alexander's battle to take Sicily in World War II was a case study in mismanagement, the author concludes. "Carlo D'Este, a retired American Army lieutenant colonel, is a fine military writer," Walter Lord said here in 1988. He has "great imagination in using his materials. And he is utterly candid." The publisher has also reissued DECISION IN NORMANDY ($14.95), Mr. D'Este's critique of another British general, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery. "It is the best-researched, best-reasoned, best-written account of that campaign I have read," Drew Middleton said here in 1984.
"G" IS FOR GUMSHOE, by Sue Grafton. (Fawcett Crest, $5.95.) Kinsey Millhone, the California private eye, is the target of a hired assassin. Last year our reviewer, Alex Kozinski, said Sue Grafton "certainly knows how to turn a phrase and has a playful eye for detail."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Theater's Godfather Reaches Entr'acte

BYLINE: By HILARY DE VRIES; Hilary de Vries writes about theater and film for The Los Angeles Times and other publications.

 BODY:
It tells you something about Lloyd Richards that when asked to assess his career in the American theater, one that spans nearly half a century, he tells a story about other people.
"John Guare once said to me, 'I have needs as a playwright,' " says Mr. Richards. " 'I need a place where I can work, but I also need to have my picture in the newspapers.' What he was saying was that he wanted to be a playwright and to be acknowledged as a playwright. He wanted a life in the theater." 
 If any individual has been pivotal in helping playwrights and other artists find homes in the American theater, it has been Lloyd Richards. From his first public success -- directing Lorraine Hansberry's groundbreaking drama "A Raisin in the Sun" on Broadway in 1959 -- to his continuing collaboration with the playwright August Wilson, Mr. Richards has served as adviser and enabler to some of the country's finest theatrical talent.
In the five decades that he has been working -- as a radio announcer in Detroit before World War II, as an unknown Off Broadway actor during the 50's and now as a Tony Award-winning director and leader in the nation's regional theater movement -- Mr. Richards has commanded as much influence in the country as any theater figure working outside Broadway.
In the last 12 years he has held four major positions -- artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater, dean of the Yale School of Drama, director of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center's annual playwright's conference, and member of the national council, the advisory body for the National Endowment for the Arts. In those posts he has influenced the careers of such actors as Sidney Poitier, James Earl Jones and Charles Dutton and such playwrights, in addition to Mr. Wilson, as Lee Blessing, Athol Fugard and Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian Noble Prize winner.
 "You see Lloyd's influence everywhere," says Zelda Fichandler, former artistic director of the Arena Stage in Washington and artistic director of the Acting Company in New York. "You see it in playwriting, the notion of developing a play, in the numbers of African-American actors working, in casting classical works with people of color, and in his merging a school with a functioning theater."
Indeed, in the American regional theater movement Mr. Richards's preferred role has been that of teacher, mentor, nurturer. Even on the eve of his retirement from Yale (he will be officially replaced next month by Stan Wojewodski Jr., the former artistic director of Center Stage in Baltimore), Mr. Richards's influence persists.
He describes his aims simply: "There is a social and political conscience to everything I do." This personal agenda has helped broaden the nation's cultural parameters, especially through increased ethnic diversity in the American theater and play development.
As director of that original production of "Raisin," Mr. Richards is regarded as among the first artists to unveil middle-class black family life to white audiences that had not yet encountered the civil rights struggles of the 60's. Edith Oliver of The New Yorker has said of that seminal production, "It opened up a whole way of life to all of us."
Twenty years later, Mr. Richards was using his positions at Yale to create an artistic home for Mr. Fugard's excoriating South African dramas and Mr. Wilson's searing black history plays. Mr. Fugard's " 'Master Harold' . . . and the Boys" and "The Road to Mecca" had their world premieres at Yale, as have all of Mr. Wilson's works (under Mr. Richards's direction), from "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom," "Fences" and "Joe Turner's Come and Gone" to last year's "Two Trains Running." Mr. Wilson has said of his director, mentor and colleague, "because of Lloyd, I found a home in the theater. I will follow him wherever he goes."
To talk with the soft-spoken director about his accomplishments is to encounter a study in self-effacement. Short, compact and bespectacled -- the playwright Wendy Wasserstein, a former student, once called him "the black Santa Claus" -- Mr. Richards looks every inch the paterfamilias. He is also something of an enigma, an intensely private man even to those who know him well.
And on a recent early morning, in the living room of his town house on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, Mr. Richards is a study in watchful affability. Although he has spent much of his time in university housing during his Yale tenure, for the last 20 years this has been his home -- a serene, loftlike space of exposed brick walls and hardwood floors that is furnished in antiques, African art, musical instruments and family photographs. But even now, even here, he dismisses attempts to sum up his career -- "That's a look back, and I'm not ready to do that." Rather, he discusses his accomplishments in terms of other artists (he refers to his relationship with Mr. Wilson as the "culmination" of his career) and institutions, be it the National Endowment, the O'Neill or Yale.
"My commitment to theater has had a great deal to do with the drama school," he says in his slow, narrative style. "I started out to make the kind of school that I would have liked to have gone to. Training people -- creating a bridge into the profession -- that's what I consider valuable."
He was considered a master teacher of acting whose resume included teaching positions at New York University, Hunter College and the O'Neill when A. Bartlett Giamatti tapped him in 1979 to replace Robert Bru stein as dean of the Yale School of Drama and artistic director of the theater. Mr. Brustein and Mr. Giamatti had been involved in an acrimonious dispute over the future of the drama school, which ended with Mr. Bru stein's departure.
For Mr. Richards, the next 12 years proved to be career-making. He established his reputation and cemented the standing of the school by transforming it into the most prestigious professional drama training program in the country. He increased the number of minority students and faculty members and reoriented the repertory theater from an avant-garde, director-dominated company into a writer's theater with a commitment to social concerns.
The focus of his attention was the repertory theater and he served mainly as an administrator, delegating much of the actual running of the school. Occasionally he was stretched so thin because of duties at the O'Neill center and the National Endowment that he gained a reputation among some students and faculty members as an absentee landlord. One year a petition was circulated by the students, demanding, "Where are you, Lloyd?"
"Lloyd put the rep and the school on solid ground while validating August Wilson, the most important black American voice in the commercial arena," says David Chambers, an assistant professor in Yale's directing program. "Many see the end of his tenure with both deep resentment about what has been read as his inattention to the school as well as deep respect for what he has achieved as an individual."
Athol Fugard already had a worldwide reputation as a major dramatist when Mr. Richards received the script of "A Lesson From Aloes" from the playwright in 1979. The subsequent Yale production, directed by Mr. Fugard and starring James Earl Jones, later moved to Broadway. It was the start of Mr. Richards's wider renown as an artistic director and paved the way for subsequent Fugard works at Yale.
The collaborative process was repeated in 1984 when Mr. Richards discovered August Wilson's drama "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom." That play, about black jazz musicians in the 1920's, moved to Broadway. It was followed by the Pulitzer Prize-winning "Fences" (which won Mr. Richards a Tony Award in 1986), "Joe Turner's Come and Gone" and "The Piano Lesson" (a second Pulitzer) -- all productions that began at Yale, had several subsequent productions at other regional theaters and later moved to Broadway. ("Two Trains Running" will be seen at the Arena Stage and the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, after which it is expected to come to Broadway.)
Although Mr. Richards has been criticized for his occasionally static direction and insufficient editing of Mr. Wilson, theirs remains one of the most significant director-playwright relationships in modern American theater.
"Lloyd found writers, and he stayed with them," says Arvin Brown, artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. "And he also worked with those writers in several regional theaters, promoting links between theaters as a collective home to new work."
Other observers, including Mr. Brustein and Rocco Landesman, the head of the Jujamcyn Theaters, were less sanguine. Mr. Brustein, who is also the theater critic of The New Republic, attacked the Broadway production of "The Piano Lesson" in a column last spring, complaining that Mr. Richards blurred the lines between the nonprofit and commercial theater and accusing him of running the Yale Rep as "a launching pad and tryout franchise for the development of Broadway products."
Mr. Richards maintains that such a relationship is part of the evolution of the American theater. "The commercial theater used to find talent and support it," he says. "Now it looks to the regional theaters as a substitute developmental arm."
Mr. Richards's interest in discovering and launching Mr. Wilson and other new playwrights strikes at what may be the central issue for him -- changing the scope and nature of American theatrical literature. "I think too often an American esthetic uses as its base Western European theater," he says. "The American theater will only come from an esthetic that takes from all the various cultural influences -- native and minority."
It is not an unexpected attitude from one who came of age in Depression-era hardship and social prejudice. Born in Canada in the early 1920's (he refuses to give the year), Mr. Richards is the son of a Jamaican carpenter. After the family moved to Detroit, his father died and his mother lost her sight. At the age of 9, Mr. Richards assumed much of the responsibility for the family. At his mother's encouragement, he studied pre-law at Wayne State University. But he also took theater classes where he discovered in acting "that sense that in being someone else you were permitted the full utilization of yourself."
After serving as one of the first black pilots in World War II, he moved to New York. For the next 20 years, he acted and directed infrequently, serving mainly as an acting coach. By 1966, his reputation as a developer of young talent was such that George White, president of the O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., tapped him to head its summer playwrights' conference. Under his direction, the O'Neill became the model for several theater and film workshops, including Robert Redford's Sundance Institute.
Today, after 12 years of heading a regional theater, Mr. Richards sees the challenges to directors "not only as tests of economics, but also of character." Regional theaters, he says, "are confronting 25 to 30 percent cuts in their budgets. How do you face that?"
About Mr. Wojewodski, his successor, the director will say only, "I don't know Stan as an artist." Mr. Richards says he declined to be part of the selection process and adds that he does not want to evaluate the changes that Mr. Wojewodski has already implemented at Yale. For his part, the incoming director, who is 42, is taking a more hands-on approach to the school, appointing himself head of the directing program, where he will teach several courses.
 At the moment, Mr. Richards wants to spend more time at home with his wife, Barbara, a playwright, and his two sons, Thomas and Scott, while maintaining his relationship with Mr. Wilson. They have the productions of "Two Trains Running" to prepare for and possibly a London version of "The Piano Lesson."
"The satisfaction for a director," says Mr. Richards, speaking almost as much for his own life as about the theater, "is that you put it all together and watch somebody else take off with it. As a director you stand on the ground and say, 'Look at that thing go.' "

HEADLINE: Latin America

 BODY:
To the Editor: I visited Brazil and Chile at the end of March and beginning of April. Since Latin America is a somewhat unusual destination, because rampant inflation makes the postage denominations sky high and because the stamps are colorful and interesting, I thought it would be amusing to send postcards. I gathered addresses of friends and family, bought lots of cards, wrote messages, went to post offices in Rio de Janeiro and Santiago, asked about airmail rates to the United States, paid almost $1 per card for postage, placed the stamps on myself, marked each card airmail and mailed them myself.
It has been about two months and not a single card has arrived. The explanation cannot be that all the cards were misaddressed. I suspect that the explanation is either inefficiency or corruption. It is possible that the postal departments simply take your money and never bother to send the cards.
 
THEORDORE J. JACOBS
Washington

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Buying a Home Is Still an American Goal

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
DESPITE the recession and a deep real estate slump that has eroded home values in much of the nation, a large majority of Americans still consider homeownership the best long-term investment they can make, according to a New York Times poll.
When asked if they agreed with the assertion, "Buying a home is the best long-term investment in the United States," an overwhelming 84 percent of those surveyed nationwide said they strongly agreed or somewhat agreed. The responses were nearly identical in New York City, its suburbs and the Northeast, where the value of many homes has plummeted more than 25 percent since 1988. 
 "When people go back to work and salaries start going up again, so will house prices," said Glenn Skrynecki, a 36-year-old Long Island engineer and one of more than 1,900 people who took part in the poll. "If you don't own you are like a dog chasing its tail," Mr. Skrynecki said in follow-up interview.
The poll also showed that a third of Americans, 32 percent, say they want to move, but a much higher proportion of big-city residents feel that way than do those in small towns and rural areas. And in what may reflect growing financial frustration -- and an increasingly pent-up demand for housing -- only a third of those who want to move said they would be able to do so within the next year. Among all American adults, only 14 percent said they were likely to move in the next year.
Those who want a different home say a variety of economic and family concerns are standing in the way. Mostly commonly, they cite worries about their personal finances and jobs, fears that the real estate slump may not have hit bottom and the simple fact that homes cost more than they can afford.
The poll, designed to gauge attitudes of people in the nation as a whole and in the New York region, was conducted by telephone in two phases, with 1,283 people across the country interviewed from April 1 to April 3, and 639 residents of New York City and 14 surrounding counties interviewed from June 10 to June 12.
In follow-up interviews, 20 participants expressed varied levels of confidence in the near-term prospects for home values in their cities and neighborhoods. But in almost all cases they said homeownership and moving on to something better were fundamental to their families' plans.
"Around here, you can find good quality homes that are underpriced," said Jeraldine Greene, an accountant for the City of Dallas, who, with her husband, Lonzie, wants to move with their two children to something bigger than the 1,600-square-foot ranch-style house they bought in 1976.
The house has little space for entertaining. Mr. Greene, also an accountant, is an avid saxophone player but must practice in the garage. Still, even though bigger houses are available at a discount in the sluggish Dallas real estate market, the Greenes said their finances were strained by the rising cost of education, health care, clothing and other family necessities.
They plan to move, but probably not for two years.
Just east of Sacramento, where robust population growth has kept home values rising, Robert James, an industrial supplies salesman, and his wife, Joyce, have the potential of profiting handsomely. They bought their house in 1974 for $50,000 and now estimate its value at $300,000. But they want to move. The buccolic subdivision they chose in the 70's has since been surrounded by much more intense development and they want a home farther east, in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada.
"We'll do it within five years," Mrs. James said.
And on Manhattan's Upper East Side, David Palmer, an options trader, and his wife, Helen, have been renting the same rent-stabilized one-bedroom apartment since 1974. Their son, John, is a high school sophmore; when he graduates, they plan to move.
"Buying is so expensive that for 17 years we haven't figured out how to do it," said Mrs. Palmer. "But to me, owning a home means security." She added that their move would probably take them to a smaller, less congested and less expensive community than New York.
In the poll, when Americans were asked, "Are you and your family satisfied with where you live now, or would you like to move?" 46 percent of big-city residents nationwide and 42 percent of New Yorkers said they would prefer to move. In contrast, only 18 percent of those in rural areas nationwide and 24 percent in small towns around the country said they wanted to move.
The desire for a better home apparently has no direct correlation to people's income, since roughly a third of those at all income levels, from less than $15,000 a year to more than $50,000, said they wanted to move. But the proportion of blacks who said they want to move, 45 percent, was higher than among whites, 29 percent.
The poll's findings suggest that if all the Americans who want to move were to do so soon, large cities would suffer a steep loss of population. When asked where they would like to move, the largest number nationwide of those who would like to move, 30 percent, said a rural area, and the second largest group, 25 percent, said they would select a suburb. Eighteen percent of those surveyed nationwide identifed their current residence as rural and another 18 percent said they now live in the suburbs.
Among residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut who said they want to move, the largest number, 36 percent, said they would move to a suburb, and 43 percent out of the three states altogether.
Not surprisingly, the survey also found that people in the New York region are devoting more of their income to housing than those elsewhere. Asked if their housing bills claimed more than 25 percent of their total household income, 43 percent of New York City residents and 36 percent of those in the 19-county New York region said yes, as against 26 percent nationwide.
Although polls of American homeowners and renters are not uncommon, housing experts said they knew of no survey that would provide a direct historical comparison to the Times poll's data. But they added that the Times poll demonstrates that the real estate boom of the 1980's, followed by the recent slump that has lowered values by more than 20 percent in New York, much of New England and some other areas, had done little to dampen people's desire to own homes.
"If anything, the poll suggests an uptick in demand," said Kathryn Nelson, an economist for the Department of Housing and Urban Development who in the early 1980's analyzed a special 1979 Census Bureau survey. She found that 30 percent of the public wanted to move and that half planned to do so in the next five years.
"It is always true that more people say they want to move than actually intend to," said Anthony Downs, a housing analyst with the Brookings Institution in Washington. He added that overall demand for housing was not expected to increase dramatically in the remainder of the 1990's.
One reason is population changes, including the aging of the Baby Boom generation and increased divorce rates, which created new households at a rate of 1.7 million a year in the 1970's and 1.3 million a year in the 80's. In contrast, an average of 1.1 million new households will be formed each year until the year 2000, according to recent forecasts.
Not everyone who participated in the poll is convinced of the long-term benefits of homeownership. While the overwhelming majority said they still considered homes the "best long-term investment," 55 percent said they agreed that "buying a home is not as good an investment as it used to be."
Most also said owning a home is harder than it once was. Eighty percent agreed that "these days, owning a home takes two incomes." And 80 percent agreed that "younger people today have a harder time buying a home than their parents did, and may never be able to afford the home they need."
Christopher Infurchia of Bridgeport is one of the Americans who has not found real estate ownership rewarding. "This was supposed to be the American dream," said the 29-year-old automobile salesman, who paid $180,000 in 1986 for a two-family house. He said he bought a house when "it seemed like if you didn't buy now, you'd be completely locked out." He selected the two-family house with the hope that income from renting out the second unit would cover a large part of his mortgage payments.
But with Bridgeport in deep recession -- Connecticut's largest city filed for protection under the bankruptcy code this month -- Mr. Infurchia's apartment has been vacant for nine months. Late last year, in hope of getting bank financing, he had it appraised and found it was worth $30,000 less than he paid.
"I think I may be part of a whole generation that lost out by buying houses at the wrong time," he said.
Nevertheless, other homeowners in the New York area, even those who have watched their values decline, said their belief in homeownership was unshaken.
One is Mr. Skrynecki, who in 1986 bought a four-bedroom Colonial house in Hicksville, L.I. Since house prices have slumped on Long Island, as elsewhere in the region, he said he would now "be lucky to break even" if he sold the house.
But he added that he did not regret the purchase. Among other things, he said, the tax saving he gains by deducting mortgage interest has kept his housing costs at about the same level as if he were renting.
"I don't think we've gotten to the bottom of this slump, because I expect there are more layoffs," he said. "But I'm still convinced that you have to own your home if you are going to get anywhere."
 
 
 
HOW THE SURVEY WAS CONDUCTED

The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted with separate samples nationwide and within the tristate area in and around New York City.
The national interviewing was conducted April 1 to 3 with 1,283 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii. The tristate interviewing was conducted June 10 to 12 with 639 adults in 19 counties of the greater New York area.
The greater New York area was defined as the five boroughs of New York City plus the Connecticut county of Fairfield, the New York State counties of Nassau, Rockland, Suffolk and Westchester, and the New Jersey counties of Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Passaic, Somerset and Union.
The nationwide sample, which utilized a computer to select telephone exchanges and to randomly form the last four digits of each telephone number, used the method employed for many years by New York Times/CBS News Polls. The numbers were screened so that calls would be placed to residences only.
The sample of telephone numbers in the greater New York area, also based on random digit dialing techniques, was drawn by Marketing Systems Group of Philadelphia, who also purged the sample of known businesses and nonworking numbers.
In both samples, within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results from both the national and local samples have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in each sample relating to race, sex, and age. The national sample was also weighted by region and education, while the local sample was weighted to reflect an accurate balance between the population of New York City and of the surrounding 14-county area.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than a few percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adults in the respective population: three percentage points in the case of the United States and four percentage points in the case of the greater New York area.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for those who say they would like to move to a new residence it is plus or minus five percentage points in the national sample, and plus or minus six percentage points in the greater New York sample.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Commercial Leases;
Recasting Rents in City-Owned Buildings

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
RAISING commercial rents is not an easy task for city government. Restructuring them for tenants in place, with no tenancy turnover, is harder still.
Restructuring means bringing rents in line with fair market values and ending the distortions that favor some tenants over others merely because they have stayed in place for a long time.
The administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch tried to raise the rents of commercial tenants in city-owned buildings slated for redevelopment on urban renewal sites, and for stores in tax-foreclosed residential buildings. 
 The plan was less than a detailed restructuring, but it nevertheless provoked an outcry by small businesses and nonprofit organizations and their elected representatives, including the man who was then Borough President of Manhattan, David N. Dinkins. Mayor Koch backed down and settled for a mild across-the-board percentage increase for the urban-renewal properties only.
Now, Mayor Dinkins's office has approved a new approach to the same objective. Fair-market rents, based on city appraisals, would be phased in over five years, with caps on the year-to-year increases for four years and a rent ceiling for nonprofits set at 50 percent of fair-market value.
There has been no announcement of the plan at City Hall, but the Department of Housing Preservation and Development provided details about it. The department has included in its revenue projections for the 1992 fiscal year, which begins tomorrow, figures based on what the first year of the phase-in is expected to generate.
Preliminary regulations are to be published for comment shortly, and a public hearing will follow. Officials expect the final regulations to come out this summer. After that they will be implemented community board by community board, chosen by random selection. A departmental appeals procedure will be provided for tenants who challenge the rent appraisals.
The history of the plan demonstrates the long-term troubles that arise when rents fail to adjust systematically to changing market conditions in different areas. In housing, this fuels the movement toward co-op conversion, even in areas where the sales market is not established. In buildings already converted it has produced a formidable gap between the housing costs of long-term renters and newly arrived co-op buyers. Ultimately the gap may undercut the co-op's finances.
In all there are 2,300 commercial properties owned and managed by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, 1,900 of them stores in tax-foreclosed buildings. The rest are tenants in urban renewal areas, typically businesses operating garages or loft tenants who never left after condemnation. In the foreclosed properties, the housing agency estimates that 800 properties are already paying fair-market rents.
The city's rent income from all these tenancies in fiscal 1991, which ends today, is $7 million. Restructured rents should produce an additional $1 million next year and $2 million in fiscal 1993, when all the new rents are in place, officials say.
But higher rent revenues are not the agency's main goal, said Felice Michetti, Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development.
"It's basically an equity issue," she said. "The plan has been written to mitigate hardship, but it's not conscionable to have one storefront rented at low-low rents and another next to it at 10 times the rent." That degree of distortion is not an exaggeration, she said.
The distortions arise because there is no mechanism for rent increases when leases are renewed. Rents are changed only when a tenant moves. In the last three years the city has turned to auctions to determine the vacancy values.
It is not hard to appreciate the sensitivities over this issue among tenants. Many of the stores serve the city's poorest neighborhoods. They are marginal businesses. The tenants in urban renewal areas may well feel that low rent is a reasonable price for the uncertainty of their occupancy. The nonprofits feel they are providing a community service on a shoestring.
But it is hard to justify the inequities of the current system. In one case on the Bowery, officials said, a restaurant equipment store pays the city $177 a month in rent for a space that has a current appraised value of $1,900.
On Thompson Street in Soho, a long-operating hair salon in a five-story walk-up pays $350 a month. Its neighbor, a recently arrived art gallery, pays the city $1,330 for a store the same size. A private owner's asking rent for a vacant store in the next-door building is $1,500.
"Obviously it would be more difficult for me than it is now," said Romeo DaSilva, the owner of the hair salon, Girl Loves Boy, which has been at 63 Thompson Street for 13 years with no rent increase.
"Would it put me out of business?" he said. "Who knows? A little rent increase I can see." Rent levels aside, the commercial tenants are hardly a privileged lot. Their businesses lack the assurance of a long-term lease and stable long-term occupancy. Their leases run only 11 months. If they were a year or more each lease would have to go through the uniform land-use review process.
Since they are in buildings headed for reuse, resale or perhaps demolition, the tenants are unable to make a long-term investment in them. The city provides basic services only.
These factors will be considered in the appraisals that set the fair-market rents, said Deputy Housing Commissioner William E. Spiller, who heads the Office of Property Management.
The rent restructuring plan sets up three categories of commercial tenants: those in space under 1,000 square feet; those in more than 1,000 square feet, and those leased to nonprofit tenants.
In the first category -- usually small grocers or other retailers -- rents would rise to their fair-market appraised value at a rate no faster than 15 percent a year over five years. In the final year, if the fair-market level had not already been reached, the rent would rise as much as necessary for that to happen.
For these stores, the minimum first-year rent would be $300, assuming that the fair-market rent is higher than that. If it is lower, the rent would go to that level in the first year.
For commercial spaces of more than 1,000 square feet there would also be a 15 percent cap, but the minimum first-year rent would be set at 25 percent of the appraised fair-market rent.
Nonprofits would pay a minimum of $150 a month in the first year (or the fair-market rent if that is lower). Their phase-in schedule is 10 percent of the previous year's rent in the second through fourth years, and 15 percent a year thereafter until the target rent of 50 percent of fair-market value is reached.
There are about 200 nonprofit tenants in these city-owned stores, Mr. Spiller said. The new policy would make it likely that they would have to be able to afford at least $150 a month in rent.
The five-year phase-in is intended to give tenants whose rents are far removed from market rents and who find market rents unaffordable time to move to another location. In the case of the Soho hair salon, for example, the rent would go from $350 a month in the first year to $403 in the second; $532 in the third; $612 in the fourth, and $1,330 in the fifth.
Commissioner Spiller estimated that 800 tenants would be affected by the restructuring. An important aspect of the plan is its intention to set appraisals that realistically take account of building and leasing conditions, he said. The auctions of the last three years have produced 600 storefront leases, he said. The upset price was set at 75 percent of the appraised value.
"The bids validated our appraisal methods," Commissioner Spiller said. "In almost all cases we received bids above the upset prices."
