HEADLINE: Talking: Relocation;
Helping Transferees Who Rent

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
A growing number of corporate transferees are choosing to rent rather than buy a home at their new assignment, a situation that is creating new challenges for the transferees and their employers.
 "For the first time I am hearing about people getting benefits that were never discussed before," said Priscilla Toomey, senior vice president at Prudential Relocation Management in White Plains, which handles the housing needs of corporate transferees. Demand for help with rental relocation among Prudential's 400 corporate clients rose by 25 percent in the last two years, she said. In the past, the company had provided help mainly in buying and selling homes. 
 Greg Brewer, editor of the Runzheimer Reports on Relocation, a monthly trade newsletter, reports a similar shift. He attributes it to lingering uncertainties in the real estate market combined with personal fears about the future. Another factor, other experts say, is that corporations squeezed by the recession are eager to trim costs, and rental benefits are cheaper than those for homeowners.
 Also, a growing number of transferees no longer expect to make a profit on the sale of their homes. Thus they do not have to worry about the capital-gains tax that might be due on the profits of the sale if they did not replace it with the purchase of another primary residence within two years.
 Adding to the appeal of renting for transferees, brokers say, has been the increased availability of attractive properties at favorable rents -- a consequence of a lack of buyers for these properties.
 It was just this combination of factors that led Michael Waltz, an assistant vice president at Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, to decide to rent when he learned he was being transferred from Chicago to New York City in May. "I wasn't going to make more than a normal profit on my condo in Chicago," he said, "and I was even less optimistic about the New York market."
 However, since most relocation-benefit programs are still heavily weighted toward buying and selling, employees interested in renting could miss out unless they play their cards carefully.
 For example, Chevron Corporation still provides up to $60,000 toward the cost of purchasing a home for someone being moved from a relatively low-priced area like Houston to a high-priced region like San Francisco, said David Barlow, the company's manager of human-resources policy.
By contrast, until about 18 months ago renters were able to get only the blanket bonus of six weeks' pay available to all transferred employees and a small additional allowance based on the gap between prevailing shelter costs in the two cities.
 Chevron has since made some adjustments -- renters can now get $5,000 up front and $10,000 over the following two years for a similar Houston-to-San Francisco move. But dozens of other companies have yet to formally offer much in the way of rental help for domestic transferees (most rental programs were devised for employees being temporarily sent overseas). As a result, rental transferees may need to speak up to get equal treatment.
"Although more companies are providing better benefits to renters, it's mostly being done on a individual basis," Ms. Toomey said.
 Among the possible benefits are reimbursement for the cost of placing the former home under professional property management and for difference between that home's monthly mortgage payments and the rent obtained for it; a home-finding trip to the new location; and reimbusement of any lease-cancellation charge at the new location if the transferee has to relocate again during the term of a lease.
Reimbursement of up-front rental costs is important, since those costs can add up quickly, said Marion Usdan, corporate relocation coordinator for Weichert Relocation Company of New Jersey. For instance, a one- or two-month security deposit, the first month's rent in advance, an agent's fee of a month's rent, and the cost of fuel and cleaning services could create a total cash advance of $6,500 on a $1,500-a-month rental.
 The experts say employees should also ask in advance about a "delayed trigger" on benefits. This could be important for a transferee who elects not to sell an existing home right away, since it may involve taking a loss, but intends to become a renter in the new location only until economic conditions improve.
The delayed trigger gives an employee a later opportunity to tap into sale-and-purchase reimbursement benefits traditionally available only at the time of the move -- not six months or a year later.
 One way to persuade a company to provide rental benefits is to demonstrate the compar ative savings. The latest Runzheimer survey, for example, showed that it cost $35,080 on average to relocate a homeowning employee in 1990, up from $30,760 in 1988. By contrast, relocating a renter cost a company less than a third of that amount -- $9,329 on average in 1990, only a marginal increase from the 1988 cost of $9,218.
 Linda Kabelis, who works for PHH Homequity in Rahway, N.J., recently moved from Norwalk, Conn. Before even presenting to her employer her "wish list" of benefits as a renter, she found out exactly what the costs would be. And although she did not get all she wanted, "they covered quite a lot," she said.
 It may also be helpful to demonstrate to an employer how additional savings might be achieved if certain blanket benefits available to all transferees were modified to meet the renter's needs. John Griffin, president of Griffin Realty Group of Manhattan, which specializes in rentals for corporate transferees, tells of an executive for a Midwest pharmaceutical company who found a superb two-bedoom apartment on the Upper East Side for only $1,500 a month -- something of a bargain -- on the very first day he went out looking.
 The difficulty was that the landlord required him to start paying rent immediately to reserve the apartment, even though the transfer would not take place for two months. Though the Midwest corporation had no formal policy anticipating this type of cost, the executive managed to persuade his company to cover the two months' rent by pointing out that it would not have to pay hotel costs for him and his family for their first 60 days in the city, a benefit it offered to all transferees. The hotel bill, he said, could have been $6,000 -- twice the cost of two months' rent.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Danbury Begins a Downtown Renewal

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
AFTER three decades of planning, and some false starts, Danbury has begun to revitalize its neglected downtown.
With 25 percent of retail space and 20 percent of downtown offices vacant, building a large municipal garage might seem to be the last thing Danbury needs, but a 550-car structure is now going up -- and there is method in the seeming madness. 
 "We have around 400 cars parked in a patchwork of temporary surface lots in the Redevelopment District off Main Street," said Dennis Elpern, the city's planner. "Those sites are slated for the building of new stores, restaurants, housing and offices. We have to replace the parking so that developers can come in and work."
And there is lots of work to do in a downtown scarred by two floods -- the Still River flood of 1955 that destroyed the seven acres that now make up the Redevelopment District, and the flood of development in the 1980's along Interstate 84 and Route 7 that created a flourishing second city on Danbury's outskirts at the center's expense.
Proposals for developing three of nine sites that make up the 7.7-acre Redevelopment District were given preliminary approval by the city's Redevelopment Agency on June 12. The plans would add a total of some 20,000 square feet of retail space, 10,000 square feet of offices, 165 restaurant seats, 81 units of housing and a 1,000-seat triplex movie theater. The downtown area's current inventory includes one theater, 373,000 square feet of retail space, 400,000 square feet of offices and more than a dozen restaurants.
The focal point, said Mr. Elpern, will be a 19,580-square-foot plot of greenery off Main Street that the city will landscape and beautify at a cost of $250,000 in state funds and call, appropriately, the Green.
York Associates of Manhattan has made a $5.27 million proposal to build a triplex movie theater, 46 town-house condominiums and 9,500 square feet of restaurant and retail space on a foundation installed in 1987 by a Waterbury developer, John Erichetti, who was unable to continue because of financial difficulties.
"We are not looking for one magic developer any more," said Mayor Gene F. Eriquez. "We now have smaller sites and a mix of developers."
Proposals by Davon Development Corporation and City Center Development Partnership, two local firms, were selected for the other two sites.
Davon's $5.15 million Liberty Terrace proposal comprises 5,350 square feet of retail space and 35 condominium units. City Center proposes 10,320 square feet of retail space, 9,750 square feet of offices and a restaurant at a cost of $2 million. Its project would be called Pavilion on the Green.
Each developer has a negotiable checklist of preconditions to meet, said John J. Sullivan, chairman of the Redevelopment Agency. For example, the agency would require York Associates to pay $200,000 for pedestrian improvements and $1.6 million in lieu of parking. York is committed to beginning construction next year.
"Their plan does not contain enough parking," said Mr. Sullivan, "and since they are getting the land and foundation free, they will have to fund parking elsewhere, or reduce the dollar amount by providing more on-site parking."
The 175,000-square-foot municipal garage, under construction by Desman Associates of Manhattan, will face Delay Street; pedestrians will be able to reach it from Main Street along two brick-paved, landscaped walks. The garage will also contain the city's Parking Authority offices.
None of the plans for the Redevelopment District or Main Street call for city money. The $4.3 million garage will be financed through an $8 million state grant, the rest of which will used for paving the sidewalks with brick along a half-mile retail core of Main Street, and for benches, trees and a new system of synchronized traffic signals to be installed down the entire two-mile length of Main Street beginning in August.
Felice Plain, executive director of City Center Danbury, a group of 120 downtown property owners working with the city and the Redevelopment Agency, said: "We have just completed a retail cluster plan for Main Street, something different from strip centers and the mall."
"Office supplies, office furniture, printers, dry cleaners and other services," she said, "would be clustered from Rose to White Street; entertainment and specialty retail from White to Liberty Street; decorative arts, antiques, furniture and galleries from Liberty to Boughton."
As new stores arrive, they will be clustered in the designated areas but old stores will not be forced out.
Financed by member assessments of $2 to $20,000, depending on the size of property and range of business, the organization's $150,000 budget covers staffing, marketing, planning, security and maintenance.
Figures compiled by the Greater Danbury Chamber of Commerce for its 10-town area show 3 million square feet of offices and an equal amount of retail space. "Between 80 and 85 percent of that is located in Danbury," said Joseph Wrinn, a realty broker with the local firm of Goodfellow Ashmore.
 Another boost for downtown is due in 1993 when a new train station is built by the State Department of Transportation at Liberty Street and Patriot Drive, just south of the old station and the Redevelopment District.
Richard P. Rathbun, director of rail operations for the New Haven division of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, said that "we are swapping the old station and parking area for 2.6 acres of city land at the new site; the city can then develop the old station commercially." The old station is on the National Register of Historic Places.
The new, 1,800-square-foot depot will have a ticket booth, waiting room and rest rooms, and an expandable parking lot of 150 spaces.
Of immediate concern to downtown boosters is financing the redevelopment projects in the midst of a recession. "We are confident that we can deliver backers," said Thomas Wormser, a partner at York Associates. "There is interest from movie operators and retailers for preleasing, and at around $115,000 a unit we feel that we can presell the condominiums."
"All the developers are moving forward with their plans and considering our stipulations," said Mr. Sullivan. "If we get two out of three it will be marvelous."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Rent Overcharge
 
Question: I am the prime tenant of a rent-stabilized apartment. I came to the conclusion I was being overcharged on my rent and filed a complaint with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal in June 1990. I have received a docket number but have heard nothing since then. Is there any way to establish when a complaint will become an active investigation and how long it will take to settle the matter? . . . Lise Holst, Manhattan 

 Answer: No. Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the state housing agency, said that the average waiting time between receipt of such a complaint and an investigation is about 27 months. He ascribed the delay to the number of complaints -- currently about 18,000 cases in New York City.
"Once a case is moved to an investigator," said Mr. Viola, "determination ususally comes in three months. But until then the time is spent in a queue waiting for attention."
Several variables affect how long the investigation can take, Mr. Viola said, including how much cooperation the agency gets from landlords. Determining if a tenant has been charged too much requires a rent history for the apartment and that often requires that the owner provides copies of past leases.
 
Rules for Window Guards
 
Question: I live in a four-story, 40-unit co-op. I want to know if window guards are required on the first floors as well as upper floors and in all windows in apartments where children live, and who is responsible for installing them. Where can we go for that information? . . . Thomas P. Herbert, Brooklyn.
 
Answer: Go to the Department of Health's Window Falls Prevention Program. A spokesman for the department said that Section 131.15 of the city's health code require guards on all windows, including those on the first floor, in units where children 10 years old or younger live. The exceptions are windows used as emergency exits, like those leading to fire escapes.
The owner, lessee or manager of a multiple dwelling is responsible for installing the guards, but it is up to the tenant to notify the owner or board of directors if there is a child in the apartment. Some owners or co-op boards pass along the cost of the guards to tenants; others absorb the expense.
For further information call the Window Falls Prevention Program at 566-8082.
 
Two-Family Homes
 
Question: My husband and I are confused about what "legal two-family house" means. Is there a reference we can use to ensure that if we buy a two-family home it is legal? . . . Charleen Lang, Maspeth, Queens
 
Answer: Yes. The City's Department of Buildings can tell you whether a house is a legal two-family dwelling. One criterion is the number of units listed in the house's Certificate of Occupancy. If, for example, a home has two living spaces but its certificate indicates it is a single dwelling, the second apartment is illegal.
Sometimes owners of large houses add an apartment in the basement or the top floor. When such changes are made, the owner not only needs Buildings Department permits to do the work, but also must have the certificate changed to legalize the added unit.
Information on the status of dwellings in Queens is available in the Buildings Department's borough office, 126-06 Queens Boulevard, Kew Gardens. The telephone number is 718-520-3402.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
In Cromwell, Thai Food to Tease the Palate

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
FOR a while, Thai restaurants were popping up throughout Connecticut. Now, after a recession-induced slowdown, there is a new one, Thai Gardens, in the town of Cromwell, near Middletown.
It is a welcome addition, both for its attractive and spacious dining room (including tables and floor cushions for Thai-style seating) in a small shopping center and, more important, for the authentic taste of the dishes on its sizable menu. 
 On arrival, we felt a tinge of apprehension. As aficionados of Thai food, it has been our experience outside Connecticut that some restaurants labeled as Thai are really Chinese. We weren't reassured when our waitress, who looked Thai, asked us to specify by numbers the Thai dishes we had ordered by their Thai names (it was probably our Western pronounciation) and then asked if we wanted the dishes mild or hot. We said "almost Thai hot" -- and to our pleasure that's the way they were served.
After several visits we concluded that Thai Gardens is truly a garden of Thai delights. If the menu lacks certain Thai specialties that might be favorites of yours, there are enough well-prepared dishes with sufficient variety to take up the slack.
For a newcomer to the intense spiciness of Thai cuisine, one might begin with a mildly seasoned satay of skewered and grilled pork, beef or chicken. We selected chicken, and the skewers of grilled white meat were served with a tiny hibachi for keeping the skewers warm and with two dipping sauces: peanut and a cucumber vinegar sauce with a sharp edge.
An even better starter choice was hot-hot pork (nam sod) -- a pungent salad of cooked ground pork, tossed with scallions, peanuts, red peppers and the snap of ginger and lime juice, served on a bed of lettuce. Jumping squid consisted of grilled squid, chopped purple onions, cucumber and tomatoes, with chili paste, lemon grass, hot peppers and lime juice -- a spectrum of competing flavors. The same dish made with shrimp was equally tingling.
Other starters of merit were tofu tod (deep-fried bean curd with a well-seasoned peanut sauce), mee grob (crispy rice noodles mixed with shrimp and vegetables in a honey sauce -- too sweet for some tastes), and clear noodles (glass noodles entwined with jumbo shrimp, bits of Chinese sausage, ground pork, red and green peppers, tomatoes and straw mushrooms).
A good Thai soup often shows off the complexity and balance inherent in this delicate yet spicy cuisine. At Thai Gardens, two satisfying soups were shrimp soup (full of shrimp and straw mushrooms as well as a well-balanced spice-sour interplay and a lemon grass accent) and chicken soup (pieces of white meat in a lightly spiced coconut milk broth with a ginger-like galanga root undercurrent).
An entree standout was basil duck -- small, crisp-skinned wedges, crunchy with the contrasting flavor and textures of fresh basil, bell peppers and onion slices. Also engaging (and moderately combustible) was chicken curry, a red curry with bamboo shoots and a thin coconut milk broth (tasty when spooned over rice); a similarly prepared shrimp curry was also zesty.
Hot and sour fish was another pleasure: a whole red snapper, deep-fried crisp, with firm, sweet white meat made even more delicious by a tantalizing sauce and an abundance of julienne vegetables. Garlic squid (stir-fried and peppery) was acceptable, too, but several pork dishes -- ginger pork and garlic pork -- were bland and lackluster.
Desserts at Thai Gardens are few, but pumpkin custard and coconut ice cream made cool, refreshing counterpoints to savory meals.
For $41.80 (before tax, tip and drinks), two of us enjoyed three courses apiece. But portions were generous enough so that a single appetizer, especially the Thai salads or noodle dishes, could be shared. The best accompaniment for a Thai meal is Singha beer, though other drinks are also available.
The restaurant's main weakness during our visits was service, which was cheerful but seemed slow and sloppy at times, with drink orders not taken and requests for water forgotten even when repeated. Clearly, these are reparable flaws that shouldn't keep guests from an enjoyable evening.

HEADLINE: Men's Undershirts: Out From Under, Into the Sunshine of Prints and Colors

BYLINE: By DEBORAH HOFMANN

 BODY:
Not long ago, a man could rely on being banished from his own dinner table if he was not wearing a shirt over his undershirt. These days men are wearing jackets over undershirts, instead of shirts, even to fancy restaurants. And sometimes undershirts are being marched right into the office, especially on getaway Fridays.
"This is a street fashion that caught on for its comfort and ease of care," said Chip Tolbert, a spokesman for the Men's Fashion Association, a trade group. He was at his desk wearing a white T-shirt under his suit jacket. He says that the man who wears a T-shirt to work is the same man who might wear a shirt buttoned to the neck but without a tie or, in winter, a turtleneck. 
 When asked their reasons for wearing undershirts instead of shirts, practical men echo Mr. Tolbert. They complain that it costs too much -- about $2.50 -- to have a cotton shirt professionally laundered after each wearing. A T-shirt can be tossed into the washing machine. Many such men say they buy T-shirts made by Jockey International. That traditional undershirt now comes in 12 brilliant colors, plus black, for $9 each. A beefier "sportswear" style, comes in 15 colors as well as 5 prints in several color combinations; it's $12 at Macy's, Bloomingdale's, A & S and Lord & Taylor.
For the man driven more by fashion than by economics, a variety of colors, prints and luxury fabrics can cost him, say, $90 for a designer T-shirt.
"This is the golden anniversary of the T, the peak of a cycle that began 50 years ago when American civilians were introduced to it as part of the Navy uniform in World War II, 1941," said Jack Herschlag, executive director of the National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers.
From that point, the T-shirt evolved into active wear, generally in a gray hue, with more colorful printed ones for sports teams. These were soon brightened with dramatic graphics. The utilitarian became fashionable. Soon came the message T-shirt, for conveying ideology or advertising. Novelty characters followed, and photo-print likenesses of celebrities like Bo Jackson.
And now there is the "dress" T shirt. "In two years the dress T-shirt went from nothing to being a marketing monster," said Mr. Herschlag in an interview this week at the trade show sponsored by his group at the Javits Convention Center.
Of the 700 companies that displayed there, more than 100 showed dress T-shirts in every shade, as well as in tiny, neat repeat prints, many with detailing on the chest or pocket. Typically, the crew neckband is a little higher, to conceal the collarbone a bit and to prevent a jacket lapel from chafing the neck -- "grace notes," Mr. Herschlag said, "so that there's no mistaking that this is not a makeshift look."
Sales of men's knit shirts -- which include T, polo and turtleneck styles -- have taken off. Retail sales in 1990 were up by 10.4 percent over 1989, reaching more than $3.1 billion, said Peter Simon, a director of the NPD Group, a market research organization in Port Washington, N.Y., which compiles statistics on apparel.
"In the context of the total men's wear business -- which had no growth over the same period -- knit shirts, driven by T's, buck the trend. It's one of the few growth categories," Mr. Simon said. The same rate of increase has continued this year. T-shirts outsell all other mens' tops, including shirts, Mr. Simon said.
Members Only makes cotton T-shirts in 10 folkloric, mosaic and batik-inspired prints, each in at least three color combinations; $20 at A & S and Stern's stores. Sun-bleached earth tones are popular.
Those who favor bright hues lean toward Colours by Alexander Julian, which makes a basic one-pocket T of soft pima cotton in 30 relatively brilliant colors, like iris, orange, teal, midnight, tomato, banana and black; they also have side vents and a back yoke; $26 at Lord & Taylor, Strawbridge & Clothier and Woodward & Lothrop stores.
At Barneys New York, the knit cotton T's of the fashion designer Ronaldus Shamask come in ivory and pewter, and are $90. And Giorgio Armani's luxury T-shirt knit of rust-color viscose is $345. Cotton knit T-shirts by Comme des Garcons, in purple or mustard, are $53. Barneys' private label woven cotton T's in navy, pumpkin, ivory and goldenrod are $28; beefier weights are $40.
Mondo di Marco makes 15 vivid, patterned T-shirts in cotton, drapey rayon, silk or viscose, each pattern available in five color combinations. A Florentine paisley style has been selling very well, especially in warm oranges, cool blues or muted mauve and black; at Bloomingdale's, Saks and I. Magnin nationwide, and at Beau Brummel stores in Manhattan and Queens, it is $80.
Falke makes distressed cotton T-shirts in six prints. The key colors are olive, gray and indigo. Nature themes, geometrics and Aztec symbols play on background colors of olive, gray, white or denim. A popular print depicts a brilliant yellow and fuchsia toucan in an indigo sky. Falke T's are $70 and are still plentiful at Vincci, 7039 Austin Street in Forest Hills, Queens; Aldo's, 725 River Road in Edgewater, N.J., and Tuesday's in Hartford.

HEADLINE: Style Makers;
Camella Ehlke, Clothing Designer

 BODY:
At 555 Soul, a small Lower East Side store, young people are creating fashions and accessories that reflect downtown night life.
The store, at 151 Ludlow Street, near Houston Street, offers the work of artists, designers and musicians of various racial, ethnic, social and economic backgrounds. They borrow from African, California surf, urban rap and 60's psychedelic styles. 
 They like to gather where their styles are welcome, at "outlaw" clubs, usually in lofts, old theaters or dance studios. The clubs change their locations constantly.
555 Soul's love beads have been worn by the rap artists Jungle Brothers and Boogie Down Productions.
Camella Ehlke, who runs 555 Soul, makes clothing based on designs, patterns and colors of the last four decades. Her work evokes the 60's, but, she said, "This is definitely a 90's thing."
Miss Ehlke, 21 years old, barters her clothing for jewelry made by her colleagues. Her clothes (shirts and slacks are $40 to $55) combine stripes with patterns, and then she adds a touch of street style. She says she plans to use local grafitti artists to create fabric designs. Her hats ($25) dominate one wall. Brightly colored and oddly shaped, they call to mind cartoon characters like Jughead or the Cat in the Hat.
555 Soul's jewelry, most of it love beads inspired by African trading beads (necklaces are sold at $5 a bead), includes medallions ($50 and up) made by two teams of artists. Jamalsky and Cormack, who each use only one name, produce their work as Level Vibe Productions; Sung Choi and Melissa Odegaard collaborate as Ofe Intl.
The store's hours are 1 P.M. to 7 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays. Call (212) 995-9252.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
It's a Merrily Asynchronous World We Have

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
Last week seemed to prove that the world's stock markets are as tightly intertwined as the circuitry on a computer chip. Shocks from far-flung markets -- a potential cease-fire violation in Baghdad, a tax hike in Bonn, a financial scandal in Tokyo -- helped knock the Dow, which closed at 2906.75, down by 58.81 points for the week. But don't jump to the conclusion that the world's stock markets will keep marching in lockstep.
True, investors all over the globe are becoming decidedly less provincial. Every day more than $600 billion sloshes around the world's currency markets. Foreigners tripled their holdings of American stocks during the 1980's. American stockholders, meanwhile, quintupled their ownership of foreign shares. 
 If anything, the trends that encouraged such worldliness on the part of investors continue apace, said David G. Strongin, director of international finance at the Securities Industries Association. Governments keep lifting capital controls and technology keeps making it easier to track and trade shares wherever they are.
Nonetheless, there's little evidence that stock markets are more in sync today than they were back in the isolationist 1950's and 1960's. A Morgan Stanley study of how closely stock markets move together shows that the tendency for lockstep movement is no greater now than 20 years ago. "You'd expect the correlations to get tighter," said Madhav Dhar, global equities strategist for Morgan Stanley. "But while the world is getting to be a smaller place in terms of throwing money around, other factors are making it more diverse."
For one thing, said Mr. Dhar, the United States is no longer the world economy's sole trend setter. Its share of global stock market capitalization has shrunk dramatically. For another, ownership of stocks and bonds is still overwhelmingly national. That means prospects at home -- namely, domestic interest rates and profits -- still matter the most.
Most important, though, is the happily asynchronous state of the world's economies. Nowadays, the United States and Canada are coming out of recessions, Mexico is booming, while Germany and Japan are slowing from their recent torrid pace. A few decades ago, the world mostly boomed and slumped together.
Some events still have the power to roil all the worlds' markets at once, like the global spurt in interest rates before the 1987 crash, the collapse of Communism, or last year's surge in oil prices. But even then, markets hardly reacted alike.
During 1987 as a whole, for example, Japan's market rose 9 percent, West Germany's plunged 38 percent and in the United States, things ended up where it started. Last year, after the Berlin wall crumbled and worldwide interest rates soared, Japan's market plummeted and Germany's zoomed.
As for the future, said P. Craig Ueland, director of international consulting at the Frank-Russell Company, "One might expect a greater tendency for markets to move together. At best, the conventional wisdom that they already do so is ahead of reality."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Cable and Wireless Conundrum

BYLINE: BY Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the British-based telecommunications company with a presence in 50 countries, pleased investors earlier this month when it reported pretax profits up 15.5 percent for the fiscal year ended March 31. And this in a recession year.
Moreover, more than 60 percent of the company's revenues are dollar based, so the strong rally of the dollar in the last five months sent analysts back to their calculators to raise their earnings forecasts for the current fiscal year. Although its headquarters are in London, the company's heart is Hong Kong where the currency is tied to the dollar. Cable and Wireless has a 58.4 percent controlling stake in Hong Kong Telecommunications, which provided 43 percent of the company's revenue and 59 percent of its profit last year. 
 Company officials, including its group managing director, Gordon M. W. Owen, and finance director, Rodney J. Olsen, crowed about these numbers on a recent visit to New York City. They waxed enthusiastic about the company's global digital "highway," including an American link with US Sprint. The highway is a fiber-optic cable system linking major financial centers and offering business customers such things as high-definition television and video-conferencing, high-speed data transmission and faxes. Cable and Wireless also owns Mercury Communications, the first and only competitor to British Telecommunications, the Government-owned phone company.
Despite its good looks last year and prospects in the current year, there are questions about Cable and Wireless which, at current prices, make the stock less attractive.
The stock's volatility reflects some of this uncertainty. In June alone, its price fell to 490 pence ($9.08 at Friday's exchange rate) and then rallied to 560. It closed Friday at 529. The company's American Depository Receipt which trades in New York has moved from a low of 24.875 to 26.875. It closed Friday at 25.50.
The stock already trades at a 13-to-20 percent premium to the British market as a whole, based on earnings projections.
Then there are the questions about the quality of Cable and Wireless' earnings. The company has had a good stream of average earnings over the last decade, but the yearly numbers are subject to big hits from exchange rate moves. Last year, for example, the company estimated that pretax profits would have doubled to 31 percent if the dollar had not been so weak. Now the high hopes for the current fiscal year are based on the current strong dollar retaining its strength.
Some of the pretax profit last year was based on special factors that should vanish this year. One was the sale of a managing director's house in Hong Kong that added 9.2 million pounds ($16 million) to the books.
In addition, the sale of 20 percent of Cable and Wireless' stake in Hong Kong Telecommunicatons to the Chinese Government reduced the company's borrowing needs in 1991, dropping the bank loan level from 59.9 million pounds ($104.2 million at the end-of-March exchange rate) in 1990 to 16.3 million pounds in fiscal 1991. Company executives acknowledge that borrowing will pick up again this year.
Such things accounted for a swing in the company's net-interest and other-income line from a 46.9 million pound deficit in 1990 to a 31.2 million pound surplus the following year. The 78.1 million pound shift accounts for all but 3.7 million pounds of the increase in profits before taxes.
All of these considerations must be weighed against larger questions about the future of Hong Kong, which reverts to the control of China in 1997. Hong Kong Telecommunications is not only Cable and Wireless' main business but also a source of money needed to expand Mercury back home in the United Kingdom, enhance the global digital highway and eventually make the company much less dependent on Hong Kong.
Cable and Wireless, as well as analysts like Robert B. Morris 3d of Goldman Sachs in San Francisco, are not worried about the takeover by China. Mr. Morris is more concerned, at least in the near term, about how a tax increase in Hong Kong will eat into Hong Kong Telecom's earnings this year.
"The investment program we have in Hong Kong would not be going on there unless we had confidence," said Mr. Owen, the group managing director for Cable and Wireless. But Hong Kong's future will still hang over the company and the stock for some time.
Finally, there is the fallout from recent government decisions about how the British telecommunications industry should be regulated. Analysts have generally concluded that the new regulatory approach gives breaks to both Cable and Wireless and British Telecommunications. But how they sort out to the bottom line in the next few years is still being debated.
Negative interpretations, like that of Partick Wellington of County Natwest Securities in London, emphasize that new costs Cable and Wireless could incur for access to the B.T. network and the price restructuring that will enable B.T. to lower prices to business customers could hurt the company. Postive views, like that of Michael Armitage of Morgan Stanley & Company in London, conclude that what is good for B.T. is good for Cable and Wireless.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
A Bank With Roots Deep in the South

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
When John G. Medlin Jr., chairman of the Wachovia Corporation, boasts of making money the old-fashioned way, he means it. One of the South's most venerable banks, it is also one of the nation's most profitable, because of a conservative strategy of prudent lending and rational growth.
In keeping with that strategy, Wachovia announced last week that it was acquiring the South Carolina National Corporation in a $835 million stock swap. This will give Wachovia, which has operations in Georgia and North Carolina, a new base in South Carolina and a strong presence throughout the Southeast. The combined company will be the nation's 18th largest bank, with assets of nearly $33 billion. 
 "The states of South Carolina, North Carolina and Georgia represent the economic and geographic heartland of the Southeast," said Mr. Medlin, who is 57 years old. "They've got a very solid anchor and that gives us financial strength and business diversity unsurpassed by any other banking company in the Southeast."
Like Mr. Medlin, a native North Carolinian who has spent his entire career at Wachovia, the bank franchise that he built has its roots deep in Southern soil. In 1985, a few months after interstate banking was permitted, Wachovia (pronounced WALK-ova-ya) acquired First National Bank of Atlanta, which like Wachovia was founded during the Reconstruction. South Carolina National, founded in 1834, predates the Civil War and survived Sherman's advance by moving its gold reserves around from Columbia to Charleston to Greenville.
Wachovia, the nation's 12th most profitable bank, avoided the lending spree of the 1980's by making conservative loans close to home. Nearly 40 percent of its assets are consumer loans. Of the 60 percent that are commercial loans, only about a quarter are to borrowers outside Georgia and North Carolina.
Real estate loans, which are causing so much trouble at other banks, represent only 15 percent of Wachovia's portfolio.
"Wachovia is well rooted in what it does and doesn't get caught up in fads," said Henry Coffey, an analyst with J. C. Bradford in Nashville. "They walk the middle ground. It's part of a very old culture."
Mr. Medlin is not worried about the possiblity of a merger between Wachovia's leading North Carolina rival, the NCNB Corporation, and the C&S/ Sovran Financial Corporation -- even though such a union would create the second-largest banking company in the United States.
"We'll stick to our own more patient gradual strategy," he said. "Besides, we're still plenty big to be competitive against banks of all sizes."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/June 23-28

 BODY:
THE ECONOMNY
 
Congress Finds It's Easier to Criticize on Savings and Loan Bailout 

Last week, when Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady asked Congress for $80 billion more for the savings and loan bailout, he couldn't have played to a worse crowd. First he was criticized about Administration estimates of the bailout's cost. Too optimistic, Congress said. Then he was accused of playing politics with the taxpayers money. And when he made a proposal of his own -- to remove the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation from day-to-day management of the bailout -- Congress was receptive, but only so-so. "Members of Congress are starting to feel some heat over the bailout," said Norman Ornstein, an analyst at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington. "Though Brady is not disliked, he isn't generating any deep respect." While Congress may be feeling heat, no members have taken the risk of devising their own plan. "Congress is still trying to roil the waters. It wants to focus attention on what's gone wrong," he said.
 
Honda, North of the Border
 
The Honda Motor Company builds some of America's best-selling cars in Canada. The trouble is, says the Customs Service, Honda might not be building enough of each car there to qualify for duty-free status. One car in particular is a problem -- the Civic. For it to escape a 2.5 percent tariff, at least 50 percent of its parts must be made in the United States or Canada. The Customs Service contends that Japan supplies more than half of the Civic's parts. Honda may owe as much as $20 million in back payments. Not so, says Honda. The company has dispatched its lawyers to Washington, parts invoices in hand. Now Congress has jumped into the dispute. Some members are asking for tougher "rules of origin" in the negotiations over with Mexico over a free-trade pact.
 
Making It Easier for TV Stations
 
If you think tough times for broadcast television are already here, you haven't seen anything yet. That was the message released last week in a report from the Federal Communications Commission. The F.C.C. predicts cable and other forms of pay TV will leave broadcast stations with a smaller, poorer, less desirable market. The networks -- which had 93 percent of prime-time viewers in 1975 and only 64 percent now -- will fare the worst. Commission Chairman Alfred C. Sikes is likely to use the report to try to relax rules governing how many broadcast stations a company can own. The cable owners did not like what they heard. They fear consolidation among the broadcast channels.
 
 The Slowest Recovery
 
The economy ran in reverse in the first quarter of the year. The gross national product contracted by a sharp 2.8 percent, according to the Commerce Department. That was worse than most economists expected. That all but defuses the short and shallow theory. Short perhaps, but probably not shallow. And corporate profits also took a tumble -- down 6.3 percent. "We hit bottom in April," said Ed Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence in New York. "And this will be one of the slowest recoveries on record." Why so slow? "The labor force is not growing; neither is productivity," he said. "Demographically there are not as many yuppies. And Americans bought 100 million cars in the 1980's."
 
Optimistic Indicators
 
The hope is that the nation's leading economic indicators really do point the way. According to the Commerce Department, the indicators rose by 0.8 percent in May, the fourth advance in a row. The indicators forecast economic events six to nine months in advance. "But the numbers still don't tell us the shape of the recovery," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities.
 
Unimpressed Markets
 
Orders for durable goods moved up a sprightly 3.8 percent in May. That was the second consecutive monthly gain and the biggest jump in more than a year, the Commerce Department said last week. So why weren't the markets smiling? "The figures say the upturn that has now started will be very slow," said Lawrence Chimerine, senior adviser to DRI Inc., an economic advising firm. "And some industries, like computers and machine tools, are still doing poorly," he said. Though an upturn is in sight, profits will still take time to recover.
 
Consumers Learn to Spend Again
 
Consumers are spending again. Go get the confetti. Consumer spending -- which accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity -- surged 1.1 percent in May, according to the Commerce Department. These statistics, coming after others that showed further increases in consumer confidence, were enough to get the White House to officially proclaim the end of the recession. "Unless something that we haven't forecast happens, it does look like the recession -- on a national basis -- has ended," said Michael Boskin, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Swiss Stock Up on Jet Fighters
 
Switzerland is ringed with jagged mountains and hasn't fought a war in 200 years. But you never know. So last week the Government's Federal Council said it would recommend purchase of 34 F/A-18 jet fighters to be produced by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in the United States and in Switzerland. The contract, which is expected to get Parliament's approval, is worth about $2.25 billion. With post-cold war cutbacks affecting every weapons maker, this sale is a very big deal.
 
Welcoming Gorbachev, Sort Of
 
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union will be meeting in London next month with the leaders of the world's richest nations -- the G-7. When he does, they will be handing him half an invitation. The Soviet Union can join the International Monetary Fund, they plan to say, but only as an associate. Associate status was dreamed up last week in London when the G-7's finance ministers met. An associate, they explained, is entitled to the fund's advice, but none of its money. To get the money the Soviet Union has to come up with a credible plan for creating a market economy -- something Moscow has been working on since 1985.
 
Nomura's Set of Rules
 
Yoshihisa Tabuchi, president and chief executive of the Nomura Securities Company in Tokyo, resigned last week. Nomura is the world's largest securities house. Nomura admitted that it had paid its best customers $120 million to compensate for losses. It also admitted it had provided $100 million in financing to Susumu Ishii, a well-known organized crime figure in Japan. The extent of the scandal, which involves three other firms, has observers wondering if Japan's markets operate by a different set of rules. It also has them wondering about Nomura's culture, which values deal-making above everything else. While Mr. Tabuchi is stepping aside, he is not stepping down. He will become vice chairman.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Gloom at Wells Fargo
 
Wells Fargo & Company, the nation's 10th-largest bank, has 53 percent of its loan portfolio invested in the slumping real estate market -- and that's the good news. Those borrowers continue to pay off their loans. More worrisome are the bank's commercial loans. Wells Fargo has had to put $400 million of those loans on a nonaccrual basis. Wells Fargo is expecting loan losses in the second quarter of $180 million, up from $67 million the quarter before. The bank also announced last week that it would be increasing its loan-loss reserves. The company's stock fell $6.50 to $74 on the news and finished the week at $69.
 
Boeing on a Roll
 
What recession? That must be the question asked most often in the halls of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company in Seattle. It has 110 aircraft on its order books and last week Lufthansa Leasing Group put in a request for 10 more planes worth $1.5 billion.
 
When Diversification Backfires
 
Glenfed Inc., the parent of the nation's third-largest savings and loan association, thought it had a winning strategy: diversify. So in the mid-1980's the Los Angeles-based savings and loan shifted heavily into real estate and commercial lending. Last week Glenfed said it expects $235 million in losses for the fiscal year, which ends today. The company is adding $255 million to its loan loss reserves. "The question is, Are Glenfed's actions enough and in time, and will California real estate markets cooperate?" said James M. Marks, analyst with SNL Securities in Charlottesville, Va.
 
The Apple, I.B.M. Two-Step
 
They are certainly one of corporate America's odder couples -- Apple and I.B.M. Yet the International Business Machines Corporation and the Apple Computer Company -- the nations two biggest PC makers -- are trying to work through their differences. I.B.M. has a hot new chip -- the RS/6000 -- it would like Apple to use. In return it wants some of Apple's snazzy, easy-to-use software. If the two companies do learn to dance, they may prove to be powerful allies against a consortium of computer companies that includes Microsoft, Digital Equipment and Compaq Computer. The consortium is trying set new software standards. But Apple worries that the RS/ 6000 chip will prove too expensive. And it worries about culture. When 150 buttoned-down I.B.M.-ers descended on laid-back Cupertino, Calif., Apple's managers blanched. The talks are stalled.

Ambition Rules at NCNB
 
You might say Hugh L. McColl Jr., chairman of the NCNB Corporation, is a man with ambition. Ten years ago his little North Carolina National Bank had just $7 billion in assets. Now, if the proposed merger with the C&S/ Sovran Financial Corporation goes through, NCNB will be the second-biggest bank holding company in the country. The deal -- for about $4 billion in stock -- will give NCNB about $116 billion in assets. Its operations would stretch from Baltimore, through much of the South, to Texas. The deal "is potentially a catalytic event for the banking industry," said James J. McDermott Jr., of Keefe, Bruyette Woods Inc., a research firm in New York.

HEADLINE: All About/Commercial Radio;
Too Many Stations, Too Few Buyers and Depressed Prices

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

 BODY:
These are dog days for commercial radio and not just because the recession has hurt advertising. For starters, the radio dial has become far more congested in recent years because the Federal Communications Commission has approved well over a thousand new stations since the early 1980's in efforts to foster competition. The result: more broadcasters chasing the same advertising dollars, sometimes amid increased interference.
How bad are things? Advertising revenues last year were about $8.84 billion, virtually unchanged from the year before, according to the Radio Advertising Bureau, an industry group in New York. And the F.C.C. recently reported that 197 AM stations and 30 FM stations have simply chosen to go off the air, because they could not meet expenses or find anybody to buy their licenses. In the past, analysts say, it has been very rare indeed for stations to "go dark." 
 Even when buyers have been found, they are paying a lot less than they used to. By any measure, the prices commanded for radio properties have been plunging. In 1985, according to Paul Kagan Associates, a market research firm in Carmel, Calif., the average price for a combined AM/FM station was $4 million. In 1987, the price had climbed to $6.2 million amid a flurry of speculative buying. But last year, prices fell to an average of just $1.8 million and they show no signs of recovering.
The number of stations changing hands is also down. Sales have fallen off dramatically, from a high of just under 1,400 transactions in 1986 to a low of less than 1,000 last year. Sales activity for the first half of this year indicates that 1991 is likely to be even slower than last year was.

 
 
The Neathery Solution
Don't Buy a Station, Just Buy Its Airtime
 Robert F. Neathery is a small-business man in West Plains, Mo., population 10,000, where he has owned KWPM-AM and KSPQ-FM for an uneventful 45 years. But last October, Mr. Neathery ushered in a hot new trend in dealmaking.
The practice Mr. Neathery employed is called "time brokering." In these arrangements, a struggling station sells virtually all of its airtime to another station in the same market or in a market next door. The station that sells its time becomes what amounts to a robot transmitter.
Under the deal, Mr. Neathery's AM station obtained rights to almost all the airtime of a more powerful but struggling FM station, KGAR, in nearby Willow Springs. KGAR is owned by Mr. Neathery's grandson, Bret R. Neathery. KGAR now serves as a robot transmitter for KWPM for all but a few hours on Sunday mornings when KGAR broadcasts religious programs.
"Our sponsors love it, because they get more coverage," said the elder Mr. Neathery, adding that KGAR's FM signal holds up far better at night than his own weak AM signal. For its part, KGAR eliminates almost all of its regular operating expenses and receives payment for its airtime.
Given the many stations now in dire financial straits, such deals are beginning to pop up all over the country. "If these stations can't do this, they'll just go off the air," said the elder Mr. Neathery.
But critics contend that the practice threatens diversity, because it effectively guts long-standing Federal rules that bar a single person or company from owning more than one AM and one FM station in the same area.
"What we are starting to see is stations that are not so distressed and not so small taking advantage of these policies," said Andrew Jay Schwartzman, head of the Media Access Project, a public interest group in Washington. "One can easily see a situation where a single entity will be programming and selling advertising to most of the stations, if not every single station, in a medium-sized market."
The trend has also sparked concern on the part of Representative John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, who has questioned whether time-brokering permits illegal changes in control and whether the F.C.C. is even capable of preventing abuses.
Indeed, F.C.C. officials admit they don't even know how many such deals are in effect because they don't usually find out about them unless a rival station complains. But all agree time-brokering is flourishing.
In staff rulings thus far, the F.C.C. has cleared deals in Miami, Colorado Springs and Victoria, Texas. In addition, officials say they are weighing pacts on Long Island; in Austin, Texas; Nashville, Tenn.; Jackson, Miss., and Huntsville, Ala.

 
 
First Aid for AM
New Rules to Bolster The Hardest Hit
 Plagued by static and other interference, AM radio has been losing market share to the technically superior FM stations for decades. Attempts were made to introduce AM stereo in the late 1970's, but were largely unsuccessful because the industry was deeply divided on which technology to use. As a result, AM stereo never caught on. Today, AM is increasingly the province of talk shows and all-news radio. Music fares best when it is transmitted on the clearer FM signal.
But both the government and the industry are trying to promote a recovery. This fall, the F.C.C. is expected to adopt a host of new rules designed to reduce AM congestion and promote technical quality.
The most noticeable change is likely to be an expansion of the AM band. In an attempt to reduce clutter on the dial, the AM band is expected to be expanded from 1610 kilohertz to 1710. The government is also likely to offer a licensing preference to AM stations that now cause the most interference and would be willing to move to the new band. In moving, however, the AM station would have to meet stricter technical standards to reduce interference.
A second change would allow a station to buy and shut down another station in an adjacent community that is causing interference. Under current rules, station owners who stop broadcasting must turn in their licenses to the government, which then holds it until a buyer appears.
Finally, the National Broadcasting Association has also developed a new AM "super receiver" featuring a new approach to stereo reception. It can also pick up stations in the proposed new band of frequencies.
In addition, officials from the broadcasting association say, the super receiver features circuits for screening out interference from power lines, lights and other sources of electronic "noise." The new receivers are being built by Denon Inc., of Parsippany, N.J., and they are expected to be on the market sometime this year.

 
 
'Reality Checks'
Another Look at Ownership Limits
 Ever since the beginning, of broadcasting, Government rules have limited the number of radio and television stations a single entity can own. Intended to preserve diversity and localism in broadcasting, the rules currently limit an owner to a total of 12 AM stations, 12 FM stations and 12 television stations (one each per market). The rules were relaxed in 1984 from the previous limit of seven AM, FM and television stations.
The F.C.C. is now proposing to further relax the ownership limits, hoping to shore up the beleaguered industry. "In a rapidly changing marketplace, it makes sense to do periodic reality checks," said Alfred C. Sikes, chairman of the F.C.C.
But consumer groups and a number of key Democrats in Congress argue that the move would lead to fewer choices for listeners and harm local programming. Meanwhile, minority broadcasters contend the move would drive up prices of radio properties, making it impossible to "trade up" to bigger stations.
The F.C.C. has asked for comments on an array of new liberal formulas. Among them:
* Raising or eliminating ownership limits for AM stations, but keeping them for FM stations.
* Keeping the total cap on stations, but allowing owners to buy any combination of AM and FM stations.
* Excluding from the limits any stations with very low ratings or stations in markets that have at least 30 separately owned stations.
* Allowing a radio group to exceed a numerical cap on ownership as long as its combined share of the national audience stays below a designated percentage.
But these proposals, suggested in May, have already generated rumblings of opposition from Capitol Hill.
Representative Dingell has suggested that Mr. Sikes was promoting consolidation in the industry.
Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of the subcommittee overseeing communications, has made it clear that many lawmakers want to keep the existing rules in place.
But the real question may be different from the one posed by both supporters and critics: Does anyone want to own more stations? At present, no company owns both 12 AM and 12 FM outlets. Only three -- CBS Inc.; Great American Broadcasting Inc. in Cinncinati, Ohio, and Nationwide Communications Inc. in Columbus, Ohio -- have reached the limit of FM stations they can own.
 
 
DIGITAL BROADCASTING AHEAD

For many, there simply is no easy way to deal with digital audio broadcasting. This new technology makes it possible to broadcast music over the airwaves with the clarity of compact disks. Though digital sound is noticeably superior to the analog transmission systems now in use, the technology confronts broadcasters with a devilish diemma: Digital radio would require listeners to get new radios. As a result, broadcasters that switched to digital would inevitably lose most of their audience -- at least temporarily -- while new radios are purchased.
Beyond the trauma of the transition to digital, another issue frightens broadcasters: Direct satellite broadcasting of music in digital form. Satellite broadcasts could be recieved directly by digital radios, bypassing today's stations. Such a system has been proposed by a startup company, Satellite CD Radio of Washington.
The National Association of Broadcasters is convinced that digital radio will happen, so it has tried to get in front of the issue. The association endorsed a digital transmission system developed in Europe that requires an expansion of the current transmission band. The association proposed that the F.C.C. give all existing broadcasters the right to "homestead" in that new frequency.
But critics note several drawbacks in the association's proposal. For one, they say, it would consume too much of the radio spectrum. But it would also allow speculators to obtain potentially valuable digital licenses through the homestead clause simply by buying cheap, unprofitable AM stations now.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
What a More Powerful Pen-Based Computer Can Do

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
The NCR Corporation has introduced an intriguing pen-based "notepad" computer that is truly ahead of its time. The notebook-size NCR System 3125, operated by an electronic stylus rather than a keyboard, does not yet have any software, and it has not yet received approval from the Government agency that approves electronic devices. While NCR says the System 3125 will be ready in August, it may be many months before there are software applications to take advantage of the machine.
Even so, people who saw the prototype computer at the annual PC Expo trade show in New York City last week said it represents the beginning of a class of computers that are likely to be widely used by businesses in years ahead. Millions of people, from blue-collar workers to doctors, cannot use conventional portable computers because the keyboard is inconvenient when they are walking around on the job. 
 As a result, these workers often record information using a clipboard and a pencil, then re-enter the information into a computer later on. A store clerk takes inventory, an architect sketches a room, a police officer fills out an accident form, an insurance agent fills out an application, and so on. Clearly, these workers could benefit from the computer's power to store and retrieve information. As a result, NCR and dozens of other computer hardware and software companies are racing to develop computer systems that can read handwritten characters and link electronic forms to business data bases.
"The NCR 3125 is the thunder before the storm," said William Bluestein, who tracks the nascent pen-based computer market for Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. "This whole class of computers won't take hold until I.B.M. enters the market -- I.B.M. has spent a ton of money developing its own pen-based machine -- but still, NCR now has about a six-month head start." Although the decline in its market share has been widely noted, I.B.M. is still the dominant computer maker, and many people believe its participation is needed to legitimize the pen-based market. Big Blue says it plans to introduce its pen-based computer by the end of the year.
The only working pen-based notepad computer today is the Grid Systems Corporation's Gridpad. Grid officials said 10,000 Gridpads were sold last year and that the pace this year was "double that." Grid, a division of the Tandy Corporation based in Fremont, Calif., last week showed off its new version of the Gridpad, which differs from the original mainly in its use of an illuminated writing surface.
From a technical standpoint, the NCR machine is significantly more powerful than the Gridpad. The NCR 3125, which weighs slightly less than four pounds, is built around the Intel Corporation's i386 SL microprocessor, which is several generations ahead of the Gridpad's simple 8086 chip. While the Gridpad can "read" only upper-case, block-printed letters, the new NCR machine is apparently able to decipher upper- and lower-case letters with a high degree of accuracy. It cannot, however, recognize cursive writing -- let alone a doctor's handwriting. (The NCR machine uses a cordless stylus, unlike the tethered one used by Grid. At the rate that ink pens are lost, this could turn out to be an expensive liability.)
NCR's machine is also significantly more expensive than the Gridpad. A basic Gridpad costs about $2,500, and the basic NCR 3125 will cost around $4,700, company officials said. The price, NCR officials said, includes the buyer's choice of either the Penpoint operating system being developed by the Go Corporation of Foster City, Calif., or the Windows for Pen Computing operating system being developed by the Microsoft Corporation of Redmond, Wash.
Equipped with enhancements, like a modem, hard drive and software, the machine could cost as much as $6,000. "Six grand is a lot to spend to outfit a field technician," said Mr. Bluestein of Forrester Research.
 Alan Lefkof, Grid's president, said the Gridpad is an "electronic clipboard," while the new NCR machine is of an emerging breed he called a "personal productivity tablet." He said Grid planned to introduce its own personal productivity tablet sometime next year, "probably in the same price range as NCR's."
The difference between the two types of pen-based machines, he said, is that electronic clipboards are designed for a blue-collar work force that deals primarily with forms. Such workers typically have no need to run a spreadsheet, for example. The personal productivity tablets, Mr. Lefkof said, are designed for white-collar executives who need the power of a PC to manipulate data in more sophisticated ways.
The true power of these executive notepad systems will become apparent in a year or two when new types of applications, designed specifically for pen-based computers, emerge. "Some day an architect will plug an infrared measuring scanner into the computer, stand at one wall, and the exact room measurements will be captured and converted into a room diagram that can be saved as a standard CAD file," said Ralph A. Phraner, chief executive of the Stylos Development Corporation, citing one example of how pen-based computers might be useful in computer-aided design. "It significantly cuts down on labor, and reduces three site visits to one."
Other likely uses will be the ability to respond to electronic mail with handwritten notes; the ability to send and receive facsimile documents with signatures, sketches and diagrams; calendar and scheduling software, and many features for traveling sales representatives.
Such interesting applications will come about only after some very hard work by software developers in the months and years ahead, of course. And the biggest issue for these software developers is which operating system software to embrace.
 Go, a private company, is believed to be the front-runner with its Penpoint software, scheduled for delivery later this year and already endorsed by I.B.M. Penpoint is a completely new operating system designed for pen computers.
Go's chief rival (seemingly everybody's chief rival these days) is Microsoft, the software giant. Microsoft has vowed to release Windows for Pen Computers before the end of the year, and it has been waging an aggressive campaign to woo software developers. Windows for Pen Computers is an added layer of operating system atop Windows and DOS. Its advantage is that it will work with existing Windows programs as well as any new ones written specifically for pen computers.
Hardware vendors are being circumspect. NCR officials said they would offer both systems and let the customers decide. "The level of diplomacy would make the United Nations proud," Mr. Bluestein said.

HEADLINE: Studying Business? Why Stick to Just One Continent?

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: FONTAINEBLEAU, France

 BODY:
Marieke Bax, a 30-year-old Dutch M.B.A. student, said it would have been foolish to attend a Dutch business school when there are institutions like Insead nestled here in a famous forest 40 miles south of Paris.
"I'm Dutch so I didn't want to go to a Dutch business school," she said. "I wanted to go to a school with an international flavor." 
 She came to the right place: the 460 students studying for a master's degree in business administration at Insead come from 30 countries, with French students comprising just one-sixth the student body. Like other business schools, Insead has study groups in which students work together, but the six students in each group often come from six different nations. What is more, those attending Insead, whose formal name is the Institut Europeen d'Administration des Affaires, have to know three languages to graduate.
After decades of imitating American business schools, Insead's professors say that with the world economy becoming more global, it is time that American schools start copying Insead's international brand of education.
Indeed, officials at Insead -- and at Europe's other truly international business school, the International Institute for Management Development in Lausanne, Switzerland -- contend that they, rather than America's top M.B.A. institutions, should serve as the model for the business school of tomorrow. The two schools, in fact, are so hot that they are spawning imitators around Europe, and American students, in search of an international business education, are flocking to them in record numbers.
"American schools teach international business as a subject," said Daniel Muzyka, a Boston native who teaches entrepreneurship at Insead. "At Insead, it's integrated throughout the curriculum. At Insead, it's the reason for being. The fact that the U.S. is no longer the sole driving engine of the world economy has created more need for a transnational focus."
Officials at the European schools argue that American business schools focus too narrowly on their domestic market at a time when business is becoming far more international, managers are jumping from country to country more than ever before and the United States needs to export more.
"When I go to the U.S., I'm amazed at how little the people who teach mainstream business school courses know about what's going on outside the U.S.," said Kamran Kashani, a marketing professor at the Lausanne school, known as I.M.D. "Many American schools treat international as an elective, and that is a statement about what they think is necessary and what they think is a luxury."
In ways, American business schools have focused naturally on their home country because it is the world's leading industrial power and commercial market. Even so, officials at these schools say that they are becoming more international-minded, introducing more courses on international subjects and taking in more foreign students and faculty.
Over the last two years, Harvard, for instance, has not only increased the number of international cases and courses in its curriculum but also raised the proportion of foreign students to 25 percent from 16 percent of its M.B.A. candidates. Harvard business students now come from 50 countries, but 75 percent of the 1,600 M.B.A. candidates are American. In comparison, I.M.D.'s 65 students come from 30 countries, with no single country representing more than 12 percent of the student body.
"Any business school in the United States can claim that it has many nationalities," said Francis Bidault, director of the M.B.A. program at I.M.D. "But the American schools are dominated by students and faculty coming from one country."
Maybe so, but as some critics like to point out, the European schools are dominated by students from Europe, and thus are pan-European but not truly international. "All of us need to be thinking more in international terms than in continental terms," said Thomas R. Piper, senior associate dean at the Harvard Business School. Insead and I.M.D. have also been criticized for placing heavy emphasis on programs for corporate executives -- a focus that has caused some critics to call them more training schools than academic institutions.
Still, Insead and I.M.D. graduates have become hot commodities as European companies, spurred by plans to scrap internal trade barriers in 1992, jockey to become pan-European and even global. Last year's I.M.D. graduates landed salaries of $74,000 on average, school officials say, substantially above the $63,000 that new Harvard Business School graduates earned. Insead graduates who went to work in the United States earned $64,000 on average. (School officials explain that they compute country-by-country averages, but no overall average because currency fluctuations create distortions.)
One reason for the higher salaries is that I.M.D. and Insead students are generally older and have more work experience than Harvard students. The average age of students at Insead is 28, and at I.M.D. it is 30.
Because their students are older and do not want to take two years off from their climb up the corporate ladder, the European schools usually offer shorter programs than American business schools. Insead's M.B.A. program is 10 months long and I.M.D.'s 11 months. "It's hard to teach management to people who don't have experience in business," said Ludo Van der Heyden, a Belgian who is co-deab if Insead.
One index of how "in" international business schools are is the record number of Americans seeking European M.B.A.'s. "An international education will be an advantage to us in the salary we receive and the types of jobs we're offered," said George Halow, a 29-year-old American at Insead.
Another indication is that even German companies, which have traditionally shunned M.B.A's in favor of in-house training, are hungry to hire graduates of the two schools. Markus Kirchgeorg, a recruiter for Siemens A.G., which interviews 50 people each year at Insead, said, "We need people who have international perspectives, people who think, 'Europe, U.S. and Japan.' For that, an M.B.A. background is very helpful."
As business internationalizes and as more young Europeans clamor to obtain M.B.A's, other European business schools are rushing to imitate I.M.D. and Insead. The London Business School has rapidly increased its international enrollment, so that 60 percent of its full-time M.B.A. students are non-British. In Barcelona, at the Instituto de Estudios Superiores de la Empresa, part of the program is now in English and 40 percent of the students come from outside Spain.
The students who go to I.M.D. and Insead say they cannot help but learn about the cultures and business practices of dozens of other nations. Insead's 79-member faculty comes from 22 countries and teaches many cross-border cases, such as the difficulties Electrolux, the Swedish appliance manufacturer, had in acquiring and absorbing Zanussi, an Italian appliance maker.
And when a study group throws Japanese, Swedish, Italian, Brazilian, French and American students together, they have to learn how to work with people different from themselves. Much of their grade is based on group projects. One American student talked about how difficult it was working with Lebanese and French student group members whose notions of teamwork are so different from American notions.
"You acquire skills that enable you to get all these people working together, despite national differences," said Holt Thrasher, an American student at I.M.D. Or as Dominique Heau, Insead's director of executive education, put it, "Vive la difference is what internationalism is all about."
Insead's policy is to structure study groups to encourage clashes. "We try to make it hard at first," said Arnoud De Meyer, head of Insead's M.B.A. program. "In their future work, they'll confront people they don't like. You have to learn to work with a variety of people."
These international schools are not trying to become a melting pot where students become like each other; instead, they are teaching students to understand differences. At I.M.D., one study group was assigned projects on the business climate in Brazil and on the worldwide paper recycling industry.
"We're not producing homogenized global managers," said Chris Parker, an organizational behavior professor at I.M.D. "We're producing graduates who appreciate the differences between people and why they act the way they do."
As an example of how crucial it is to appreciate differences, I.M.D.'s dean, Juan Rada, cited the way Americans and Japanese executives treat gifts. In the United States, if a company gives a gift to a subcontractor, it might be treated as a bribe; in Japan it would generally be seen as legitimate. The students also examine the short-term focus of American business, the long-term focus in Japan, the in-between approach of the Europeans -- and the pros and cons of those approaches.
"As far as we're concerned, the world is getting bigger, not smaller," said Mr. Rada, who is Chilean. "Until two years ago, we didn't have to know how management worked in Hungary, Romania, Russia and Moldavia. Now we do."
Insead and I.M.D. officials say they place less emphasis on imparting knowledge to their students and more on training people how to apply all the information they have. "The American schools probably go more in-depth in various fields," said Mr. Bidault of the I.M.D. "Our students don't know the latest techniques of finance. We train them to be able to integrate the various dimensions of a problem."
 
 
 
ELDER TRAINING IN EUROPE
 Internationalism is not the only thing that sets Insead apart from American business schools. It also places far more emphasis on educating existing, not just budding, executives. Its 460 M.B.A. students each year are joined by 2,500 executives who spend one week to seven weeks on campus. Executive education is even more dominant at the International Institute for Management Development in Lausanne, which educates 65 M.B.A. students each year and 2,500 corporate executives.
Corporations helped found the two schools, and that largely explains their focus on executive education. Insead was established in 1959 after corporations decided that more business education was needed to help companies cope with the new rules of business resulting from the formation of the European Community. The two schools that merged in 1989 to form I.M.D. were established as executive training schools for Nestle and Alcan.
"We discovered that the real need of Europe was not necessarily the M.B.A., but executive education," said Claude Rameau, co-dean of Insead.
Another factor that has pushed these schools to pay attention to executive education is that they are not attached to universities and have minuscule endowments.
Professors at the two schools say that teaching executives makes them keep their lessons relevant and helps them stay plugged into the latest developments in business. "Our research and teaching has to be oriented toward adding value on Monday morning," said Kamran Kashani, an I.M.D. marketing professor.
Some American professors accuse I.M.D., and to a lesser degree Insead, for being so involved with executive education and being relevant that their research gets short shrift and is often short-sighted. The Europeans respond that research at many American schools is so abstract that it is irrelevant to the needs of business. Even so, both European schools have beefed up their research budgets.
