HEADLINE: Cuba vs. Pan Am Games: And the Winner Is?

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COJIMAR, Cuba

 BODY:
Seven days a week, often late into the night, workers can be seen ferrying truckloads of earth, welding steel beams and laying tiles at the huge seaside athletic complex here that is being rushed into readiness.
Despite being strapped with what the Government has called the worst economic crisis since the seizure of power by Fidel Castro in 1959, Cuba has staked its prestige on the successful hosting of the Pan American Games and with less than five weeks to go before their start is engaged in a frantic and costly race to complete their preparation. 
 Mr. Castro has repeatedly called the games a "sacred commitment that we must honor," vowing that nothing will be allowed to tarnish the country's image. But for many Cubans who must ride bicycles to work through the summer rains because of a lack of public transportation and wash with plain water for lack of soap, the construction of 27 new sports-related installations in the Havana area alone speaks of the Government's insensitivity to more pressing popular concerns.
On the streets of Havana, where long lines of citizens awaiting rationed food can be seen throughout the day, the investment in the games has become the subject of wry jokes. "We want the Pan Americans all right," said one university student. "We want pan," or bread, "and the Americans."
Although the bulk of the new arenas are largely complete, much finishing work remains, and the down-to-the-wire approach has led many to question whether the kinks can be worked out by the opening festivities on Aug. 2.
 
8,000 Workers on the Project
 The rush has been particularly grating for the 8,000 workers employed in the project, who foreign diplomats say have been regularly subjected to directives from Communist Party officials and bureaucrats who descend on the worksites to decree alarmingly imminent deadlines for various facets of the construction.
Diplomats said that the pressures on the workers have led to angry confrontations, with workers rejecting some targets as unrealistic and denouncing the authorities for leading privileged lives in comfortable Havana suburbs while they sweat out 12-hour days in the hot sun with an unappealing supply of rations.
During a guided tour for journalists at one construction site, workers heatedly refused the instructions of one official to clear away debris strewn in a pathway so that journalists could proceed. Returning angrily to the limousine, the official said the obstruction had been created deliberately to keep visitors away.
Cuban officials acknowledge the pressures on workers involved in the project are great, but say the games are a source of immense national pride. Moreover, they say, workers involved in many of the construction projects belong to "micro-brigades," or special construction crews introduced two decades ago who, unlike most Cuban workers, have material incentives for productivity. Many of the 1,403 apartments built to host the expected 5,200 athletes, for example, will later be occupied by these workers.
 
No Details on the Cost
 Even as they decline to provide details on their cost, saying only that it amounts to no more than 1 percent of the country's budget, senior party officials have strenuously defended the decision to proceed with plans to host the games.
"We hope to celebrate games that don't distinguish themselves by their luxuriousness, but by their efficiency and seriousness," said Jose Ramon Fernandez, vice president of Cuba's Council of Ministers, who dismissed reports that the construction projects had cost as much as $500 million.
"We began building these facilities in 1986, when no one could have predicted the changes that took place in Eastern Europe in 1989," Mr. Fernandez added, referring to the collapse of Communist governments that had been important economic partners for Havana. "When that happened, we were half way through with this effort, but went ahead because these were facilities that had to be built sooner or later anyway."

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Frank Lynn

 BODY:

Giuliani Maneuverings
Rudolph W. Giuliani, who prematurely announced his 1993 mayoral candidacy to a gossip columnist at a cocktail party and then backtracked on his statement last week, is nevertheless laying the groundwork for a City Hall run by taking sides in an unusual struggle for control of the comatose Brooklyn Republican organization. 
 The fight is essentially a rehash of the Giuliani/Ronald Lauder battle for the Republican mayoral nomination in 1989 with Mr. Giuliani backing William DiMaria, a mayoral campaign supporter, for the G.O.P. county leadership against Robert DiCarlo, who was a Lauder staff aide. Among Mr. DiMaria's backers is Gerry O'Brien, who started out as Herbert London's mayoral campaign manager and then switched camps to support Mr. Giuliani.
The incumbent Brooklyn Republican leader, Alfred S. Pantaleone, who is also deputy executive director of the Board of Elections, either jumped or was pushed not to seek re-election after 10 years in office. He said he was "tired" and was not taking sides. But he opposes Mr. DiMaria as a "rule or ruin" Republican. Mr. Pantaleone had backed Mr. Lauder for the Republican mayoral nomination.
Mr. Giuliani said that Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island and his daughter, Representative Susan Molinari, a Staten Island Republican whose district also includes the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, are also supporting Mr. DiMaria.
As for Mr. Giuliani's "announcement" of a mayoral candidacy to Cindy Adams of The New York Post, he tried to laugh it off. "I thought I was having a friendly conversation; I was thinking it was a year from now," he said while acknowledging that a mayoral candidacy is "something I would very much like to do."
The former Federal prosecutor doesn't completely rule out a run for the United States Senate next year, but his friends do -- barring an indictment of the Republican incumbent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who is under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for his role in obtaining Housing and Urban Development contracts for campaign contributors. Even Guiliani fans acknowledge that he would have a difficult time defeating Senator D'Amato in a Republican primary with its conservative electorate, and that he would have a tough time winning the general election without the Conservative Party, which rates him a liberal at heart, in part because of the ties he developed to the Liberal Party during his 1989 mayoral bid.
 
 Nuclear Fallout

The President pro tem of the Connecticut Senate, John B. Larson, a Democrat from East Hartford who considered running for governor last year and who was a strong critic of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s income-tax plan, has dramatically toned down his oratory in recent weeks.
One possible cause: nuclear waste.
Mr. Larson's district, near Hartford, includes all three sites selected earlier this month by an independent state panel as the final candidates for a low-level nuclear waste dump.
Mr. Larson, whose constituents are vocal and passionate in their opposition to the dump, sought a $500,000 appropriatione for a study of the site selection process. He needed Mr. Weicker's support to convene a separate mini-session to take up the waste study.
Mr. Larson, who had called the Governor's income tax "voodoo economics" only a few weeks ago, changed his tune to being "unconvinced" about the tax after meeting with the Governor.
On Friday, he was rewarded for his lowered decibels. The Governor signed the study bill in Mr. Larson's office.
 
 The Incumbent Edge

It pays -- literally and figuratively -- to be an incumbent member of Congress. Not only are 98 percent of incumbent members of Congress re-elected nationally, but incumbents also do much better than their challengers when they pass the campaign fund-raising basket.
In an analysis of fund-raising patterns in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the good-government group Public Citizen found that the gap has widened between the fund-raising success of incumbents and challengers in the last decade.
In New Jersey, incumbents in contested races in 1980 raised twice what their challengers were able to muster; in 1990, they raised eight times as much.
In Connecticut, challengers and incumbents raised roughly equal amounts in 1980, but by 1990, the gap there had also risen to eight to one.
In New York, incumbents and challengers also raised about the same amount of money in 1980, but by 1990, the numbers were nine to one in favor of the incumbents.
 
 Rinfret's Pulpit

Last year, Pierre A. Rinfret ran a disasterous Republican campaign for New York governor, but that has not stopped him from issuing periodic newsletters on the state of the state and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The latest lists lots of reasons why Mr. Cuomo "can never be president," including the fact that he never served in the military, didn't do that well last year against "two political amateurs and political unknowns" -- Mr. Rinfret and Herbert London, the state's economic problems, and Mr. Cuomo's "lack of experience in world politics."
Mr. Rinfret, 67 years old, said in a telephone interview that he is not interested in any future candidacies, that he is still active and successful at Rinfret Associates, a Manahattan financial consulting concern, and that he is trying to be non-partisan about the state and its problems. He noted that his next newsletter would discuss "why the Republican Party has failed New York." He sends out about 1,000 newsletters at his own expense to movers and shakers and is about to increase its circulation.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN YUGOSLAVIA;
For Yugoslav-Americans, Partisan Emotions and Worries Over the Bloodshed

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
When Croatian- and Slovenian-Americans met for a fish fry and dancing to ethnic music in a Chicago suburb Friday night, their monthly social gathering turned to serious talk of civil war looming in the Yugoslavian federation.
For many immigrants and descendants in the United States, the jubilation over the rebellion for independence in their native lands is now tempered by other emotions.
 
Opposition to the Breakaway
 They are worried by the violence that has erupted, fearful for the future and frustrated at Washington's failure to endorse the declarations of independence by the republics of Croatia and Slovenia. 
 "We celebrate their independence, and we are waiting for our Government to step in and stop the bloodshed," said John Bursa, a retired businessman who attended the fish fry at the Slovene Center in Cicero, Ill.
The divisions pulling apart the Yugoslav union after decades of ethnic, religious, linguistic, economic and political tension are being played out by their relatives in the United States.
Serbian-American groups expressed opposition to the breakaway movement and expressed fear that the United States would officially recognize Croatian and Slovenian sovereignty.
A lawyer and vice chairman of the Serbian Unity Council in Cleveland, Milosh Milenkovich, said his group was in daily communication with Yugoslav officials. He urged that "the unity of Yugoslavia be maintained" but conceded his own doubts, saying, "God knows how it can be retained."
 
Jammed Overseas Phone Lines
 Croatian and Slovenian groups were busy raising money, donating food and clothing, praying, demonstrating and lobbying. Some said they were prepared to return home and take up arms, if necessary.
"When it concerns my own people, I will fight," said Matt Mihaljiv, a Chicago developer from Croatia.
Most Croats and Slovenes expressed the belief that independence will ultimately triumph.
"The people will not go back" to the old system, said the Rev. Slavko Saldo at the Croatian Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan, where hundreds came for an emergency meeting and all-night vigil on Friday. "Independence is the will of our people. It would be slavery to go back."
 
Migration to Industrial Regions
 Anxiously monitoring news reports on the latest events, Yugoslav emigres and relatives have jammed overseas telephone lines for reassurance about the safety of family and friends. Peter Remec of Scarsdale, N.Y., a professor of international law at Fordham University, said it took two days to get a call through to his native Slovenia.
Hundreds of thousands of people from Yugoslavia live in the United States, and even more Americans have ancestors from there.
Their main migration was into the coal and steel regions of Pennsylvania and Ohio and on to Chicago. Gov. George Voinovich of Ohio is the son of a father born in Serbia and a mother born in Slovenia.
The biggest Yugoslavian concentration is in the Chicago region, with 150,000 Croats and Slovenes, according to estimates, and an equal number of Serbs. Cleveland has a total of about 200,000 residents from the three groups.
"I was very happy and overjoyed when Croatia declared its independence," said Lou Matesic, secretary of the Croatian Council of New York. But, concerned about the Yugoslav Army's attempts to crush the move to independence, he is now busy helping arrange a rally today at the United Nations.
 
Thousands of Calls to Washington
 Chicago's groups appear to have organized the most support for independence. Croats there say they have raised nearly $1 million since February, and last month they sent 500 boxes of donated food and clothing.
About 1,200 Croats and Slovenes rallied in Daley Plaza Friday, calling on Washington to reverse its policy. The groups said they made a thousand calls to Washington Thursday and Friday and are also sending letters, telegrams and faxes.
"The U.S. Government is the most powerful government in the world," said Corinne Leskovar, director of a Slovenian radio program in Chicago. "What they have done is betray these two young democracies. Our people are very, very upset -- I would use the words appalled or ashamed -- that the U.S. Government is supporting the Yugoslavian Communist Government."
Yugoslav-American organizations tend to follow the divisions of the old country.
"There was absolutely no relationship to begin with," said Mr. Milenkovich of the Serb group in Cleveland. "All three peoples lived in their own little enclaves."

HEADLINE: Toxic Pollution At Military Sites Is Posing a Crisis

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
On the eve of a vote for a second round of military base closings, the Defense Department is running into serious trouble selling or leasing installations already scheduled to be shut because of toxic contamination at the sites.
The military industry has produced the most toxic pollution in the country and virtually every military installation has been extensively contaminated by the hazardous byproducts of activities like repairing aircraft and making weapons and by the disregard of safe practices for disposing of waste. 
 Military officials estimate that it will cost more than $1 billion and take until the end of the decade to restore the environment at just the 86 bases selected in 1988 for closing.
 
Savings Will Be Erased
 Those costs will offset the $5.6 billion in savings over 20 years that the Government had hoped to gain from turning over the bases to private companies or communities.
And the problems affecting the initial round of closings, which were scheduled to be completed by 1995, are virtually certain to become issues with the second round of bases, which are to be selected on Sunday.
In addition to the expense, a thicket of legal and regulatory issues and the concern of potential buyers and managers that they may be liable for damage are emerging as significant barriers to the transfer of the installations and causing concern in the communities where they are situated.
 
'Disaster for My Community'
 "If we don't get these problems worked out, the base closure process will be a disaster for my community and 100 others," said Robert W. Holcomb, the Mayor of San Bernardino, Calif., where Norton Air Force Base is scheduled to be shut in 1994. "The base will sit fallow, a no man's land, with no opportunity for our people to find employment."
The intent of closing military bases was to save the Government the cost of operation and maintenance. The 1988 base closing commission also said the economic effect on communities would be minimized if the military hastened the process of transferring the properties for use in other enterprises.
Neither goal is being reached as the panel envisioned. The problem at Norton and at other installations is that the Government left a mess.
 
A Decades-Old Mess
 The problems were caused by more than four decades of environmental neglect. The haphazard disposal of toxic waste in lagoons, leaking undergroud storage tanks and dump sites caused acres of ground to become saturated with hazardous chemicals that also seeped into underground water supplies. Among the toxic constituents are heavy metals from electroplating, deisel and jet fuel, solvents and degreasing agents from operating machinery and chemical byproducts from munitions manufacturing.
The military services this week estimated that cleaning up more than 1,800 United States installations, including bases, depots, munitions plants and other military centers, would cost $30 billion and take at least a decade. Most experts say they believe it will take much longer than that.
The slow pace of the cleanup, though, is just one of the problems. Another is that Federal law prohibits the Pentagon from selling any property on bases until contamination on the entire site is cleaned up. The law also appears to cover leasing arrangements, say Pentagon lawyers. Thus, even if only 50 acres of a 5,000-acre base are contaminated, the Pentagon is unable to transfer the pristine property until the polluted land is restored.
In Portsmouth, N.H., executives and military authorities negotiating the transfer of Pease Air Force Base are encountering the statute's affect. Pease was the first base on the 1988 list to be closed, taking with it more than 4,000 military and civilian jobs.
 
Negotiating Is Hampered
 For months, state and community leaders, Portsmouth business leaders and a development agency have been negotiating with Deutsche Airbus, the German subsidiary of Airbus Industrie, which wants to use the base for maintenance operations that would employ more than 1,000 people. But the deal is being hampered by the prohibition against selling, and perhaps leasing, property until all of Pease is cleaned up, which would take years.
Roughly 100 of the base's 4,400 acres are contaminated with solvents, fuel and other toxic wastes. The Pentagon has spent more than $10 million investigating polluted sites on the base and tens of millions of dollars more will be needed for a full restoration.
The negotiations with Deutsche Airbus are at such a sensitive stage that members of the Pease Development Authority declined to answer a reporter's questions.
 
Effort to Clarify Law
 This week, Representatives John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, and Al Swift, Democrat of Washington, sent a letter to the Environmental Protection Agency asking Government lawyers for help in clarifying the law on selling contaminated property.
A Defense Department panel is studying the issue and changes in legislation may be proposed, said Kevin A. Doxey, director of the Pentagon's Defense Environmental Restoration Program Division. He said the panel would make its recommendations in November. "The Pease situation has brought the issue to the front burner," he said. "We're moving as fast and doing everything we can to respond to it."
Representative Richard Ray, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services environmental restoration panel, has proposed legislation to allow the Pentagon to sell or lease uncontaminated property.
"It's obvious that they ought not to sell a base that is so contaminated it's dangerous," Mr. Ray said. "But we also don't think a base ought to sit there year after year."
 
Reservations on Altering Law
 Other members of Congress have expressed reservations about changing the law for fear that it might reduce the pressure that communities and Congress could exert on the military to compel faster cleaning of contaminated bases.
The potential that managers and buyers could be liable for future legal, cleanup and health costs as a result of the Pentagon's pollution has emerged as another issue affecting the transfers of bases.
San Francisco, for example, is negotiating with the Navy for a lease that will allow the city to take control of the 550-acre Hunters Point Naval Station, one of the bases on the 1988 closings list. The shipyard, inactive since 1974, has potential to be used for housing, small businesses and other commercial activities.
Hunters Point also is thoroughly contaminated with metal working wastes, fuel, acids and asbestos. The Navy has spent nearly $30 million on cleanup work there and will spend millions of dollars more. San Francisco wants a guarantee from the Navy, or may seek Congressional action to exempt it from liabilities associated with the pollution.
 
Old Base Brings Company Problems
 In the rare instances where the military has succeeded in transferring property from a base it plans to close, companies are encountering a separate set of problems.
One of the first major companies to seek new opportunities on an old base was the Lockheed Corporations. In July 1990, the company formed a subsidiary to lease an old hangar at Norton Air Force Base to modify and maintain Boeing 747 jetliners.
But last summer Lockheed discovered toxic contamination beneath the concrete floor of the hangar. Lockheed needed to remove the floor anyway and replace it with one strong enough to support a 747. Lockheed gained the Air Force's permission to dig up three feet of soil, providing the company enough room to pour new concrete floors.
Days after the Air Force approval, though, the Environmental Protection Agency objected, saying the plan violated an agreement for cleaning up contamination. The agency required a more thorough plan, and a solution that would prevent the polluted soil from contaminate another site after it was dumped. The delays, contracts for an engineering company to design the program, construction and other activities added $6 million to the $40 million project, Lockheed officials said.
"It's been an unbelievable process, a nightmare really," said Richard Crail, vice president and general manager of Lockheed Commercial Aircraft Center. "Unless the rules change, I would be surprised if Lockheed pursues another operation on a closed base."

HEADLINE: In Step Toward Budget, California Assembly Backs Tax Increases

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 29

 BODY:
In a major breakthrough in long-stalled negotiations to close a $14.3 billion budget gap, the California Assembly passed large tax increases late Friday night and cut payments to families on welfare.
The actions, which include increases in sales and alcohol taxes and in motor-vehicle fees, still leave California $2 billion to $3 billion away from a balanced budget for the 1992 fiscal year, with a deadline of midnight Sunday. But Gov. Pete Wilson, who had faced a tax rebellion among fellow Republicans in the Assembly, said this afternoon that he was pleased by the actions and that he had received most of what he had asked for from the Democratic-controlled Legislature. 
 The Governor also indicated for the first time today that he might be ready to relent in his longstanding opposition to increasing personal income taxes.
 
Income Tax Surcharge

He and the Legislature have come under increasing pressure from the California Manufacturers Association and other business groups to impose a 5 percent surcharge in income taxes as a substitute for a 6 percent tax on telephone and cable television bills and increasing the tax on utility bills by 2 percentage points.
"I think the business community is saying it does not support personal income or utility taxes, but if it must take bitter medicine they are prepared to take the income tax," Mr. Wilson said at a brief news conference outside his office this afternoon. He added, "We are in a situation in which the Constitution requires a balanced budget."
As for his own position on the income tax, which would raise nearly $1.5 billion, the Governor said, "We have not determined what we'll do." He had previously ruled out any such tax as unhealthy for California's faltering economy.
 
Sunday Meeting
 Both the Assembly and the Senate are scheduled to meet Sunday evening to vote on the final elements of the $54.6 billion budget. and officials in both the Governor's office and the Legislature said they expected to resolve everything by midnight.
The final frenzy comes after weeks of intense arm-twisting, deal making and lobbying. The moderate Republican Governor's chief problem has been persuading Assembly members of his own party to accept the tax increases. The California Constitution requires a two-thirds majority vote on budget matters, and the Governor was able to bring along just enough Republicans to get the bare minimum of 54 votes needed in the 80-member Assembly last night.
The less fractious Senate passed most of the tax increases earlier.
The measures passed by the Assembly Friday night would:
*Raise the state sales tax by 1.25 percentage points, bringing it to 8.25 percent in Los Angeles and other major cities. Also, the tax would be extended to such previously exempted items as candy and snacks, bottled water, newspapers and magazines, and ship and jet fuel. These taxes are expected to raise about $4 billion and would go into effect July 15. The Governor has said $7.7 billion in new taxes will be needed.
*Cut welfare payments by 4.4 percent, or about $31 a month for a woman with two children, who currently receives $694 a month. Also, routine cost of living increases would be suspended for five years.
*Reduce the state's contributions to the California Public Employment Retirement System, or Calpers, as it is called, and use about $1.6 billion of earnings by the fund to help balance the general state budget over the next few years.
Governor Wilson had argued that the fund was too rich and generous and could get by with lower contributions from the state. The Governor drew national attention by proposing to take control of the Calpers board, which has been a thorn in the side of major corporations in which it holds stock.
Ultimately the Governor gave up that fight, but got the Assembly to require that an outside actuary, nominated by the Governor and confirmed by the Senate, determine the appropriate state contribution to the fund.
In addition, the Assembly voted to raise the fees to register vehicles beginning Aug. 1. For example, the fee would rise to $360 from $340 on a two-year-old car that cost $20,000 new. Also, the tax on a gallon of beer or wine would go to 20 cents from less than 4 cents and the tax on a gallon of liquor would go to $3.30 from $2.

HEADLINE: SMALL COMPROMISE ON CITY TAX PLAN

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration and the New York City Council took the first halting steps yesterday toward a budget compromise on increased taxes as both sides worked against a deadline of 12:01 A.M. tomorrow for the adoption of a recession-scarred city budget.
The movement came on a day of frenzied maneuvering at City Hall that featured angry demonstrations outside and nonstop meetings and lobbying inside, aimed at reversing the dismissals of thousands of city workers last week and searing cuts in basic city services. 
 The administration is struggling to close a gap totaling at least $3.5 billion between revenue and spending -- some officials have put it as high as $4 billion -- in the city's $29 billion budget, through a combination of service cuts, state aid, taxes and concessions from the city unions.
 
Unions and Council Intertwined
 But the talks between the Mayor and the Council, and the Mayor and the unions, have become deeply intertwined, with neither the union side nor the Council willing to show its hand until the other has reached an agreement.
Union leaders said yesterday that they were willing to make concessions in order to restore the jobs of some of the 6,300 workers laid off on Friday, but not until the outlines of the city's budget were made clear. They want to make sure that jobs saved now will not be lost in a few months, if the city's finances worsen.
"We are ready to make economic sacrifices," said Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. "But we have to know: in return for what? When we ask, they say 'in return for our thanks.' "
At the same time, a budget agreement yesterday between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the legislative leaders cleared the way for the city to receive state aid, variously estimated at $75 million to $200 million, that the city had been counting on to balance its budget.
If the complex effort falters, Mayor David N. Dinkins could lose control of the city's finances to a state oversight agency, the Financial Control Board -- a blow to the city's reputation and the Mayor's personal prestige that he has pledged to avoid.
"We are making progress on all fronts," Mr. Dinkins said as he returned to City Hall yesterday afternoon to monitor the parallel negotiations.
Governor Cuomo has scheduled a meeting of the seven-member control board for Tuesday to discuss the city's fiscal problems. Yesterday, he said both he and the control board would play a more active role in the city's affairs "with the Mayor and at the Mayor's request."
"We will be aggressively cooperating with the Mayor," Mr. Cuomo said. "The Financial Control Board should be aggressively cooperative without seeking control."
Mr. Dinkins had called for more than $1.1 billion in new taxes, to make up for declining tax receipts and increasing spending, but the Council, complaining the taxes would damage the city's economy, agreed to a far lower figure, $636 million.
 
Council's Own Budget a Threat
 When an angry stalemate ensued -- with the Mayor orchestrating a lobbying campaign against the Council -- the Council, acting under stronger budget powers granted in the new City Charter, drafted its own budget. Council negotiators had threatened to adopt it today if Mr. Dinkins did not agree to a compromise on taxes.
But in staff talks that began on Friday evening, continued into the early hours yesterday and resumed later in the day, negotiators for the Mayor indicated they could accept something less than the full tax package Mr. Dinkins had originally demanded.
The Council in turn said it was willing to consider a somewhat larger increase in property taxes, particularly if the unions made important concessions that would reduce the cost of government for many years.
As the talks reached critical issues late Friday, the Speaker of the Council, Peter F. Vallone, who had gone home earlier, returned to City Hall to join in the negotiations.
 
Still Far Apart, Official Says
 But one Council official who spoke on the condition of anonymity, because both sides had agreed to a news blackout, said that though the principle of compromise on taxes had been established, both sides remained far apart on a final number.
"I don't think we have arrived at a critical negotiating mass," said one Dinkins administration official. "If a bomb is ticking it is a soft tick."
The Council budget would restore $220 million of the most severe cuts requested by the administration and would increase the property tax by less than what the Mayor had wanted. It would pay for this by making another $300 million in cuts, using reserve funds and starting an early-retirement program for city workers.
Mayor Dinkins denounced the Council budget and said it was out of balance by hundreds of millions of dollars.
Under the City Charter, Mr. Dinkins has the power to reject spending that exceeds his estimate of available revenues and veto additional spending. Yesterday, Council officials stopped short of endorsing the Mayor's criticisms but said they were nonetheless making at least $50 million in additional cuts to eliminate some revenue figures Mr. Dinkins had said he might challenge.
 
Council Seeks Union Concessions
 Council officials said they hoped the additional cuts would put pressure on city unions to come up with concessions before the deadline for adoption of the budget.
The Dinkins administration, seeking up to $600 million in concessions from municipal unions, has given their leaders a list of options, including a roll-back in wage increases and a requirement that the union members pay much of their health-insurance costs.
Union leaders have been hoping to avert layoffs through stepped- up attrition, early-retirement programs, and a change in pension rules that would reduce the city's pension-fund contributions over the next few years.
But city officials have refused to consider any of those changes, which would not hurt individual workers, except as part of long-term cost-cutting concessions. The unions have discussed the concessions among themselves, but not in direct talks with the city, union officials said,
Yesterday Stanley Hill, executive director of the city's largest union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said he was optimistic that an agreement could be reached, but discounted the possibility that the unions would make deep concessions.
 
'Still Fighting to Save Jobs'
 "There is no done deal," he said after a speech at a union rally in lower Manhattan. "But we are still fighting to save jobs. We're considering things that will not do further harm to our members."
But last night, after a lengthy negotiating session, other union and city officials said they were increasingly pessimistic that an agreement on concessions could be reached before a budget was adopted. Those same officials, however, suggested the possibility that an agreement could be reached later in the week that would allow some laid-off workers to return to their jobs.
At City Hall yesterday, police officers manned the gates at both the Mayor's and the Council's sides of the building, keeping lobbyists out of a Council meeting room where members were caucusing on budget cuts.
The mood was informal, if serious, with Herbert E. Berman, the chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, appearing at negotiations in running shorts and shoes, without socks. Even Mayor Dinkins, who is usually seen in public in either fastidious double-breasted suits or baseball warmup jackets, showed up in a pin-cord sports jacket, with casual slacks.
But elsewhere in the city the mood was grim, as city workers who were laid off on Friday listened to the radio to find out whether an agreement was reached that might mean they would have their jobs back soon.

HEADLINE: Baseball;
Yankees Weigh the Costs Of Signing or Not Signing

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

 BODY:
Can the Yankees afford Brien Taylor? Can they afford to pronounce him too costly?
As the mother of the first choice in the baseball amateur draft waits for the Yankees to resume stalled negotiations, baseball executives watch to see if another organization will reaffirm the concept of paying more than $1 million to a recent high school graduate. 
 When the Yankees selected Taylor with their first No. 1 choice since Ron Blomberg in 1967, the organization expected a smooth and brief negotiation with the family of that most rare of baseball commodities -- a left-handed pitcher with a fastball measured as high as 98 miles an hour that a Yankee official volunteered was superior to Dwight Gooden's at a similar stage.
But the process considered simple less than four weeks ago has begun to show signs of becoming a nightmare scenario, a contest of wills the Yankee organization cannot afford to lose.
 
Haggling Wasn't in Plan
 Scott Boras, a California-based attorney with a reputation for aggressively demanding top value for his clients, became an adviser to the family. The $1.2 million agreement reached last summer between high school pitcher Todd Van Poppel and the Oakland Athletics -- with Boras as an adviser at first, and then a representative -- is considered by the Taylors to be the industry standard.
The Yankees maintain that the extraordinary circumstances leading to Van Poppel's contract do not apply to Taylor. Gene Michael, the vice president and general manager, said that the organization's offer was "significantly more" than the reported $345,000 the Atlanta Braves invested in Chipper Jones, a high school shortstop who became the top choice of the 1990 draft. Each side appears resolute in its principles -- the family in gaining what it considers market value; the team in preventing the type of economic spiral that symbolized the era of George Steinbrenner's control.
Michael, the general manager since last August, who also held the position during the 1980 season, faces the challenge of convincing a family from Beaufort, N.C., that a multimillion-dollar New York company, with cable television revenues unprecedented in the history of its industry, is not trying to take advantage of a 19-year-old.
 
No Acrimony but One Warning
 Nearly four weeks since the Yankees chose Taylor over Mike Kelly, an Arizona State outfielder who was the 1990 college player of the year, Michael and Taylor's mother, Bettie, who has represented the family in the talks, have not discussed terms face to face.
Boras has said that the negotiations have not been acrimonious, but he has communicated one warning from the family. According to the adviser, the Taylors have decided that if their son enrolls in a junior college in August, communications with the Yankees would end and they would wait until the 1992 draft.
If Taylor chooses that path, the Yankees would become only the third team in the 27-year history of the June draft to fail to sign the top selection. Their refusal to use the Van Poppel contract as a model, which Michael says is firm, is based on the events that led to the 1990 draft.
Van Poppel, a powerful right-handed pitcher, informed organizations before the draft that he intended to enroll at the University of Texas.
Oakland, using the 14th pick, offered a three-year contract, unprecedented for a high school player, and a $1.2 million package to convince the prospect to change his mind. Van Poppel has already advanced to the Class AA level, two steps from the majors, where he has a 4-7 record and 3.13 earned run average for the Huntsville Stars, a team with a winning percentage of just .382.
In addition to the size of the financial package, Michael was opposed to the procedural risks that an agreement similar to Van Poppel's could create. "That was a bad contract," he said, adding that the A's could eventually face the type of no-win decision with Van Poppel that the Yankees must avoid with Taylor: Advance the prospect to the major league roster before he is ready, or risk losing the pitcher and allowing another team to use a player that had been paid and developed with Yankee money.
"Someone else could reap the benefits," Michael said. "We have to be careful."
"That's so far from the truth," Boras said. The adviser said that Oakland would not risk exposing Van Poppel to the waiver list until 1994, after his fourth spring training with the club. If Taylor signed a similar contract, he would not be available for another organization to claim until 1995.
 
Cost Control
 "If he must clear waivers," Boras said, speaking of Van Poppel, "do you think another major league team is going to go out and claim him, and take him on their major league roster, and pay the salary the A's are paying him? If you believe in your talent assessment, you don't worry about these things, as the A's didn't. You don't draft a player No. 1 and say these things. Otherwise they should have taken Kelly."
 As baseball attempts to control its most recent economic growth spurt, with the understanding that its television revenue may be very different by the time Taylor reaches his prime, Coach Russ Frazier sits at Louisburg (N.C.) College. Frazier, who said the family has given him an oral commitment should Taylor attend college, waits to see if he'll be coaching the most celebrated pitcher of his 32 seasons.
"When people ask, I tell them I'm willing to go 50 bucks above the Yankees' offer," Frazier said, and chuckled.

HEADLINE: For the Nations of Eastern Europe, The U.S. Is More Symbol Than Model

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SECRETARY OF STATE James A. Baker 3d received two very different receptions in his visits to the Eastern European neighbors Yugoslavia and Albania last weekend. In Yugoslavia, his appeal to the leaders of Slovenia and Croatia not to secede fell on deaf ears and Mr. Baker was bluntly told that his advice was neither valued nor desired. A day later Mr. Baker went to Albania, where he was received by 300,000 Albanians who cheered his every utterance and made him an honorary citizen.
The contrasting receptions reflect America's paradoxical role in the world today. On the one hand, as the Albanians attested, America is still an incredibly powerful symbol of certain basic values -- freedom, democracy, self-determination and economic opportunity -- that tantalize the long-suppressed peoples of Eastern Europe. The Albanians who poured out to receive Mr. Baker did so with an almost religious fervor, armed with crudely made paper American flags and placards that were more passionate than grammatical: "Welcome Mr. Becker," said one, "Welcome Mr. Beaker," said another. They were never quite sure what his name was, but then it didn't really matter, because for them he was no more a person than the papier-mache Statue of Liberty that Chinese students erected two years ago in Tiananmen Square. 
 "America is a big myth here," said Ilir Ikonomi, an Albanian journalist. For four decades freedom is what Albanians wanted and under totalitarian Communism they could not have it. America represented that freedom and so when it showed up on the streets of Tirana for the first time in the form of James A. Baker 3d, Albanians celebrated it. A week before Mr. Baker arrived, the German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, also made his first visit to Albania. No Albanians came out to receive him, even though ultimately they will probably get more material aid from Bonn than from Washington. Germany symbolizes nothing for them. Only America has such emotive powers.
But what is both ironic and poignant is that when it comes to providing something more than a symbol, the United States falls short. It is at a loss to provide a blueprint for how these multinational Eastern European societies -- whether it is Yugoslavia or the Soviet Union -- can get from where they are now to the democratic destinations they profess to seek. "The Federalist Papers" do not translate well into Serbo-Croatian or Russian -- or Georgian, Lithuanian, Ukranian or Azerbaijani.
America's brand of federalism aims to forge one nation from people of diverse origins. That is not a realistic aim for multinational societies like the Soviet Union or Yugoslavia. For them, the challenge is to design political structures that can contain many nations -- who want to retain their separate national identities -- yet remain part of a single political and economic unit.
"The challenge confronted by the multinational states of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union is that they are at once too large and too small," said Michael J. Sandel, a Harvard political theorist. "If Slovenia or Azerbaijan want to break off, they are too small to compete economically in a global economy. After all, even France and Germany prefer to be members of a larger economic unit, the European Community. But Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union are also too large to give full expression to the national identities of their constituent communities. So economics is pulling them toward bigger units and culture is pulling them toward smaller units."
That is not the only problem. As events in both Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union so dramatically demonstrate, when democratic reforms are suddenly loosed on these previously repressed multinational societies the risk is that what will emerge first and foremost are intense forms of nationalism: not secular, pluralistic Jeffersonian democrats, but rather Serbian, Armenian, Croatian, Russian and Albanian nationalists.
Precisely because nationalism can turn ugly and undemocratic and trample on individual rights, Mr. Sandel said, central governments in these countries not only have to be loose enough to allow national self-expression, but also strong enough to protect minority rights -- much the way the Federal judiciary in the United States, invoking the Constitution, steps in to preserve civil rights from abuses by states and localities. Central authorities will be needed to protect the Serbian minority in Croatia, or the Armenian minority in Azerbaijan, and minorities everywhere else in the ethnic patchwork of Eastern Europe.
The challenge of politics then in these countries, and in some ways for American foreign policy, is to design federal arrangements that would help these societies manage these conflicting impulses while holding together. But it will require a kind of federalism not yet invented.
 
One Democracy's Glue
 "We often forget how unique is our experience," said the historian Daniel J. Boorstin. "In America you become a democrat simply by crossing the ocean and becoming part of the American community. It's easy. At the same time, we have developed a series of institutions and traditions that help us keep in balance our sense of community and quest for independence. Everything from baseball to technology to television help overshadow our separate family genealogies, reinforce our sense of common history and keep alive what Lincoln called 'the mystic chords of memory that remind us of the better angel in each of us.' But the Soviets or Yugoslavs cannot become democrats by simply dropping a few phrases. You need the right institutions."
That is not the only reason, though, why America will have a hard time being helpful. America itself is torn between conflicting impulses when it looks on the Albanias and Yugoslavias. The United States has been both a force for order and an agent of change in the world, both a seditious revolutionary and a policeman. Mr. Baker loved being celebrated as the symbol of liberation in a place like Albania, and he urged the crowd on, but the same man recoiled in horror when he saw freedom giving rebirth to dark tribal nationalisms in Yugoslavia.
As the political scientist Robert W. Tucker has written, America favors "freedom of nations" but often has problems dealing with "freedom in nations" when it leads to self-determination for smaller and smaller groups. That becomes a threat to the international order. But where should the line be drawn? Why do the Latvians deserve American support for an independent state and not the Croats? Why the Estonians and not the Slovenians? These are tough calls that are only going to get tougher in the coming years.

HEADLINE: The World;
How Tito's Heirs Made A Mess of Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
YUGOSLAVIA'S latest agony its third in this century after the deaths of more than one million citizens in each of the two world wars -- is traceable in many respects to one man: Josip Broz Tito.
It was Tito who in 1971 cut down the bright younger politicians -- men and women -- who might have led the country on a more liberal path nearly two decades ahead of the overthrow of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe. 
 It was Tito who created the cumbersome and ultimately unworkable 84-page constitution of 1974 on which the Yugoslav ship of state is currently foundering.
Tito died in 1980 at 87, having ruled Yugoslavia for 36 years as a kind of Communist king with all the royal trappings except a mace and a crown. He designated no successor, leaving the country to a manifold dynasty of lesser Communist officials in Belgrade and the republican capitals. With few exceptions they were men stunted by the suffocating atmosphere of a one-party state.
With few exceptions these children of Tito are also directly responsible for the mess confronting the 24 million people of Yugoslavia today. They are the ones who held on to the Communist Party structure until it fell apart in 1990 -- well after the Communists had been thrown out in all of Eastern Europe except Albania. They are the ones who have retained the vast bureaucracies and habits of the Marxist-Leninist-Stalinist-Titoist system even after more or less democratic elections were held in each of the six republics.
This is not to say that all of Tito's heirs have behaved badly. The Bush Administration, European governments and many Yugoslavs agree that Prime Minister Ante Markovic, 66, has done his utmost to hold the country together while accommodating the outrageous behavior, including the wholesale theft of Government funds, of colleagues . Others widely credited with having conducted themselves maturely in the crisis are Macedonia's Kiro Gligorov and Vasil Tupurkovski and Bosnia-Hercegovina's Alija Izetbegovic. Of these only Mr. Izetbegovic was not a Communist.
But Mr. Markovic and these allies have not been able to muster sufficient strength to overcome the separatist demands of the leaders of Croatia and Slovenia or the hegemonistic designs of the leaders of Serbia.
The principal antagonists among Tito's children are Serbia's President Slobodan Milosevic, 49; Croatia's President Franjo Tudjman, 69; and Slovenia's Milan Kucan, 50. For all the antagonism between Mr. Milosevic and the other two, these men have much in common.
All three were members of the former Communist Party. Since they were affirmed in power in republican elections last year, all three have exhibited authoritarian tendencies, maintaining heavyhanded control of the newspapers and television stations in their capitals -- excluding news and views from parts of Yugoslavia that they deem hostile. All three have raised and equipped private armies. None has dismantled the ponderous government bureaucracies or the overstaffed factory managements inherited from the Communist era.
Mr. Tudjman, who reached the rank of general in Tito's army of Partisans, has even instituted an honor guard with splashy uniforms that could be worn in a performance of a 19th century operetta.
In short, while chosen in relatively democratic elections, none of these three republican presidents could remotely be called a democrat.
All of that might matter less if these men had not indulged themselves in the most jingoist kind of nationalisms -- a cardinal sin for Communists as they well know, and a lethal malady for anyone in the ethnic stewpot that is the Balkans.
This indulgence has had bloody consequences: : 29 Serbs and Croats killed in communal violence in the last six months; perhaps as many as 100 people killed in last week's clashes in Slovenia; and more than 90 ethnic Albanians shot by militiamen in the troubled Serbian province of Kosovo.
The motive of Tito's children for promoting radical Serbian, Croatian and Slovenian nationalism? One can only conclude Messrs. Milosevic, Tudjman and Kucan have chosen this as a sure means of holding on to power inside the confines of their republican borders.
But you cannot eat nationalism. Nor does it fuel automobiles or produce electric power. Yugoslavia's economy, which could be booming, faces disaster. Production has dropped 50 percent. There is little or no money to pay wages in any of the republics. All because of the political struggle.
Is there any hope?
Yugoslavia could still implode into the kind of civil war that left one million dead in the period 1941-45. Or, it could fall apart in order to reconstitute itself along the lines of a compromise drafted only three weeks ago by the republics Macedonia and Bosnia-Hercegovina . Under this plan, each republic could retain a measure of sovereignty while a central government controlled finance and defense.
But whether this can be achieved by leaders whose idea of politics is a combination of narrow nationalism and authoritarian practices is questionable, if not doubtful.
There are democratic forces in Yugoslavia, in all of the republics. Demonstrations in Belgrade last March showed there are many thousands of anti-nationalist Yugoslavs -- especially among young people. It is this Europe-minded generation, comfortable with the West and free of the worst habits of Communist lockstep, who might be called the grandchildren of Tito and the remaining hope of Yugoslavia.

PUB-DATE: June 30, 1991

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2; Column 4; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 907 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Is the Vote, Too, Wasted On Youth?

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN 18-, 19- and 20-year-olds won the right to vote 20 years ago today, proponents heralded the ratification of the 26th Amendment as a sure remedy for the alienation of the nation's youth. With a direct role in the political process, they reasoned, young people would no longer feel disconnected.
"We will gain a group of enthusiastic, sensitive, idealistic and vigorous new voters," Senator Edward M. Kennedy said at the time. 
 While the enthusiasm may still be there, it is not for voting. Turnout among young people is shrinking with every election. The fact is, the vaunted youth vote never became the electoral force that some expected it to be.
Unlike many of their elders, young people nowadays cannot be accused of abandoning the political process. Most were never involved in the first place.
"You can't drag people in to vote," said Birch Bayh, the former Democratic Senator from Indiana who helped draft the Constitutional Amendment with Mr. Kennedy. "My disappointment goes not only to the fact that young people aren't voting, but that neither are their parents."
The young, however, are the least likely to exercise their right to vote, the most quantifiable form of political participation. Voting among youth dropped sharply after a high of 48 percent in 1972. In 1976, the figure was 38 percent, and 33 percent of 18- to 20-years olds said they voted in the 1988 elections, as opposed to 57 percent of the population as a whole.
Sounding civic-minded alarms about these statistics are a host of public interest and voter participation organizations, from the League of Women Voters to the Y.M.C.A.
"This is more than a matter of abstract good citizenship," said Sanford D. Horwitt, director of the citizens participation project for People for the American Way, a liberal advocacy group. "This relates to real public policy." As an example, Mr. Horwitt said, urban school systems face terrible budget problems but often have low political priority at least partly because the young people who have first-hand, recent experiences in public education tend not to vote.
Trying to explain the decline, many politicians and academics repeat the same adjectives used in the 1960's by those who championed the youth vote: that young people feel "disaffected" and "disenfranchised." But a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted on the eve of last November's elections found, in fact, that younger people seemed to be less turned off by politics than were their elders.
Asked how often they could trust the Government in Washington to do what is right, 28 percent of the 18- to 29-year-olds said most of the time, a response given by only 20 percent of those 30 and over. And 37 percent of the 18- to 29-year-olds agreed that it makes no real difference who is elected, compared with 45 percent of those aged 30 and over.
 
What's the Problem?
 If they are not completely disgusted by politics, why are young people not voting? Some argue that the issues now are not as compelling as, say, the Vietnam War, and that members of the current young generation are too self-absorbed.
Another reason, argues Senator Kennedy, is the dearth of inspirational figures. "I think young people are thirsting for leadership," he said. "They want to be asked to do things. I don't think during the last 10 years anybody has asked anyone to do anything for any one."
An 18-year-old from Middletown, Del., named Drew, interviewed as part of focus group on voter participation by People for the American Way, said he thought teachers and parents were not doing enough to encourage young people to vote. "As soon as you turn 18," he said, "it's not like you can just switch on our 'vote' modes and go out and vote."
There are also practical explanations: Young people are so transient that it can be difficult getting them to the polls or registered in the first place, with many confused over whether to list their residence with their parents or in their college dormitory.
Hoping to increase voting among the young, a coalition of about 50 organizations announced a campaign on Friday to institute voter registration drives in public high schools across the country.
"We ought to have a vision," said Mr. Horwitt, a leader of the coalition, "that everybody gets out of high school with a diploma in one hand and a voter registration card in another."
But Curtis B. Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, a Washington group, argued that the most aggressive registration efforts never translate into significant rises in turnout. "My judgment is that in the absence of a deep recession, which would cause a temporary upsurge in turnout, we're not likely to turn this around any time soon." In the meantime, others are pressing for assorted schemes to entice young people to vote, including lobbying for pending "motor voter" legislation that would allow a person to register to vote in conjunction with obtaining a driver's license.
Patrick Lipper, executive director of Rock the Vote, a record industry group based in Los Angeles, contends that the best way to stir young people politically is on the issue of censorship of records. To advance that message, the coalition has broadcast several public service spots on the MTV Network.
In one 60-second commercial, Madonna, while being spanked by two male dancers, warns viewers: "If you don't vote, you're going to get a spankie."

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: June 30, 1991

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 2; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 2814 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The Conservative Majority Solidifies

 BODY:

Criminal Law
 
Rights of Convicted Cut Back Sharply
Two rulings among the many significant ones of the term, which lasted from Oct. 1, 1990, to June 27, cut back sharply on the ability of death row inmates and other state prisoners to challenge the constitutionality of their convictions or sentences by filing petitions for writs of habeas corpus in Federal court. Both were decided by 6-to-3 votes, with Justices Marshall, Blackmun and Stevens dissenting. 
 In the first, McCleskey v. Zant, No. 89-7024, the Court raised almost insurmountable barriers to the filing of second or successive habeas corpus petitions. Federal judges must dismiss such petitions as an "abuse of the writ" except in unusual circumstances, Justice Kennedy's majority opinion said.
The second case, Coleman v. Thompson, No. 89-7662, held that inmates forfeit their ability to bring even an initial Federal habeas corpus petition if, through a lawyer's miscalculation or some other procedural error, they have failed to present their appeal properly in the state courts. Justice O'Connor's opinion overturned a 1963 Warren Court landmark, Fay v. Noia, which held that state prisoners were entitled to seek relief from the Federal courts as long as they had not "deliberately bypassed" state proceedings.
The Court ruled that the use of a coerced confession in a criminal trial does not automatically invalidate a conviction, but may be treated as "harmless error" if other evidence introduced at the trial was adequate to sustain a verdict of guilty.
The 5-to-4 decision overruled part of a 1967 precedent, Chapman v. California, under which a coerced confession could never be treated as harmless error. Chief Justice Rehnquist wrote the opinion, Arizona v. Fulminante, No. 89-839, which was joined by Justice Souter.
The Court overruled two other recent precedents on the last day of the term, voting 6 to 3 to permit prosecutors in death sentence proceedings to introduce evidence about a murder victim's character and the effect of the crime on the victim's family. Chief Justice Rehnquist wrote the opinion, Payne v. Tennessee, No. 90-5721.
It overruled two earlier decisions, Booth v. Maryland in 1987 and South Carolina v. Gathers in 1989, in which the Court ruled unconstitutional the use of victim impact evidence in death penalty cases. Justices Marshall, Stevens and Blackmun dissented from the new ruling, Justice Marshall with an angry warning that the majority's approach to precedent cast doubt on the stability of many of the Court's constitutional landmarks.
Making it harder for prisoners to bring lawsuits challenging prison conditions, the Court ruled 5 to 4 that the hardships of prison life do not violate the Constitution unless prisoners can show that the prison's officials have acted with "deliberate indifference."
The decision, based on the Court's interpretation of the Eighth Amendment's prohibition of cruel and unusual punishment, changed the focus of earlier rulings from the conditions themselves to the state of mind of the officials. Justice Scalia wrote the majority opinion, Wilson v. Seiter, No. 89-7376, which Justice Souter joined.
The Court voted 5 to 4 to uphold a mandatory life sentence without parole for nonviolent first offenses including possession of as little as 1.5 pounds of cocaine. Justices Scalia and Kennedy supported the judgment in Harmelin v. Michigan, No. 89-7272. The Court rejected the argument that the Michigan law at issue, the only such law in the country, imposed cruel and unusual punishment. Justice Souter joined the Kennedy plurality.
The Court ruled 6 to 3 that the police do not necessarily violate the Constitution by boarding long-distance buses, approaching passengers at random, and obtaining permission to search their luggage for drugs.
Justice O'Connor's opinion, Florida v. Bostick, No. 89-1717, overturned a ruling by the Florida Supreme Court, which held that police questioning within the cramped confines of a bus was inherently coercive. Justice O'Connor said the question was whether, under the "totality of the circumstances," a reasonable person would feel free "to terminate the encounter."
The Court ruled that drugs or other evidence discarded by a fleeing suspect can be admitted in court regardless of whether the police had any reason to suspect the person had committed a crime when they began chasing him. The 7-to-2 decision, California v. Hodari D., No. 89-1632, was written by Justice Scalia. He said that because a fleeing suspect has not been "seized," the Fourth Amendment's prohibition against unreasonable search and seizure does not apply.
The Court ruled 5 to 4 that people who are arrested without a warrant may be imprisoned for as long as 48 hours awaiting a determination of whether the arrest was proper. Justice O'Connor wrote the opinion, County of Riverside v. McLaughlin, No. 89-1817, with Justice Souter in the majority. A 1975 Court decision had required "prompt" determination, without defining the term.
The Court broadened the ability of the police to conduct warrantless searches of suitcases and other closed containers found in cars, overturning a 1979 precedent that barred such searches unless there was probable cause to search the entire car. Under the new ruling, California v. Acevedo, No. 89-1690, the police can search the container as long as they have probable cause to believe it contains drugs or other contraband. Justice Blackmun wrote the 6-to-3 decision.
In one of a handful of decisions in which a criminal defendant prevailed, the Court overturned a Mississippi inmate's murder conviction and death sentence in Minnick v. Miss., No. 89-6332. The Court ruled that once a suspect has asserted his right to a lawyer, the police may not initiate further questions unless the lawyer is present. Justice Kennedy wrote the 6-to-2 decision, with Justice Scalia and Chief Justice Rehnquist dissenting; Justice Souter did not participate.
 
 
 
Free Speech and Press
Abortion Advice Can Be Forbidden
 In the ruling that stirred the most intense public reaction of any this term, the Court upheld Federal regulations that bar family planning clinics that receive any Federal funds from all discussion of abortion with their patients.
The vote in Rust v. Sullivan, No. 89-1391, was 5 to 4, with Justice Souter joining Chief Justice Rehnquist's majority. The opinion swept away First Amendment and statutory arguments against the regulations, which were adopted by the Reagan Administration to replace longstanding rules under which health counsellors had been required to inform pregnant women of all their options, including abortion. The Chief Justice said that although abortion was a "protected right," the Government was not constitutionally required to "subsidize" speech about it.
In a celebrated libel case, the Court ruled 7 to 2 that fabricated quotations attributed to a public figure may be libelous only if the alterations materially change the meaning of what the person actually said. Justice Kennedy's opinion, Masson v. The New Yorker, No. 89-1799, permitted Dr. Jeffrey Masson's libel suit accusing a writer, Janet Malcolm, of fabricating quotes to go to trial, but ruled that taking liberties with quotations does not necessarily amount to "falsity" of the kind that establishes liability.
The Court ruled, 5 to 4, that the First Amendment does not protect news organizations from lawsuits for breaking promises of confidentiality to news sources. Justice White wrote the 5-to-4 opinion, Cohen v. Cowles Media, No. 90-634; Justice Souter wrote a dissent.
The Court ruled that while erotic nude dancing is a form of expression with some First Amendment protection, states may ban it. The vote in Barnes v. Glen Theatre, No. 90-26, was 5 to 4, with a plurality opinion by Chief Justice Rehnquist and a concurring opinion by Justice Souter.
In Gentile v. State Bar, No. 89-1836, the Justices upheld the limits that most states impose on public comments that lawyers can make about pending cases, but it said that the rules had to be precisely written so lawyers know what is prohibited. Justice O'Connor provided a swing vote for shifting 5-to-4 majorities. She joined Chief Justice Rehnquist in holding that Nevada's rule did not infringe lawyers' First Amendment rights, and Justice Kennedy in holding that the rule was unconstitutionally vague. Justice Souter voted with the Chief Justice.
 
 
 
Federal Authority
Rescue of S.& L.'s Avoids Liability
 The Court ruled unanimously that the Federal Government cannot be sued for damages when efforts by Federal banking regulators to rescue troubled savings and loan associations go awry. The decision, U.S. v. Gaubert, No. 89-1793, written by Justice White, was a source of relief to the Government, which faced lawsuits with a possible liability in the billions of dollars.
The Court ruled that the Government can be sued over the way it is administering the amnesty provisions of the 1986 immigration law. The 7-to-2 decision, written by Justice Stevens, rejected the Government's view that the Federal courts have no jurisdiction to hear class-action lawsuits on behalf of large groups of illegal aliens. Chief Justice Rehnquist and Justice Scalia dissented in McNary v. Haitian Refugee Center, No. 89-1332.
 
 
 
Civil Rights
Schools Get a Way To Stop Busing
 The Court ruled, 5 to 3, that formerly segregated school districts may be released from court-ordered busing once they have taken all "practicable" steps to eliminate the legacy of segregation. Chief Justice Rehnquist's opinion, in a case from Oklahoma City, left many questions unanswered, including the definition of "practicable" and how to decide when "vestiges" of segregation have been eliminated.
The Court will attempt to answer those questions next term in a similar case from suburban Atlanta, when the Chief Justice may have a more comfortable margin. Justice Souter did not participate in the Oklahoma City case, Board of Education v. Dowell, No. 89-1080.
The Court ruled that the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which bars sex discrimination on the job, forbids employers from barring women from jobs that might harm a developing fetus. Justice Blackmun wrote the opinion, Automobile Workers v. Johnson Controls, No. 89-1215, invalidating a policy that a battery manufacturer had adopted to avoid exposing female workers to lead.
All nine Justices agreed that the particular policy was illegal, but were divided over what standard to apply. Justices Souter, Marshall, O'Connor and Stevens agreed with Justice Blackmun's view that such policies are always illegal.
In cases from Louisiana and Texas, the Court ruled that the Voting Rights Act of 1965 applies to elections for judges. The two 6-to-3 opinions by Justice Stevens open many state court systems, particularly in the South, to challenge on the ground that judicial district lines are drawn in ways that diminish the chances of electing black or other minority judges. The cases were Chisom v. Roemer, No. 90-757, and Houston Lawyers v. Texas Attorney General, No. 90-757. Justices Scalia, Kennedy and Chief Justice Rehnquist dissented.
The Court ruled that neither the Federal law against age discrimination nor the Constitution bars states from setting ages at which judges must retire. The vote in Gregory v. Ashcroft, No. 90-50, was 7 to 2. Justice O'Connor, in a majority opinion joined by four others, based her conclusion on a view of state-Federal relations that suggests a willingness to overturn recent precedents that uphold Federal authority at the expense of the states. Justice Souter voted with Justice O'Connor.
In two decisions, both written by Justice Kennedy, the Court expanded significantly on its bar against excluding jurors on the basis of race. In Edmonson v. Leesville Concrete Co., No. 89-7743, the Court ruled 6 to 3 that neither side in a civil case can use race as a basis for excluding jurors. In Powers v. Ohio, No. 89-5011, it said that defendants in criminal trials can object to the prosecution's exclusion of jurors based on race, even if the defendant and the excluded juror are of different races.
The Court ruled 6 to 3 that the Civil Rights Act of 1964 does not protect American workers overseas from discrimination by U.S.-based employers. Chief Justice Rehnquist wrote the opinion, Equal Employment Opportunity Comm. v. Aramco, No. 89-1838.
 
 
 
Business
Juries Keep Discretion Over Damages
 The Court decisively rejected a long-awaited constitutional attack on punitive damages. The 7-to-1 decision left juries with the broad discretion over damage awards that the insurance industry and other business groups have attacked as a violation of the guarantee of due process of law. Justice Blackmun wrote the majority opinion and Justice O'Connor dissented in Pacific Mutual v. Haslip, No. 89-1279.
The Court rejected an Internal Revenue Service position, ruling 7 to 2 that savings and loan institutions can create paper losses for Federal income tax purposes by swapping portfolios of low-value mortgages with other S.& L.'s . Justice Marshall wrote the opinion, U.S. v. Centennial Savings Bank, No. 89-1926.
In an important copyright ruling with broad implications for the computerized information industry, the Court ruled unanimously that the alphabetical listing of names and addresses in the white pages of a phone directory is not protected by Federal copyright law. Justice O'Connor wrote the decision, Feist Publications v. Rural Telephone Service, No. 89-1909.
 
 
 
PRECEDENTS WERE OVERTURNED IN SEVERAL CRIMINAL CASES
 The Court overturned five of its own precedents this term.
Automobile Searches: In California v. Acevedo, the Court overruled a 1979 decision, Arkansas v. Sanders, which had barred the police from warrantless searches of suitcases or other containers in cars without probable cause to search the car itself. Now they are free to search the container as long as they have probable cause to believe it contains contraband.
Coerced Confessions: In Arizona v. Fulminante, the Court said the use of a coerced confession at trial can be "harmless error" if other evidence supports a verdict. A 1967 case, Chapman v. California, held that coerced confessions could never be harmless.
Habeas Corpus: In Coleman v. Thompson, the Court ruled that most state prisoners who fail through a lawyer's error or other mistake to present their appeals properly to state court forfeit their right to Federal court review. It overruled a 1963 landmark, Fay v. Noia, under which prisoners could file Federal petitions for writs of habeas corpus as long as they had not "deliberately bypassed" state courts.
Victim Impact Evidence: In a 1987 case, Booth v. Maryland, and again in South Carolina v. Gathers in 1989, the Court barred prosecutors in death sentence proceedings from introducing evidence about the victim's character or the grief of a victim's family. Those cases were overruled in Payne v. Tennessee.
 
 
 
EXCEPT ON LAW AND ORDER, SOUTER REMAINS A MYSTERY
 It is not surprising that David H. Souter has not yet established a clear judicial voice after barely nine months on the Court. New Justices seldom do.
After a slow start, he produced eight opinions -- less than his mathematical share, but not dramatically so. Justice Harry A. Blackmun had 10 opinions and Justice Antonin Scalia had 11. There was evidence that Justice Souter was assigned one or two additional cases, but lost a majority after Justices switched sides.
His opinions included criminal cases, complex commercial disputes, and a border conflict between Illinois and Kentucky. His approach is methodical and comprehensive. His questions from the bench are probing, delivered in a polite but firm manner and demonstrating his grasp of the issues.
But he evidently has not yet adopted the veteran Justices' habit of delegating much research and writing to law clerks. One of his opinions, handed down on the last day of the term, was in a complicated securities case argued Oct. 9, the first day he sat on the Court.
The term did relatively little to resolve the mysteries that lingered after Justice Souter's confirmation last September. It was evident from his record as a state court judge and New Hampshire attorney general that he is a law-and-order conservative, and so he proved, in a term with many criminal cases. He has yet to be heard on race, religion and abortion.
At age 51, he is the Court's youngest member, and has replicated as best he can the ascetic lifestyle he maintained in New Hampshire. He lives in a rented apartment in a modern complex in southwest Washington. He works late in his chambers most nights, and then often runs on a track at an Army base near his apartment before going home to a late supper.

HEADLINE: So What's Going On in the Soviet Union?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The United States news media, The Times included, is presenting the Soviet Union in an incorrect light. 
 True, people are dying of political-ethnic violence in Armenia, but at the same time, the Armenian economy is growing. Most important, Russia, by far the largest and most populous part of the Soviet Union, is quite calm. (I was in Leningrad for the last two weeks of May. I also spent two days in Estonia.)
There is no hunger, mood of revolt or danger of a social explosion of any kind. People are annoyed at the economic difficulties, yes, but at the same time they are going about living their lives, and they laugh at the talk of impending disaster that is now so common in the West.
On June 18, NBC News used the word "turmoil," and on June 19, Sidney Blumenthal stated in "Boris at the Front Door" (Op-Ed) that "Soviet politics have become chaotic and irrational." I protest. I saw and heard nothing to warrant such sensationalist terminology. It is frightening Western tourists away at a time when the Soviet Union could really use their money.
 
KARL W. RYAVEC
Professor of Political Science
University of Massachusetts
Amherst, Mass., June 20, 1991

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Tinkering at Radio Shack

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Radio Shack grew into the largest retailer of home electronics by selling solid if unflashy house-brand consumer electronics and electronics parts. But last week it said it would do a bit of tinkering with its successful formula.
 Radio Shack's parent, the Fort Worth-based Tandy Corporation, announced that in September some Radio Shacks would begin selling name-brand products. A week earlier, Tandy said it would open six stores to sell name-brand computers as well as its own line of machines. 
Was Tandy taking defensive action to halt the four-year slide in profit as a percentage of revenues and to cushion the shock of the most recent quarterly earnings, which were 50 percent lower than expected? Not precisely, says Bernard S. Appel, the fast-talking 59-year-old president of Radio Shack. He concedes that his unit, which last year contributed roughly $2.9 billion of Tandy's $4.5 billion in sales, did not do as well last year as the year before, but he says Radio Shack's problems are those of the industry as a whole -- mainly the general flatness in consumer electronics.
 In a phone interview from Chattanooga, Tenn., where he received an honorary doctorate from McKenzie College, a two-year business school, Mr. Appel scoffed at the notion of a fundamental change in direction. He said Radio Shack expected to add only about 1 percent to its sales volume by selling higher-end audio and video equipment, like large-screen televisions, in 140 of the 4,500 company-owned Radio Shack outlets. The 140 outlets will be in remote markets where there is little competition.
 Mr. Appel thinks Tandy's performance will improve as the recession ends and consumers resume spending. But Some analysts are less sanguine. "True, there is softness in consumer electronics, but Radio Shack labors under a stigma," said Charles Wolf, an analyst at Goldman Sachs. "It hasn't been able to establish its Realistic label as a viable alternative to the Japanese."
 The company plans to stick to basics. "We won't de-emphasize our major thrust, which is still private-label products," Mr. Appel said.
