HEADLINE: West Cork's Wild Peninsulas

BYLINE: By CHRISTINE S. COZZENS; CHRISTINE S. COZZENS, a teacher of writing at Agnes Scott College, in Decatur, Ga., has visited Ireland many times.

 BODY:
IN the language of history and legend, the lure of the West of Ireland has always had a magical quality. The English, who never succeeded at bringing the western reaches of the island under their authority, believed that the farther one traveled beyond the limits of the Crown's jurisdiction the less the rules of civilization applied. Enveloping the southwestern corner of Ireland, County Cork spreads out from the republic's second largest commercial city, Cork. But its western peninsulas -- the Mizen and the Beara -- retain their wild aspect, and unlike the more famous Ring of Kerry to the north, the ring routes that edge their jutting cliffs and sheltered harbors have not yet become worn paths of tourism.
West Cork, sometimes known as West Carbery in the ancient baronial nomenclature, has always been a land unto itself. The soft southwestern climate maintained by the Gulf Stream nurtures palm trees, banks of fuchsia and rhododendrons and midwinter wildflowers along a ragged coastline formed of limestone and slate. Boiling seas at Dursey Island, Sheep's Head and Three Castle Head menace shipping while guarding the graceful bays -- they are really drowned valleys -- of Bantry, Dunmanus and Roaringwater. 
 Rich in natural resources such as copper and other minerals, an abundance of perfectly formed harbors, fish, shellfish, mild weather and extraordinary scenery, the peninsulas of West Cork beguiled would-be conquerors from the ancient Irish tribes, to the Vikings, to the English under Cromwell and to early 20th-century schemers. Again and again, twists of circumstance and human folly defeated the aspirations to prosperity of every generation that attempted to settle the long fingers of pastureland and bleak rock stretching westward.
The tantalizing copper and barite lodes -- like those that lined the slopes of Mount Gabriel near Schull -- proved less rich and more treacherous to mine than expected. In the 18th century, sailing ships packed the harbors of West Cork to take on supplies, but the coming of the steamships meant fewer stops on ocean voyages. The great famine of the 1840's devastated the villages of West Cork, where the rough peninsular terrain impeded relief efforts. In our century, eager entrepreneurs overfished the lobster, crayfish and crab population around the Mizen and the Beara until the shellfish industry failed entirely.
No part of Ireland has been more transformed by waves of emigration from famine times to the present. The deserted village at Mizen Head is just one of many settlements abandoned by desperate emigrants fleeing to America or Australia or England. Shiploads of Irish men, women and children caught a last view of their native land as they steamed past the farflung outposts of West Cork -- Fastnet Rock and Brow Head, where a few older residents still remember watching their flight. Ironically, in recent times emigrants returning in large numbers for Christmas visits have created a lucrative winter tourist season, a welcome contribution to the precarious economy of the West.
Though history may have betrayed the promise of West Cork's riches, it jealously preserved the land for the eye and the camera. Today the profits of a modest tourist industry, coastal contours that are ideal for yachting and the region's growing popularity as a summer home for foreigners enable this generation of West Corkers to make a living in one of Ireland's most appealing and least crowded corners.
Tours of West Cork usually begin at the busy market town of Skibbereen, which dominates the region's business and tourist industry and has an Irish Tourist Board office as well as comfortable hotels and restaurants. But the special character of the ring routes depends on the proximity of the sea, and accommodations at Schull, Bantry or Glengarriff are situated near the main cross-peninsular routes and overlook the peaceful bays dotted with sailboats and trawlers.
The one-hour drive from Skibbereen to Schull passes through rolling countryside criss-crossed with hedges and into the tiny hillside village of Ballydehob, a handful of brightly painted shop fronts. Perched above an estuary that changes its shape with the tides, Ballydehob looks out on a 12-arch railway bridge built in the late 19th century to carry passengers, copper and fish during one of West Cork's promising periods. Abandoned in 1947, the bridge is now a pedestrian walkway overgrown with wildflowers -- an eloquent testimony to the changing fortunes of this now sparsely populated region.
From Ballydehob, the road winds around the base of Mount Gabriel to Schull, the gateway to the Mizen Ring and one of Ireland's loveliest seaside villages. Once referred to along with Skibbereen as "those two famine-slain sisters of the South," today Schull combines the sparkle of a yachting port with casual but comfortable tourist amenities and easy access to all of West Cork. Schull's southerly view encompasses the harbor, the large Roaringwater Bay beyond, Clear Island (birthplace of St. Kieran and still an Irish-speaking community), Long Island and Calf Island in a tapestry of shapes created by land and water and colored by the rapidly changing weather patterns that sweep across Ireland from this southwestern point. In the summer, a series of annual racing fixtures attracts sailors from all over the world, and during Schull's Calves Week Regatta in mid-August, the pubs and small family-run hotels along the village's main street burst with merriment and good-natured rivalry. During the short days of winter, the sun both rises and sets above the swatches of color and light in Roaringwater Bay, and a furious hailstorm is likely to be followed by a flood of sunshine and blue skies.
THE road from Schull toward Goleen and Mizen Head traces the crest of the peninsula through mounds of brush and rock daubed with the brilliant yellow flowers and spiny green branches of gorse. At Toormore, an inlet bends the road suddenly inward. Here the pastoral scene gives way to seascape as waves pour over jagged-toothed rocks, swirl into tidepools and splay out across the mudflats that line the shore. From Goleen the road turns to Crookhaven and a naturally protected harbor so typical of West Cork. The string of row houses painted in warm pastels -- apricot, yellow, salmon -- stands out against the deep green slope that stretches between Streek Head and Brow Head. This strategic site was once a thriving settlement in the heyday of the sailing ships, and it came alive again briefly with the discovery of copper and the resurgence of the fishing fleet. Marconi himself came to Crookhaven in 1902 to supervise the building of a radio transmission station at Brow Head, but the station was soon moved to a better location.
After Crookhaven, the Mizen Ring bends to the north and cuts across the stretch of land and water known as Barleycove, where layers of foamy breakers extend for hundreds of yards. The broad sandy strip -- the only beach for miles -- is backed by soft dunes and a tidal lake reaching far into the center of the peninsula. Flocks of oystercatchers and other wading birds wander the mudflats here at low tide, and the lake is fringed with tall rushes that are blown nearly flat by winter gales.
Just a few miles away, the wild seas and dramatic cliffs at Mizen Head seem a world apart from the shelter of Barleycove. The Anglo-Irish novelist Edith Somerville described this promontory as "a giant spoke of headland that sticks up like a boar's tusk above the rugged lip of the Irish coast." A safe, paved path dips down the face of the cliff to a white iron bridge that spans the inlet and connects to the Irish Lights Office on the Head; travelers wishing to venture out to the lighthouse must seek permission in advance. Many a doomed ship lies beneath the giant swells that batter these cliffs. At Three Castle Head you may leave your car at the road's end and walk down steps to within spray distance of breakers that arch high in the air before pummeling the rocks, or choose a more peaceful climb through fields to the three-towered O'Mahoney Castle, which has withstood nearly 800 years of violent weather and surf.
The northern stretch of the Mizen Ring route from Three Castle Head to Dunkelly, Dunmanus and Durrus follows a ridge overlooking sloping pastureland that ends abruptly in black rock plummeting to the sea. Layers of land and water -- Dunmanus Bay, Sheep's Head, Bantry Bay and the Ring of Beara -- line the horizon and appear and disappear as banks of fog, rain and clouds drift in from the sea. At Dunmanus, the massive walls of another O'Mahoney castle dominate the bay. The little peninsula to the north of the Mizen has several names -- Sheep's Head, Muntervary and Kilcrohane -- and a splendid ring route of its own. At the village of Ahakista the road plunges into tall woods in one of the lush, almost tropical settings that characterize West Cork. Farther along, a flourishing spring flower industry at Kilcrohane brightens the hillside with fields full of daffodils, tulips and irises. At Sheep's Head, an easy walk from the car park brings the visitor to a view that extends from Mizen Head to the Kerry mountains.
At Bantry, the roads from the Mizen and from Sheep's Head converge on Bantry House, a grand Georgian mansion overlooking the ample proportions of the bay. Filled with treasures of art, the house opened to the public in 1945 -- the first such house in Ireland to do so. The present heir, a descendant of the White family that has owned the house since 1750, runs the tours, teas and bed and breakfast business that enable him to keep up with the demands of maintaining and gradually restoring the magnificent house and grounds: Bantry House's 52 chimneys attest to the monumental nature of that task. The Whites living here in 1796 must have stood on their wide terrace gazing fearfully at the hostile French fleet that waited in the bay, poised to invade Cork in one of Wolfe Tone's ill-fated attempts to liberate Ireland with assistance from abroad. Once again, West Cork eluded the outsider. The road from Bantry to the Ring of Beara winds around to Glengarriff, a hospitable town, and the Eccles Hotel. At Glengarriff, boats leave regularly for nearby Garinish Island, one of several exotic island gardens in the mild West Cork climate. The coast road from Glengarriff to Adrigole dips in and out of deep forest, affording glimpses of more islands, inlets, bits of lakes -- a lantern show of scenery. The twists and turns of the coastline here provided cover for generations of pirates and other outlaws.
ON the Beara, the massive mountains of the Caha range fill the central part of the peninsula, dividing Cork from Kerry to the north and creating an atmosphere of grandeur in contrast to the intimacy of the Mizen and Muntervary peninsulas. Between Adrigole and Casteltownbere, Hungry Hill towers above all the other peaks. The copper mines in the area caught the fancy of many an entrepreneur, but following the pattern of other mines throughout West Cork, they failed to fulfill their promise and closed one after another when better sources of copper were discovered in Africa. Daphne du Maurier chronicled the story of these mines in her novel "Hungry Hill," which was inspired by the dealings of the notorious Puxley family, Welsh settlers who came to the Beara to seek their fortune.
Castletownbere, also called Castletown Bearhaven, lies at the entrance to Bantry Bay on yet another sheltered harbor. A headquarters for the Irish fishing fleet, this town has managed to re-establish itself as a commercial center in spite of its isolation. The bustling waterfront is lined with bars, tackle shops and small factories. Travelers following the Ring route may cut across the Beara at Castletownbere for spectacular mountain scenery, or drive out past the ruins of Dunboy Castle -- scene of a famous siege by the English in 1602 -- past Black Ball Head and Crow Head to the peninsula's tip, where Ireland's only cable car crosses a dangerous sound to Dursey Island. This squall-lashed island is one of Ireland's bleakest points -- the tiny villages and livestock seem to cling to its steep slopes -- but mountain walks here afford breathtaking views of Cork and Kerry and the sea.
The north-facing stretches of the West Cork peninsulas are quieter and more austere than those that face south; the rocky northern slopes of the Beara roll majestically seaward, broken by a few scattered cottages, stone circles or boulder burial sites from the Megalithic period, and abandoned mines, some of which are hundreds of years old. All the guidebooks warn hikers to beware of hidden shafts.
The Ring of Beara curves northward around Coulagh Bay at Ballydonegan and Allihies -- where the ruins of a 19th-century Cornish copper mining settlement still stand complete with engine houses -- and eastward along the mouth of the Kenmare River, plunging suddenly down into the village of Eyeries, its garishly painted houses visible from high in the mountains. After Ardgroom, Cork gives way to Kerry. Travelers can choose whether to traverse the Caha Mountains at the Healy Pass or by the slightly longer tunnel route from Kenmare to Glengarriff: both passes intersect a web of hiking routes that span the peninsula's swollen center.
 
PLACES TO STAY AND PLACES TO EAT, FROM SKIBBEREEN TO BEYOND BANTRY BAY

 
Getting There
The nearest airport to the region is in Cork city, about two hours by car from Skibbereen. The drive to Bantry from Shannon Airport, 112 miles to the north, takes about three hours and passes through some of Ireland's most spectacular scenery, including the Lakes of Killarney. The Mizen Ring and Ring of Beara can be driven in a day; a leisurely drive along the Muntervary Peninsula ring route requires half a day.
 
Places to Stay
Comfortable bed and breakfast accommodations can be found at farmhouses and cottages throughout West Cork during the summer season for about $20 per person per night, calculated at $1.50 to the Irish pound.
The East End Hotel, on Main Street, in Schull offers bed and breakfast for $25; telephone (28) 28101.
The Schull Holiday Cottages are fully equipped, with kitchens, and overlook Schull Harbour about a half mile from town; a week during the summer costs $534. Further information: James Lyons O'Keefe, 48 Main Street, Schull, County Cork, Ireland; (28) 28122.
For resort-type accommodations farther out on Mizen Head, try the Barleycove Beach Hotel and Villas, (28) 35234. Bed and breakfast is $57.
Bed and breakfast at Bantry House, (28) 50047, is $54 to $68.
Ballylickey Manor House, (27) 50071, between Bantry and Glengarriff, also overlooks the bay. Bed and breakfast is $58.
At Glengarriff, the elegant Eccles Hotel, (27) 41200, charges $38.
For first-class acommodations on the County Kerry side of the Beara Peninsula, the Park Hotel in Kenmare, (64) 41200, offers bed and breakfast from $98.
 
Places to Eat
A number of moderately priced, fine restaurants open up on the Mizen Head in the tourist season, from the end of May to October, including the following:
The Altar, at Toormore, (28)-35254, and Journey's End at Crookhaven (28) 35183, both of which specialize in local seafood. Dinner for two at both places about $40.
The Bunratty Inn, (28) 28342, on Main Street in Schull, serves wonderful pub lunches, including local seafood and specialty soups, with warm basketsful of homemade Irish brown bread. Prices $5 to $10.
Across the street, Adele's Coffee Shop, (28) 28459, sells quiche, homemade ice cream, soups, salads and baked goods. Prices from $1.50 for a coffee and scone.
Nearby, The Black Sheep Inn, (28) 28203, specializes in baked stuffed trout and an original Irish coffee cake. Dinner is $36 to $46for two.
 In Ahakista, Durrus, the only Japanese restaurant in the west of Ireland, Shiro, serves a superb dinner for about $100 for two; (27) 67030.
 
Books
Mizen Books, Main Street, Cork, Ireland, (28) 28414, has an extensive collection of travel and historical works about West Cork and will fill credit card orders from the United States.
If you have time to read only one book try Peter Somerville-Large's "The Coast of West Cork" (Appletree Press).
 
Information
The Irish Tourist Board, 757 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017, (212) 418-0800, can supply information about everything from accommodations to restaurants. -- C. S. C.

HEADLINE: IN SHORT: NONFICTION

BYLINE: By KENNETH UVA

 BODY:

COBBLESTONE LEADERSHIP
Majority Rule, Minority Power.
By James MacGregor Burns
with L. Marvin Overby.
University of Oklahoma, $17.95. 
 This study, "Cobblestone Leadership," written with L. Marvin Overby, who teaches political science at Loyola University, is an expansion of a series of lectures the Pulitzer Prize-winning scholar James MacGregor Burns gave in 1987 on how to make democratic government more effective. His premise is that the United States actually has adopted seven "bills of rights." The first was the Bill of Rights set forth in the first 10 amendments to the Constitution, which guaranteed that particular liberties of certain citizens would be free from government interference. The others he cites include the emancipation of slaves, women's suffrage and the economic rights that underlay the New Deal. Every expansion of rights has created a new class of people entitled to protection, Mr. Burns argues, but has also increased the tension between majority rule and minority rights. This, coupled with the checks and balances that the Founders built into the Constitution, has created a government that cannot govern effectively, a government of "stalemate and spasm." Mr. Burns's historical analysis is thoughtful and incisive. His suggestions -- strengthening political parties and amending the Constitution to strengthen them -- are, in the face of a declining civic culture together with immense corporate power, perhaps more in the nature of philosophical musings than practical solutions.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A New Company Promises a New Voice

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: RUTHERFORD

 BODY:
WITH theaters in attrition, the arts in crisis and the economy in recession, what sort of time is this for a new professional theater company to be springing up?
"We're not thinking about all that," said Steven Bloom, who with William MacNeil is co-founder and co-artistic director of the Rivoli Stage Company, the new resident company of the William Carlos Williams Center for the Arts. "We're taking a chance. Our voice is different and we're not doing what others are doing. And our unique position makes it worthwhile to attempt." 
 For a first hearing of that voice, the company is producing the United States premiere of a double bill of monodramas called "Wild Abandon, Plus" by a 29-year-old Canadian playwright, Daniel MacIvor.
In an unusual case of reverse routing, the play has had six tryout performances at the Westbeth Theater Center in Manhattan before opening at the Williams Center for four performances that began last Thursday and end with a matinee today at 3 P.M. (The telephone number for ticket information is201-939-6969.)
The Rivoli's regular season is to begin with "Dog Eat Dog" by Mary Gallagher (Nov. 7 to Nov. 24), a play about three prosperous couples learning how to cope with being broke during hard times. It was produced at the Hartford Stage Company in 1983.
The second slot, from March 12 to March 29, is to be filled by John Guare's "Bosoms and Neglect" or Oliver Hailey's "I Won't Dance." The first is a mordant comedy about a terminally ill mother and her son's embattled marriage; the second is about a paraplegic's violent streak. Both were Broadway failures, running, respectively, for two days (in 1979) and for one day (in 1981).
The one to be selected is to be determined by audience response to "semistaged readings" -- of Mr. Hailey's work on July 15; of Mr. Guare's, on July 29. Both will be at 7:30 P.M. and are free to the public.
Obviously, mainstream theater is not within the mission of the Rivoli, which, fearing legal repercussions, isn't going by its name of first choice -- Serious Fun. That name has been taken by Lincoln Center's five-year-old arts festival, which starts July 11.
Still, "a theater of serious fun" is how the Rivoli explains what it is about in publicity releases. This refers, Mr. MacNeil said, to "plays that entertain -- and deal with issues, giving audiences something to think about."
For starters, the company's current double bill is more serious than fun. In the first of the two plays, "See Bob Run," a young woman named Roberta, the Bob of the title (played by Jessica Pennington) is a victim of sexual abuse by her father, who calls her Princess. She hitchhikes across Canada, moving from car to car. This is represented by four chairs on stage. When she walks atop them, they become rocks over the water, into which Bob gets ready to jump.
In the second play, "Wild Abandon," an alienated young man, Steve (played by Marc Battista), looks at a noose and says, "This is my option," but his fate is left up to the audience.
"Both plays are desperate cries for help from young people scarred by dysfunctional families, but the second play really is funny," Mr. MacNeil said.
Mr. Bloom said, "The characters are on a journey -- that's the key word I've been using with the actors." He is also the play's director.
"They're actively trying to find answers, not feeling sorry for themselves," Mr. Bloom said. "They're not just accepting or wallowing. They're making a real effort and they want to know and to be better and to be loved -- and that's what I find enriching and very theatrical."
The new company came to be when Mr. MacNeil, an Edgewater resident who said he was "closer to 50 than I want to be," was asked by Jack Banning to head a resident theater at the Williams Center. Mr. MacNeil had been associate artistic director of the Playhouse at the Park in Union City.
Mr. Banning, who is the Williams Center's executive director, had been the artistic director of the Playhouse at the Park. Mr. Bloom, a 35-year-old director, heard of the plans and invited both men to see one of his Off Off Broadway productions.
"The three of us were on the same wavelength about the kinds of plays we wanted to do," Mr. Bloom said.
Mr. Bloom, who was the assistant director of "Lend Me a Tenor" in the national touring production and the Paper Mill Playhouse version in Millburn, has worked in directing and theater management "all over the country," he said.
"As a professional director," he said, "I prefer to work in my back yard -- Guttenberg, where I live, is 15 minutes from Rutherford -- and at the same time, we can create a theater for the community."
Mr. MacNeil added, "Only American Stage in Teaneck is nearby -- about seven miles -- and we can fill the void left by the demise of the Whole Theater in Montclair, which was four miles away."
About the Rivoli's beginnings, Mr. MacNeil said, "Instead of waiting, we wanted to start small." The current production, which he said cost "between three and four thousand dollars," was financed by Mr. Bloom and Mr. MacNeil.
"We have two Equity actors and one Equity stage manager," Mr. MacNeil said. "The set consists of two paintings, which were lent to us, and the sound designer worked gratis."
Various fund-raising events are scheduled to finance the fall season, which is budgeted at more than $40,000, Mr. MacNeil said.
Mr. Bloom, explaining what he called the company's "unique position," said: "We're creating a relationship with the center, which offered us a brand new home, so we don't have to raise money to build a theater, and they're gaining the prestige of having a professional theater company here. And we split the costs. "We raised the money to produce; they get a portion of the box office -- and we don't have to worry about real estate. In New York, that's what it all winds up being about. All of our fund-raising is for money to go into our productions."
The Rivoli Theater, a movie house built in 1922, was devastated by a fire in the 1970's. It has been divided into two performing spaces, one of which is a "black box," with flexible seating arrangements (capacity: 300). Private and corporate donations totaled $100,00 for this space, which is where the new company is playing.
The other space is a 600-seat theater that is being renovated at a cost of $250,000. It is scheduled to open as a showplace for ballet and popular and classical concerts in October.
About the new company, Mr. Bloom said: "The plays are not only serious fun; they're being discovered -- or rediscovered."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Make the Free-Trade Vision a Reality

BYLINE: By RICHARD E. FEINBERG and PETER HAKIM; Richard E. Feinberg is executive vice president of the Overseas Development Council, Washington. Peter Hakim is staff director of the Inter-American Dialogue, Washington.

 BODY:
With the end of the Cold War, trade has displaced security as the centerpiece of relations between the United States and Latin America.. Yet there is not one organization with the mandate and expertise to exercise leadership on inter-American trade issues. This is a vacuum that now should be filled by the governments of the Americas.
President Bush set off a flurry of activity a year ago, when he put forth the vision of a Western Hemisphere free-trade area. Country after country in Latin America declared interest in free trade with the United States -- and six have signed bilateral or multilateral "framework agreements" with Washington providing for regular discussion on key issues. The proposal has also reinvigorated existing trade pacts throughout Latin America; prompted Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay to work toward a common market, and spurred other nations to begin free-trade talks. All this activity surely will accelerate now that fast-track authority for United States trade negotiations has been renewed. 
 This, then, is the time for the United States and other governments to create, with the private sector, an Americas Commission for Trade and Trade-Related Matters. It would help promote unrestricted hemispheric commerce, serving as:
* A clearinghouse, to collect, systematize and disseminate trade statistics and information on national trade policies;
* A think tank, to analyze trade and trade-related issues;
* A trade monitor, to review and evaluate proposed trade arrangements among nations, and
* A source of technical assistance, to provide expertise to countries formulating trade policies and negotiating trade agreements.
Over time, the commission could be entrusted with the more sensitive tasks of defining rules to guide hemispheric trade negotiations, mediating them, investigating alleged violations of trade accords and settling disputes. It could be set up within an established institution like the Inter-American Development Bank or as a free-standing agency.
Trade is now reshaping hemispheric relations. Expanding commerce could help create a Western Hemisphere economic community along European lines. But burgeoning trade could, just as easily, produce new conflicts in the Americas, as it has in relations between Washington and Tokyo. An effective hemispheric trade organization could help prevent this by injecting order and purpose into the current mosaic of trade negotiations. With some imagination and a small investment by hemispheric governments -- no more than $10 million a year -- the Americas Commission for Trade could be up and running in short order.

PUB-DATE: June 30, 1991

SECTION: Section 3; Page 23; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 900 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Dirty Shirts at the 6:18, Clean Collars Tonight

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
It's 6:18 on a Tuesday morning, and the Greenwich, Conn., train station is bustling. Cars drop off sleepy-eyed commuters, who dash to the newsstand, coins and monogrammed briefcases in hand, before heading to the Manhattan-bound platform.
 Some commuters, however, carry something more. James Carrier, a salesman with Reuters Information Services, races in with an armful of crumpled shirts. "No starch," he blurts to an attendant at the blue-and-white booth just inside the station's entrance. "See you tonight." 
When Mr. Carrier returns 12 hours later, his fresh-pressed shirts will be waiting, done by Commuter Cleaners, a four-year-old service that has grown to seven outlets -- at railroad stations and in small shops -- in suburban Westchester County and Connecticut. "It used to be that I could never get to my cleaners except on weekends," Mr. Carrier said. "This is much more convenient."
 Commuter Cleaners is the brainchild of Paul McDonald, a 31-year-old former accountant who got fed up with working long hours and commuting -- and never having a clean shirt as a result. His early efforts involved standing outside the Greenwich station with a laundry basket, offering to ferry commuters' clothes back and forth from local cleaning shops. Today he runs a $1 million business with 20 employees, a fleet of vans and his own production plant. It is, to the best of his knowledge, the only such service in the country, and he also offers tailoring and shoe repair.
 "Our concept is to attract the time-sensitive customer," Mr. McDonald explained. "These people spend 40 hours a month on the train. Anything they can do to save a little leisure time is a big help."
 Operating a cleaner along one of the nation's chief power corridors means Mr. McDonald sees some unusual dirty laundry. Take the morning Tom Sexton, manager of the fixed-income department at First Boston, left a pair of golf slacks at the Greenwich station. During the cleaning, a money clip turned up -- with more than $1,000 in cash. "He gave our driver a pretty big tip when he found it waiting," said Mr. McDonald.
 Another time, a prominent executive -- whom Mr. McDonald won't identify -- arrived with his wife. When he dumped his clothes on the counter, a peep show token rolled out of a pocket. "He told his wife he found it on the street, that it was a coin from another country," recalled Mr. McDonald.
 Until 1987, Mr. McDonald had had little experience with either commuting or cleaning. The Oklahoma-bred entrepreneur earned an M.B.A. from Tulane University in New Orleans, then took a job with Arthur Andersen there. When the regional economy headed south, he headed north to Creditanstalt Bankverein, an Austrian bank with offices in midtown Manhattan. He settled in Westchester, and for 18 months commuted to his job as an account supervisor.
 "There's a lot of time on the train to sit and ponder your future," he said.
 Armed with demographic statistics from Metro-North, Mr. McDonald did a market analysis of commuters using the New Haven and the Harlem-Hudson lines. He started his service in Greenwich because it had the right station configuration. "You need to get customers between their cars and the train," he says. "It helps if they all come through the same entrance."
 He negotiated for a lease on the Greenwich (there are also Old Greenwich and Cos Cob stops) station, from a private real estate company; later, in Stamford and Chappaqua, two other station sites, he had to win approval from the municipalities.
 To insure success with customers, he undercut local services, charging $1.50 a shirt instead of $2. Because his business required only low overhead -- a few feet of space in the station and a truck to transport the clothes, which were processed at a low bulk rate by local cleaning plants in their downtime -- he turned a profit in his first month. (Recently, he raised shirt prices to $1.75, to cover the cost of his production plant.)
 Metro-North's research suggests that more than 60 percent of the area's commuters are men, but Mr. McDonald is trying to woo women, too; their clothes are more expensive to clean, generating higher profit margins, and they are highly appreciative of his service. "With two-career couples, convenience becomes a major issue," says Molly Ingram, director of consumer promotion programs for Cahners Publishing, who commutes from Greenwich. "This has made things much easier for us."
 But some of Mr. McDonald's best customers aren't commuters at all. Two years ago, he added home delivery, and makes pickups and deliveries twice a week. He now also has four small shops in Westchester to soak up his cleaning plant's additional capacity. His storefront customers include the likes of Carl Icahn, who has been seen dashing from his car with dirty shirts in hand. But Mr. McDonald would not air customers' dirty laundry -- or at least the names of the owners of said dirty laundry -- for publication.
 There are still a few kinks to smooth out, such as how to deal with executives who want to drop off shirts in Chappaqua and pick them up in Stamford. But plans are underway to expand this fall into three more stations and Mr. McDonald is considering other sites. "Imagine Long Island," he said, eyes gleaming. "The Huntington station alone has 5,000 commuters a day. Think of all those shirts."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Commuters picking up their clothes at the Greenwich, Conn., station. (Suzanne Dechillo for The New York Times)
